Khmer golden age!. Angkor Thom complex is about 2 km from Angkor Wat temple. The complex, built around 12th-13th is a city by itself with the Royal palace, the state temple, various other temples as well as the living quarters of priests from various ages and times. This city was built by Jayavarman VII, the great Hindu King who defeated and pushed back the Champa invaders, the Hindu rulers from what is now South Vietnam. This area was continuously inhabited and developed by Khmer kings for many generations. It was known as Yosodharapura earlier, from the previous Khmer king, Yasovarman when the empire was invaded by the Champa rulers defeating Yasovarman. After successfully pushing back the Champa invaders, Jayavarman VII built monuments on an extended area which had seen successive Khmer emperors such as Indravarman, Yasovarman build temples and cities in and around and sometimes overlapping the same area. Other temples such as Preah Ko (dedicated to Shiva, of the Hindu Trinity) built by Indravarman around 879, already existed in this area. Jayavarman VII built his beautiful state temple- Bayon with the grans 4 faced monuments within this complex as well as Ta Prohm and several other monuments.The royal palace was built of wood and has not survived the test of time. However, the ruins of temples which were made of stone, still remain. This area became known as Angkor Thom from around the 14th century. Angkor Thom means Large city - Angkor is a word derived from Sanskrit 'Nagara', meaning city and Thom is large. The city is surrounded by a massive wall and a moat. The ruins of the wall are still visible.There are several gates, the most impressive being the South gate where the enigmatic 4 faced Head (whether it is Brahma - the Hindu God of Creation or Buddha or Jayavarman VII himself is still debated) at the gate greets you, preceded by about 300 meter long figures on both sides of the entrance on the main road, enacting 'Samudramanthan' - Churning of the ocean - a Hindu mythology. The story goes thus - there was a long battle between the Gods (Devatas) and the demons (Asuras) regarding the control of the universe. The Gods, being afraid of the demons taking over, sought help from Vishnu, the preserver God of the Hindu trinity. He advised them to fetch the Amrita, the Nectar of immortality, lying at the depths of the ocean of milk. The ocean has to be churned to get the nectar and Vasuki, the snake God agreed to help. Vasuki is used as a rope by the Gods and the Asuras to churn the ocean. To be successful in churning the ocean, Vishnu advises the Gods to collaborate with the Asuras. During the churning, Apsaras (angels) and the Goddess Lakshmi also emerge along with the Amrita. Instead of sharing the Amrita with the demons, the Gods manage to consume it all and became immortal thwarting the advances by the Asuras to take over the universe.Lot of walking... parking is quite far from the ruins. Must carry water and umbrella if sunny. Good walking shoes are a must.

Amazing. Gets very busy so go early in the morning. Stunning views and cravings. Getting a nose to nose photo is a must (you'll know what im talking about when you get there).Not for those with walking difficulties as lots of steps.

Beautiful. All the temples are beautiful and all are unique and magnificent in their own ways. This one is no exception, with the integration of the trees into the structure. Some beautifully preserved carvings.

The best of Angkor Wat.. While pretty much all of Angkor Wat is impressive, Angkor Thom and Banyon Temple was my favorite. It actually covers a large area, but seeing the main sections of the area is not a large walk. Less people than at the main site and I did not feel as rushed as I did elsewhere.

Worth the walk. Angkor Thom is a walled city, next on the road after Angkor Wat. Once you go over the causeway and enter through the city gate you are greeted with a number of temples to view. We arranged with our driver to meat us near the Terrace of the Leper King, where there is a large parking area. I found that three hours was enough time to walk around and view all the sights. There is a bit of a walk between them all, though you get the sense of discovery as you come upon one ruin after another. As you walk along the track just be aware of where you tread as there are many still uncollected stones from the ruins protruding from the ground. The walking track is well travelled and you will not become lost, and definitely worth it.
Hidden Treasure. For hundreds of years lost in the jungle. Outstanding . Bring good walking shoes and an open mind. Inspiring and makes you think how lucky we are.Thankyou

Beautiful. Lovely place to visit. Arrived by coach and loads of shops in front and good toilet facilities. On entering the site, there are three levels to reach and lots of Buddhas to see with smiling faces, lots of amazing carvings in stone. Spent a good hour here climbing around some steep steps. Was hot and humid

Immerse yourself in Cambodian history. The intricacy of those buildings and sophistication of how society worked at the time can be unravelled by these temples. A guide on at least one of your temple days is a must they really help bring the stories of rhe temples together. Plus a visit to the museum will also give you background to work from.

Interesting Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom, like other temples, requires that women have their knees and shoulders covered. At the entrance to Angkor Wat, vendors sell scarves and 3/4 length loose pants for women.

A must see temple complex. Angkor Thom is a huge temple complex which has a number of sites n temples inside like the bayon, elephant Terrance etc. Get there early in the morning. Basically see the sunrise at Angkor wat, complete Angkor wat and then head to Angkor Thom. U ll see monkeys and a lot of them ready to pose and that too healthy ones thanks to all the tourists feeding them. Buddha faces carved on the walls, headless Buddha statues showing what various battles resulted in and a lot of history n mythology. Tip: walking shoes a must, lot of water n women... Please be well covered. A lot of temples do not allow sleeveless n short clothes.
The city. Angkor Thom is a great place because is the sum of a few amazing temples and sites. Bayon is there , Bauphon is there, The Elephants terrace is there ... and so on.

Magnificent. Angkor Thom was the first temple of the complex that we visited and it made a huge impact. Very dramatic, large and atmospheric. Wear comfortable shoes as the ground us uneven and there is some considerable walking involved. Also very hot when we visited. But well worth it.

The entire complex shows how vibrant religion once was in the region. Lots to explore and lots of places to go to several temples and reasons of temples in this area. Take your time, take lots of fluids. If you come early you get to see the monkeys March to one of the gets waiting to be fed. There are about 100 of them ... It's an amazing sight to see.
The 'Great City'. Loved exploring the ancient capital city of the Khmer empire. So much to see and explore. Yes it busy but you can always find your on piece if you head a little of the beaten track.

I might be wrong but Angkor Thom was a collection of many places listed on here. The way my driver described Angkor Thom was everything from the Victory Gate, Bayon, Terrace of the Elephants and Leper King and much much more making it a large sprawling complex, and not really an individual temple. It has some amazing spots but is quite huge, I think you could spend a full day or two here and still not see it all, although i'm not sure you would want to.

Another incredible temple but Bring your walking shoes. My second favor of the temples as this one felt like there was hardly anyone there due to its vast size. We really benefited from a guide here due to the number of things to see. Plenty of trees help with the heat but Make sure you bring water. See if you can find the wild passion fruit!
Wow. Often people say this is there favorite Wat in Angkor, It is an amazing place. If you go in the morning after the sunrise tours it can be less crowded.

Amazing Place. I've never seen so many Buddha faces in my life. It is amazing that you can walk around any corner and find a face of Buddha looking at you. This can be very crowded so I'd advise getting here early if you can. That way you can take some great pictures without someone else being in it. Just a short drive from Angkor Wat. It's a temple that is a must see.

Room to breathe. The ruins here a spread across a reasonable area which means you can explore at leisure and away from the hordes of visitors that flock to the individual major sites around Angkor. The Terrace of the Elephants is fantastic with a great view across to Prasat Suor Prat. We also really enjoyed Baphuon. There are places to eat and drink which make it a good place for a bit of respite.

Amazing. Probably the most interesting of the Temples. Ignoring the movie scene it was fascinating to see the damage done by nature and how it is being arrested. One every aspiring structural engineer should visit.

Another amazing experience. You can only stand and stare when you consider that Angkor Thom was built as a new city because Angkor Wat was sacked by the Cham marauders, and how big it was, with hundreds of houses around the main buildings. It is all hard to comprehend in a short visit, and takes some time to sink in once you are back home!

Angkor Thom. We approached Angkor Thom via the most popular south gate. This is truly a jaw dropping, awe inspiring sight comparable to Ramsess II tomb at Abu Simbal. The long causeway flanked with mythical figures of restored demons on one side and gods on the other side are indeed impressive. The stone faces on the towers are one of the most intriguing and stunning features of Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom was apparently the last city built by the Khmer Empire and the temple complex itself is also a walled and moated Royal City. The complex is quite massive and it is really impossible to stay too long because of the heat.
Divine enterance. We feel that we are in totally different world when we start to enter the Thom. Classic mammoth sculptures of NAGA pulled by the Demons on one side and Devas on the other
Lovely. Impressive temple, one of the biggest in Siem Reap. Very crowded with loud Chinese tourists, but where isn't? Definitely a must visit!
It's a must!. Definitely a great city! Beautiful 3 dimension towers and architecture! It makes the Angkor Wat visit complete! Hard to imagine how they built these giant Buddhas.

Huge Temple Complex that Rivals Angkor Wat. Most visitors are likely surprised to find that Angkor Thom is a huge complex in its own right, with multiple walls, temples and pools. You can easily spend a few hours here, or breeze through for a quick tour if you're not up for any climbing. The front entrance with it's huge platforms and vista of multiple towers offers something not found elsewhere in the park...you really get a sense of how grand it once was. Definitely a must see if you have a full day to tour the greater park area.

Highlight of my trip to Angkor. For me, I found Angkor Thom more impressive than Angkor Wat. The 'faces' were fascinating and the monkey's roaming around just added to the jungle feel. I could have stayed all day at this temple alone.
Amazing. well, put aside the excruciating hot n humid weather. Angkor is just amazing place to visit. the architecture work on all these stone n put them together is just wordless.

Angkor Thom rocks!. It's very exciting to go there and attempt to read the stories on the walls. Although it is hot, do not bring an umbrella as it may get cramped. If you've been there for a while, challenge yourself by trying to tell which plant is which.

Angkor Thom. The gounds of Angkor Thom are huge. The temple in the center is mostly rebuilt but it's still stunning. The rebuild attemps to keep the original work in mind. The rock carving is very detailed and the time it must have taken is mind blowing. Make sure you stop at the gates to take pictures as they are just as stunning as the temple itself.
Wonderful. A very pretty temple with all the trees growing through the ruins. Everywhere you look there is something different to see.
Another must see in Siem Reap. Another must see in the temple park. Less known that AnkorWat but as impressive as all other temples and a great location to spent time and reflect.
Lovely temple. We saw a lot of temples on our visit to Cambodia and this one was very enjoyable. Definitely worth a visit.
Go see those this. This is such an iconic temple. Easy to photograph, easy to see and all around a great time. It's possible to see this with families
Tuk Tuk Taxi driver. Dear Value Costumer for visit in Cambodia. I am Tuk Tuk Taxi driver, I would like offer the best price for tour and free pick service.

My Favourite!. This is the best of all the wonders located within the 100 of square miles of the Angkor Wat National park.It ha a stunning story it is so impressive in terms of its size and splendour. Walking around you can only begging to imagine what this place was like during the Golden Age of Angkor. Go with Sorm Son local guide. English speaking and so knowledgeable he will bring the place to life. On the first day with visited here and three other temples all of which had a different personality which was full explained. sormson16@hotmail.com he is also on tripadvisor.

My favourite part of the complex. We attended a variety of temples in the complex over 3 days with a guide. The guide made all the difference, our guide pointed out things I wouldn't have noticed otherwise, our guide also showed us what part were original and what were reconstructions. It is amazing how they preserve the sites. Angkor Thom is my favourite, it was the most interesting but watch your step. We went at around 4pm when the light was perfect and the crowds were surprisingly sparse. You could spend hours there taking pictures of all the faces. Make sure to check out the south and east gates.

Wish I had more time to spend. Having visited temples in other places of the world, I was very impressed by the size and magnificent architecture. Spent a few hours visiting it, but wish I had planned a full day
Hypnotic. Take your time to absorb everything about this place and be sure to take the steps to the highest point.

many faces. unique it is
temple of many faces
its like you are being watched
it comes as a package in a day temple tour pass
the architecture is spectacular ;-)

Visit the Angkor Thom complex first thing. The Angkor Thom complex is a walled park like area, where several heritage temples can be visited, e.g. the Bayon temple, the Wat Baphuon and the Elephant Terrace. This complex presents a preview of what can be expected of the Siem Reap surroundings. Enter the complex by the main drive over the bridge with the impressive statues and through te stone gate. Cars, taxis, tuk-tuk's and elephants will keep you company in an endless stream. Yes, Angkor Thom is a top tourist attraction. But worth the journey.
wondrous moments. enjoyable trip. must visit to discover hidden facts, where else in the world you can see these . its only in sieam reap. you must see these places. its worth

Bayon temple. Angkor Thom was just as beautiful and amazing as Angkor Wat! This was the second temple we did and it's the one with the four faces on each tower. Our guide (we got one from our hotel, Borei Angkor), was really informative and was excellent in explaining the historical significance of the three main temples (we also went to Ta Phrom). According to our guide, a lot of people mistake the actual temple as Angkor Thom but the name of the temple is Bayon Temple and the entire compound itself is actually Angkor Thom. This is essentially a walled city with the beautiful Bayon Temple in it. Highly recommend that you put this on your list! It's also very crowded any time of the day but go earlier in the morning so it won't be too hot. There are also elephant rides from outside Angkor Thom for USD 20. These rides go from outside Angkor Thom into the compound. There is another elephant ride station inside right next to Bayon temple but that ride only goes around the the temple and is a shorter ride for also USD 20. Bayon Temple is not as big as Angkor Wat but no less majestic and it was a privilege to be able to see it in my lifetime.
LOVED THIS. Loved Angkor Thom better than Angkor Wat. Go in the early afternoon when it is cooler. Don't forget to head over to the elephant wall.

Awsome architecture. It is a must see to all those interested in arts, culture and history, the architecture has to be seen by naked eyes to be appreciated, pictures cannot reveal the beauty of the detailed carvings.
Well preserved. The ruins are very well preserrved, It seems thy have reconstructed a part of it, however it was very well made. Like all the ruins in the Angkor complex, I liked a lot

Greater than the Angkor Wat. This is the creation of the great Khemer King, Jayavarman VII. Please read my comment on Angkor Wat in Tripadvisor. The whole complex exudes of the goodness of the Khemer's greatest king.
Angkor Thom. These temples are better with a guide. they can bring alive. otherwise all the temples in this area become monogomous :)

Amazing place to visit!. This temple area is absolutely amazing! It has taken a huge effort and high quality skills to build such an area during the times when muscle power and elephants did all the work. Even if this area is a tourist area it is possible to get a feeling of being and adventurer here! Absolutely a great place to visit. Visiting the bigger temples can take between 1-3 hours per temple. Toilets can be found with a help of a local driver but there is not any inside the temples.
Amazing!. This exceeded our expectations, it felt like a privilege to have such access to this incredible place. The history here is fascinating.

Second favourite in Siem Reap. Immense complex with many parts that all add up to an extraordinary experience. It starts when you enter the complex across the bridge crossing the massive moat. The bridge is flanked by 54 gods and 54 demons on either side of the bridge. You can elect to ride an elephant across the bridge to enter the complex which adds to the experience. Certainly one of the highlights

Huge. Angkor Thom is a moated island where you will find many temple ruins like Bayon, Baphuon and the Terrace of Elephants. It's a massive area so be prepared for a walk but there is lots to see so don't be afraid to spend some time here. You can ride elephants at the south gate where there are more ruins and an incredible bridge.

Loved it. This is the largest site by land mass. It has multiple sites to visit including Bayon Temple. Take your time and enjoy all it has to offer. You could spend months here and never take in every wonderful detail. Watch out for the geese they are little gangsters...
Temple of faces. Lots of steps, be careful. Otherwise beautiful temple - partially restored, further work ongoing. Another famous must see place in Siem Reap

Ba Phuon! definitely visit that temple in the Angkor Thom complex. This temple was our favourite of the many temples we visited; mainly owing to the flight of steps we had to take and around the temple. The experience was different to the usual site seeing in temples as this little climbing activity was included too. Was lovely to go around and just relax at few spots. Not crowded as well compared to the other temples.

Out of this world, left us speechless. Seeeing Akhkor Thom in photographs and in video just doen't do it. You must walk through nthis awesome place.Carvings on walls and cielings take your breath away. Truely you need days to take in his beauty but anytime spent here will give you a great sense of it's power. At every turn there is more to see and take in. Amazing.

An ancient city in itself. This 9 square kilometers monument comprises of many other monuments in a single compound surrounded by a moat. The layout of many of the monuments is unclear - erased by time in many places.

Ruins of an Ancient City. visiting this enclosed city mostly of which is in ruins , will take most of your day if you decide to see it in detail. and for detail you have to have a local guide with you. I personally recommend having an Local guide to all the places in Angkor , as this will greatly enhance your visiting experience in Siem Reap. There are numerous big and small ruins in this forested ruins , take time to visit most if not all. Bayon Temple is also located inside this.

Amazing !. Truly amazing to walk among ruins created by the ancient people of Cambodia created. Beautiful- we were on a cycle tour with Grasshopper Cycle tours - great way to see the Angor Wat complex !

Amazing. Another amazing site. The entrance is fantastic with the gate and the Giants on either side. Once in you have access to the entire site including the royal palace, the bayon and the phaeokonastra (spelling?!?). It's all pretty impressive. We had a guide and a driver so we were driven to the bayon from the main entrance gate and then walked to the royal palace. It is walkable but takes more time and it was hot!

The Last Capital of the Khmer Empire. This "great city's" construction began in the 12th century. It's huge, covering more than 12 km. There were four massive gates (the heights of which were determined by the room needed to accommodate an elephant and howdah with parasols). We entered the South Gate where there are well-restored statues of "asuras" (demons) on the right and on the left are serene-looking statues of the gods. Upon entering you can see four faces of Buddha around the Tower. The Eastern face represents light, the Western face represents mercy, the Southern face represents Sympathy and the Northern face represents Equanimity.In the middle of Angkor Thom is The Bayon, a three-tiered temple with a 45 meter tower topped by four gigantic carved heads. More than 50 smaller towers surround it, facing the points of the compass. The walls of The Bayon are covered with bas-relief. Outside they depict historical events; inside they depict gods and legends. There are scenes of everyday life: ox carts, fishing with nets, drinking, jugglers, chess players. In the land battle scenes there are warrior elephants and chariots. In the naval battle scenes there are fish, crocodiles and corpses floating.North of The Bayon is the Royal Palace, the Terrace of the Elephants, The Terrace of the Leper King, The Phimeanakas (meaning the Celestial or Flying Palace in Sanskrit). At one time lions guarded the four staircases leading to its central tower and they were covered in gold. Now that is all ruined.South of the Royal Palace is the Baphuon. It is reached by a 200 meter long causeway built on pillars. There was a lot of walking, and I won't lie: it's extremely hot & humid. Make sure to wear appropriate clothing and to drink a lot of water. You won't want to miss it as there's so much to see and interpret. I was fascinated with the combination of both Hindu & Buddhist aspects. We were very lucky to have an excellent guide, Mr. Than Sopheap from the Seven Candles Organization. He knew so much about the history and the sites we visited and really made it come alive for us.
Take the time to visit them all.. Take the time to visit them all. Be prepared and read a little before getting there. Plan your visit and take a local guide to compliment your visit.

A site made for a King. After viewing Angkor Wat, you think you have seen all there is, then up comes Angkor Tom, the last and most enduring capital city of the Khmer empire. The city is a great site that is impressive to walk through. A good guide will show you the drawings along the wall the describe life during its construction from farming and fishing to merriment and war. The Buddhas throughout the site show numerous facial expressions.This is a site not to be missed if you visit this part of Cambodia

Khmer Faces in Stone. I found this temple prettier - if that's the right word - than its big brother, Angkor Wat.Where the latter is bigger, more famous, to me more forbidding, Angkor Thom seemed to have a lighter touch somehow.I liked the avenue of faces over the moat fascinating. They were so Khmer, in fact one on the left hand side looked exactly like our guide. So much so that I had him stand next to it and copy its expression. On the right hand side were the angry looking faces.I wondered at the bas relief carving on every surface and way up high. How perfectly portrayed and hundreds of thousands of figures, all the faces different. And how long it must have taken goodness knows how many supremely artistic and talented people.Oh, and by the way, I definitely cannot bargain with people who are offering garments for sale at $4 each for well made singlets with attractive designs, from good fabric.

So many interesting aspects to this site.. A guide is a must as he/she will guide you through the highlights of this massive site - it was a city of 1,000,000 people in its day. I would say that the smiling faces were the best part.
Temple of Many Faces. I enjoyed walking around the perimeter of this temple, in addition to climbing the steps of it's many levels. The carved faces are beautiful & serene.
Another fun temple and place to cure your inner archeologist. Wear good sneakers and bring water as you immerse yourself in the history of the era. Take your time as you wander in among the ruins.
Amazing Experience. A definite must see if you are visiting Cambodia and Siem Reap in particular. Has to be seen to appreciate the atmosphere.

Excellent and Amazing . None of these major temples should be missed, and this one is no exception. All are amazing feats of architecture and quite awe inspiring. If you are visiting in the wet season you might want to space out your temple visits over a few days as it is easy to become tired after seeing two, and you risk not experiencing them to their fullest. Hire a guide for the best experience, the Khmer guides are highly informative and exceptionally friendly, and will show you small interesting intricate elements of the temples you might otherwise miss.
Even more amazing architecture!. Even more amazing architecture. Well worth the time to explore and soak up the history and atmosphere here. Also worth visiting the photogenic South Gate area.
Beautiful. This is a lovely complex of buildings which, although it lacks the scale of Angkor Wat, I think outshines it in beauty.
Excellent. Wonderful, largely unrestored temple. The faces in the stone are amazing to see. This is one you should not miss.
The AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING. I have no word but amazing!! It is the must-see before you die! I hate walking but I kept walking non-stop just to see more of this and I love it!

Peaceful ancient place - great for kids. We visited with 2 x2 year okra so decided to opt for Angkor thom (rather than Angkor wat). We saw elephants and monkeys. We hired a tuk tuk for the day and managed to get around with 2 prams, which we managed to get around just places, although we did leave the prams sometimes so we could climb around unimpeded which the kids loved. We had food in the middle of a forest in a place our tuk tuk drives took us too. There were lots of shops and great toilets. We fed the monkeys by the road on the way home which was $1 for some sort of green fruit/nut. The monkeys seemed to love them and the children had a great time.

Amazing architecture . I went Angkor Thom last year. That was one of the most beautiful and amazing experiences of my life. I love environment, amazing architecture and friendly local people. In my opinions this place can not visit in one day because there is very large area and many place to go. I will be back for sure.

Fascinating faces. Angkor Thom is the best place to start your Angkor Temple adventure and at the Bayon side. Full of fascinating faces of a DEVA, some huge,some tiny, it is interesting to see how many you can find. There are also many doorways that dont really go anywhere, it is quite intriguing. On the down side was that in high season, it was packed with tourists who were not really interested in seeing the site, bur more interested in taking selfies in doorways which made it difficult to navigate the site. There are a lot of rocks and rubble and it can be tricky to navigate. I preferred Ta Prohm which I visited next, however found Angkor Wat temple the best of all.

Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom, the last capital of the Khmer Empire, was a fortified cit enclosing residences of priest, officials of the palace and military, as well as buildings for administering the kingdom.

Step away from the crowds. Walk the perimeter of the property for a totally different perspective. The trails aren't clear, but you'll find your way. Of course you'll want to climb all over the ruins as well, but, from a distance, you start to appreciate the magnitude and majesty of this city.

Beautiful. Angkor Thom is a photographer's dream (I'm no expert, but I love taking photos). Like so many temples in Siem Reap Angkor Thom has so much details on the walls and statues. Just incredible!
We did a 3 day tour and I highly recommend doing a private tour. Everyone should come here once!

go with a guide. Angkor Thom is huge and full of interesting historical facts, so I suggest a guide and if you are fit rough try a bike tour. I suggest Grasshopper, they were great, food was excellent. There are great gateways to view, four are entryways to the city, and each has four giant Buddha sculptures, very impressive. Take mosquito repellent especially if during wetter season

Angkor Thom gets less press than Angkor Wat, but is a much larger experience.. The Angkor Thom experience includes several temples, terraces, walkways and pools. It's worth more than 1 day of your time. The carved faces of Bayon Temple are the highlight of Angkor Thom - don't miss it!

Great View at the Top. Prasat Thom is a 2-hour drive to the north east of angkor Wat, but is worth the drive. There are very few visitors here, and at the far end, there is a towering pyramid, similar to Mayan architecture. We climb the steps (and there are many) to the top for a beautiful 360 degree view of the surrounding countryside. Some of the stonework is in incredibly good shape, with very detailed carvings and Khmer script.
Another fantastic temple. One of my favorites. Loved the smiling faces. An incredible experience standing in the presence of these ancient temples.
Empty. We was so lucky to have been dropped off really early after visiting Angkor Wat and it was completely empty. it was brilliant. cant say much more, just go!

Fantastic details and overwhelmingly huge. Angkor Thom is one of the must-see destinations in Sieam Reap. It's massive and many of the other sites you read about (like Bayon) are actually inside/part of Angkor Thom. If you get wrapped up in the endless details, like intricate carvings found on all of the walls/temples/etc... you could easily spend an entire day here. We were here in 2011 before sunrise and had it entirely to ourselves for over an hour; in January 2016 it was significantly more crowded, though we found quite a bit of open space on a weekday after 3 PM. Highly recommended, and once you're there get out and explore because many fascinating features are tucked away and not immediately visible
Amazing . Angor Thom was another photographer's dream. We were with a tour so getting around was no problem. It didn't seem to be as crowded as Angor Wat. It was a magical place.

Nice place . Really had a nice time learning the history. It's very walkable but mind the signs as there are unstable and dangerous areas of the site ... Oh and there are spiders but you leave them alone they leave you alone.
Simply Amazing. This is one of the most eye catching temples. To see all the huge faces this temple has is Amazing. Don't pass this one up on your tour.

Absolutely amazing!!!. Cambodia is one of our favorite countries and this is THE site to see there. Go w someone who can explain it to you and who knows their way around as it is immense and confusing. Take an elephant ride there, too!

Simply stunning. A breathtaking temple with some fascinating and very well preserved faces of Buddha, this temple is a small maze one can get lost in and hide from the blazing sunshine. Some of the steps are rather steep and not for the faint hearten but the effort is worth it.

my favorit temple. these heads watching you from a fabulous and rich past are not to be missed! My favorit visit during our 4 days trip. Everywhere one looked there was fabulous sights to capture on pictures

Do not go for the "breakfast at Bayon". Maybe I am thrifty. Afterall US$7 isn't a lot of money. But most meals in Cambodia costs as cheap as US$1 to US$4.5. So US$7 is definitely quite overpriced. And it was only for a simple fried rice or fried noodles. Ask the driver to bring you elsewhere. The Tuk Tuk driver tend to bring you to expensive places for food.

A must see. This is be of the four temples that is a must see when visiting Siem Reap. I would suggest visiting before it gets too hot or too crowded. Plan on taking at least an hour or more to view the temple.

Loved it!. Cambodia is an amazing place, and Siem Reap's temples are a must! The beauty and the history of this place is just amazing. We visited Bayon Temple, Baphuon, the Elephant and Leper King terraces, walked a lot and despite the heat, enjoyed every minute! Tips: comfy shoes, sunblock, we didn't have probs with mosquitoes but repellent sounds like a good idea, water and start as early as you can. We also did the elephant ride, and was a very nice experience.

A must see. Loved this place as well and just like Banteay Srei, get there early before the heat of the day and the Chinese and Japanese tourists decend! A tranquil Temple can turn into Oxford circus if you time it wrong and get slammed by a couple of tour parties, they tend to arrive around mid-day so adjust your timings accordingly.

the popular face temple. Protip:come early in the morning, less crowd, less hassle. There is one spot in the temple crowded with people to get the typical camera shot. And dont try to climb the temple. Another protip.
Amazing. Just as incredible as Angkor Wat, actually I liked it more perhaps because it was not as busy as Angkor Wat at the time we visited.

Interesting. Not as impressive as some of the other temples but very unique historically in it's own right. Worth a visit if you have the time because it is one of the top 3 but not as impressive as Angkor Wat so don't start here first.

My favorite site in Siem Reap. I got some 200 photos about the stone faces at this amazing site. We reached here around 9.00 after the sunrise walk so it was not too crowded.
Angkor Thom has rich history and lesson of life to learn through its walls. For me, the site is absolutely photogenic and worth at least 2 hours.

Better than the rest. After visiting Angkor wat and ta promh we stopped by Angkor Thom and loved it. Don't get me wrong the first temples were great too but there was something special about Angkor Thom that we loved. Well worth a visit!

Collection site of popular temples. Angkor Thom includes the temples of Bayon, Baphuon, Terraces of the Leper King and Elephants, and others. There is alot of great stuff to see here but bring your walking shoes. Even though it may not have the grandeur of Angkor Wat I thought everything was breath taking. Leave plenty enough time for the walking around Bayon and to see the temples in the forest.If you visit Siem Reap you have to visit here or its just not a complete trip.

Angkor Thom.. An amazing setting,with fantastic weather and a photographers heaven!The architecture around here is awesome too and I found that I was able to take heaps of photo's.This was when the Khmer ouge were still very active though,and I had to report 2 undetonated missiles whilst there.

A city not a temple!. This sizeable walled city dating to the 12th century and contains a number of temples and other archeological sites including Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas... all of which deserve your time. We spent the better part of a day touring the complex finishing at the Terrace of Elephants used as a viewing platform for military parades.
Over 100 kings. Angkor Thom is a really astonishing exampel of a historical selfie in over a hundred copies. The monument of a very proud king.

Best temple in Angkor!. I LOVED this temple in Angkor! It is so beautiful and the pictures I took were outstanding! The big stone faces are so incredible and offer a different look to Angkor that what you see at Angkor Wat. I must see!

Wonderful temple. Make you to take plenty of time to visit Angkor Thom. It's pretty special and different from the temples around and the history behind it is worth a read. It was being renovated during my last visit, but the workers were very discrete so this did not affect our visit at all.
Amazing. Again another Angkor temple that blew my mind. Must do them all. Best over two or three days . Xxxxxxxxxxxx

Amazing . We went to Angkor Thom as part of a tour group. At first glance I felt like I was on the set of Indiana Jones. The immense stone structure and exquisite carvings look like they are from another world. Despite intense heat and a very difficult climb up and down I finished the tour and was so glad I did. If you are in Siem Reap do notMiss this incredible visit going back about 1000 years. It's worth the trouble. Just be sure to bring water and sunscreen.

Amazing!! . Angkor Thom was amazing. Although smaller than Angkor Wat, it is still just as awesome. Is only a short bike ride from Angkor Wat and you can see monkeys on the roadside on the way. Don't miss Angkor Thom, it is fantastic!!!

Loved the visit. This was the first temple I visited and I really loved it here. Went in the morning. You can get an elephant ride outside the grounds if you wish to pay for one. The carvings in the temple are beautiful, and the many faces throughout the temple are fascinating. Make sure you go to the Bayon Temple and enjoy the views. It can be quite busy and there are some people that are in costumes that you can pay and have your photo taken with them. It is great to see that they are restoring parts of the temple. A good size temple but nowhere near as large as Angkor Wat.

Amazing faces. This used to be my favorite temple as the faces are fascinating. 54 towers containing 216 faces of the king facing each compass point. However nowadays it is hard to recommend when to visit as there is not a lot of room at the top of the buildings and there always seem to be many busloads of tourists loudly having their photos taken in every possible window and doorway.

In Top Five Temples to See in Siem Reap. The carvings are amazing, go in late afternoon for best photo light which is very golden as sun sets around 5:45pm during dry season. This is a very large temple tat requires a good 2hrs to explore.

Angkor Thom. Our Guide told us that it is Said that this Temple was for the higher Society! The Elefant Terrace and the Terrace of the Lepa King really fantastic and the stone carvings on the Temple Walls of Buda faces, one is called the kissing Buda, if you stand in a special position and take a picture it Looks like you are Rubine Moses. If you have a guide they will Tell you where to stand, they will also show you where the best places are to get great pictures.Lovely carvings well worth a visit.
Ms Maggie Savolainen . Its my favourite temple. Its so different with its tree roots encasing the stones like a human hand. It just felt so spiritual.

A group of temples a short distance from Ankor Wat. You should definitely visit the temples of Ankor Tom on the same day you see Ankor Wat. The temples are smaller but well worth the stop. WARNING! There are lots of steps.

Huge and beautiful!. The place is very big. Don't forget to go to Bayon Temple, Ta Phrom, Elephant Terrance, King Lepher Terrace. I would suggest you bring some food of your own, the reataurants there are not very tasty and they're kind of nasty tourists traps.

Another amazing religious site. Close to Angkor Wat this is another example of 12th to 14th century architecture and engineering prowess by the Cambodian people. The site is currently being excavated and restored and has suffered the centuries wear and tear; the years of war by the Khmer Rouge and just neglect. Cheers to the many organizations dedicated to bringing back this historic sight.

Tomb Raiders must go. A quieter temple compared to Angkor Wat however has been made popular by the film Tomb Raider where some scenes were shot. Contains Bayon Temple with the cool looking natural trees that have grown over the stones and have torn up walls and steps giving the setting a unique look as if you have just stepped back in time. Here you can also get your classic kissing face photos with the kings 196 faces and learn about the story of the Gods & Demons working together to fight the Naga serpent snake. I felt like a good in a ghost story brilliant must visit.
Wow. We spent two days touring ancient sites in Siem Reap. This was among the best. Up there with Ta Prohm. This is the one with the giant heads. Well worth the visit. You will not be disappointed.
my wife's favorite ruin (besides me!). Great Temple the faces are amazing one of the essentials on any trip as with all of them try and pick our time

Great feeling, lots to see.. Angkor Tom is the old city, now it is filled with trees and temples. While the temples are the main attraction the whole area has a great feel to it. We hired a tuk-tuk (remork) from Siem Reap for the half day so we had transport, bikes would have been so cool as well.

Incredable place to visit. I visited the Angkor Temples with out doing any research. My wife asked me to join her on her visit to Cambodia. I enjoyed visiting the temples very much. The only down side was that the temp. was in the low 90'S. It was hot. The up side was that were were amazed at the high level reached by the Khmer people from the 10th to 12th century

One of Many. Angkor Thom was the first temple we visited and we were impressed with the history and remains. However, it did not make our list of top 3 temples. As an aside, I was bothered by the elephants carrying tourists around the park as they looked poorly and one was bleeding from being hit by its driver. Personally, I see this as animal abuse. Aside from that , the park itself is lovely and should be included in your temple tours. You can make your own judgement.
tomb raider was made here. a superb place lots to see this i believe was where tomb raider was filmed..i would highly recommend a visit to all the temples in siem reap

Go here!. Went here as part of a small group tour. Had plenty of beautiful photo sports here and easy to imagine this place in history. Lots of Spung trees to add the beauty of Angkor Thom. Our tour guide took us all around and showed us some great photo spots

Beautiful and bigger than I thought. If you can, try to go in through one entrance and instead of walking back, have your driver meet you at another. This is a general recommendation for the temples although most drivers won't offer you that. Ask them if that's possible (it is in most cases).
Fascinating.... You cannot help yourself being fascinated by the Art of this Temple, the ruins are more than ruins they are memories a Country and the history that goes with it
Must see . Amazing temple with many face sculptures in the towers. There were some crowds in the late morning but didn't really hinder our exploration.

Amazing amazing amazing!. Great place to visit and really as wonderful as Angkor Wat. There is so much to see and learn, you must get a guide or I feel you wouldn't even know what you are really looking at. My favourite part is the South Gate, an incredibly beautiful entrance to the ancient city. Definitely recommend to anyone who visits Siem Reap.

Some pointers to this huge site. There are a few unlisted places on Trip Advisor within Angkor Thom that is worth noting.The restored South gate of Angkor Thom;This entrance are used by most visitors and for a reason. It’s restored to some parts which provides a magnificent view. The moat is there, the demons and gods are there and the gate looks just as you want Angkor ruins to look. It is however crowded there, but you might see elephants riding through the gate with tourist, providing somewhat of an ancient feeling. The not restored North Gate of Angkor ThomThe bridge is in rather poor shape (from an archeological view – not traffic safety) with most of the statues gone or falling into pieces and the moat overgrown in parts. The gate itself has an authentic, rustic feeling to itself which is very nice and motivated a short stopPreah Palilay a miniature Ta Phrom located Northwest of the Leper King Terrace.A miniature alternative to the jungle temple of Ta Prohm if you want to see strangler trees creeping on buildings. However, only one tower and the biggest tree is cut of in the top. Few tourists find their way here so it is quite peaceful.

Smaller but should be visited. . While in Siem Reap, visit more than just Angkor Wat. While small by comparison, Angkor Thom is another amazing and beautiful site. We visited it as part of a Grasshopper cycles tour and we had an excellent guide, Som, who gave a great explanation of the place then left us to wander in amazement looking at the beautiful stonework.
Go . Hire a tuk tuk to get around in peace. Wear flats. Take drinks etc. Or be prepared to pay loads. Queues start around lunchtime so go early.

Traveling alone. This place is very nice. If you're collecting pictures, it's a nice place to be your subject.Just negotiate with the kids inside the temple. They are not certified tourist guide but you can learn something from them. They can take your pictures too. Maybe just don't give them much bec I am not sure if they are really students.

Magnificent. Angkor Thom is the larger complex encompassing Bayon Temple and several ancillary facilities including the Terrace of Elephants. Impressive on its own, but pales in comparison with Angkor Wat. But it's still a must see when in the area.

Huge place!. A city on it's own, felt like we've walked for miles. But it was all very amazing. The entry to Angkor Thom is very impressive with carved Buddah heads and a moat around it. The building structures, the carvings and even more so, the stories behind it. Make sure you get a tour guide when you are on your tour.
Amazing. Quite simply amazing!! A must see when visiting the Temples of Angkor, beautiful statues, faces, carvings. In particular i liked the entrance with its beautiful bridge.

Fantastic. We watched the sunrise and it was a magical moment. This is a must visit place and the sheer majesty of the temples and intricate carvings is beautiful. One of my best experiences ever during travelling, Angkor Wats got to be on your bucket list.

Vast Compound with Various Attractions. Angkor Thom with its walls and gates facing four directions is an impressive compound. However it is within these walls where the key attractions are located. Therefore Angkor Thom should be considered as the walled town. Normally in other destination it can be a major attraction however among the Angkor Temples it paled as an attraction. The Churning of the Milk of Ocean at the entrances are very impressive.

Angkor Thom is a large complex of more than 16 places of interest.. 16 and counting... If I was to explore ALL of Angkor Thom, it might take me a week at my slow pace, taking pictures of everything. And then I can go on to explore Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and the others for another week. I'll be "templed-out" in 3 days---if not 2 days! This is why I suggest you choose which temple is most interesting to you and zoom in on it. Then you can take your time and discover the rest.

Fascinating area. Angkor Thom ( Great City) , 9km in area is was the last big capital city of the Khmer empire Here you will see temples like Bayon , Baphoun along with the terrace of the elephants and much more.

Fantastic ... brings you back almost 1000 yrs.. To be honest, I actually preferred visiting the smaller temples of in the Angkor Thom complex than Angkor Wat itself. When we were there, basically no people, peaceful, and you could spend your time looking at the details. It is a sight you will not forget. You can do it with a tuck tuck but you gain more out of it with a guide and air conditioned car. You have a chance to recuperate from the heat. When visiting the temples it not for people for are walking impaired or can easily fall. Actually, you could spend a week here photographing at different times of the day. Leave yourself two full days. At lunch time you cam forget it, it is too hot. You should be drinking Angkor beer......the best! Even better than Tiger Beer.

Fantastic!. It was the last site of the Angkor Wat tour. When approaching the entrance, I thought, "it's hot, it's been a long day....him, another temple." How wrong I was! It's so different to all the other temples. All of the sudden, fatigue has disappeared, my curiosity and interest have returned! Marvellous!
Multi faceted. Loved the temples and trees in this complex. the 5 gates, inc victory gate have so many beautiful faces, worth seeing!
Ancient Temple. Be prepared to walk alot. Hugh build up. Very old and falling structure being proped up. Very uneven floor with lots of steps. Wear comfortable shoes.
Do not miss Bayon Temple. Try to get here at a quiet time of day as we did. The giant smiling faces will stay with you, a beautiful spot.
Worth the trip. The whole Angkor complex is amazing, and well worth the price of admission and the price of getting a tuk-tuk driver to take you everywhere.Angkor Thom is huge - there's a lot to see!

Beautiful huge temple complex. The gates into Angkor Thom are awesome. The many beautiful temples and grounds require at least a day - preferably two days - to explore at your own pace and rhythm to get a little bit of the sacred feeling of these old world sites. Beware of the huge crowds and find a way to travel through the complex against the main flow the tourists.

Only One in the world,. Amazing cannot believe in my eye, soo wonderful, it is the magic archaeological from Khmer empire, Great atmosphere surrounding by water lake, and forest with very lovely location, wild animal monkey, elephant, feel like we are in old town, and very coolHigh recommended for you plan to visit .

Amazing Temple Complex. Angkor Thom is actually a Temple complex that "contains" all temples in Siem Reap except Angkor Wat. It is worth spending not just your day but many days in the area. Do get a guide and do your homework before your visit.

A lot of scenery. This is a big area, and much to see. We had a walk through Angkor Thom and saw the Elephant terrace, South gate, temple of the skies, bayon temple and the remains of the kings Palace.
Our favourite at Angkor Thom is the Byon temple.

picturesque temple. I really am a fan of temple architecture, and angkor thom is one of those temples you shouldn't miss. Get a tuktuk driver familiar with english to explain to you the different qualities and characteristics of the temples. it's a long walk, but there are many opportunities for photos.

Beauty at Every Turn. Entering the south gate of Angkor Thom City was spectacular, we ventured through this beautiful place with mist rising over the waters, monkeys in search of food, and in awe of the beauty surrounding us at every turn.

A Fascinating Temple Complex. We (I and my wife) were part of a tour-group and had visited Angkor in November, 2015. The Angkor Thom temple complex is simply fascinating. There are a large number of temples which together make-up the Angkor Thom Temple Complex. One of the "must-see" temples in the complex is Bayon Temple.

Go of the tourist path.... Many of the temple entrances are popular. Ask your guide to show you a walk along the city wall, almost immediately we were without tourists! Just a little walk but nice to met the local monkeys and get some good photos.

World Heritage Site!. A must to tour when visiting the temples. Just have to watch out for the crowds of Taiwanese and Korean tourists. Go ahead and take as many photos as you can. You wont be disappointed.

Simply amazing. Before I came to Siem Reap I literally thought it was just Angkor Wat.What a surprise to see so many more quality temples and sights here.Angkor Thom is amazing with so many sights inside. Great City indeed !The south gate is a marvel and I couldn't stop myself from joining the throngs and snapping away on the bridge and also up to the tower itself.Take your time and visit Angkor Thom over a few days to make the most of your experience.
Most interesting of all.... The faces make this, IMHO, the most interesting in the complex. Should be 1or 2 of the visit, you will take lots of pictures.
Part of the temple tour . This is a whole town and lots of different things to see here. When I got here too many people were here the same time and made photography almost impossible.

The Roman Forum & Circus Maximus of the East!. Angkor Thom, meaning "Great City", is a testament to the strength of the Khmer Empire at its height. This walled city includes the magnificent Bayon Temple and Terrace of the Elephants and several other ruins. Visit with a local guide who can explain the various elements and how the central ground was used for elephant battles for the entertainment of the royal family.
Must visit. Ancient, beautiful and mysterious. Must see this place during your trip and feel the breath of ancient time.
One of the best. Do not miss this temple it is a must. Beautiful and mysterious and just great. All the faces are really fantastic.

ultra-photogenic for historic, botanic, aesthetic and religious reasons. many people take photos of themselves and each other in front of these very photogenic scenes. If you come in mid-morning or mid-afternoon when the sun moves in at a slant, even better.

"Tomb Raider". Our guide took us here in the afternoon and was outstanding. My preference as this is a smaller site without the stairs. Fantastic scenery and amazing to see trees growing on top of and amongst the ruins

Magical Place. I liked Angkor thin over Angkor wat. They are 2 totally different temples and styles. The 8 faces appealed to me. Again it is a historic landmark and has restoration issues. You will need you angkorwat pass to access thus venue.Tip : sunscreen , sunhat, water , camera, suitable footwear, suitable clothing for temples, look after your belongings, pick pockets around

Part or our 3 temple tour. Second stop. Monkeys at the entrance were cool. Lots of four faced Buddhas here and an easy enough scramble around the ruins. The visit was very good, short of magical, though.
Mesmerising. I stood here for hours taking it all in. HOW? That's a question I asked myself repeatedly. HOW? It's enough to take one's breath away.l

Bayon Temple is part of Angkor Thom. People don't seem to understand that Angkor Thom means "Big Angkor" so there's lots of temples within it. Bayon Temple is one of those temples so you're practically seeing the same thing. This place is majestic and you can totally see what Royalty used to be like in these temples. Stunning, photos don't do it justice.
Lovely temples . Yet another bit of stunning history in Cambodia, this part is definitely a must do while visiting the temples of Angkor wat

Magnificent!. I am still pinching myself that we visited this temple. Some reviewers have already stated that this area does not get as much publicity as Angkor Wat and they would be correct. It is still a beautiful temple and definitely worth the effort despite the heat and humidity.
Regal and beautiful. The Kings residence and a must see - the approach is long and not for the unfit, but the moat and the detail is a must see!
Fascinating. A good couple of hours spent, Really not take plenty of water and find a shady bit to rest. The guide was well worth it too.

Magnificant. The scale of this site is breathtaking. The Great City built in the 12th century to the honor of King Jayavarman VII. Part temple, part palace covering 9 square Km. Swimming pools, arenas the list goes on. The scale is astounding, the architecture is magnificent. An absolute must see, plan for at least 1/2 day

Spectacular temples. Some reviewers have already stated that this area does not get as much publicity as Angkor Wat and they would be correct. It is pretty spectacular and there is so much to see. If you are going here from Angkor Wat in a taxi or tuk Tuk then just a tip for you. The toilets are at the other end of the temple tour so get your driver to take you to the toilet before you let him leave as they are at least a kilometre away! You will probably spend more time here than you did at Angkor Wat as there are various temples to see and they are magnificent and in my mind more interesting especially if you are a keen photographer. Your ticket price for AW will include this area and it is just a couple of miles away from the main temple. Keep your ticket stub as you will be asked to show it on entering. It is very, very hot so take plenty of water and sun screen as you will be outdoors most of the time. A good tip is to go to the museum before visiting any of the temples as it gives you a good idea of the history.

So many amazing temples to see.. There are a couple of hundred of these temples to see in Angkor Wat region, some are better than others. You can visit plenty of the smaller ones in one day, all very interesting.
Filled the second of three days.. This site is certainly one to see. By no means a lesser complex. Plenty of walking and climbing with very good photo opportunities.
Yes. The one with the many faces.. Well worth a visit. Probably the most unique of all the temples in the area. Hundreds of carved faces, everywhere. A must see.

Entrance to Angkor. This is the magnificent start toYour adventure here. You enter via the south gate, I was surprised to see elephants at the entrance here. Lots of amazing art & architecture everywhere you turn. Wear your joggers. Take a banana for the monkeys. But don't try and touch them. Ever. It's fantastic!
Visit the South Gate!. This was a cool gate we visited after the sunrise at Angkor Wat. The south gate has an awesome bridge leading with statues lining it that slowly turn to respect the King.

Awesome Vestiges of a Great City. Angkor Thom means "Great City" and, literally, it looks like it. Being the last and most enduring city of the Khmer Empire, this is not to be missed. Inside this city are great temples and monuments that will leave you breathless and in awe. That there was this beautiful and great city in the past makes you ponder on your present circumstances and yearn for a past that seems so grand and worth-keeping.

faces at Angkor Thom. We highly recommend visiting as many temples within Angkor as possible. The entrance fee is $20 a day for the entire UNESCO park, a bargain when you have a car and driver and guide. You'll be able to see the major ones in a day - another reason not to use a tuk tuk to get there. They're just too slow. Angkor is not to be missed. We wish we had spent more than 3 nights in Siem Reap. More time would have allowed more in-depth exploration.

a must see temple location at Angkor. a must not miss site.. make sure you have time to spend here to wonder around and enjoy the atmosphere and choose the time of day carefully, maybe better if you can towards later in pm when there are hardly any people

WOW again. Another WOW as in must see. This site does not get the the publicity of Ankor Wat but the moat is way bigger. It is amazing the size of these places all built by hand and the stones from so far away. All the stone work is fantastic.

Really interesting temples . We loved our time at Angkor Thom, we started our temple tour here and found it amazing and inspiring. There is literally so much to see and you could spend hours wondering round taking it all in.
Amazing. This is a must see, if you are in Siem Reap. It take about one - two hour to see the most importent.

My favourite temple in that huge area of temples. Well worth reading about the history of the temples and this one especially as lots of the heads had been ruined. Great photo opportunities. Beautiful temple. They were doing works there when we were there. You can imagine thousands of people visiting it everyday there needs to be some work done to preserve it.

Wonderful. Angkor Thom was one more of the must see areas of the park. It is a large area that encompasses many of the sites you want to see including Bayon, Terrace of Elephants and of the course the fabulous main gate.
such an amazing place. I love the all the stonework at all of these old temples. Not too touristy here, which is nice for a change

Bayon is the highlight of the trip!. Angkor Thom is a great place to visit just after sunrise at Angkor Wat. There aren't many people there yet so you can enjoy the scenery in peace, taking your time to get around. Bayon at Angkor Thom is by far the highlight of my trip to Siem Reap. It's beauty is astounding and it was surreal being there. Going there around 7a was the perfect time. There were only a few other people there, monkeys were out and the sunlight provided for some of the best photos I've ever taken.

An ancient city with numerous curiosities. It will take a good few hours to take in the various sites within this complex. Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to do some strenuous climbing. You will be rewarded by what you will see!

Impressing. This city was constructed at the end of the 12th century and was enormous. Inside its moats there was easily enough space for any medieval European walled city. We visited the Bayon temple, the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leper King. This was impressing and interesting, but quite enough on a hot day.The South Gate of Angkor Thom with the demons on one side and the gods on the other side of the bridge was wonderful. And just at the moment we were going to pass the port, a huge elephant emerged from the other side and made us hesitate and wait until it had passed by.Look for more reviews by MulleEllum.

Sprawling with lots of walking, but so worthwhile. At this complex down the road from Angkor Wat, visit the Elephant Wall and the Baphuon Temple (built about 3 centuries before Angkor Wat). All else is unessential. The climb up Baphuon is frightening for the faint-of-heart but so worth it for views and a sense of accomplishment!
Walk of faces . There are lots of temples in the area and this one is of my favorites. You get to do the walk amongst all the guardians and the demons and all the faces.
Nice temple. Another great temple to visit in the Angkor area. Very fascinating and full of history. Absolutely recommended to have a guide here.

Just like the movie. Raiders of the Lost Ark was filmed here, among the temples ruined by huge creeper trees. Forest and temples completely intertwined. One of the archeologists who discovered the site had the brilliant idea of preserving it as it was, doing enough cutting of the foliage to slow its destruction. Fortunately he was listened to.
On the list of must see's .... Worth a visit, as with many of the other temples it is amazing to witness the incredible work that was done so long ago.
Beautiful!. The biggest part in Angkor. There are several temples comprised in this area among Bayon, Elephant Terrace, etc. It is a must see!

Angkor Smile. Trying to avoid the crowds is nearly impossible due to the sheer awesomeness of the temples in Angkor Thom, which makes them so popular with tourists and locals alike.If you wanting holiday snapshots without the crowds, try using a zoom lens to isolate subjects of interest while visiting the temples.

Palace complex. Angkor Archaeological Park includes the temples of Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Pnohm Bakeng, etc.In the centre of this park lies the magnificent city of Angkor Thom (with its huge awesome gates). South gate and East gate are particularly good.The Angkor Thom city has the palace building, Bayon temple, terrace of the elephants, terrace of the leper king, the very ancient Baphoun temple and some other ruins.A guide may not be needed for Angkom Thom city (but surely required for Angkor Wat temple)
Walk of the faces. One can never miss this temple as this opens to other temples of the vicinity. Most prominent are the rows of heads that lined the street.

Incredible. Cambidian architecture it is just amazing! I love every moment of it. I wish i had more time to apreciate it. If you have more time try to come on your own the next day ao you can enjoy it to its fulness. Tickets for temple visit $20 per day.

Huge place with over 20 temples. Depending on the time you have... you can spend 3 days or 2 hours there. But interesting and worth a visit... though it will rank as number 3 behind Ta Prohm and AngKor Wat, in my view.
Angkor Thom. Alot of people mistaken this place as Angkor Wat. A place with lots of different temples and different buildings for different purposes.
amazing. It can be really hot walking around these temples, and a lot of people struggle with the heat take your time and drink lots of water.
Another must see. This temple and the details of each face carved in the stone is a must see! The temple is breath taking.
Great experience. We visited Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom on the same day and both sites were truly breathtaking and wonderful to see. This is a must see.
Another must see temple. Smaller than Angkor Wat but somewhat more beautiful. The same issues for physically challenged and older travelers
Fun for Kids!!. Great temple for children to enjoy - our boys loved it!! Great to visit in the afternoon as the sun is going down...

In some ways better than Angkor Wat. We didn't have much prior knowledge of all the temples apart from Angkor Wat, so Angkor Thom was a nice surprise. The approach across the moat into the 3km x 3km area was cool, and the temple itself with the multiple 4-faced towers was unlike anything we had seen before. At one point you can see one of the faces in profile which makes a great photo opp for a nose-to-nose profile shot!If you found this review helpful I'd appreciate your vote.
Interesting temple complex. Several different and interesting temples to visit here, all within walking distance. Take a scarf to cover your shoulders at Phimeanakas temple.

Many beautiful temples. There are many beautiful buildings. Of course there is the Bayon which might be the main attraction but also a lot of smaller buildings where we saw barely any tourists. There are some medium sized temples aswell and there you find some tourists but there're not completely overrun by them
remarkable Angkor Thom. this part of the old Khmer Empire ruins is huge, interesting and impressive - this should take one of the several days you book at Siem Reap

Thom terrific!. Would have to be the well know Jewel of the Angkor Wat complex. Intricate stone work set off by 300 year old tree growth. On the down side because of its beauty and history, it is very popular and crowded, but it is still possible that get that one off photo. Be aware that unofficial "tour guides" will try to join you while there. While they may or may not be knowledgable, ensure you either rebuff them or negotiate their fee first, rather than get an inflated one at the end of the tour.

A beauty Greeny Angkor. All a Part of Angkor wats Visit, a call Siem Reap a city of Wonderns with all the Angkors and temples, a strange crazy combination all in One placewell the Angkor is loosing some of it charm due to time, and I suppose non Maintenance, so be carefull where you are putting your feet

Not as Busy, so you can enjoy it more. A great example of the architecture and reliefs of a temple. The entrance witht he 54 gods and demons is impressive. Our guide was important for us to understand the historical significance of the site.

Totally impressive!. The scale and magnitude of these structures would leave anyone awestruck. Some prior knowledge would definitely make the trip more meaningful. An well informed guide is recommended.

Amazing Temple Structure - Must See!!!. This was one of my favorite temple sites visited in Siem, Reap, Cambodia, although there were so many I loved!!! Angkor Thom, located in present-day Cambodia, was the last and most enduring capital city of the Khmer empire. It was established in the late twelfth century by King Jayavarman VII according to Wikipedia.

Huge trees and temple. Not just attracted by this amazing temple and also attracted by the trees. Not really sure that how the trees could grow up around the temple for hundreds of years. Strongly recommend to visit this place.

Contains Bayon and a lot more. If I would go again I think I would go by bike. It gives you freedom to explore the many sites, and not only the most famous ones. Although going by bike requires a fair bit of selfstudy because there are no easily available maps over the site.

Angkor Thom. Our first sight on our visit to Angkor Wat. It's a squared city with four ways, one from each direction like a cross with the Bayon Temple at the center. Entrance to the city gate are carved stone towers. Morning seems to be a good time to visit - less tourist.

well worth going. Wear a hat & bring some water,the walk from where your transport leaves you to the temple is around 100m and open to the searing heat. The wall carvings were amazing, guides are available to explain the history as you walk around (negotiate a fee) but I managed with some background reading / research. I hope to explore it further in March 2016.
Another amazing temple. Had a great time here, its worth hiring a tour guide to explain the meanings of different carvings and what not
Beautiful place. Beautiful place but very crowded. Even in winter is very hot so better is to plan a visit not for noonday...............

First Stop at Angkor Wat Complex. Huge 12th Century Royal City restoration offers an excellent overview of over 50 years of archaeological renewal. Featuring a multitude of towers, the King's reviewing stand, and towering trees which have become intertwined with the ancient stones of the complex
History. We say Ankor Thom with a guide who really understood the history. Climbing to the top is not for the unadventurous - but you don't have to!
The biggest temple in Siem Reap I think.... Angkor wat is big but this temple is even bigger. I'm really enjoy walking around this temple becaues there are plenty of space out side the temple.

Ancient gems. Visit these pieces of history before they all disappear. Be prepared for the heat though. Wear comfortable walking shoes and some climbing is involved. Pack water and patience and try not to visit during their wet season as the humidity will make it even more unbearable.

Breathtaking. Further up the road from Angkor Wat, but with its size and variation of structures is equally worth visiting. You can easily spend 2-3 hours here, even taking an elephant ride if you want to.

The core of Angkor Wat. This area is the core of the region and not to miss even if you have only a one day pass. The elephant terrace is beautiful and unusual. Bayon is probably the most beautiful building in AW.

Amazing. There is so many superlatives that you could use to describe this wonder of the world - rising out of shadows as the sun rises is an experience which will never be forgotten. There is so much to enjoy and see and it is well worth having a guide to walk you through the history and symbolism of this marvellous place - just magical
Fantastic. A very enjoyable day exploring with our Group from Travel Marvel Unbelievable to think of all the history here

part of the package. its very close to ankor wat and bayon so come as part of the package - the gates to this are awesome with the faces carved into them. lots of temples and other notable buildings inside a large area - if you are into history or taking pictures of historical places this is another must do in siem reap

Faces on the towers. Their is faces on towers here at the city gates, who were add to the main structure, It may be represent the king, who knows?. and you can cross the moat in front of each tower.The gateways themselves are very high; naturally the doors are missing. Try to imagine, how many hands work on this piece of Art???
Very cool. Make sure you go when it's not too hot. Excellent ruins to climb and explore! Sensational photos but lots and lots of tourists. We didn't get one but there were elephants around to ride.
Very nice temple in Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is one of the best temple inside Angkor Wat. This place is one of must visit place in Angkor Wat.
Becomes too touristic.... It's amazing on its own but tourists have no respect anymore for other visitors which makes the visit a little bit uncomfortable :-(

Royal City from the 12th Century. We began our tour of the Angkor Archaeological Park with a visit to Angkor Thom. This royal city includes all kinds of temples and interesting sites to see. You will need a guide to help you get the most from your visit. Our tour began with a walk over the bridge over the moat through the main gate. The huge crowd of visitors also entering the site included people from all over the world on foot, on elephant, on tuk tuk, and in taxis (gate is too narrow for buses). Very interesting to visit this historical sight. We visited in December during the "cool" season -- be warned the climate is hot and humid -- even in the winter.
A blast from the past. It was a great experience visiting this place. Learned a lot of things about this UNESCO declared world heritage site.

Amazing.. Great temple. My sons loved climbing on the structure. There are parts where you can climb and be at the top of the temple. Worthy trip even though it is quite hot and humid. It was really amazing.
Smiling Buddhas Are Charming. Great place to visit to explore the site. What remains is lovely. The carvings and sculptures are worth your time. You will enjoy visiting Angkor Thom.
wonderful. If you're going to see anchor wat this is another to go to once again covered shoulders and knees as you won't be able to enter.
Huge temple city. Major temple. One cannot image this was built was humans. The king at that was that powerful? Tuktuk is needed inside, it is that huge.

Next best after Angkor Wat. You need to read a little history first - try the Wikipedia webpage for starters. It includes three substantial temples plus the remains of a royal palace and associated structures. This was the final capital of the great Khmer empire c. 800 - 1450 AD.

Interesting restoration and a dream spot for photo shoots. The Indian government has been involved in the restoration that is unique as they have kept the natural setting of the tree roots that overgrew the original site to make it look part of the landscape. If you like photos, there's many places to choose. Movies were filmed here, so it's popular and some of the photo shoots are a little overwhelming if you want to take a photo of yourself.
Just wow. Angor thom alone was worth of the 20$ entrance fee, but there is so many more temples to see. Go there and enjoy.

Great fun in the Great City.... Visited Angkor Thom with a group of friends to see the historic site in and around the area. The site has a lot to see and behold with plenty of opportunities for pictures and you are even joined by the wildlife (as I saw a few cheeky monkeys playing). The scale of the site which is believed to be over 800 years old demonstrates an age where royal was considered to be divine, a truly educational experience. To miss the crowds I would recommend visiting either in the early morning or late afternoon where you can explore the temple more freely. But I would also recommend a guide to supply further details about the history of this temple and bringing water, sun screen, a hat or umbrella if sunny or raining and of course a camera.

Wow it's great. This place rivals Angkor Watt, a must see while in Siem Reap.Together they make up one of the seven wonders so you can't miss them and this place shows how the jungle was taking over before discovery in modern times

Beautiful structures and lovely surrounding area. This was the third temple we visited. It was just as wonderful to see as Angkor Wat and Ta Prom. However, the surrounding countryside was especially beautiful. We got some really lovely photos of the environs.

Lara Croft for a Day. One of my favorite temple within the heritage park. The stone formation is just breathtaking. I love the rustic mood of the temple. It brings me to the time where Royal people are celebrated with so much respect. The temple is huge. The cambodian people assigned in the area are accomodating and friendly :)

Angkor Thom houses the Bayon and Baphuon temples. The bridge with the snake balustrades is where we entered. The walls of the complex, had some of the classic heads adorning the entrance gates.
There's a garuda to the left of the entry gate, and on the back side of the entrance on the right, you can see a three headed elephant.
Even more impressive than Angkor Wat. The name means "Great City" and this must have been an amazing site 900 years ago. It is still impressive and a fascinating place to visit.

Loved it so much I bought a wood sculpture of bayon!. Very detailed temple! My teens loved climbing on the structure. There are parts where you can climb and truly be at the top of the temple. Amazing! Love it!

Many temples and terraces. People easily forget the other temples and terraces in this area because the Bayon is so overwhelming. But it is worth to explore at the other attractions as well. You could easily spend a couple of hours or more in this area.
I love this place!. this is an amazing place !!!! you'll never know how amazing the drawing is if you never come this place!! total recommended!!!!

My favorite sight in Siem Reap. Angkor Thom has the most impressive and memorable giant artifacts. The smiling faces carved on the stone exude peace and love as you walk around them. My favorite place.

Crowded and beautiful!. Try getting there as early as possible, if you are crowd phobic!
Unfortunately tourists are not always polite.. Be prepared messing with photo bombers from all other the world, but obviously it is 100% worth visiting this unique cultural spot in Cambodia.

Lots of temples in the area. This is really an area with a few temples and is not a temple itself.
Bayon was my favourite temple in the Angkor Thom.
Royal Palace, Phimenakas and Elephant terrace were OK but not anything to rave about compared to Bayon or Angkor Wat.
early temple. this is one of the oldest temples, the faces guard the 5 entrances. Huge impressive place and not quite as busy as Angkor Wat

best photo op. There are really amazing places for photo op at the Angkor Thom. I even submitted one of the pictures where your nose seems to touch the nose of the statue above and it won the first place. Take a guide or a person who can tell you the best locations for trick photography, scenic photography
Go see it. This temples lives in a shadow of Angkor wat despite the fact it is just as marvelous and beautiful in all its differences. Do yourself a favor and spend some time there too.
