This is a must see. Amazing temple and history. Our kids loved being able to wonder and take there own pictures. We will remember this for a life time.

My favourite of the Siem Reap temples: stunning faces carved into stone towers. I actually preferred Angkor Thom to Angkor Wat - it's smaller and I just loved the faces carved into the 20m+ stone towers in the Bayon temple. Mesmerising. When entering from the south gate, you cross a bridge over the moat lined with stone sculptures each holding a length of Naga, the giant king cobra snake in a tug-of-war stance. Then you can walk through the temples of Bayon, Baphoun and Phimean Akas, not forgetting the Terraces of Elephants and the Leper King outside. The bas reliefs carved into the stone (laterite) walls show well preserved people and animals (fish, monkeys, elephants and dragon-like creatures). I could have walked round this all day. It was just magical.
Amazing. Loved this Wat- so glad we had it included in our tour and got to see it recently restored! The carved faces are beautiful as is the history here
Excellent. Try to head out early, to avoid the crowds, the tour buses turn up around 930, and then they just dominate the place, and of the day starts heating up......

Part of the amazing city - great carvings on the main temple. This was my first temple on my visit to Angkor Wat, and the carvings around the outside of the temple showing the history are amazing.There is a great place up on the top of the first temple to get a shot of three smiling buddhas from three different towers.Great place and then walk through to the other two temples on Angkor Thom, especially liked the elephant terrace and the view of the 12 towers from it.

Angkor Tam. That is how you would say this if your Scottish. Great temple area beyond Angkor Wat. Again the 3 day pass covers this. Angkor Thom has several areas that should be visited. Elephant Terrace, Bayon and Leper King etc. It would be expected as part of a 3 day pass that at least 1 day would be spent in this area. All the tuk tuk guys will happily take you there. Inexpensive and unlike tuk tuks in Thailand or Philippines - very comfy and quiet.
Pretty cool temple. Alot of great history here and one of our favorites we went in the afternoon and started again the next day early in the morning for some exceptional photos.

My Favorite Temple. This one is different from all the rest with the smiling faces on each pillar and the great ambience of history and decay. A great mix of history and art will help you appreciate this site, or just makes for great pictures in any light. This one was my favorite because it was so different and we had excellent timing to have it almost to ourselves for a few minutes.

Visit this: The last capital city of the Khmer empire. Angkor Thom means 'great city' it was a Buddhist temple built in the 12th century. A must visit place when in Cambodia as it reflects a long history.

Once in a lifetime experience... truly amazing. You can't visit Angkor Wat without coming here too. They compliment each other. The architecture is just incredible. The site is huge and takes a while to see it all.

Best of the temples!!. Forget Angkor Wat and Ta Prom which are busy, Angkor Thom consists of three temples, my favourite being Baphuon temple. This is very high, with amazing views, is hidden in the trees and has an amazing atmosphere. Obviously you ll still see the other temples, but this has a unique charm.
A good place to see the sun setting.. Went to see the sun setting here, worth the climb up and crowds, took my breath away. Go and see for yourselves.

Another Great Temple. It would be a shame to only visit Angkor Wat and miss this - another amazing feat of engineering. Our pass covered the whole of the World Heritage site so we didn't have to pay extra to see this one. Well worth the effort.
It's where you go after Angkor Wat. Just up the road from Angkor Wat, a lot of the temples are here next to each other so you just walk thru one to the next
Amazing Angkor!. Angkor Thom is a big area full of temples. It is a breathtaking thing to see these significant architectures!!! Worth your life time!
Visited as part of the full Angkor Wat tour. To see what people have created 1000 years ago and is still standing with such magnitude is amazing. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

A gateway to Angkor Wat. It is an amazing experience to walk thru the narrow passage with the wooden gate on both sides. Sad to see so many valuable figures got stolen or destroyed. Glad that other countries pitched in for the restoration.

Beautiful temple. This is a must see. We took the elephant tour around this temple to get the perspective and then went inside for details. UNESCO is rebuilding parts of it so it will be even better for future generations.

As good as Angkor Wat. You can't visit Angkor Wat without coming here too. They compliment each other. The architecture is just incredible. The site is huge and takes a while to see it all. Take your time and absorb it.

A bigger area to explore. Ankor Thom is a rather bigger area to explore, remember which entrance or exit you came from, cause the have two, so make sure your driver knows exactly which one to meet you.
Unbelievable. Set in beautiful surroundings . A true wonder of the world . You have to see it to believe . Spectacular

Best for photo and architecture enthusiasts. My Siem Reap trip was so fulfilling, and being an engineering student, it's amazing to see historical pieces with your own eyes-- and ones filled with history as well.
Must visit!. Angkor Thom includes some of the top things to see in Angkor Wat. Great if you take a Tuktuk to Elephants Terrace then continue through Phimeanakas, Baphuon, then Bayon.

another Great temple. I had come here as part of the tour package that i had arranged and again was not disappointed in this temple . It is well worth the effort to visit please wear comfortable shoes and again bring lots of water and a hat

Large ancient city. Angkor Thom was the latest city built by the Angkor Empire, and also the biggest. It incorporated some old buildings, like Baphuon, but built new ones, like Bayon. The entire city has many temple ruins worth visiting.

Spectacular complex. Awesome set of ancient Khmer temples
Took about 2 hours to wander around
Photo opportunities everywhere
Stunning. Stunning ruins with overgrown trees. Well worth the visit. I saw this as part of a tour and definttely was a highlight.
As good as the reviews say. There are so many ancient temples to choose from in this area, but Angkor Thom is unique and highly recommended.

The view is spectacular!!!. It is the largest site in the Angkor Archaeological Park, It was estimated that the city had a population of nearly one million. To enter the city, you must go through one of the five great gateways that are topped with four giant faces and bridges leading to the doors are lined with statues.You will spend a lot of time walking and climbing so dress comfortably. This complex is not as well preserved as Ankor Wat in its entirety but parts of it is and it is all definitely worth seeing. Its also worth taking an official guide with you to tell you about what you are seeing and where you are. We would never have known that the forests we were wandering through was once the royal palace or that the ponds were their swimming pools. You should also be aware that you need to buy a pass from the registered office to visit any of the temples around Siem Reap

Another great temple. Impressive face carvings! Sometimes during the daylight, some priests come there to pray. Some of them even have the latest gadgets such as iPads and iPhones to make pictures :)! The temple is clean and well-maintained.
In Angkor. There are many temples in Angkor, this is only one, but filled with history. Be sure to see as many as you can

Amazing . As all the temples,the place is amazing and stunning..!!
You can have a tuk tuk for 15$ a day and he can brings you to the temples.!!you need 2 days..!
It's worth it..!

Huge Area of Ruins and History. The site is extensive and includes many features and ruins of various parentage and history. Having once been the country's Capital, it has much to offer in terms of ruins and structures. Spend a good bit of time here as there is much to see and experience.
A piece of history. Incredible structure with an amazing story, part of the many wonderful structures in the area. This one was no less incredible and interesting to see.

Awesome. We brought our two young children (5 and 2) here and were quite simply blown away by the site. It is so picturesque and a photographer's dream. We were a bit sceptical of bringing two young children here fearing that it would not be ideal but they loved it - the sense of adventure more than anything else. we came by tuk tuk and spent a good hour or so wandering around - without the constraints of young children the site would quite happily entertain you for days... We took an elephant ride which was great fun!

good walking. Good historical building to see. It was fairly quiet the day I went. Once you are inside the area with all the temples it is nice to stop at as many as possible. Take lunch and sit and enjoy.

The temple of many smiley faces. The first impression of the temple is how amazing the structure is preserved even after it was hidden for hundreds of years.The multi smiley faces reminded me of 4-face Buddha of Thailand. Do come visit with a guide to learn more.Do wear proper foot wear and be prepared with lots of water to dehydrate after all the walking.

Part of the tour. This was more interesting because it (through the guide) offers insight into the everybody needs to have their own temple history. It is a large complex that is interesting but not as impressive as others. Close enough to things that one shouldn't miss is it.
Really beautiful. Cambodia doesn't stop with it's surprises! Angkor Thom is probably even better than Angkor Wat with all the carvings on the temples.

Monkeys everywhere. I felt like I was in Indiana Jones with the monkeys jumping and playing everywhere. As worth it as the other temples with less of the crowds, I would wholeheartedly go again. When getting to the top it can be quite busy, and even in the early morning there were crowds of Chinese tours blocking people's way.

A must see. All we can say is you must see this place , so interesting amazing,the hotel we stayed at they arranged the Tour guide and used their own Tuk Tuk not at all expensive. Sorry for late review

Lost Khmer capital city. Angkor Thom is actually the ancient Khmer imperial capital city that includes all the temples in the Angkor archaeological park. It was a dream to come and visit this temple complex in Siem Riep and I was extremely excited to be here for a couple of days. You need a couple of days to visit it because is massive and all temples have something else to say about the lost Khmer people. You do need a tuk tuk to move around the temples as they are far away from each other. It is breath taking to see the grandeur of the lost capital city.

Amazing place. This was part of of our self-guided "tour" to Angkor Wat. We had a blast and lots of walking as well. I'm taking it won't be too long till access to some of the ruins will be closed to the public for better conservation, which then makes us lucky ones. Thumbs up!

Everything you want to know about history of Khmer. If you are a fan of history and want to explore Cambodia, Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom is must-go places. The Angkor Thom is a citadel of ancient Khmer Empire. There are many things that I can explore in the " Great City"

Second only to Angor Wat...an absolute must see temple complex. If you visit Cambodia without going to Angkor Thom; you have failed! I love this area because of the unique temples and carvings that can be seen here. Some of the relief carvings are absolutely amazing and have to be seen.

Grandeur of lost capital city. Angkor Thom is actually the ancient Khmer imperial capital city that includes the famous Bayon temple and others. We entered via the awe-inspiring South Gate, crossing a medieval bridge flanked by a row of angels on the left and demons on the right. There are a number of temple ruins within the city, the most famous being Bayon in the center. The square city is surrounded by a moat and remnants of a wall and rampart, with a bike trail around it.
Favorite Angkor. Personally like this place more than the others as they are more iconic and left a deeper impression with the many face carvings. It should definitely not be missed!
Fascinating!. Definitely worth a visit and a really fascinating place. My favourite among the tamples in the Angkor complex
Amazing. Wonderful experience. built on days when modern construction equipment are not available. Walking around and climbing the ruins in hot humid weather is tiring, but one of memorable visits.

The temple of faces . Another great temple to go top of your list. Lots of huge temple towers with faces (all different) carved into them. Also an amazing frieze all around telling a historic story of the ancient peoples. This temple will take 90 mins to visit but is one of the best.

Face on face. This venue is iconic and of course should NOT be missed.
The only negative comment to be made here is crowd control.
The area on the second level is not expansive and narrow in parts and so should you be there at peak hours then be prepared to feel as if you are trapped in a department store sale.

Incredible. The temples at Angkor Thom are absolutely amazing. They are sprawling, awe inspiring and stunning. The grounds are large. Make sure you have good walking shoes and plenty of water. The history is fascinating and the structures and sculptures and complex. A guide is a must to really have a full appreciation of what you are seeing.
Buddhist temple site. Like Angkor Wat this is another very interesting temple site which dates back 1000 years and shows human endeavour and achievement.
Majestic. An awe inspiring temple. Large, intricate detail with much history. Even though there are lots of visitors, the views are stunning
Faces, Faces Everywhere!. Only Temple of the big three with a railing to go up and down huge flights of steps. Loved the huge wall relief mural. Get a guide or book to help explain the history.

The Best of Angkor. Angkor Thom is not just one set of temple ruins, but more like a mini walled city with many temples, terraces, amazing gates, etc ...the most incredible ruins at Angkor by far!!! At the center of Angkor Thom is The Bayon. There are many must see areas in Angkor, but Angkor Thom is definitely #1.

Wonderful Temple. It's definitely smaller, but quite lovely. If you really want to avoid crowds, head to the 'temple of the dead'. Some Tuk Tuk's don't want to take you there because of superstition. There are very few people for this reason. It's the entrance that they took deceased people through. Some parts of AT are very crowded, but worth viewing, the elephants, and the small gates are all pretty magnificent. Take your time, and take your patience with you as well.

Well worth a visit.. Our guide Rany explained the various sites to us, it was a particularly hot day and a bit of a walk but well worth it, so interesting to get the history behind the various temples.The temple carvings are amazing, so intricate with so much history behind them, our guide was great as he knew the best times to visit the various temples so it was not to busy and we got some great photos.

Huge, must visit, much much beigger than Ankor Wat. I did not know at the time that Ankor Thom is many time larger than the better know Ankor Wat and there is the much smaller Ta ProhmWe did all three in about three hours, we did not do our home work and I guess our guide did not take us all of the temples in the area!We did go to the National Museum before going on the tour but the information at the museum did not give any guidance on what and where.Amazing place, what can I say, take you time and check it out.
Great place to vsiit. Smaller size than Angkor Wat but just as interesting. Again be prepared for a fair size crowd. Included the 3 to visit Angor Thom and Ta Prohm

Simply amazing complex. Had an amazing time here. Could have spent days and days here. I would recommend buying a three day pass, although 2 day would be ideal but this isn't an option unfortunately.
This ancient complex will not disappoint.
Would recommend you come prepared with lots of water and a packed lunch.
Date visited: 1 Dec 2015

Originally the capital of Cambodia. The history here was truly interesting to me. Again, have a guide who knows the place. I wish I had not lost the card of who we had. There are so many cool intact carvings, It is not the biggest temple but the oldest besides the womens temple
Worth the visit. Its a long walk, and its better not to take the full tour so you can move on your own pace. As for food i say wait till you get back to the city

Everything about Cambodia and its sites are worth visiting. Like Angkor Wat .....this site was just as spectacular. wear comfortable shoes and a lot of walking takes place as you visit all the more archaeological sites. All four major sites can be done in one day. It's long and tiring but well worth it.

Angkor Thom temple.. This temple was unique in that it had not been restored and the massive tropical plants had overgrown many sections. It was fascinating to visit and totally different from the other temples in the area.
Beautiful. A beautiful site. Like stepping back into history. Well maintained. The day I visited it was not crowded

Beautiful. Not to be missed. My favorite after Ta Prohm temple. Our pictures are fabulous. All these faces seem they are all looking at you in the eyes. We hired a guide from our hotel (Golden Temple Hotel) which was very informative and showed us the best spots for unforgettable pictures. We were there at sunset and it was magical.

If you only have a day.... If you only have a day then I would definitely recommend the short circuit which takes in Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom....you def get your money's worth. Always lots of tourists but doesn't take away from the experience. Angkor Wat at Sunrise was amazing!

Wow. A maze of temples, towers and jungle this place is one of the highlights of Angkor park. A good walk-around will probably take at least half a day. There are food and drink vendors around, you can also purchase long pants in few places (especially around Bayon). Don't forget, some places require you (especially women) to wear something more covering than shorts and tank-tops. Be sure to climb on the South Gate - it is worth it.
Must do. Great temple to visit given its historical significance and awesome architecture. Maybe try to space out the temple visits as you start to lose perspectives and temples start to look similar

What an experience!. Up at 4.30 am ready for an experience of a lifetime. We went by Tuk Tuk, which was really cool. Once there our guide found a spot right up the front to obtain the best view of the sunrise. The atmosphere was amazing, everyone waiting and the sounds of clicking cameras trying to get the best photo. The temple is sooo big and the walk through it was amazing. It was hard to imagine how it was built so many years ago. Our guide was very informative. A must visit if you visit Siem Reap.

A must site to visit. In spite of the crowd, people were patient and cordial.The site is clean and needs a lot of time to absorb its history and significance why these were built to begin with.If you like history this is a place to see.Although the temp is hot and humid cold drinks were readily available.I will definitely come back.
A temple of many faces. No matter where you turn you will see a face looking at you. Quiet a spectacular place. Part of the grand tour so worth booking this tour along with Angkor wat

FANTASTIC. This temple was the first that i visit. Traduzirfiquei maravilhada. Centenas e centenas de anos já passaram por aquela estrutura. Interessante pensar que estamos a pisar os mesmos locais que uma civilização antiga já pisou.I was amazed. Hundreds and hundreds of years have passed by that structure. Interesting to think that we are treading the same locations that an ancient civilization ever set foot.You gotta go!!!
Very good. Many tourists, but what do you expect. Well worth the tour as part of a wider tour seeing Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm.
Wondeful experience. Felt as if I was walking back through time. Highly recommend this tour when in Siem Reap. Our tour guide made the expeience wonderful.

The North and South gates of Angkor Thom are awesome. I've been to Angkor Thom twice now in consecutive years as part my Angkor Wat International Half Marathon runcation. The entrance gates never fail to impress when passing through Angkor Thom. A suggestion to anyone visiting is to walk or ask the tuk tuk or van driver to stop on the way to the Victory gate of Angkor Thom after visiting the Terrace of the Leper King & the Elephant terraces. You can get a great up close view of Prasat Sour Prat (the Acrobat temples). Its also close to the start of the forested area behind Prasat Sour Prat and is therefore relatively shady (some thing to be appreciated in very hot and sunny Siem Reap) . For me for reasons unknown, this is my favourite part of Angkor Thom - its almost mystical.

amazing. This was one of my favorite temples. Lots of faces carved into the masses of stone. Great views fro the top overlooking the jungle. Wear comfortable walking shoes as it is a lot of walking and climbing.

Ancient capital city. Angkor Thom was once the capital city of Khmer empire. It covered an area of approximately 10 sq km within which important monuments and beautiful temples were located. e.g. Bayon temple, temple of Baphuon, etc. The city was enclosed by a wall and wide moat. We entered via the monumental south gate over a causeway lined on either side by statues od gods and demons, each carrying a giant Naga. Inside the city wall, there were ruins of monuments and temples.
Good to see!. This is very similar to Angkor Wat, but a bit smaller. It does not detract from the experience. If you have time ... see both locations.

Another must do. Not far from Angkor Wat. This is another must visit. Uneven ground but no climbs. We visited this temple as part of an organised trip with Viking Cruises, but you can get your own trips. If staying at a hotel near area then book you trip through them. When we visited it was Very hot in area. So Take sun cream, sun hat and plenty of water.
Cool spot. The ancient carvings of faces were really neat surrounded by crumbling structures. Worth the stop. Try to avoid the crowds if possible, everyone wants the same picture.

Must see ..... I was so impressed with this site.It is a Must see! ! ! From the incredible gateway to this site to all the temples to explore within the 9 km. Angkor Thom translated means "great City".I imagine it was in the 12 century. I really liked the Bayon temple. Impressive boardwalk to Baphuon.Such details to absorb terrace of the Leeper King. I also really enjoyed the elephant Terrace. We enjoyed Lunch here, priced where absolutely fair and really great service and food. We bought a few souvenirs. Easy 1/2 day but if you can 5 hrs or so to really explore all that Angkor Thom has to offer
Real must in Angkor area. Baron is the centre go Angkor Thom. Its's one of the most impressive temples in the whole area. Head figures are stunning.
Breath-taking. This temple is vast, complex, and jaw-dropping. You should plan on a few hours to even begin to grasp its meaning and depth of execution.
Cultural overload!. Go as early in the day as possible to avoid the hordes of tourists. Be prepared to take tons of photos. Beautiful!
soo pretty... just more lovely history that you can explore... take lots of pics..and make sure you have a guide ..worth the extra money...
Lovely. Angkor Thom means "the great city" in Khmer. Rich history, stunning and the surrounding area are scenic (Terrace of Elephant, Phimeanakas, Baphoun and Bayon temple).

Beautiful. A really beautiful temple. Lots of tourists around, but if you brave the afternoon heat and come during lunch time, crowds do thin out. This is a lovely temple with excellent photo opportunities.
Very interesting . Like Angkor Wat this is straight out of the jungle book. Loved it but you'd need a guide to get the most out of it.
The best of Ankor Complex. This is the best experience you can get while visiting Ankor Complex. This a must watch for Siem Reap Tourist.

My fave temple. This temple in my opinion, is better than angkor wat.
It just has a better vibe.
Although they are seriously undergoing repairs at this site, so areas are off limits.
Must go see!!

Favorite Siem Reap Temple. I found the faces absolutely enchanting and exotic. More so than the architecture of Angkor Wat or Bayon Thom. Don't forget that these are temples - so cover your shoulders, midriff and legs down to at least your knees. If you want to go to the top levels (recommended, but it is a bit of a climb) then the staff will be very strict about dress code. Out of courtesy, please help respect these sites and the people by adhering to their standards of minimal conservativeness whenever in the temples.

A great way to spend a couple of hours. The trick to this site is lots of water and slowly wander everywhere. Take your time to look around and follow as many paths as you can otherwise you will miss so much.

Another amazing temple. It was drizzling with rain when we visited this temple but not even that could mar the spectacle of this temple. This was the last great capital of the Khmer empire and it is surrounded by a 100m wide moat for protection against invaders. It is thought this city may have supported as many as 1million people in the surrounding region.The bas reliefs of the Bayon are decorated with 1.2km of carvings of more that 11000 figures engaging in everyday life in 12th century Cambodia. Each section of the wall shows people occupied with different tasks from fighting to providing the food for the warriors but the most amazing section is the 54 towers decorated with 216 enormous faces. It is interesting to note that when you add the numbers of individual features; the answer always come to 9; the lucky number we were told by our guide.We arrived late morning and because it was raining, the sun had no affect on the beauty of this site but still we found it a magnificent place to visit. Whether it is raining or not, I would suggest wearing good walking shoes to prevent slipping.You can get some amazing photos here. Your guide will know all the best spots and my tip is to give him your phone and let him click away; you'll be amazed at the resulting photos. Jenine Tracey

One of Many. Each area we saw had its own draw. This was pretty well left as it was, but you were allowed to walk around and into the buildings which surprised me. Some had artifacts inside them. Very interesting. Worth It.

Fascinating. One of the biggest complexes of the Angkor temples, this one in particular stands out thanks to its beauty and rich history. Don't rush the tour as you'll want to spend a few hours going through the archways and up the stairs to appreciate the monumental buildings and views!
sightseeing. Another amazing place the temple were stunning and the areas around so scenic. Again guide knowledagable. go early to avoid crowds and heat,
top attraction. Very interesting and grand architecture, wear comfortable walk shoes and take water. quick look or long study, up to you.

This area is worth seeing. Angkor Thom is an area worth seeing because it comprises of some of the major highlights (Bayon, Phimeanakas, Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, etc.) The southern gate is the most intact and your driver will take you through it as you exit Angkor Thom. We didn't get to all of it and took the route backwards to end at Bayon. It doesn't too long to go around, but there is a lot of climbing up and down. Bayon and the South Gate are definitely the highlights.
Stunning. You read about and see the photos but nothing prepares you for the reality. Just stunning, one of the best sites in the world.

Angkor Thom is awesome !. This temple was one of my favorites ! The faces are unreal. You could spend hours here exploring and taking photos... you get a workout for sure climbing steps. Bring Mosquito spray to all the temples.

Gateway to the archeological park. As you approach Ankor Thom, you will be flanked by a long row of fascinating sculptures, demons on one side and gods on the other. Some have been partially restored.
Magnificient Gateway. It has the most beautiful gateway with statues lining both sides with lake on either side. You can also see majestic elephants and the mahouts riding them.

Easily Lost. I found this much more enjoyable than Angkor Wat because it is cooler (temp. wise) and more like a maze. There was less of a crowd which is nice and you find different ways to get to places within. I found a way to the center and took my mom that way and it took about 30 mins to find the way back. A definite must see!

Awesome temple and very close to other sites. Really neat temple to see. Almost felt like a maze at times. It is also very close to a large shrine and a really big wall with elephants and about 2 minute drive from a bridge with deva statues lining it. A pass is required to enter like many of the temple sites. This one offers little in the way of shade and umbrellas are awkward in many of the corridors so an earlier morning visit is recommended before it gets really hot. This temple does require you to go up stairs to see the majority. On the lower level however are beautiful murals showing daily life. Not difficult temple to tour but there are stairs and uneven stones so wear good shoes not flip flops

Amazing Tree in the temple. Among all the temple I visited, I love this the most and I can see how amazing is Mother Nature is. The highlight of this temple is the tree that tucked in the temple. Most of them are grow on the roof of the temple and the root climbed down all the way. I can't recall how many years they grow but you can tell from the root that they are there for sometimes. I somehow missed the Buddha in tree scene as we did not manage to find it. Nevertheless I really feel amazing although a lot of area has already been destroyed.

We were blown away by Ankor Thom. The famous bridge at the gateway to Angkor Thom is breathtaking. It was carved 10000 years ago and still just as impressive today, Out All Points East small group local tour guide made sure we visited it at a quiet time of the day - mid afternoon , so that the narrow gateway was not clogged with traffic. We could wander around and look at the devils and divas, and explore the carved gateway. The Terrace of the elephants and the maze has incredible carvings and then you can wander through the ruins of the Royal Palace and imagine what it was like all those years ago.

Quite worth the visit!! Beautiful historic ruins. Loved it, spent time wondering how they built it without machinery, so impressive. Our tour guide was great, it was a bit hot walking around but so glad we did it. Even took a group selfie in the temples 'center of the universe'.
What an amazing place. Well worth the visit. The memories will stay with me forever. I do agree that a good guide is essential so you get a better understanding of the place and the history.
Faces !. The number of faces carved into this temple are numerous. Everytime you turn around there is another amazing carved out face.

Beautiful spot. Might be Angkor Wat's little cousin, but I think I liked it more. Loved all the faces and got many great pics - some I can hopefully frame. So much to see, it's impossible to cover it all in one trip. Unfortunately I'll not be there again, but saw enough to make a huge impression and great memories.

Amazing Art. After several hundred years, it is amazing how ancient people have created such beauty and with durability
Bayon is one of my favorites for the secret smile of the giant Buddha faces, each one of them is also grinning very differently.
Nothing to say but amazing

Must visit. Smaller than Angkor Wat still really worth a visit. Beautiful work amazing history.
Still really busy with tourist visiting.
Ensure you have a great guide it makes all the difference.

Angkor Wats little cousin!. The massive gates are the introduction to Angor Wat's lesser known neighbour The approach bridge is impressive with the tug of war between gods and demons. The huge face carved in stone are the most memorable.The main part is the Bayon with it's mile of bas reliefs incorporating over 11,00 figures Save it for the second day of your 3 Day pass.
A great follow up to What.... Different architecture to What and 'smaller' in terms of walking around. ... amazing faces remain into the 'turrets'... great to see.

Beautiful Faces. This was the second of the temples that I visited. A few more people here, but the chance for some amazing photos. There are so many different faces. Its mind blowing at how old they are and how perfect they still are. Worth a look
quite crowded. tried to get photos without other tourists in them but couldn't manage. very crowded and quite overrated

Some prefer The Bayon ti Angkor Vat. WE loved both of them !. It's necessary to go there very early in the morning, and begin by the upper terrace, when there are very few people. If crowdy, you may not enjoy it !

Cool temple structures. Most peoples obvious reason for travel to Siem Reap is Angor Watt, and other temples such as Angkor Thom. The temples are magnificent, only letdown are the sheer amount of tourists visiting, making it rather crowdy. However worth a visit, and should be on every "before I die" to do list.

Just the walls left. The main attraction is the entrance, and the terraces... a guide is a must to understand why this is important. Also if you don't like walking in the sweltering heat, get a tuktuk around... it's 3 km on each side of a square structure... so it's very big.
amazing place to visit. another highlight of a trip to angkor worth a visit if you get time while seeing the highlights of the site
aka Bayon. It can be circled in a few minutes. It was fun to go in and out of the labyrinths. You can see the famous face on a couple of turrets in the temple.

South Gate of Angkor Thom. The Southern Gate was very impressive what with all the stone statues lining the entrance causeway. On one side are statues of Guardian Guards while on the other side are statues of Demon Gods.

Visit early. This (and Angkor Wat) seems to be first on the itineraries of the tour buses. Come 8:00am, they've arrived with hundreds of people.
Get there early, enjoy the morning light, and the peace anbd quiet of this amazing place.

Massive and amazing. The gates to this lovely city are just outstanding. My guide let me get out of the car and walk through the gates which was a little scary with the traffic, but well worth it. The whole area is filled with wonderful history and I can't wait to go back for a longer period of time.
You'll be amazed by the scale. The sheer number of histoic sites in Angkor Thom is mind-blowing. I especially enjoyed the Terrace of the Leper King, with layer upon layer of intricate carvings.
Angkor Thom. Like Angkor Wat or Rolius group with a beautiful range of tempels. Don't miss out on Baphuon also. Go early ,visit first Bayon and Baphuon and than to Angkor Wat.

Same but not the same. You would think that because you have seen angkor wat you've seen 'em all but actually each of these ruins have their own "aura" so it's still worth a trip to this place. Nice photo ops. (Went Jan 2014)

Wonderful Experience. This large collection of temples are breathtaking to behold and take a good while to navigate! The spectacle of them is truly breathtaking especially the Bayon with the 4 faced pillars! A must see!

Stunning. My wife and I hired a guide through our hotel to better learn about the history and culture of this ancient capital city at Angkor Archaeological Park. We are so glad we made the trip to Cambodia to visit this UNESCO World Heritage Site. The guide gave us a better understanding of the historical significance of Angkor Thom. We came back a second day to wander around the city and its temples and terraces.

I think better than Angkor Wat. While Angkor Wat has a stunning vista Angkor Thom is a wonderful walk through various types of temples with differing styles. I could walk around here for days enjoying the experience. Amazing.
SIEM REAP beauty. With boyon temple and elephant terrace it is amazing place for visiting .. Also Baphuon Temple was very very nice and not so much overcrowded.
Amazing temple. We visited 3 temples in the area and Angkor Thom was one of them.We enjoyed it very much and the scenery is even better than what I expected.
A Gem!. Images similar to those used at he end of Apocalypse Now (for those of you of a certain age). The scope and serenity are powerful

Four faces. Best to visit early as the sun will cast a shadow downwards on the faces midday. Early or late afternoon would be great. Monkeys abound and make sure your pack has no exposed food. Steep climb up to the tower.

You could spend day after day exploring Angkor Thom. In and out of the ruins. Up and down the stairs.. It is such a vast place that even though we were there in high season we could avoid the crowds. If it was raining the steps could be a problem

Largest city in the world. This place once was the largest city in the world, and get that sense of greatness when you cross those gigantic doors. A must, even if it is very difficult to figure out how big and swarming with people and life at heights of the city times.

One of my personal seven wonders of the world. My friend and I have just recently returned from a 3 week tour of South-East Asia covering several parts of Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand and without a doubt Angkor Thom made the entire tour for us both. One of my personal seven wonders of the world, a place I could visit again and again as it captures you entirely.We spent just 1 day at Angkor Thom, covering all of the temples including the Bayon Temple, the Baphuon Temple, Phimeanakas, Ta Phrom temple and the ever famous Angkor Wat. For those of you interested in the history of Cambodia and King Jayavarman VII (creator of Angkor Thom) I would highly recommend you pay additional for a private tour guide - ours Merlin was absolutely astounding, he was literally a walking encyclopaedia!You will also need to prepare for some form of transport inside as Angkor Thom covers a large area and I wouldn't recommend walking in the heat - taxis, tuk tuks and elephants are all available on the inside.Whilst it is possible to cover all of the temples in just one day, given the chance now I would have personally stayed in Siem Reap longer and perhaps covered just one of two of the temples each day. The architecture entices you completely! If you ever visit Cambodia do not miss out on such a phenomenal walk through history!
great architectural example. Great murals on the side walls of the monument and the stone sculpture at the temple. amazing complexity with the high aesthetically value.... must visit

A real surprise. Many a 'bucket list' would include Angkor What, but a visit to Angkor Thom should be a must. See it in the early part of the day to avoid the hot, steamy temperature and marvel at this ancient site. At the height of its time , the city had a population larger than London. The Temple is a marvel of architecture, carvings so clear as if done yesterday, and a frieze which tells the story of a religious battle. Marvel at the Leper's Terrace and the Elephant Terrace also. You can even take an elephant ride or just amble.

Love this place. Awesome place really enjoy to walk around to see different area even its too hot.but cambodian people said it the weather is ok compare summer its really hot march until may is to hot.november and december best time to go there.

Crowded but beautiful. We visited Angkor Thom during the summer and even though it was super crowded, this place is so spectacular. It is good to hire a guide that knows the time of day to go and the shortcuts in the temples. We would love to be back for a second visit.

There are Elephants. Like all the temples Angkor Thom gets really busy and very hot. Make sure you take a few extra dollars to feed the Elephants that are there every morning until 11am. You can also ride them got $20

Big old capital. Angkor Thom is an old ancient capital with several temples within. You need at least two hours to conquer all the temples in Thom. Please bring enough water to refill under hot weather. 5 stars for Angkor Thom.
views just go on. Part of the Angkor Wat complex, and quite easily think its the same building But no less interesting
Cool temple. It's a cool temple next to Bayon and Angkor. They were doing lots of construction so half of it was closed.

Vacation. Don't overpass this as it is as good or better than Angkor Wat.We had a very good guide who pointed out the carvings and explained the country history and symbolism on the walls.Be ready for some rocky terrain and bring plenty of water. Frank Cimino
Impressive. Another impressive part of Angkor! The whole site is magnificent and i'd recommend it to everyone!!! You can't really become bored of it either, so much to see.

Just Magic.. You stand and wonder atop of the monument. How did they build this so long ago from what they had. Place is so flat and the mountains where stones came from are so far away. How many artisans worked on the carvings?

Second Stoop!. Visit Angkor Thom after you visited Angkor Wat prior to more tourists arrived. Start from Bayon, slowly proceed to the end of Terrace of the Elephants. Angkor Thom consists of Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Royal Palace area, Terrace of the Leper King Preah Palilay, Tep Pranam.If you have time and the energy, walk across the street to visit North and South Kleang, Prasats Suor Prat, and Preay Pithu Group. Again, wear good hiking boots as there are many steps to climb. Especially, the temples within Bayon and Phimeanakas.

World's largest city in the 12th Century!. Do yourself a favor and make sure you hire a guide for the temples of Siem Reap - you won't be disappointed. Our guide made our tour of this majestic site - with its carved heads and laterite city wall (which you can walk along!) - so much more rich and meaningful. He was able to provide rich history and insight into the people who inhabited this area so long ago. Without him, it would have been simply marveling at cool remains. I feel so much more connected to the temples because he was there to explain everything to us.

Must see!. I was shocked the food in Angkor Thom was a good price as were the gifts at the gift shops. The site is surprisingly open and no restrictive and you can freely explore where ever you like. Very fun to explore in shoulder or off season.

Amazing place. One of the top three temples in the Angkor park. You need an entry pass and you can get a multi day one for $40. Allow time to do this as you have an id photo taken.The temple itself is fantastic. Worth taking the time to read up about it before you go as you will understand more about the history and splendour. If you can, go with a tour guide, you will learn so much more and avoid some of the crowds.A true spectacle and definitely a 'must see' when you come to Cambodia. There are many street vendors and children selling postcards and souvenir stuff. Cambodia is a poor country and although the children do pester, a firm but polite 'no thanks' does work. They are trying to earn a living and you have to applaud them for that. They are happy!This is one of the most magical places in the world and I feel honoured to have had the chance to see it. Check out the reviews on Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom.

Quite an average!. I'm not a huge fan of temples so this wasn't that interesting. Maybe I would be more interested if I saw the movies of Tomb Raider. A lots of tourists, but not as much as in Angkor Wat. A man tries to sell guide books saying "just one one dollar". So he means 11 dollars, not 1 as I thought :-D

Atrractive contributions by the rulers.. The intermingling of Hinduism and Buddhism is so clearly indicated in the ruins of the Angkor Thom. There is also the indication of intolerance of the religious sects towards each other by the defacing of the statues. The belief of hidden treasures being buried has also resulted in several statues being unfortunately removed.

So interesting. ankor Thom is younger than ankor watt but very intersting and certainly worth a visit Perhaps slightly less tourists than ankor watt but one must see them both and the jungle temples which I actually preferred .

a Must see Famous Spot. My favorite temple so far! I visited Angkor Thom on a Sunny day last February with 6 more guys. We've been doing a bike tour of 6 hours and the experience was great. We first start with the most famous one, Angkor Watt, then Angkor Thom and after lunch, the rest. All faces carved on the stone had been one of the most amazing places I've ever seen. No words to describe them!

Hit by history!. When in Siem Reap, you must do the various Angkor temples. On a guided tour, we visited Angkor Thom as the first of the various temples within the Angkor. It really does make you question history, previous civilisations and the realisation of your place in this world. Visited in March, so can be a little hot - and good footwear required. Great photo opportunities as well. Awe inspiring.

Angkor Thom Complex. With Bayon, Baphuon and Phimeanakas in the complex this capital and great city to the Khmer Empire is stunning. Go in through all Gates but do not miss the East and South Gate. Tranquil and Spiritual in many respects.

Amazing.. put this on your bucket list!. We went here first and climbed all around looking at all the faces carved into the rock which were amazing. Our guide was excellent and really went into detail without boring you. There I believe is a total of 8 faces carved in rock..at one point you can see five of them.. a must see, it truly is amazing.

Just okay. Unlike Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom was a bit in rubble. Probably recontructing. However there were some parts of the temple that smell of pee. Please don't pee on those places. These are majestic sites and heritages of Cambodia and they deserve utmost respect.

Great Place to wander around. Actually preferred this over Angkor Wat. Open spaces and lots to see and take pictures. My wife and I wanderred around for hours and barely saw anyone. But we were early after Angkor Wat in April so maybe that is why there were so few people.
incredible Siem Reap. this is a temple not to be missed in Siem Reap - it is spectacular as are the others in the region -- enjoy, enjoy
Yet another Cambodia Wonder. This was one of four temples we visited in our one day of touring. I wish we had a half day at least at each one, and this one was no exception. Truly visually stunning.

They couldn't do this today!. The scale of the place is mind boggling and seriously impressive
Again it is near the other monuments and so worth a visit.
The carving on all the temples was amazing.. We saw so many interesting temples in all different stages of repair. Some had been left to show how they were discovered.
Excellent architecture. Majestic temple complex. Big faces on temple sides though roughened up due to weathering give a glimpse of the architecture marvel of 8th century kings.

Magnificent. The architecture wonder. To watch sunset or sunrise you need to get there at least 1hr before the sun set or sun rise in Oder to secure your spot as there is a limit of how many people they allow to go up.

Huge complex. This is a very large complex with many, many temples inside the 9 square kilometer city. Angkor Thom means "Great City" and it definitely qualifies. With the large man made moat surrounding the city and the long, spectacular entrance bridge, it is easy to imagine the elegant processions that made there way into the city. There were monkeys wandering throughout the city and we saw a procession of elephants available for rides. These helped to enhance our imagination as to what might have been. It is said that as many as a million people may have lived inside these walls making Angkor Thom the largest city in the world during its time.

Unbelieveable. As you cross the bridge to Angkor Thom, you are immersed in ancient ruins with monkeys running around and elephants carrying their passengers for a ridden tour. It is almost surreal. The carvings on the stones are very interesting and access is relatively easy even though there are some steep steps. Make sure you allocate times to truly explore this wonderful site.
Impressive. One of the must see temples! Once you visit then do an Internet search to see what archeologists believe the complex looked like in its original state.

Good attraction. Visited this place on July 2011. This is one among the main temples that the tour normally bring the tourist in Siem Reap. I did admire the beautiful stones carvings that line-up along the way to the entrance of this temple. I was amazed also of the hundred years old trees that still alive rooted on the rocks that bulit this temple. According to our tour guide, this is the place where Lara Croft had shoot a scene in the movie Tomb Raider. Can recommend.

Beautiful. Angkor Thom is called "Great City" and encloses all other temples like Bayon, Baphuon, Ta Phrom, etc. So, the start of our visit was entering its beautiful south gate. The gate is beautifully carved with the face towers and the "angels" and "demons" that lines up as its bridge. It is a busy area though as it also allows access to cars, tuk-tuks and buses. So, care is needed when taking pictures of the south gate.

An amazing experience!. Ankor Thom means Big City and boy is it huge! You must walk the ancient grounds to have the feel of the enormity and the ancient grandure of its time. A good guide is a must to get the full experience of the tour. If you just view it without understanding the details that went into building Ankor Thom you will missing out.

Beautiful!. Angkor Thom is so completely different to Angkor wat in that is more of a ruin. But that makes it even more interesting strangely enough. The temple seems to be engulfed by huge trees that burrows it's roots deep into the massive walls of the temple. A very interesting site to see!

For Those who love to see Temples (Buddhist). Just a few minutes away from Angkor Wat and you can use the TukTuk Cab to reach there. For those who appreciate temples, this is just fine. Else, nothing more except for long walks. Better pay for the elephant ride around the temple to make it an experience.

A must see monument. Surrounded by a moat like most of the places you will see - this site is accessible by a small bridge which has the devas and asuras on each sides of the bridge. Must have a good guide to tell you all about it. Ask for Happy Angkor Wat tours and Mr. Veasna - the tour guide.
Angkor Thom. The entry to Angkor Thom is spectacular with a bridge lined with demons and gods. Inside is also super interesting. Recommend

South Gate is Beautiful. The South Gate is the favorite entry point to Angkor Thom, Angkor Thom contains five temples in the enclosed ancient capital. In the South Gate, we took an elephant ride for 20 USD each. Along the way you will see monkeys in the trees. Beautiful carvings in the gate

Incredible that these temples are still standing..a credit to Unesco and dedicated archaeologists.. Walking over the bridge , through the arch to Angkor Thom you can see the wonderful stone carvings .The towers on the temples and the carvings that depict the people and their daily life activities were explained to us by our guide Dalign from Angkor Happy tours. He explained details we would have missed without his knowledge . This tour was ended with cold drink and a tut tut ride back into town ..great day ...started at 5am ...pick up from hotel and sunrise at Angkor Wat .

Hot. Hot, crowded, touristy, templey,but i would still not have missed it for the world. Recommend going early or late afternoon. And ignore anyone that tries to start giving you a guided tour of the place unasked for. They expect payment at the end and jibber jabber all along until you send them away.

Amazing Angkor Thom. Although Angkor Wat was one of the best temple visits that have made I found Angkor Thom far more interesting. When you view the effect that the tree roots have had on the buildings you can see how they were constructed. How the volcanic rock was used as a stronger material for the foundations and the softer rock used as decoration. We think we know it all in our era, these people done it all by hand and elephant. Oh! the elephants used today have there own doctors and are pampered.
Beautiful . A very large ruin that is a must see. Be wary of cheeky monkeys after fruit from travelers. Bring water and sensible walking shoes.

A fantastic and interesting archeological site.. Along with Angkor Wat, this is the most interesting and beautiful of the many sites in the area. Though it was built a bit after Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom still has a fascination of its own which is well worth seeing. Spend a morning or afternoon here; it's worthwhile.
Well worth a visit. Just loved walking around these ancient places. Carvings & size incredible. Early morning a good time as you miss the avalanche from the bus tours. Bring good walking shoes.
Bucket List Place to visit. The cravings are so delicately beautiful. Make you wonder how it was done on block blocks of stone weighing over a ton.
Beautiful. Of all the temples, this is a wonderful place to visit. beautiful place with many towers. Show better than other temples.
Classic!!. Beautiful temple of this amazing culture. The main one and the most important one. Very easy to go and to walk around,
An incredible huge site and temple. We were fortunate to have a driver to take us to the entrance! There are two large entry ways lined with carved in stone gods and devils! Just amazing!!!!
In one word 'Enchantress'. If a beauty as beautiful as this welcomes Visitors into the World of Khmer Empire, just imagine what it would be to explore and be engulfed by the beauty from within.
Great Photo Place. Lovely place for shooting. Need to go at the right time to avoid crowds if you do not fancy people in your shoots. Best to go during meal times, morning or evening.
Another great site. This is as amazing as Angkor Wat. It is wonderful to explore. We had a guide which meant that everything was explained for us. We went in October so the weather was reasonable.
Carved out of the Jungle. Cool temple, a must see. The jungle had reclaimed a lot of this temple, but the government was working on restoration efforts when we visited.

Amazing Place. Angkor Thom and it's many sights are a must see for any world traveler. The poverty will remind you of Baja, California in the 60's and early 70's. The people are fantastic! The food is insanely good! The thing is, Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are the reasons to go to Cambodia. If you stay in Siem Reap you'll have to stay near pub street and the night market. It will be some of your most memorable moments you'll have in Asia.

Can't fail to be impressed. I entered the complex via the South Gate, which features a very impressive causeway lined with around 150 stone statues (gods on the left, demons on the right) leading up to an enormous stone archway. It all feels very "Indiana Jones". This temple is of course famous for its many carved stone faces - and quite imposing they are too. There are some superb photo opportunities on this site. Before you even enter the complex there are at least 2 very large buddhas on the perimeter. Sadly, this temple gets EXTREMELY busy with tourists, so try and get there as early as you can to avoid the crush. The Bayan is the best known centrepiece of this temple, with 54 towers and over 200 stone faces. Amazing. When you exit, you will walk past the Terrace of Elephants and the Terrace of Leper Kings. Be aware that elephant rides are offered as a means to approach the temple and look magnificent - but, my guide advised me to avoid using them as the elephants are apparently treated poorly and work very long hours. I took his advice.
A must go place in Siem Reap!. Magnificent !! Imagine how human could build such beautiful building. Both Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat are must visit places even you are not temples crazy people :)

Beautiful.. Words can't begin to describe, and none of my photos will do it justice. This is one of those things that needs to be seen with your own eyes. We did a Grasshopper pushbike tour and thoroughly enjoyed it as it covered a few different temples and riding the wall of one temple. If you get a good guide they'll explain the history of the temples which is amazing to hear - especially for an Aussie when we come from such a comparatively young country.

Best show case of Khmer Empire . The beautiful ancient capital of Angkor Thom, the city of the king. It is well preserve and we'll organize. However, do not get on an elephant as it take a short track and $20 is not worth the price at all.

Majestic gateways. The immensity of the complex combined with the intricate detailed scrolling and finishing of plaster work revealed a magical site. Adding the gate /entrances which are actively used by tourist and locals alike, takes one to another time . More than one visit is necessary to have a brief observation of this wonder.

One of the better temples. Personally I think Angkor Thom is better than Angkor Wat, much more impressive and a wider variety of sights. The trees growing around the temple make some great photos. Try not to get stuck behind a tour group, it gets very warm, very fast inside the temples and the tours take ages to make their way through!
Beautiful. It isn't so beautifl as Bayon or Angkor Wat. However, it is still wonderful. Each temple is diffrent and each are wort visiting.

Guidad tur. Beautiful tempel! We are so thankful that we had our fantastic guide, otherwise we´d never seen all the detaljs and know about their history. Our good and safe driver took us all day long between the tempels.I can really recommed both of them. If you are going there, you should go with them.Driver: mr Sarath, phone +855 70 636232 Pick up is free. Small tour: Ankor Wat + Ta Prohm Temle + Taprom 12 US dollarHe also have a lot of more tours, give him a call.Guide: mr Seanin Chean, English speakting tour guide with certification. Really good guide och easy to understund.Really help guide and driver.Took us to nice dinnerplace and stopped on market when we wanted a stop. I can really rekommend this two! Have a nice trip :)/Maria Åslin
Temples of Angkor Thom. Group of several temples built a century or two before Angkor Wat. Lots of walking but quite fascinating and well worth the effort.
Spectacular. This was my favourite of all the Angkor Temples. It was other worldly. The trees growing from the temples and the ruins all around them, it was just beautiful.

fantastic place to visit. this temple is another beautiful place to see in Siem Reap,it is quiet big so allow plenty of time for your visit, we did a tour and managed 3 temples in 1 day but we were exhausted when we were finished, but going on a tour is good they will drive you from one place to the next.

amazing complex. well worth visiting Ankgor Thom whilst not as 'repaired' as Angkor Wat this gives the temples here Bayon and Bauphon a different atmosphere. Bauphon was my favourite of all the temples visited.
highlight of our Siem Reap tour. Angkor THom is definitely the most amazing part of our visit. I can only recommend going there early in the morning and wonder around the forests around the temples.
Amazing. Lovely visit and a very interesting guide. Amazing place to walk through and well worth a visit for anyone.
Wonderful place to visit. Visited Angkor Thom as part of the whole Angkor Tour and was a great build up to the main temple. Should not be missed.

Should Go!. 7 ponders huh? Better visit here once in your life time. Its an old city, i presume. There are numerous structures dissipate around. Its exceptionally hot however. PS my BF said he doesn't see much contrasts from Angkhor Wat. By and by, i think they are the same as old khmer structures, yet the distinctive would be the engraved on the stone. That is the thing that intrigues me.

Great historical site. Beautiful temple with amazing artwork and interesting history. Every wall, surface, spire, and alcove tells a different story. It's amazing to consider the amount of work that went into building this - long before the industrial revolution.
Amazing. Great place, unic and beautiful. It was a pleasure for me to see this place. I spend there only 1 day but it was great. Don't miss it.

Magnificent galore!!. Another ruins of our magnificent and grand history. A must see for everyone. Better to hire a tuk tuk to visit this place. Temple pass is a must and a guide will provide better insight to its histiry
Just a short addition to the Angkor tour. Allow bout 1 hour to view this site.It is quieter than Angkor and just as beautiful and breathtakingNot as difficult a climb S Angkor!
A must see!!. Spectacular! Just take a bottle of water with you and plan on going in early.. try to avoid the tour buses ;)

Cool place. 7 wonders huh? Better visit here once in your life time. Its an old city, i guess. There are many buildings scatter around. Its very hot though. PS my BF said he doesn't see much differences from Angkhor Wat. Personally, i think they are the same as ancient khmer buildings, but the different would be the engraved on the stone. That's what interests me.

Yet another MUST SEE in Siem Reap. Best seen after Angkor Wat. The magnitude and preservation of Angkor Wat give a point of reference that is invaluable at Angkor Thom. What an incredible wonder to explore.

South Gate Entrance - Wow Factor. Temple with a lot of character, this one has a slight difference with moat and a bridge in order to get over to the temple itself. Its massive entrance and worth the visit.
A must.. Glad this was a part of our vist was great and our guide Sam made it so mch better with his knowledge.

Not the Angkor Wat temple but one of similar ilk.. Another amazing experience! Take your time to absorb the enormity of this site. An added experience and fun is to take the elephant ride to this location. About 15-20 minutes lumbering along on the back of one of theses majestic animals.
Loved it. I was so intrigued with this temple, I felt this ancient feel and was mesmerized with the old grey facade`s silhouette`s against the blue sky. I loved every moment.

Fabulously atmospheric!. We arrived by tuktuk from Angkor Wat - cost us £2 - takes about 10-15 mins. From the exterior you have no real idea of what you will see inside. You go through the gateway and follow a long pathway through jungle and come to the most amazingly huge site of temples. Many are not restored at all and have huge tumbled down areas and buildings overgrown with enormous trees. They look like a fantasy world. Far fewer people come to these temples and much of the time we were almost alone as we wandered round the stunningly carved temples. Many are huge and you feel wonder at the skills of the original builders. We chose to follow the arrows that pointed a way through the complex as you lose all sense of direction with the many high walls. It is quite magical.We experienced one huge PROBLEM!!!! we had not been warned by our driver [who waited for us at the gate] , nor could we see on the map of the temple area, that it is a square site, 2 kms square. It has a huge wall around the edge and a gate in the centre of each side - but noone warned us that the route with the arrows took us to a different exit! They look identical! It took over an hour to walk round the sides to the next gateway where our driver was.This is more interesting and stunning than Angkor Wat where everyone goes!
Lovely place to walk around to soak up the ancient atmosphere. The ancient heart of the original city was lovely to walk around seeing the original entry gates and bridges.
Nice. . We didn't get to climb Angkor Thom! We got here super early because we done sunrise at Ta Prohm instead of Angkor Wat. It was nice enough but not our fave. Still a must see.

Scale is mind-blowing. This is a whole city of temples and to do it justice you need at least 2 days, especially if you prefer to do your sightseeing in the cooler mornings. There is plenty of drinks for sale by the local vendors and your friendly tuk-tuk driver is always happy to recommend a restaurant for a rest over lunch.

A must see! . Definitely put this temple complex on your to do list. There are a few interesting sites to see within walking distance of each other. You can start from the Bayon temple, where the real interesting part is on the first floor and where you can see all the nice statues. From there you can walk up to the Baphuon Temple. (Climbing is only allowed if you are covered up and above 12 years old. ) After this you can walk up to the Royal Palace, a nice shady hike that also brings you through the ruined Preah Palilay Temple. From there you can walk to the Elephant terraces near the main road where the parking lot is with the buses in. A very enjoyable 1,5 hour walk with some part through shady bush.

A must see, don't miss these wonderful ruins. You can spend all day here. A must see when in Cambodia. You can spend all day here exploring the ruins and area surrounding. Everything is splendid and amazing. Don't rush through here or you will miss unbelievable things.

Just amazingly stunning. Amazing ancient architecture in one place. Like walking to the entirely different world. Would definitely be back again. Bring your cap/hat and water with you. Summer is pretty brutal in Siem Reap. Putting on sunscreen is highly recommended.
Ephesus of the Khmer. A great city that serves as reference of the Khmer culture, much like Ephesus is for the Roman Asia Minor.
It's ok. At this point I will say I have seen a couple of temples and this temple doesn't take my breathe away. However it is park of the Angkor Wat circuit.
Mysterious Temple. This is perhaps most mysterious temple in Siem Reap. Inner recesses of the temple evoke sense of timelessness and spirituality.

Majestic Angkor wat. It is the inner temple of Angkor wat and is included in the series of Angkor wat temples. It also gives a great areal view of some of the temples when you climb up the highest level of the inner temple.

Most Celebrated Temple in Siem Reap. Angkor Thom is the most fascinating and mysterious temple in Siem Reap. The four sided Royal faces belonging presumably to the erstwhile Hindu Ruler of Angkor or perhaps to Lord Buddha remain unsolved puzzle. Inner recesses of the temple impart unmistakable mysterious aura of deep spirituality.
Second best temple in Siem Reap!. Don't miss this temple if you loved Legends of the Hidden Temple! Seriously, this is the second best temple in Siem Reap.

Angkor simply breathtaking. Historian calls it a city. We name it a wonder. Exactly what we imagine about the core of Angkor complex: huge, artful and mysterious. We decided to visit Angkor Thom in the late afternoon to take sunset photo. My tour guides recommend to rent a gondola to get around the moat surrouding Angkor Thom and it did not depress us. This is also a good idea to avoid the too crowed Phnom Bakheng hill but we still could capture the whole Angkor reflecting from the water. Another advice is to cycle from the metropolis to Angkor Thom. Yes, biking on shady forest paths and beside huge temples on each corner of the four walls in Angkor Thom. With bike, you can go farer inside Angkor Thom than the usual walking paths other tourists go on. This is an easy way to get away from the crowds.

We loved this place. Angkor Thom is so completely different to Angkor Wat in that it is more of a ruin, but that makes it even more interesting strangely enough. Wandering around the temples you do need to be careful, making sure you have good walking shoes and here there are many steps to climb and they are quite steep.

Another surprise. This temple needs to be part of a tour of the other nearby temples to link the relationships and timing of the development and demise of the immediate area . A good guide is so important

Visit Ta Pro temple. Ankhor Thom is huge but this is another area that you shouldn't miss. The huge roots holding everything together are amazing. It is quite a walk in from where the shuttle bus drops you off. It rained while we were there but we were fine with umbrellas
Charming place. Actually, Angkor Thom is not a specific castel or temple, its the name of the vast area with many many sites, But worth seeing at least its entrance towers.

Incredible. WOW - I honestly could not pick my favourite temple within Angkor Wat, But All of the Angkor Thom area is so beautiful. You feel like you are being transported into another world...but I guess you kinda are! We biked through this area right after sunrise, just before it was too crowded - stunning!

Huge. Angkor Thom is huge so when u go there, always have a bottle of water ready to stay dehydrated.
The place itself is just pretty much like the temples of Angkor Wat. Amazing.
A must see with Angkor Wat. Went to Angkor Thom with our private driver in a comfortable car. Spoke very good English,. Went the same day after Angkor Wat. Perfect day!
Love going through the gates. Angkor Thomas is quite a large area, depicted here are the gates, which are amazing to go through, I felt like I was in tomb raider!
Disappointing. Although this was once a major large city, only the walls remain now. The interest lies in the temple sites within the walls, such as the Bayon temple.
Stunning!. A truly gob-smacking experience, I knew about Ankor Wat of course but this came as a complete surprise, fabulous!

ANGKOR THOM / SOUTH GATE ANGKOR. Nice place to take photo under the hot sun!
ANGKOR THOM / SOUTH GATE ANGKOR.
Our driver bring us at south gate and we walk around angkor thom.
The angkor is nice.

A Wonder of the World. The complex is huge and you can only look on in wonderment at the magnificence of the place. How they built it and then the carvings are so detailed and everywhere you look...just fantastic! Certainly a must see. Three day day pass for $40 but you could spend 3 weeks there!!!!!There is just so much to see .Unfortunately, like the Sphinx was damaged by Napoleon's soldiers using it for target practise, so too have the Khmer Rouge used the carved heads to fire at and the damage can been seen on those that remain. Many have been stolen, but many are being replaced and it will take a number of years for them to mellow and discolour like the originals. Just explore, but look also to places that are NOT the main tourist attractions as you will be amazed at what you can find. If you have a guide, then yes let him show you the normal stuff, but guide him also if you see somewhere that is less crowded. Just be mindful thought.......I did come across a snake in the grass so to speak that reared up not far from me, luckily it was non poisonous... but could have been!! It's a jungle out there!!!!!!!!

Can't Miss It!. Angkor Thom is as famous as Angkor Wat. You can't visit one without another. Go back in time and witness the way of Khmer life; ancient architect, and even Great Naga in front of the entrance. It's worth it!

Massive Temple, choose your gate.... It's all about the gates, lined with happy and unhappy spirits depicted by headless statues. Unfortunately missing heads is a recurring theme in all of the temples due to theft over the years. Find the 2 gates next to each other on the east side - 1 is the Victory gate, sadly the other is for the losers!!Keep an eye out for the Terrace Of The Elephants - a wall decorated in elaborate elephant designs.

Ride the elephants, combe the monkeys out of your hair.... My personal favorite - on a vacation that saw me suffer 'Temple Overload' Plus finally, some monkeys! This is the stuff we see in the travel brochures and on TV documentaries. Putting aside Angkor Wat, this is the only other temple you need to visit if you are on a tight schedule. It has it all, elephants, monkeys, beggars and old buildings. Highly recommended. Visit anytime of the day, as there is plenty of shade here.
Brillaint location to visit. really good temple to explore. Full of history and very moving. I would definitely return. get a guide or read up on the history for the best experiance

Another amazing place. Angkor Thom is the whole area including the Bayon Temple, the Terrace of the Leper King and the Terrace of Elephants. You could spend all day just at this one site but if, like us, your time is limited, then get a good private guide to show you around. You'd struggle to walk the lot in the heat anyway as the site is 3 km by 3 km.

Angkor Thom - The Jungle Temple. Angkor Thom is a temple shadowed in its magnificence only by Angkor Wat. It is the site of the movie Tomb Raider starring Angelina Jolie. The temple seems to be engulfed by huge trees that burrows its roots deep into the massive walls of the temple, a very interesting site to see.
What an entrance. The entrance looks like a gate to heaven. It looks so narrow, but it is much larger when you are close to it.

Glory of Jayavarman. Built by king Jayavarman VII, this temple is a must see in your list. It has 216 faces that faced into 4 directions. Many scholars said it was representations of king Jayavarman himself, the others said it was belong to Buddha. This temple is more likely to gets crowded in late morning and afternoon, so prepare yourself.Angkor Thom was an amazing spot to take pictures with, so don't forget to snap pictures and bring water with you.

Able to climb high up.. This temple has a unique point in that you can climb up and feel the majestic atmosphere.Unfortunately for us, on the day we went it was too cloudy for us to be able to see the sunset.
It's outdoor. This would be the only attraction that I would go to visit if I am in Siem Reap....be sure to have a guide with you to do this site. It was a historic site for sure.

Especially the gates are interesting. Angkor Thom is the old capitol. It comprises many interesting sites, even the Bayon temple is inside the Angkor Thom area. Other interesting places include the Royal Palace, the Terrace of the Elephants and a couple of other temples.

A CITY OF ANGKOR. Angkor thom is quite big to walk. But well worth the tiredness. It was amazing and contained many amazing temple. One of them, Bayon is my favorite. North and south gates with the faces of buddha were terrific

Amazing! Don't miss out!. This place is huuuge! Really lovely place to imagine how it was living here back in the days. Was not very crowded when we were there just after lunchtime. Paid (an overprice) $30 for a tuk-tuk from sunrise to sunset and had time to see the following (with time left over, so if you're on a budget one day is enough and you don't have to rush to be able to see all of this): angkor wat (sunrise and the entire temple), banteay kdei, sras srang, pre rup, ta prom, ta keo, chau say thevoda, thommanom, preah khan, angkor thom, bayon and phnom bakheng (sunset, more of a view point). Doing it in that order also seemed like a smart plan as we were almost all alone everywhere (except sunrise and sunset and some people at ta prom). So don't listen to "you can't do it in one day", at least not if you are young and healthy and can climb the stairs quite easily. Don't forget to bring clothes that cover your knees and shoulders when walking in some part of the temples. I advise you to bring it though and take it off in between in order not to faint because of overheating...
Another amazing temple. this temple can get a little crowded so be flexible with planning your time to visit. like all of Angkor its amazing

Still a great precinct. This was our second visit and were not disappointed. Its vast 9 square km area holds several temples and much of the walls are still intact and the South gate needs help before it crumbles further. It is pleasing to see some completed restorations of heads on the bridge over the moat.

Wonderful!. Angkor Thom is the walled town containing numerous temples in the middle of the archeological park, just north of Angkor Wat. The four gates are impressive and each is approached by a bridge with devatas and demons holding the huge nagas, snakes. These are in various states of decay and reconstruction. The Bayon is right in the centre. There are eating places and many tourist shops in the city.
Outstanding Temple. This is one of the highlights of the Angkor Wat Experience. Many folks prefer this over the Angkor Wat Temples.

Temple with moat, stunning!. Another temple with a lot of character. This one is set apart by a moat and a bridge in order to get over to the temple itself. This has the iconic men pulling on a rope, on bilateral sides framing the temple entrance beautifully.Note1: Take a bike! They're $1usd and most come with locks, not that you really need them. Some routes/circuits are 10-12km, but you obviously don't have to follow the recommended three day tours. Biking allowed us to observe daily life in the rural areas outside the temples as well as Siem Reap as a whole.Note 2: do not go ticketless! They will fine you. Grab tickets en route to the temple roads, on your right approx. 3km before arriving at a fork in the road. Angkor is to the left of the fork. Note 3: Money is changed in USD, Cambodia uses the reil as change, like cents. Note4: snack stands and beverages available near Angkor Wat - restaurants too, and vendors line up near other temples. Prices slightly elevated but it's not ridiculous inflation.

Great temple smothered with trees. The. Very peaceful. Compact and easy to negotiate. If you keep walking through the other side has a hidden gate. Some wee kids are selling fridge magnets for very cheap! If you need fridge magnets then this is the place to buy. We do not so did not. Has some lovely huge faces on the gate.

Great Place to Visit. Really enjoyed the South Gate entrance. My friends actually took an elephant in and to the temple it self which was a lot of fun. I just took photos and watched and then walked to our tour guides van and met them at the end. So much to see here, great photos. Make sure to stop here on the way
inspiring. The traffic level wasn't too horrible when we went. The diverse art and nature combined are inspirational.

Best place to visit after Angkor Wat. Most of the temples are in ruins ... but international help is on way to conserve the heritage sites ... a must visit to the temples in the mornings..... Tomb Raider starring Angelina Jolie was shot here.

Wow. Wow and wow. What an awesome experience. Plan to purchase the three day pass for the Angkor Wat site. You will need it. We spanned it over 5 days with a rest day in between. Wow!! Each site just added to the magnificence. A must fir when you visit Cambodia.
Worth the stop.. The least impressive of the temples we saw but still worth it for the victory gate and just the shear size of it.
