It is impossible not to think how was life here centuries ago and from where did the builders/slaves get all these massive stones which they have used to build a complex like this which survived the elements of nature for so many centuries. One stood astonished in front of all these temples and wished that you could just have a glimpse of the royal monarchy who lived here. If you are not afraid of heights, make time to climb all the steps. Just be careful because the steps are very narrow and steep. Wear good walking shoes. Remember your sunhat and water, because the tropical sun and heat can get extremely hot. We had a wonderful day and recommend this attraction to all tourists.
Day one of temples. Amazing to see, very busy when we got there so had to await a good time for photos , the guide was excellent and really added to the visits
Day trip. Another of the great temples that is a must see when visiting seam reap. Best done in the morning before crowds and heat.

Amazing. We were there in May and it was uncomfortably hot. But well worth it. The walkways are uneven and make it a bit uncomfortable to walk around. There are a lot of steps everywhere. Highly recommended taking water and snacks to help keep up the energy . Not recommend for young children ( under 7) . It was very crowded with other tourists and was difficult to get around . But, with all that it was simply amazing!
nice jungle experience. great to see how the jungle grew over the temples. great for kids. no negative experiences at all. for the children a highlight
Amazing. Its a must see, was hot but great , like Cambodia itself you have to see it, go early to beat some of the heat & the crowds.
Iconic Angkor temple. The scale is simply massive with massive stone walls and deep moats. There are many peaceful locations where you can get away from the crowds. Definitely worth a visit.

A must-see. Along with Angkor Wat, this is one of the must-see places in the world, let alone in Cambodia. The Bayon and the gates of Angkor Thom certainly produces some of the most recognisable images among ancient ruins. The place is big and contains a number of sites worth looking at, so give yourself plenty of time when visiting. I visited in April, and be warned, it is hot at that time of the year, so take plenty of water. However, despite it being a must-see, I'm not giving it a top rate. This is because, like Angkor Wat, for a site of such international importance and one of the major tourist attractions in the world, the place is poorly managed. It is a dismay to see ramshackle shacks selling tacky goods within the compound, and to have children constantly pestering you to buy things at inflated prices. It detracts from the experience. Those who manage this place should at least give the visitors a proper place to eat and rest (at least they built one outside Angkor Wat) instead of shacks, with good souvenir shops and properly licensed vendors.

Dont Miss. Lovely temple with more carvings than most of the other areas. In good condition considering the temples age. Book a full days taxi tour from the airport but dont get ripped off by the added 'options' the drivers try and sneak in!

Visit To Angkor Thom. Another of the Temples visited by my wife, daughter Emma and her boyfriend Karl and I. It soon became very clear during our visit, that despite the main Temples of the area, that there are something like over 300 temples in the Siem Reap area alone. Another thing that became very clear was despite not having anywhere near as much as there Western counterparts the local people are very proud of their heritage, their country despite the awful events of the late 70's and 80's.We found Angkor Thom to be another very interesting Temple with plenty to see and learn about.Another must see when in Cambodia for me.
The Amazing Angkor Thom. To see this is to believe it! Watch the National Geographic special before viewing this to truly appreciate the size and magnitude of what this was before nature took over.

Still a great place - if you avoid the crowds.. Angkor Thom - the very name conjures up images of a glorious Khmer past. This place holds some beautifully serene and peaceful places to wander if you plan your time well.The south (main) gate is generally always busy, so just keep going and visit the lesser visited West Gate and Spirit Gate (300m south of the Victory Gate).For something completely different, walk the wall from the Spirit Gate back around to the main South Gate. Interesting, seldom visited ruin at the SE corner of the wall. There's actually one at each corner, but the SE is the best preserved. Great walk late afternoon.Preah Phithu is best early morning, as is the Phimeanakas, Terraces,Palace area and Preah Palliay (check a good map).Suor Prat towers and Kleang's best late afternoon, as is the Bayon. Nth Gate great for photography around 4pm onwards.
Love this temple. No matter how many temples you visit in Siem Reap your mind is continually blown away by the history, beauty and magnificence of everything. Angkor Thom is one of my favourites.
Amazing temple !!!. Just only one and haft hour to visit this Golden temple when early morning with sunrise tour . Temperature very comfortable and sound of bird it is so great .

Angkor Thom - an amazing place. We spent some hours here and really enjoyed it although we had already been to several other temple places in the area and was quite saturated with impressions.We really think Angkor Thom deserves several visits if you want to see most of it.Well, most visitors just want to see all main places, so a special interest might be needed for those who want to spend days instead of hours here.A good idea is to have a book about the places and spend some time reading before or during the visits.

Another fabulous temple in Siem Reap. Nothing to dislike. Before I went to Siem Reap I thought that Angkor Wat was the main reason to travel there but soon found out that the entire area is full of gorgeous temples, in varying states of disrepair-yes, but there is work going on to prevent further disintegration. A must-see.

Magical. Angkor Thom is one of the big three temples. Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm being the other two.We visited during the Cambodian New Year celebrations and it did mean that Angkor Thom was turned into a bit of a circus so best to avoid. New Year happens in early April so do check.Archaeologically, Thom is the most important of the temples and it is vast. Time is needed to take in the wonder of this place.A pass is required prior to entry. A taxi or Tuck Tuck will take you.A real must see.
A large complex. I enjoyed the entrance to Angkor Thom, with the naga and the gods and demons flanking the bridge across. The area itself is vast with lots to see.

Yes, jungle and buildings go together. Guess it is obvious. If you go to Angkor Wat you must visit this one. It is as impressive as the rest of the sites around the place. Go around lunch time (is true for most places) as the tour groups are having lunch (I got many pictures with only my family on it!)
Outstanding. I think this is better than Angkor Watt.walking shoes as the steps are very steep and a lot more than Angkor Watt......a must to see but start early

Closed by walls and time. Angkor Thom, the “Great City” was the last capital of the Khmer empire.If you just reading about it, or looking at it on the map, you can’t realise how vast is this area. When you read the details, the 12 km wall surrounding it, you easily can think, -so what? The Chinese Great Wall is longer. - You have to go there, and have your own experience to be able to really appreciate it.We spent the whole afternoon strolling around, exploring, and adoring the various temples.

Fantastic. Our first temple of this complex and it was very special - the worlds largest city in the 12th century and the stone faces are truly special. The Bayon temple at its center has 216 enigmatic smiling stone faces and the adjacent terrace of the elephants also merits a look. We visited at about 10am before going onto Ankor Wat. Timings were great.

Feel the past. I like the old city very much. Even though we visited it during preparations for new year celebrations - which meant a lot of people working in the Angkor Thom, but still fascinating with the faces on the towers at the city gates, ruins with vast displays of bas-relief depicting the various gods, goddesses, and other-worldly beings from the mythological stories and epic poems ...

Amazing!. What a privilege to be able to view this wonderful temple. Truly a place to marvel. Lots of climbing and as we were visiting in April very hot so come early and bring plenty of water. A must see when visiting this temple complex.

One man's vanity. It was a great introduction to an otherwise, amazing wonder. However, the king's face Jeya something was plastered everywhere, ie the four faced facades/carvings which made it much of a grand self indulgent gesture of his vanity. But I suppose during his time, that was his way of putting his stamp on it. So in some twisted way, we owe him for leaving a grand legacy for the Cambodians, which eventually garnered a UNESCO recognition. So, umm, well done?
Worth the visit. I actually preferred this to Angkor Wat but that is personal. The whole visit was a great day. Soak up the atmosphere
Lovely, everything I ever imagined.. I loved the way the jungle was taking over the ruins, and the pride the people of Cambodia have in restoring the temples.

Remnants of an Empire. Angkor Thom is the last and most enduring capital of the Khmer empire. Established on the 12th century by Mahayan Buddhist King Jayavarman VII. One inscription on the wall inside refers to Jayavarman as the groom and the city as his bride. Angkor Thom is special because of its unique entrance where on the right you can see the demons behind the naga serpent and on the left the gods churning the ocean of milk in order to get the potion of imortality (yes, you can learn a lot and make it so much more interesting if you get a guide...) HYDRATE, HYDRATE, HYDRATE!

Great City. A Great City as it is known for, so incredibly beautiful even though the ruins can be seen everywhere. Photo shoot is recommended here.Do bring along your hat/shawl/hand fan as the heat is unbearable for some people. Highly recommended.
Stunning Temples!. Stunning temples everywhere you turn! It was really amazing to walk around the grounds and see the ruins. We also loved taking a float along Tonle Sap!

Another Excellent Stop in Siem Reap. Not like its big brother "Angkor Wat" so majestic and extensive, this one has enough magic to (especially after midday) for some of the greatest shots you may get on your vacation. Get properly hydrated, and bring some cool clothes.
Loved this Temple. Each Temple so different and intricate with libraries all over the area too… Many well preserved after almost 1000 years… Don't miss it...
Visit the ruins of Angkor Tom. Well worth the visit, it sets the scene for what you may expect when visit Angkor Wat. Can get very busy there with the crowds.

A series of ancient areas. There are several distinct areas to this place ... and each has something special to offer. Allow several hours to see it all and then relax in the main restaurant area where you can have a delicious meal and drink.

The place to see.. Must make an effort to see it at sunrise. Very peaceful but you will need to fight the other hundreds of tourists fighting for best photo opportunity. Went with Happy Angkor Tour - Private car with tour guide "Mr Em". Fantastic person!
Hot Thom!. A hot day, same as Bayon. Could have seen it all in a shorter time without the standing and waiting for many religious stories.

A trace of the past. I didn't expect that much until I got there. Such a wonderful woneder. Vietnamese shouldn't skip it in your traveling destinations. So close to Vietnam & so so cheap for a trip to Siem Riep.

a good place to relax. there are many corner in angkor thom if you like to see the original how it was build. our tour guide took us around and shown us a small spot in many places to see. it was great
Different to Angkor watt and well with visiting. Visibly different construction when compared to Angkor wat and well worth seeing. Much smaller but no less impressive.

the most interesting in siem reap. first you could pay $20 per person for a 15 minutes elephant ride to go around the temple once. the rock carvings had more stories to tell than other temples. interesting photo opportunities. certainly my favorite one in siem reap.

Fascinating all that space and ancient stones. Such big space. Dose temples and that lonely silence.
The carved stones in the colors , all is magnificent and magic

Well worth a day trip (or 2)!. Taking a day trip to Angkor in Siem Reap is well worth your time. Visit here to see a detailed review of this destination - http://BelovedAtmosphere.com/Angkor-Thom-Cambodia. Not only are the temples massive and intricately crafted, but each is unique. I highly recommend hiring a local guide to help you navigate Angkor, since they know the landscape, and can best decide how to escort you through the park. It can be extremely busy at times, so a good guide will help you avoid the crowds by taking you to each temple during "low" times of traffic. Furthermore, if you want a genuine feel for the landmarks and stories related to each temple, a guide is your best bet. Angkor Thom has a very cool story. Interestingly, we saw the most saffron-robed Buddhist monks while touring this wat.
Fascinating. The story and history are fascinating and you will keep asking yourself how did they build it - the detailed carvings are amazing

BEAUTIFUL!. I disliked when people call it "The Angelina Jolie temple" but besides that that is the temple in which Tom Rider was filmed, I learned that She does helps a lot in the country and with the temples.It is a FANTASTIC sight with a beautiful architecture and photographs opportunities in every corner.

Go straight after sunrise to avoid the tours. We came here just after watching sunrise at Angkor Wat and it was almost empty. Lonely Planet advises this is the best time to visit temples because the coach load of Chinese tourists go back to their hotels after sunrise to have their breakfasts before returning.Towards the end of our visit of this temple, it started to get very busy!

Excellent. All the temples in Siem Reap are worth seeing. Have been twice to Siem Reap and fortunately, my guide Kamsan, knew where to take me each time. Visiting the temples of Siem Reap is an experience not soon forgotten.

The most famous temple. Though lots of tourists make their way to the temple, there are not much of them inside climbing through endless corridors and stairs. It is easy to get lost in huge building. Pay more attention to the walls - they are incredibly beautiful crafted.

So much to see. My wife and I visited this site and loved it. You must have good shoes, plenty of water and air vented clothes. When you get into the ruins there is no air current, hot sun and climbing. So you will sweat and be very hot. But go - don't miss it. It's a small price to see possibly one of the oldest ruins and get a guide to explain what you are looking at. A must - I was hot and sweaty for 4hrs but went back to the hotel for a cold shower, and I had wonderful memories & great pictures of the day. Totally recommended.
Amazing trees. More cool are as you have a lot of tree shades..amazing trees - ruins reclaim by nature. Somehow during my visit there is a few places closed for conservation.
Amazing. We took a Gondola ride at the end of our first day around the moat for the sunset. It was so peaceful on the river and the sunset was stunning too. It rounded off our day perfectly.
The entrance is really neat. I loved the entrance gate, and there were monkeys playing on the side of the road. The temples we beautiful but after Angkor Wat, it wasn't quite as exciting.

Ancient Royal Palace. Ancient Palace from the Hindu/Buddhist eras in Cambodia. Probably the best place to start for the day as Angkor Wat tends to be overcrowded in the mornings. Plenty to see here. It's a large complex with plenty to see and great pics to be had. Water, sunscreen, good shoes (not sandals), and a hat are key. Be sure the camera is handy too. The site entails more than one temple in the same area, so be ready for some walking and climbing. As is the case with many other temples, not wheelchair or stroller accessible, and there are areas/temples where small children are not allowed due to the steep climb.

Essential addition to an Angkor Wat visit. Angkor Thom is not a single temple but an old city area with several temples of slightly different styles and character. The same ticket as for Angkor Wat is needed to get access to Angkor Thom. Allow a few hours for Angkor Thom.
Exploring this area is a real blast. What a great area to explore. You definitely benefit from having a guide here, to hear all the information and to show you the highlights.

A Truly Impressve Ancient City. This is an enormous site surrounded by a moat and 8 metre walls, each side of which is approximately 2miles (3km) long! We approached from the south along an impressive causeway flanked by numerous large stone figures of gods on one side and demons on the other. The south gate itself has huge stone faces looking out in each of the 4 main directions. Once inside, we found it hard not to be in awe of the skills and achievements of the people who built the city and the attention to detail in the stonework. There is too much to go into here, but the whole site is amazing and equally as impressive as Angkor Wat. A must if visiting Siem Reap.

The mixture of hinduism and buddhism. Still beautiful and stunning. The 4 faces of Buddha follow you every step walking around. The faces can be scary but sometimes can be very kind. I just love walking around looking at the faces. The same as Angkor Wat, it is now under the risk of collapsing. Please go while it is still ok.

Very interesting. We were lucky enough to have a knowledgeable personal tour guide for the two of us. This made the tour more interesting as we got a lot of background historical information about the ruins.

The complex of temples.. We were wecome by the balustrade of Samudramanthan and the moat around the temple complex.We entered the gate with the Buddha heads. My camera just went clicking the various facades and details. Closing on the Angkor Thom complex, the modalities of how it was constructed were evident through demos.Nearing the temple, the detailed bass relief on the walls had lots stories to tell. They should put barricades to restrict people away beyond the pillars so that one could see the detailing without obstruction of a onlooker.Inside the complex with so many heads in different position, it was a feast for visitors to record themselves in different postures, positions, with Apsaras and what not.The palm trees behind themselves were photogenic.There were many areas one could pose for a photo and I could catch models posing freely for the onlooker.There was no count of how many hours passed by but our guide had the duty to show us as much possible in the available time.

Bike ride to Angkor Thom. My husband and I were enthusiastic about riding bikes to the temples so we opted to do this with our guide. It was Sunday and the usual bike rental place that the tour uses was closed so we went to another one in Siem Reap. The ride to the temples was fine, though traffic in Siem Reap is crazy. Only cars seem to obey any traffic rules (such as driving on the proper side of the road) and so the ride was "interesting". Just when I was feeling good about being on the shoulder a motorbike was headed directly for me. Most of the ride there was fun and I figured it would make for a good story. We saw wild monkeys on the road and free range pigs. The bikes were then left in the care of people the guide knew. The entrance into Angkor Thom was beautiful with the long rows of statues (soldiers?) along either side. I believe that several temples are considered to be part of Angkor Thom but I am not sure. The temples were within walking distance from one another and I'm sure we only saw a small part of each. The Banyon Temple with the 200 faces of Avolokitesvara was quite amazing... as was the Elephant Terrace that came next. We were brought back to our hotel to rest up to see Angkor Wat in the late afternoon. After Angkor Wat we had to pick up the bikes and ride them back to the bike rental place. This ride took well over an hour and it became dark in the middle of the ride. If traffic was bad in the morning it was horrendous at rush hour. At one point we lost the guide amidst all the vehicles. We just kept going straight and eventually found him waiting for us. This ride was more thrilling than any amusement ride because it had the element of truly getting yourself killed (we had no lights on the bikes). If you ride steadily (just the way they teach you to cross streets there) then the vehicle drivers will adjust to you. Only at one point when we had to cross a particularly crazy intersection did I get off my bike and put my hand up to stop traffic so we could cross safely. In the end it made for a great story!
hidden Gem. This site is truly phenomenal. Trees like monsterous octopus growing from the ancient walls. Wow you can taste the atmosphere. A truly great place to explore

Temple so cool, climate not. We had a half day tour beginning of April and was orinally meant to see Angkor Wat first but switched it about to suit our requirements. Our guide was a fascinating fella, very informative as he had worked previously on the temple sites in a heritage capacity, helping to restore and clear mines years back. The entrance to this site was extremely busy (10am) so we ditched our taxi driver before the bridge and headed over by foot. The bridge itself is spectacular with large statues either side the whole way over the moat. The gate is impressive with the faces cut in to the rock. This was my favourite temple, so many carvings depicting wars, nature and various day to day and community activities from ancient times past. Truly magical and such an amazing structure that the Cambodians can be so proud of. It was exceptional humid and the sun blazing down is immense. This was my first temple which might explain why it was my favourie. I swear I lost a stone in weight walking which is why I sped round later temples as I needed the a/c of the car. Will return as nothing quite like it, truly outstanding experience and a must when in Cambodia

Another incredible piece of history with amazing guide. Mr Chhin +855-0-12948963 was our guide and he was fantastict!!!! Mr Chhin takes the time to explain about this history of an amazing site like Angkor Thom and how it differs from other temples. The site itself is incredible, April is probably not the best time to visit as it is incredibly hot, particularly between 11am and 3pm, however make sure not matter what time you visit Angkor Wat is one of the sites you visit.
Just as good as Ankor Wat.. Very interesting place and easily accessible and easier to walk around than Ankor Wat. Great place for self exploration.
Another temple to explore. Worth a side trip when you visit Angkor Wat. Some of the area is being restored so don't be surprised to see workers and modern equipment being used to restore the ruins.

Beautiful experience. TONG HANN +855-0-89986497 was our guide and he is the best!!!! He took the time to really tell you about the rich history of Cambodia and he is unlike the guides in tour companies wherein he is holding a bullhorn or a flag and basically just recites a script that he has memorized.

Beautiful!. We loved this place. Rambling ancient temple ruins in the forest. However, we were surprised to see a crane in the middle of the complex. Restoration works are being carried out and there is quite a bit of construction going on.

Leave yourself enough time for this amazing sight!. I went to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm on a group tour, and we did them all in three hours. I found that very rushed. They were all stunning, and Angkor Thom was fascinating to wander around. Bring lots of water and sunscreen!

Fantastic historical 'must see' wonder of the world. The sheer size and magnitude if thiese ruins blows your mind. When you walking Ankor Thom you need to first view it from a distance to understand how significant this is. Try and get a map first and do some homework on Ankor Thom before you go. This should not be missed.
So Much to See. Angkor Thom consists of several temple sites all in the same general area. It's easy to start at Bayon Temple and just walk around the area and see all the other sites.
Angkor Thom - Siem Reap, Cambodia. The Temples were great. It is a bit of a walk most of the temples and it is hot in Cambodia so be sure to bring water with you.Instagram: @tommiesox

A nice big museum and not to be missed.. You can spend the whole day learning the history & it's not enough
if you'll read all the notes/inscriptions. Everything I liked & nothing I disliked.

Ankor wat and area needs 2-3days. You've gone all this way spend 2-3 days and explore the area. If you are semi-fit adults and have teenagers go with Cambodian Cycling. Riding gives a broader range and a better view.

Must visit!! Go for the elephant ride!. Go for the elephant ride. The ride will take about 30 minutes. Do go there before 10am. The elephant will greet you at the South Gate of Angkor Thom and will transport you to the Bayon temple in a regal style. The price per person: USD20. Payment cash on the spot.Check out the little tips pocket on the back of his shirt. :)Tip to the elephant: Do buy a pineapple as a treat for the lovely elephant :) (sold on the spot).

Don't try to do this in one day. We "did" Angkor Wat starting early in the morning and tried to "do" Angkor Tom the rest of the day/ It was a mistake. There are too many things to see in a day unless you are an Olympic athlete and even then you'll only see it on photos and video after the event. Its probably better to do Bayan, the biggest temple, in several hours because its HUGE then one or more smaller temples and come back a second day to finish. The 3-day pass costs the same as the 2-day pass and maybe that's why. The temples are amazing and some parts are better than Angkor Wat proper.

Like a scene straight out of a movie. Also known as the walled city of Cambodia. It is where the ancient Royal Family was housed. The Giant heads standing guards along the entrance is a scene out of an adventure movie. Inside, the huge complex of temples will take your breath away.

great temples but rip off cafe. The elephant and leper terrace were great with awesome carvings. However the cafe complex was terrible with street corner food at 5 star hotel prices. Take a packed lunch or avoid being anwhere near the anchor thom area at lunchtime.

Khmer "Great City". Buy the three day pass and see several Wats in this area. Terrace of the elephants (a reviewing stand) is fabulous and the gods and monsters which eat your time ( don't we have them today?) line the walk to the city gate . The carvings arein terrific shape.

Ancient metropolis. Like most of the Angkor complex there are parts which are teeming, but the city is large enough that there are quiet spots too. All that is left is the stone of the temples - everything else was made of wood which termites have long since destroyed, but it is easy to imagine the teeming city of 1 million people crammed into 4 square miles.
Beautiful Bayon . All the carvings and long walls. And the towers with all the Buddha faces. I think it may be my favourite. Make sure to 'kiss' the Buddha face.

beautiful and amazballz. wonderful architectures. beautiful relics. amazing histories here.... there were elephant rides, fun for family. it was very hot and you're expose to the sun a great deal. wear long sleeves and bring an umbrella - plenty of liquid as well, lots to walk. must get a guild to explain all the histories.

Fantastic!. Probably my favourite temple - fantastic carvings of Aspara.
Get up & see it early if possible & be prepared to climb fairly steep stairs - & take a big SD card in your camera.
Tip - use the local registered guides - well worth it as they know where to go & the history.

Excellent Ruins - large area to cover. Angkor Thom (literally means Great City) is a large area that encompasses many different ruins. It is well worth the visit and you can spend at least a 1/2 day here exploring it. It is quite spread out, so you will need to rent a tuk tuk or another mode of transportation to take you around. It'll be well worth the money.In addition to Bayon temple - located inside this area - you can see the Elephants Terrace and the Terrace of the Leper King - all with bas-reliefs still in good shape.Make sure to visit the south entrance with its giant face tower gate and bridge with statues. Very impressive.

The Gods are Smiling at Bayon Temple. Our Favorite Temple Inspired us to Just "Be Happy". Angkor Thom is a fortified city protected by a Moat. The main temple here is Bayan Temple, or the temple of smiles. It is an incredible place and makes you feel happy because each tower welcomes visitors with four smiling Buddha faces. the south gate entrance is stunning and greets visitors with over twenty statues on either side of the bridge. The Gods are on the left and the demons on the right. Many of the heads of these statues were stolen during the war, but some originals remain. The true beauty lies behind the walls of Bayon Temple. The beautiful structure and the carved Buddha smiling faces is gorgeous. Most of the spectacular happy carvings at Bayon Temple remain. There are 37 towers with four smiling faces pointing in each direction. That is a total of 148 happy faces plus two from us gives a grand total of 150 smiles at Bayon Temple.  There was an Asian elephant in front of the temple and we walked past it to visit the Terrace of Elephants. This was another temple on the Angkor Thom complex that was built in the 12th century and dedicated to the power and love of elephants. Elephants are truly the most incredible creatures and they were the work trucks back when the temples were being built. They used the elephants to carry the stone to make the temples.  Bayon Temple was our guide's favorite temple in the Angkor complex. He was proud and joyous to share his passion about this spot and it showed with the beaming smile on his face. There is a happiness and serenity here, along with a love of elephants that also made this our favorite temple we visited during our tour. Spend time here and you will leave Happy.

A must see!. Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are world heritage sites. There is a reason for this obviously! They are masterpieces of architecture. See Angkor Wat at sunrise. It is well worth the inconvenience of getting up very early.

Intro to the Angkor complex. This was the first of the many temples we saw on our Siam reap visit and was for us the most impressive. You need a guide otherwise they are just an impress pile of stones. The guides bring the place to life and give you a little insight into the enormity of creating such an edifice. Quite remarkable. Take lots of water and don't be in a hurry. Its quite steep and not great for the very old or very young. Strongly advise a good break in the middle of the day. Siem Reap has lots of inexpensive and very good local restaurants. If your hair is getting thin, take a HAT.

Magnificent Wat { Temple }, Worth Cycling to.. This is a magnificent site and can easily be navigated on a bicycle. My hotel recommended this and they had bicycles for guests to use free of charge. As it happened, I hired a tuk tuk for the day and went round several sites that way. The paths and 'roads' around the complex are good and easily navigable. The Wat itself is a marvel and just thinking back to what it must have been like at the height of its spendour. Breathtaking. Take plenty of water and a good SPF Sunscreen.
Nice. If youre going to Angkor Wat you should go and take a look at these other temples too.Amazing workmanship on this temple too.

Worth going that extra mile to visit!. My favourite place of the bunch, especially the templeruins of Bayon. We hired a tuk tuk driver who took us from the hotel to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm and back for $15. I would recommend doing so as the distance between the temples are long, the areas to explore massive and sun very hot. Also, be aware of children trying to sell you things for ONE DOOLLLAAR and friendly strangers wanting to "tell you the stories of the temple" as they will (over)charge you. Why this country is nicknamed "Scambodia" becomes really apparent here! But the ruins are truly impressive and worth visiting, tho we find a 1 day pass being more than enough.

Another amazing wonder!. Along with Angkor Wat, the mind boggles at such magnificence and what it would have been like when it was at it's peak. As I said with Angkor Wat, I worry about preservation so that we don't all spoil what we so wish to share.

Bike Angkor Thom. Out first day in Siem Reap we visited Angkor Wat and took a guided tour. We decided to do Angkor Thom differently and rented bicycles from our hotel. In a 5 week trip of Asia, riding through Angkor Thom was one of my single favorite days. The roads throughout Angkor Thom and the surrounding complex are quiet and easy to navigate. Catching wind on the bike is refreshing between climbing to the top of each temple as you explore. Highly recommended way to see all the minor temples in the area, but bring lots of water!

the pathway is splendid.... what can i say, i so love the pathway/bridge.. i imagine duplicating it for my wedding :)
Angkor Thom has a distinct beauty from Angkor Wat... both are worth visiting and a must when in Siem Reap...

Grand.. This is another Temple that you should visit.
The size and the talent of those who built this is remarkable.

Phenomenal. This was just remarkable. Leave enough time to see it all. A guidebook or tour guide is recommended. Our tuk-tuk driver let us use a very good English guide book (Focusing on the Angkor Temples: The Guidebook (3rd Edition). It is highly recommended. If you're going, I'd recommend you buy it and go through it before or as you visit the temples. Enjoy!
worth it. This city was the first capital of the Khmer empire, and just like Tha Prohm is full of trees carved in the sandstones. Very beautiful and it as a big garden around
Awesome and Stunning!. Part of the Angkor Wat complex, incredible sites and history. Loved learning the history and a photographer's dream!
what else. So many things, to see in Angkor Thom, the Elepanft terrace, The Terrace of the Lepra King, Baphuon, the rainbow Bridge, the gates and the top Highlight Bayon templeit´s a must

Facinating experience.... What a mind blowing experience. Please watch any uTube coverage you can find before going, you will enjoy and get so much more out of your visit. DO NOT go with Siem Reap Shuttle Tours, that was our big mistake. The group started with eight by the end of the day it was only my husband and I. It started off quite well with the guide telling us a lot about himself! But after we had refused to buy the very expensive over priced lunch the whole thing went rapidly down hill. The guide practically ignored us and made it very clear we were some kind of nuisance in his life! he would drop us off at sites and say where and when to be collected with no other information about the amazing sites we were about to see. We have now watched many programmes since and we could have discovered so much more than we did. Highly recommend this place for a once in a life time must do....we will certainly be going back. Angkor Thom is simply beautiful with its tree root infestation mingled with the temple ruins. The reconstruction restoration work is under way so we plan to go back soon before and again after...thats how much we loved this place....dont forget the prep work x
my favorite of all the temples. This was my favorite of al the temples we went too. The monkeys , the elephants , the history!!!Fantastic few hours !!

Amazing. I suppose if you come to Siem Reap for one temple you must see all the better ones, and this is certainly one of these. Being less well known than Angkor Wat, it is far less busy and we were able to wander around and take photos without really being aware of any other visitors. Make this part of your visit.

Vast site with great history, amazing architecture and awesome carvings. A must see along with Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and and Banteay Srei. This is the largest of these four sites and you really need a full day to see everything. There are five huge gates with carved faces (start with the Victory Gate and take a short climb up and along the wall to the little visited East gate). The highlight is the Bayon which originally consisted of hundreds of giant smiling stone faces; four faces being carved into each side of 50 stupas or towers. Here there is access to all three tiers and you can get some creative photos from the third tier especially early in the morning. There are some interesting bas reliefs depicting Kyhmer history. Tours also focus on the the Elephant and the Leper Terraces (best carvings are to be found on the internal walls of the latter - fabulous carvings deities, dancers, snakes etc). Behind these there is the three tiered royal enclosures (Phimeanakas) with some broken elephant and lion guardians. The large Baphuon temple has some lovely carvings of scenes of Angkor daily life on west side of first tier. Hire a guide to ensure you get the best out of the history and design – you can’t possibly get this from a guidebook. There are no restroom facilities on the Angkor Thom main site but there are a couple in the general area (free entry included in the Angkor Archaeological site ticket but you may struggle to find without a guide). Take plenty of water and sensible walking shoes. Can get busy and noisy with tourists but with a bit of patience you will find a quiet space.

Really worth a visit. Angkor thom is fantastic and a little eerie. It is where Tomb Raider was based. It can get very very hot though so bring plenty water. Toilets are a bit lacking in the area. It is easily and cheaply accessed by tuk tuk.
More lost history. Another of the main attractions in the Angkor Wat complex, it adds to the overall sense of the place.

Hard going in the heat. Touring is hard going in the heat. Also hard going with new knees when the steps are uneven, sloping and small. Our tour guide made it easy by, at times, taking us the wrong way if he thought that it was the kinder way on the knees.

Second trip to Angkor Thom. We decided that one trip to this spectacular ruin was not enough. We enjoyed our first visit two years hence, but this one was even better. The interaction between the roots and trees with the ancient temple is surrealistic. One gets the feeling of unity in a strange way.
Our advice is just do it!

Start here!. This is a great place to start your temple pilgrimage in Siem Reap. Early in the day, it is already abuzz with tourists, but it is easy to see everything, even if you can't get too many shots without people in them. Get a guide to help you enjoy the context of these and the rest of the area temples!!

Awesome. Well, there is absolutely nothing to dislike about the whole Angkor realm. It is utterly amazing and we loved every minute of every day we spent there. To comprehend the workmanship for that era is gobsmacking.

Crush of people. Go early before the massive tour groups arrive and hog up the space with multiple photos of each other in front of every tree and root. Do they realize what an obstacle these selfish people pose (literally posing) for others who wish to enjoy the locations too. Still, Angkor Thom is an amazing place to visit.
Also beautiful. Another temple well worth the visit. A bit further on Than Angkor Wat, the road is a bit rough, but worth going to. Nothing to dislike.
Fantastic .... Magnificent temple and a lot of giant trees ...breathtaking....A must visit place if you are here...

Wonderful. Angkor Thom is another beautiful temple in Siem Reap and a must to visit.It has very peaceful,smiling faces of Budda carved into the sandstone that are huge and look out at you from all over the temple.

Wall Carvings. Our guide Rany made sure that we visited this site when it was least busy which was a bonus so we could enjoy this visit. Rany knew the best photograph opportunity places were on this site

interesting,view spot you cant go as restorationin progress. excellent as expected,i got there around 10am ,hire a driver for 4 days this was on the 2nd day of my seam reap visit,sadly my driver wasnt too keen on all day tour drop me off after 1 or 2 temples so i was back at the hotel every afternoon after lunch for those 4 days.
mmmmmmmm
Excellent. Another great temple to put down as a must see. Early morning is a good time to visit this one. If you only visit a few temples, sdee this one.

Not to be missed!. This magnificent temple with so many giant faces crafted on is not to be missed while you are in Siem Reap. Spend at least some time admiring the beauty of this particularly unique temple.

Another ancient gem. all the temples in the complex are awesome. You just have to visit most of them. Angkor Thom starts off with a Naga Bridge that embodies Hindu mythology. They are all just amazing.... you just have to visit them.

A vast place that needs plenty of time to take it all in.. As Angkor Watt, Angkor Thom is breathtaking but is on a whole lot bigger scale. Take your time, wander at your leisure and get to see the hidden and secluded places that the organised tours rush past.

Great carving art. I love the buddha faces here. I love this area even more than the main temple of the Angkor wat. Walking in side Angkor Thom, I found the smile of all buddhas and their friendliness and my life is so easy

impressive. A must see - this set of structures is much more spread out but there is lots of great stuff to see. You could probably spend a day just in this section of the Angkor Park. We saw the main bits, the gates and the large tomb, the elephant temple is beautiful but lacking in majesty. There are also lots of minor temples - they are OK - but there are others that are much more impressive.

Must see at sunrise. Great view as the sun rises over the temple but you need to be very early as the best positions get taken very quickly. From there its a good tour through the place and up the relatively short flight of steep stair to some good views across the landscape.
beautiful. A must see while in Siem Reap. Visit in conjunction with seeing the Angkor Wat and the temple where Tomb Raider was filmed (cannot remember the name).

Part of an amazing day. Each of the temples commonly visited in the Angkor complex is an attraction by itself. Take at least a full day tour through the Various attractions. Angkor Thom has the most amazing carvings and bas reliefs.
Stunning seat of ancient power. Make the effort to climb all those stair to see the view from the top of temples. The view and change in perspective is well worth it.

AVOID the elephant rides, don't buy from kids and watch out for the selfie sticks at sunrise!. BEWARE! Watch out for the elephant rides! You hear so many horror stories of animals being mistreated for tourism. And I was very aware of this whilst on my 6 month travels, this was the only case I was witness to. As I was standing beside the group of elephants that walk people to the temples, an elephant was making sad whimpering noises, it was clearly unhappy. The guy on top ignored it whilst playing on his phone and to my complete horror, another guy approached the elephant and punched it on the lip and stood on its trunk. The elephant didn't react and continued to make whimpering elephant noises whilst playing with a leaf. So sad, and no wonder animals act out. If only I could have gotten away with the same actions to the guys, let's hope karma is real.I was travelling solo as part of an adventure group. Our day started with an early rise to watch the sun come up over Angkor Wat. As beautiful as this sounds, be warned that hundreds of people and tour groups have the same idea. You will need to arrive at least an hour to two before the sunrises in order to get a good spot by the pond that doesn't involve cameras and selfie sticks being shoved in your view. What really disappointed me was how people watched the whole thing through a screen and took an unnecessary amount of photographs, no appreciation at all. And people will push you out of the way to get that picture! (Also, a bit of a mission finding the loo at this particular point, you will need some loose change or a dollar when you do find it)Kids will pester you to buy postcards and keychains but don't buy anything as they will honestly follow you everywhere and you will have a group of them since you bought off another. The temples themselves are really cool but again go early to avoid the masses, we done the faces temple first, the tomb raider/tree temple 2nd and finally Angkor Wat... In this order it was relatively quiet. It would have been a great experience if it wasn’t for people… or if everyone there was a Buddha.

Amazing...Not to be Missed. I was more impressed with Ankor Thom then Ankor Wat, although both are not to be missed. We were with a tour and, therefore, were directed to a special ticket area, thus avoiding long lines. Your picture is taken for placement on the ticket (good for both Ankor Wat and Ankor Thom), which is frequently checked. If you are not utilizing a guide guide then reading up prior to visiting is a must. Be prepared, there is plenty of walking and steps to climb. Proper footwear and comfortable clothing is a must. Drinking water in the heat is a necessity. The history, size, construction of the temples is totally amazing.

Simply Amazing. We had a 2 day private tour with Asian Trails so there was just the 2 of us, our guide and driver. Depending on when you visit certain areas get really busy and it was pretty hot so having the benefit of a driver with aircon vehicle made getting around easy and in comfort. It truly is an amazing site and certainly one of those 'must visit' places in Cambodia. One thing to bear in mind there are no restroom facilities actually on the main site, there are a couple in the general area, which we would have never found if we didn't have our guide and driver. The site is vast and it really is worth hiring a guide.

Tranquil. This is my favourite Temple,nature has taken over,destroying huge amounts ,however the tranquil atmosphere with nature and man creating this wonderful place.The photo opportunities are fantastic,unbelievable that Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolle was filmed here.well worth a visit ..

Angkor Thom. The entrance to the citadel is breath taking just make sure that you go through one of the gates that has had restoration work done on it. Start at Bayon and follow the trail to end at the terrace of the leper king.

Amazing. This was our first temple visit and we were hugely impressed. We went early in the morning with our guide and were almost the first people there. The sheer scale and detailing of the stonework was stunning, ranging from detailed social and historical frescoes to huge carved heads.The Bayon Temple is part of the complex as is the Elephant Terrace and the whole experience was terrific. Highly recommended.
Amazing Temple!. Extremely hot.. bring alot of bottled water! A must see temple! Significantly less tourists at this temple.

The best temple complex in my opinion. Visited in the afternoon after spending the morning at Angkor Wat. Immediately pleased with the relative lack of other tourists! Could really walk around and listen to our guide explain the history of the place without rubbing shoulders with other well-meaning visitors! Also there were many places where we could climb/ascend to the top of the structures for a birds-eye view of the region - felt like there was a bit more to do than at Angkor Wat. Recommended!

Very interesting. This being our first temple visit in Cambodia, was amazing. I could not believe how many faces there are there. The harder you look for them the more you discover. We had the pleasure of being with a knowledgeable guide (just two of us and him) who told us all about the stories carved in the walls. Completely fascinating. It is a large temple so plenty to see. If you are in to temples, them this is worth a visit. The only down side for us was that there were several large tour groups from one nationality, who were very noisy, shouting and singing and clapping. I just wish they could have been more respectful to both the location and other tourists.

Loved the frescos and carvings. this is a great and famous temple, with lots to offer sight seers and historians, alike. Thereare quite a few very narrow and steep steps to manoevre.....those with knee problems, beware. The carvings and frescos were special...I particularly liked the dancing ladies. I also noticed that all of the carved heads were smiling....does this mean they were a happy people?....one can only hope. I really enjoyed this temple...but go very, very early to avoid the blistering heat and the hoards of Chinese tourists. It opens at 530 am. We left by 830

Brilliant place.. Go early 7am, when cool best time as it does bet so hot later on. Take water. Cool clothing. Lot of walking. Very very hot so be prepared. But its a must to see. Enjoyed the whole thing. Day ticket $20 each. Easy done in a day.
big. A different type of temple , you walk through and the driver picks you up at the other side , it was a fantastic experience .
Fantasic. Did many temples while staying in Cambodia and this was one of my favourites after Ankor Wat it really is well worth a visit.
Lovely.....especially the elephants!. We didn't go for an elephant ride/tour but it looked like lots of fun, the Angkor Thom area is big and beautiful. Highly recommend.
A must see. Angkor Thom is a large temple complex, much bigger that Angkor Wat in land size containing many different temples within its walls. A must see, amazing visit.

Must See. After Angkor Wat this is usually next on the tour so try to get there early or if you can take the heat early afternoon seems quieter (tour lunches?). We found this a very hot site so hat and water a must. Fantastic structures quite well cleared of vegetation so photo opportunities are plentiful. There are some steep stairways to get to higher levels but well worth it. Recommended site.
Heritage at it's best. I loved the old blended with the new (restoration) and the high regard the Cambodian people hold for their heritage.
amazing. Its beautiful, cant miss it but take hat, alot of water and dont come in april, its the hottest mo th! Good shoes because you have to climb and walk too much
Beautiful. Most of the temple offers architecture and beauty within the temple. Walking around is going to be tiring as it is a huge complex. Go with a cap/hat and plenty of water.
Another must-see.. Beautiful ruins and so many photographic scenes you may need extra camera batteries. Morning is best as afternoons get quite hot.

Beautiful. Walking shoes and hiring a guide are a must coming here.
There is so much to see and so much history relating back we're not aware of. Bring your camera and bring cold drinking water

Must see! Wonderful place!. Another beautiful temple, the bar is raised once you've seen Angkor Watt and Ta Prohm, but you won't be disappointed with this one!
Spectacular historical builds with trees hugging over the stones.
There's so much history to drink in so make sure you hire a good tour guide!
Join me in my adventure!
http://www.monicawong.com/2015/03/projectmcambodia-siem-reap.html

Angkor Thom - it takes a day to see. Angkor Thom is a huge area. Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Prea Palilay, Tep Pranam, The Terrace of the Leper King, The Terrace of the Elephants, Preah Pithu, Northern Klang, Prasat Suor Prat, Southern Klang. The the southern, eastern, northern and western gates. Fortunately there are food stalls near Preah Pithu!

Not a place to rush, but rather to savor and relax!. Plan to arrive at this site early morning or late afternoon to benefit from a relaxed exploration not pressurized by crowds or the heat of day. Take time out to just rest, breathe and soak up the wonder of this space.
Stunning. A whole city with stunning temples, pyramids and carved terraces. A photographers delight. So much to see!

Amazing feat of 12th century construction. Angkor Thom, a walled city of 3x3 km with a couple of major temples in it, notably the Baphuon and of course the most playful Bayon. Enormous feat of construction for the 12th century Khmer people. Of course part of every day tour to Angkor Wat - which is itself outside the city for Angkor Thom.

Angkor Thom - old capitol. This was probably the busiest site that we encountered. Still well worth the visit which will involve a bit of wandering. There are a number of sites to visit within the area. As you wander around the crowd drops off. People seem to drop off as you continue through most of the sites. Be prepared to walk around and enjoy the history. We throughly enjoyed this site.

Amazing. The temples are magnificent. I have been 3 times now and still haven't seen them all. My biggest disappointment was the elephants. The ride itself was fantastic, but the way the rider treated that poor elephant was disgusting. When we got off he kept hitting the elephant on the head with a metal rod. I left there feeing so ashamed. Because we as tourists are promoting this behavior. So we can 20 minutes of fun. You can see the tears rolling down the elephants face. I will never ride them again :'(
Must see.. The first Angkor temple we visited and should not be missed, it does appear to be on all the guides itineraries and as some interesting features especially theTerrace of the Elephants.

The pick of the temples. Think National Geographic photos of the area and this is it.
Wonderful ruins, and some spectacular instances of massive trees straddling the walls - which one is holding which one up?
Plenty to see and marvel at how this was made so many years ago.

Wow za. Angor Thom , is a larger complex than Angor Wat but still magnificent, I have no regret for coming to see it. There are so many ancient temples in this area. Come and see and enjoy these beautiful created temples. Just a reminder bring some water as we were all over the place and your body knows it with the humidity and heat .

One for the 'must see' list. Ankor Thom should be on your list of 'must see' temples in the Ankor Archeological Park. It is close to a number of smaller temples and despite the crowds, you can still enjoy your visit. Plenty of great photos possible here.

A Great Ruin and so Photograpical!. This is a stunning sight with so many photo-op locations n case you need some marvelous photos to show the folks back home. Take time, as you wander the ruins, to marvel at the construction and to imagine how and who brought all these huge stones from a great distance away to construct this immense temple. If it is, as it usually is, very hot and often humid, take your time to indulge in the site. By the way, if you bought a Day Pass, most of the revenue apparently goes into private hands and not into site maintenance and preservation. A little source of wealth for wealthy Cambodians.

A must-see. Bigger than Angkor Wat. We visited Ba Yum which was a splendid complex even if in worst condition than Angkor Wat. For all Angkor temples I suggest best thing to do is to hire a local guide. You can choose a 3 day pass ticket which ensure you entrance to the majority of the temples.
Fantastic. Don't miss this one. How can you, really? If you go to Angkor Wat they are all right there. Don't skimp. They are all unique onto themselves.
Stunning. Go first before Angkor wat and beat the crowds. Wished we had a guide to point out the history and meaning of the carving.
Beautiful, haunting, bucket list!. Bayon temple's carved faces are wonderful, lots of work still going on at the temple but lots to see as it is.

Another magnificent Wat. Angkor Thom is another magnificent temple , as you approach you see the statutes lining the road and wonder how magnificent they must have looked when first built . There is plenty to look at and some great photo opportunity, we went in the afternoon not much crowds but lots of kids following asking for a dollar . Well worth a visit .
Worth a see.. The temple are all quite different so it is worth having a look at this one too. You won't need too long here though.

Nosey Buddas. A fascinating temple with a relief illustrating the battles won and lost by the Khmer against the Cham invaders, very interesting details which our guide illustrated for us.This was built as a Buddist temple and some of the gates still have the 4 faces of Budda, at certain angles it is possible to get two Budda faces such that they touch noses, there is another where if your partner or guide get it right you can appear to be touching noses with a Budda.
Worth seeing. This is part of Angor Wat and well worth visiting. Again get a guide to explain what all the carvings mean.
Amazing. Not to be missed. It is hot, so be sure to bring water and wear comfortable shoes and clothes.Be sure to bring a camera with lots of memory

Great Temple Amongst Many. My own personal favourite from the zillions of temples. It's a personal choice. There are so many and they are very similar. Angor Thom seemed to me to have the best atmosphere and some very interesting carvings. if you are pushed for time I'd put this up there with Angkor Wat for your priorities. See what you think.
Same Same with RE Angkor Wat. See my review of Angkor Wat. You have to visit these temples to get a feeling for the time and energy expended making them. Few other sites like it on the planet.

Must see attraction. It's what we came for and employing our own tour guide was the best bit of advice we were given. Rather than just wandering around this wonderful place we were given a running commentary of all the intricate details that are all over the place.
Ancient Temples and Ruins. Wow. What a sight and who had the foresight to build all these huge temples. We liked to walk through the ruins and admire them.

Another Cambodian Must See!. This is another spectacular Temple. The history behind it is amazing and our guide for the tour was full of stories of the fabulous past. The carvings are fabulous and the pics don't do it justice. You must go and see it! Be very careful how you dress. Knees and shoulders must be covered as this is a holy place and they won't let you in wearing short shorts and a tank top. Take lots of water and wear a hat. There are girls selling beautiful scarves there and I bought one for $10. Very cheap and the quality is wonderful. It was Chinese New Year when we were there, so it was very busy, but we were spaced out nicely so it was easy to get close and see all the magnificent carvings. Well worth the trip!
Unusual!. The gates of this city are unique with the towers, ponds and the bridges. Angkor tom is impressive. it is recommneded to go there in the morning before tons of people just flood it.

Truly magnificent masterpieces. One can not miss the massive, large scale face towers guarding the entrance of this city and the giant - mostly smiling - figures accompanying each tower and temple. The designs are unique and usual. There are several carvings of animals: snakes, pigs, monkeys and roosters. The highlight of Angkor Thom is the mysterious Bayon Temple, replete with spectacular bas-reliefs and over 172 giant smiling face. One hopes that this historical site can be preserved, for there is much to learn from these masterpieces.

Cool faces!. This was our first temple when after buying tickets. It's quite large and the whole grounds are quite confusing. There are many things to see, but I loved the faces on one of the structures. If you need to cool down, there is a long raised walkway to an actual temple (which requires you to be covered to the knees and full shoulder coverage) that gets a nice breeze. Walking between the attractions here gets very tiring, so communicate with your tuk tuk driver. As noted, if you want to go into the ancient temple on these grounds, you must dress properly. We saw half a dozen in tank tops get turned away as we walked up. This temple is basically a very steep climb up, a nice view, a small exploration, and a steep climb down. There are secure bars to either side, which are handy for helping you to pull yourself up if you get tired (some people clearly did) and my muscles felt it the next day. Like many of the Wats here, it gets extremely busy. My hotel recommended going during lunch time, but you would have to bring your own food, perhaps, because we were told that the restaurants usually close after 2 or 3 o'clock.

Angkor Thom WOW!!. Hard to miss the crowds especially during chinese new year but our private guide, Kamsan, made sure we visited at the quieter times which made it more enjoyable... A truly beautiful place that is so captivating in all its grandeur....

Great place!. Hired a guide for $20, well worth the money..very informative & knowledgeable. Amazing place! Be prepared - they are VERY strict regarding the dress code for the upper levels ( it's a holy place), & be prepared to queue to go up, and down! It gets quite hot up there but worth the time & effort!

Magnificent place. We went there early in the morning to miss the crowds. However, it was Chinese New Year, so there were still crowds. It is a beautiful place to visit. However, you must have a guide to show you around as they can explain the history and features of the site. You should also take plenty of water. You need to ensure that you either have a one day or multi day pass to enter the area

Amazing and incredible!. Just when you thought you have seen enough temples, you need to make room for one more! It really is worth it! So beautiful that it makes you forget the heat. Consider the elephant ride around the temple for another view and some great photos. Well worth it!

Attractions. I have traveled all over in many countries that have Maya ruins but seeing the temples in siem reap were way more than I expected.I thought they were better than any Mayan ruins I have seen.and definately worth visiting any of them.
Mind boggling. This temple is so unique you will want to spend some time here to appreciate the magnificence of the structure and the decoration.

Smaller Temples - more intimate. I preferred Angkor Thom to Angkor Wat as it was much ore intimate. Angkor Wat is teaming with tourists seeing this fabulous location but it is not an intimate experience

The best!!!!. Angkor Thom is never to be forgotten. It is really the most unique and spectacular of the Cambodian temples. I loved it. As a teacher of history, I was overwhelmed. Go in January or February when the crowds are more manageable and the weather is more dry.

A well-designed city. I will say the design is very much after the Tang Dynasty city in the 9th century. Per history data, Angkor Kingdom did send embassies to China during that time. Nice to walk around the Thom, it's not that crowded and allow you to wander among the wonderful architectures.

Difficult to keep in perspective.. Amazing, but without a good guide or some research it becomes difficult to understand your place within the overall temple. Much larger than Angkor Wat, but not easy to appreciate it unless you realize how all the sites interact.

Mega Structure. The intricate details of the temple is really awesome. I was imagining the time when the ancient people of Cambodia are building the temples. It's a must see when you visit Cambodia. We were able to do the temple visit from 8am to 4pm. Make sure to wear a hat or bring a scarf or bandana and apply sun screen because it is scorching hot in Cambodia.
i love this place. This is a miracle. This place is in my heart. Amazing and fantatic. This is must see category. I want go back.
Incredible. My favourite temple... The 'jungle' tomb raider experience. Amazing. Some reconstruction work going on so be prepared for scaffolding and workmen.

Spectacular.... We came after Angkor early in the morning. I can honestly say this place was huge, fascinating, full of history and as the day went by, we were hot and tired!! Make sure to wear comfortable shoes and have water. We didnt do the elephant ride as we didn't know the exact conditions of the establishment ($20 US dlls for 20 min). We walked from the main entrance all the way to the Elephant complex. There was a bathroom available on that side of the complex. I wore sleeves and shorts below the knees. Make sure to have water and wear a hat.

Faces, Faces, Faces. We liked the feeling of being in something holy, ancient, and rediscovered after centuries of being 'lost'. We enjoyed the creativity of its builders, and the piety of its designers.
Amazing. Fascinating living area for 1 million people at its peak. Amazing freezes and architecture. One could spend a whole day just visiting this area and the elephant terrace, side buildings et.

More temple goodness. This area includes gems like the Bayon, the terraces of elephants / leper king, Phimeanakas, Baphuon and more ... there are elephant rides being offered and if you get there early, you can possibly see a bunch of monkeys, which are more shy than I had thought (compared with i.e. temple visits in Nepal) and not as greedy-grabby as others .. we got some nice photos, but always beware of rabies!
Fantastic!. Take the time to visit all the various temple sites. We had a great guide from AMA Waterways who was very knowledgeable and helpful.

Awesome. my favorite of the temples I saw. I could spend hours taking photographs at this temple. The faces in the towers are just amazing and there are so many little turns and corridors it is built for exploration. Note that it is also very easy to get separated from your group. You can't get eternally lost, but you can certainly spend awhile going in circles trying to find your friends. So stick close or just agree to meet up on the outside.

A place to go with a guy to understand and enjoy it.. Was part of a private tour, with a private guide, who explained to us all the interesting and cultural aspect of the site. The site is unique and a lot of ancient civilization's architecture to see.

Angkor Thom. Very impressive. It is always exciting to enter a temple complex and the south gate of Angkor Thomwas the first we ventured through. It has left a lasting impression. It is worth a walk around the outer walls if you have the time, less tourists and very peaceful.

Angkor Thom Temple. Amazingly beautiful and very very large Temple and surroundings. Each gate is unique and beautiful. The carvings and walkways are amazing and beautiful. This and all the other Temples in the Archaeological Park are all a 'must see', I suggest you buy a 3 day pass at least. Also remember to have $US to purchase your passes.

Great archaeology!. In Khmer, ( which is pronounced as Kamayi), Angkor Thom means, "Great City". This , in the 12 th century, was established by King Jayavarman, and this great attraction is spread over 9 kms. At the center of the City, stands the State Temple of Jayavarman, The Bayon, which is surrounded by more than 20 towers. While entering , one can find the mutillated statues of Devas on one side, and Asuras on the other. Each of the group is holding a serpent in its hand, and it is said to be the " Samudra Manthan" , the churning of the Ocean. Angkor Thom lies on the West Bank of Siem Reap River. There are gates at all the cardinal points, and the South Gate is the entering point for all the tourists. Many intricate sculptures are depicted on the wall. The churning of the ocean, the historical sea battle between the good Khmer and the bad Cham of Vietnam, who were experts in sea battle. There are many four faced statues, which may represent Bodhisattva, which we may call Brahma. I definitely want to mention here about one Angkor Tour Guide Service, and one Mr. Sok Chea, who was our wonderful tour guide. Always with a smiling face, always trying to be helpful, his presence and guidance, made our stay in Cambodia great!

Ignore your tuktuk driver. All tuktuk drivers will construct a little route that is best for you, and you'll unknowingly agree to it, but it's worth planning ahead.We did a one-day trip, which was plenty for us, and didn't come here 'til later in the day, which was a big disappointment for me in the end as AT was the place i wanted to see the most.

Awesome Place and a Must Visit. Read my review on the Angkor Wat. This is a must visit place after you see Angkor WatA smaller Wat but with the history of the movie Tomb Raider being shot there, this is a very popular visit. Visit will take about an hour to see properly as it is a smaller wat. Lots of photo opportunitesDo take good sturdy shoes as the footings below can be a little loose (I did witness a gentleman trip and almost caused serious injuries so just a mention of caution when u visit)Enjoy Angkor Thom and take loads of pics!!
Part of the Angkor experience. This is not as crowded as the other temples on the one day tour and well worth the visit as each temple is differant than any of the others.

Old and Beautiful. We entered Angkor Thom thru the south gate (narrow for a bus, but impresive) which was the capital city of Khmer rulers. There is an entrance fee to Ankor Tom and the other temples in the Angkor Wat area but it is well worth it. You may want to get a mutiple day pass because there is a lot to see.
Loved this place. Smaller than the nearby lmuch larger Ankor Wat, but worth the visit. Very elaborate without too many stairs to climb.
The stringent pattern. Bayon as a turning point, by itself enough reason to visit Angkor, but all elements put together, gives a greatnes out of all kind of measurements

More context to a spectacular site.. As I understand it, Angkor Thom is the city containing Angkor Wat and several of the other sites. It is more than worth the effort to walk around and gain a feeling for the size of the city and it's design. It helps to give you the context necessary to get a feeling for the daily lives of the million people who lived here.
A "must" see . Angkor Thom, the capital of the ancient Khmer Empire is quite well preserved & well worth a visit. Come & marvel at the many Buddha faces carved into the ancient stone. Beautiful

temple temple temple. very good day a little bit of a que to get tickets but the temples were great most of them are a bit of a trek but worth it don't forget to take a t-shirt as you will not be able to go up to the top of the temple the views amazing. its a long day and tiring but well worth it."make sure you have plenty of water"
Beautiful. But busy. In retrospect we should have come here before Angkor Wat as tourists are concentrated in a smaller area. That is a minor point however, as the site is absolutely amazing.
Must visit. A must visit while in Siem Reap. Especially liked the South Gate of Angkor Thom where fifty four gods and demons line the road.

The small favourite. Because of the deep shade from the trees and the relatively small distances to walk through tumbled rock or stone alleys, this temple was our favourite. Such are the wonders of the temples. They stop your modern mind in its track and push you to imagine life here 1000 years ago....
Stunning. Can just imagine Tomb Raiders being filmed here. This is probably one of my favorite temples in Angkor Wat.

Stunning!. Angkor Thom was one of the largest of all the Khmer cities, and the South entrance (where one typically enters) is fantastic! It must be seen to be believed. Follow the tree-lined avenue to the central bayon, and let your imagination grasp the magnitude and duration of this accomplishment.

Well preserved faces. Don't miss Angkor Thom with all the Buddha faces, facing every direction. If it is extremely busy with tourists, wait a minute or two for a clearing to take photos. There is always an ebb and flow to the crowd, so be patient. A lot of people like to get that cheesy, fun shot where one lines things up so that it looks like you are nose to nose with one of the large faces. This temple is very well preserved with lots of fairly undamaged areas.

quite busy. I liked the view from the front. Since a road goes right through it, it was a little hard getting good pictures. There is a small temple (much older) to the right side just before going in but I think the best part was seeing it with the water reflecting all the carvings.

Must See in Siem Reap. While Angkor Wat is the most famous temple, Angkor Thom is even cooler with more intricate designs and most of the original stonework preserved. An important tip - go to Angkor Wat for sunrise, then leave to see Angkor Thom and when you circle back to Angkor Wat later in the day it will be less crowded.

A must!!!. The angkor thom is must see one. It has many temples and architectures. However, visit angkor thom must walk to see it all. The Bayon, the elephant terrace and another temples which you can walk and visit. Visit in the morning is recommended, the terrace of elephant has no shade to escape the sun and the heat that make you sweat.
Beautiful, elephant rides a must. Do take the elephant ride around the temple. While its a bit cheesy, it will bring a smile to your face

under renovation. Ta Phrom was the one temple they decided to leave as it was. It was one of the temples where they get the famous photos of tress growing up the walls. But now they're rebuilding it so it's a bit of a building site but still well worth going.

Once the capital of the Khmer Empire. This is a massive projection of power with its 4x12km (some 4x7.5 miles) long square walls with Bayon Temple in its center. It is truly amazing to think that this "Great City" (which it translates to) was constructed in the 12th century. Unfortunately much of its beautiful artwork was later looted or simply decayed over centuries, but it is still majestic. A competent guide gave us the fascinating narrative around this site. Well worth the money!

Walled city. Angkor Thom ( Big Angkor) is a walled and moated royal city that was the last capital of the Angkorian empire .After Jayavarman VII recaptured the badly damaged Angkorian capital from the Cham invaders in 1181, he began a massive building campaign across the empire, constructing Angkor Thom as his new capital city.He began with existing structures, such as Baphuon and Phimeanakas and built a grand enclosed city around them, adding the outer wall and some of Angkor's greatest temples.there are gates to the city and the victory gate leads to the royal palace area. Each gate is crowned with giant faces.Now that's the end of the history lesson/tour !! go and marvel .go early to avoid the crowds
Great part of Angkor complex. One of the three Watts you will see on tour the Angkor archeological park. Excellent ancient site, another must see if you like archeological sites. I loved it.

An amazing experience and a must see. Another of the must see temples of Cambodia, very easy to view as part of a temple tour. Alongside Ta Prohm and the Bayon, Angkor Thom is a must see. If it were anywhere else, the temple would be world famous. Here, it lives in the shadows of the better known Angkor Wat, but that does not mean it can be ignored.

Must go and visit. A temple to visit along with Angkor it is truly a sight you don't want to miss. Similar in its appearance to Angkor, it depicts the story of the people through ruined stone carvings, showcasing the city it once was.Go and see it if your given the chance!
Superb. Tomb Raider trees and extensive temple grounds - this is another must visit site. The Thom is being restored/made safe and more of the site will be available for visits in the future

Allocate enough time. Angkor Thom is the former capital city of the Khmer empire and it is huge. If you wish to cover the whole area, it will take you hours just to get from one end to the other so make sure you allocate enough time. It's not a single structure like Angkor Wat but rather a widely spaced collection of temples and buildings and signage isn't very good. As such, it can be pretty easy to get lost among the ruins. Make sure to bring along a map of the place. A point to note is that there are many kids and teenagers hanging around the place who will try to strike a conversation with you, asking you where you are from, etc. They will then ask you for donations. It seems pretty organised since all of them have the exact same piece of paper that they ask you to read. They're not very pushy so just be polite and say no and they should leave you be.
Big Temple. Angkor Thom is a big one in all the temple in Siem Reap. Angkor Thom the meaning in English Angkor Big. When you visit that one you will see many faces style of the temple.

So Much To See. We went to Angkor Thom after spending time at Angkor Wat so we only had an hour before closing. The one temple that I did see was amazing. There is so much history in this area that you need a whole day to see it. I will definitely be back to finish my tour!!! It is a must see!!

A magnificent temple complex. As with all temple areas in the Siem Reap area, this is world heritage. And it is huge, magnificent, majestic, sublime. Give yourself plenty of time: at least three days to get round the major temples here and around.

So much to see. This is a massive site and so many temples to see within its walls. Very impressive. We visited with a guide and the next day we went again independently to see the rest and to revisit some of our favourite bits.
Angkor Thom. This was unexpected and was just as amazing as Angkor Wat itself , though in a lesser state of repair

A stones throw from Angkor Wat & just as amazing. This temple complex is easily visited alongside Angkor Wat in one day & many people would say its better than Angkor Wat, Im not in the business of picking favourites but it is a truely great place to visit
Another amazing temple. A lot of tourists but great building that is worth visiting! I visited it in the afternoon and the light was great then to take good pictures.

It's very easy to get lost here. Although it is less famous and smaller in size than Angkor Wat, but this temple also has it's uniqueness. You can easily go inside and get lost there and sometimes find yourself at the very same spot where you started from, especially when you enter from right side of it. There's a well of "Black Water" inside which is around 15m deep. At some place the walls are very close to each other and there's no way to pass. Go inside it and explore it!
Angkor Thom. Large and mostly in ruins, Angkor Thom is fantastic ruin of the Siem Reap area. Plan to spend at least half a day, probably more.

Breathtaking. Awesome historical site - temples and ancient structures that are simply amazing and that take one's breath away. But plan to come earlier in the day or later in the afternoon to avoid the hordes of tourists.
