Beautiful Temple. Angkor Thom is just one of the many beautiful temples in this complex near Siem Reap. Although Angkor Thom is less famous than its neighbour Angkor Wat, it's equally worth a visit.
excellent carvings. I think this is the temple where the carvings are basically "bas reliefs" of daily life and show fishing, hunting, cooking.
The walled city. Extensive wall and ramparts. Well maintained South Gate and Victory Gate. Contains a large number of temples in the complex.

Vast, carvings, steps, temples.... It really is big, with a 12km moat 300 feet wide, and once housing over 1M people - the largest city in the world at that time. Many, many carvings, lots of steps... you get the picture. Not to be missed.
Largest temple complex i ever seen. More than 10 temples around this Angkot thom complex, most of the temples are followed Buddhism, south and north gate entrance was really aesthetic

Easy to spend a day here. Angkor Thom is an large ancient city that probably had over one million people in the 1200s. It is huge and there are many temples and ruins to explore. Go early and spend as much time as you can. Get a 3-day pass so you can visit many of the sites around Siem Reap.
Historic visit. The wide complex consists of a few temple structures. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and admire the intricate stone carvings that adorn the temples

Yet another must see. To visit the Angkor Wat area, one has to marvel at the sheer effort and scale of the undertakings. At the time, a thousand years ago, this "city complex" was the largest in the world with over 1,000,000 people resident. Most must have been engaged in building and this site gives a feel of scale.

Angkor Thom and Bayon temple. . Truly amazing place. The scale of the place is outstanding and despite the crowds (only to be expected really) there are plenty of opportunities for photographs. Lots of little hidden gems around the complex so would recommend that you get a guide.There are some amazing views from the third level, but the steps up and down are very steep and can get a bit crowded. A bit of patience is required and take water with you.The elephant terrace is worth a look and the walls below the leper king statue.

Worth a visit. This is the largest and one of the most important temples in the area. The total area is 9sq km,but you only walk across from west to east. Like many of the temples it has suffered through many centuries of war.

First of Three!. Angkor Thom is the first of the Temples you will see in the Angkor Wat park area. It is stunning and the first of the treats you will have viewing this unique magnificent structure for the Buddhists. You will need to be reasonably fit for the walking and climbing in this area. Watch your steps carefully inside the building as there are some darker areas. Photo opportunities at every step and admiration of the builders ten centuries ago.

Largest stop in the Angkor Complex. This area is huge and takes about 2 hours or more to fully explore. It includes 5 or 6 temples including the Bayon temple. Women: make sure you dress modestly here or they wont let you go into all the area. No shorts, no tank tops. Maybe try a longer flowy skirt, because it's hot and you're gonna need some air flow if you're walking all day.

Interesting.... There were so many fascinating temples in Siem Reap, it was quite overwhelming. It was such a hot day as well, so we did not get to see as much as we would have like to. The stone carvings were so detailed and so well done. It is good to see that they are being restored. There were 54 carved stone figures at the entrance to Anhkor Thom. We were impressed with the Elephant terrace carvings. We had a driver take us around the sights as it was very hot and humid so it was good to have a guide who knew the best spots to visit. There is a lot of walking involved, and take plenty of drinking water!

Amazing. To think this was a city of millions. Staggeringly beautiful and you have to wish you could find a quiet corner to be on your own! Well worth the visit and surrounding woods very enticingly cool and tranquil.
Don't ignore this!. Wat is great but Angkor Thom and the other ruins here are if anything more impressive. To see the renovation task and work ongoing is amazing

Definitely worth visiting. Recommend getting a tuk tuk on your first day visiting the temples. Once you're familiar with the way there and have a three-day pass, it's worth renting a bike for $1/day and riding from Siem Reap. It's a lovely bike ride and Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are close enough that it doesn't take much time to read there or ride between them - just make sure you grab a map first!
Another temple. By the time I got to this one, I was a bit disappointed, had already been to several and need a break.

Move over Angkor Wat! Angkor Thom is better!!. As impressive and vastly popular Angkor Wat is, Angkor Thom is even more "jaw-dropping" spectacular! It took "monumental" to a whole new level; 10 square km of mesmerising temples.At its center is the MIND-BENDING Bayon temple with 54 gothic towers each with 4 faces (216 faces total) of the "smiling" legendery king of Cambodia.

Hard to believe. It is incredible to think that this was a city of a million people, more organised and better structured than many 21st century cities. The bridges into the city are worth stopping to admire.

Ancient city unearthed. Amazing complex of ancient city temples with its Elephant Terrace, entry Gates especially the Victory Gate, and Terrace of the Leper King. Be prepared to humble yourself as you climb your way up the stages. Absolutely worth the effort
amazing. I don't how else I can describe this place. the architecture, time spent building it, the details...amazing sums it all! it should be in everyone's bucket list.

Terrace of the elephants is a must-see. Angkor Thom was the first place we visited and was very impressive. The elephant walk features a row of elephants beautifully carved into the stone. Angkor Thom is an extensive city with much to see including the terrace of the Leper King. Again it is advisable to take a guide to make the most of your visit.
Mesmerising. The big temple , what to say . The entire siem reap is dotted with marvels . An excellent architecture

Just as good as Angkor Wat.. I loved this temple. You can climb around all the ruins as it does not seem to be as restored as Angkor Wat. Brilliant place to spend the afternoon. A must visit if in the area.

The way things were centuries ago. Angkor wat and Thom just complete your complete Siam Reap experience. this place is amazing and just makes you realize the world centuries ago. Magnificent art and a great city within a city must go

Interesting .... The temple has been taken by the nature with the trees inside the temples, making it a really special place to visit. The mix between rocks, sculptures and man set bricks is incredible and ancient time mysterious.

Tomb Raider worth the trip. While the poorest maintained of the temples, you get the feel of the ruins of a place where the jungle encroached upon it. They are clearly making an effort to upgrade the area...well worth the visit.

Understanding History of Khmer Kingdom. A must visit complex other than Angkor Wat, the main attraction is Bayon temple, I recommend you to learn a bit of the history and do not depend much from tour guide. The weather its sunny and dry with a lot of dust on January, bring hat, drink water, and lunch if you don't use tour package. Difficult to find decent toilet so bring your toiletries with you, do not over bargain book from the seller inside the temple complex, even though the price written in the cover book around 29.5 USD you can bargain for 5-8 USD. and for the postcard set its only 1 USD. I encourage you not to buy stuff from child seller. you can buy 1 day pass ticket for 20 USD, they will check your ticket each time you want to enter the major temple. your face will be printed on the ticket so the ticket is not transferable. If you love so much with Wat and Khmer history one day is not enough, you should buy the 3 day pass ticket.

I liked it better than Angkor Wat. Its easier to get around. Spectacular to see what they created in the mid 1200s. You can see how they cut the temples out of the Jungle with the trees still winding around the temples.
Go early. We had a peaceful visit and were the only tourists here for an hour, so worth getting to Anghor Tom by 7am. Amazing to walk round this magical place all on your own :-)

Huge complex worthy of exploration. Angkor Thom consists of multiple sites that can easily take up an entire day to explore. From tall towers, to ancient his and hers swimming pools, it is mind blowing. It is also a great place to take pictures, and a wide angle lens will be your best friend.

Thom Thom. Loved the architecture lots of strairs be prepared for climbing over ruins. Another amazing temple. Toilets are not very convenient to most of the temples.Taketoilet paper with you everywhere you go.

Ancient city from the legend. Angkor Thom is actually the best remained city of ancient civilization of khmers. It gives opportuniny to roam between ancient ruins and imagine the life of million people who lived and died under the rule of khmer empire. Gorgeous, picturesque, interesting, mysterious.

Well worth the visit!. You have to go and see this. This is overlooked by many due to time constraints, but it is a must. Walking through and seeing all the temples, the faces, the trees and all is just fantastical.
Elephant ride. Booked the elephant ride around Angkor Thom through out travel agent and it lasted for 15 minutes and cost a considerable amount. Angkor Thom itself was exceptional.

Very nice, but busy.. We bought the seven day pass and stayed in Siem Reap for 8 days and nights in January 2015. Hire a tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap anywhere near the pub street or market and keep your wits about you. A tuk-tuk driver will drive you to the furthest wats from Siem Reap, wait for an hour or so, and then drive you to another wat or back to town for about 8 bucks. If your hotel calls the tuk-tuk, expect to pay $20 or $15. If you flag a Tuk-tuk at the market, expect to be asked for $15 and settle for $8 or $10. If you show up at the same time as a bunch of tour buses from Korea, just tell your tuk-tuk driver to head for another nearby wat and come back later. If you see a gaggle of middle-aged women dressed like multi-coloured incarnations of Sailor Moon, run, don't walk. We visited Angkor Thom twice during the week, hoping to catch it at a lull between the swells and found it over-populated both times.

Wonderful, ancient Angkor Thom. Visited Angkor Thom which was the centrepiece of the ancient city of Bayon with 54 towers decorated with more than 200 smiling faces ! While there, why not visit the Royal Enclosure Phimeanakas, Ta Prohm Temple and Forrest Temple and the Terrace of Elephants and the Terrace of Leper Kings. To get the 'full tour' go with a reputable guide! I enjoyed lunch near Angkor Wat which is about 6klms from Siem Reap down town. If you can wait, there is a 7pm Temple and surrounds sunset view tour, but by this time, we had enjoyed a full day of touring ! Time to head back to our hotel...It was extremely hot in October..

A place not to be miss. One of the three must visit sites of historical ruins in Siem Reap. The other two are of course Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple. They are all within a short ride from each other. Would highly recommend to hire a guide as the visit would be more meaningful viewing the place with a commentary. A good guide would give you much better insights.A note here is to use the rest room when you can before you proceed on your walking tour as the next one is on the other side of the complex. Rest rooms points are not plenty here.

Interesting. The name is a bit confusing: within this area you actually have the Bayon and other temples like the Baphuon and the Terrace of the elephants and the terrace of the Leper King.The Baphuon, 5min walk from Bayon is nice but clearly a big notch below Bayon: however the access through the paved walkway is impressive and very nice to look at from the top. Beware you need to wear long pants ( below knees) to access it as well as Angkor Wat.The nearby 2 terraces (the elephants an deeper kings) are nice but not out of this world.However do stop at the gates especially beautiful North gate( from Angkor Wat) with the statues on each side> gorgeous in the mid afternoon sunlight. Around 2 hours required.

Excellent Complex. Many things to do in this place. Not only a place to bring you back to the ancient time but also a place to WOW and WONDER. How could people in the ancient time could do it? Built such amazing wonder.
Fantastic. Its really an amazing temple, sooo fantastic that you cant believe it,you can just wonder how this place looked for about 800 years ago,, my second time here but still amazing

EXCELLENT MONUMENT. One of the Khmer architectural excellence is reflected here in its gigantic face towers and causeways of the gates,with the Bayon at its center,was built in late 12c during the reign of Jaya varman vII and successors.Buddha statues inside at many places, Four headed figure (Some say it represents king and others say its Brahma, Four headed Hindu God of creation) at many places really worth visiting. there is ancient SIVA LINGA not to be missed. We can spend hours here to appreciate the Khmer architecture.Its in dilapidated condition and under renovation. WE MUST PRESERVE IT FOR OUR FUTURE GENERATION.
Great. One of the Big 3 and is another fantastic example of the architecture of the time. Very interesting.

Buddha, elephants, demons and devas - what else do you need. As well as the marvelous Bayon with its 256 giant faces, there is a treasure trove of excellent architecture to see. I really enjoyed the Terrace of the Elephants and the Leper King - so many fine details. The grand causeways, moats and gates lead you through to adventures at every turn. Keep your eyes in and try to spot the giant reclining Buddha forming one whole temple wall.A amgical moment
Another wonder, Angkor is top. Impressed, impressed, impressed,… This is the trip double worth. Everyone should visit Angkor..Just book your flight and go

Angkor Thom. I was mesmerised when I reached this place a few days back. You can not imagine that it is about 900 years old. Of course part of the temple has crumpled. It was a long walk though. We were very tired by the end of looking at the whole temple.

What a wat!!!. Angkor Thom on the wat circuit shouldn't be overshadowed by Angkor Wat. We were tired and almost passed Angkor Thom up. Glad we didn't. Each wat is worth seeing for its archaeological feat.

Anghor elephants.. We had an elephant ride these are majestic creatures strongly recommend this to anyone who wants to experience the gentleness of these animals. Once again the history of this whole area is incredible, the people are so obliging and go out of their way to please. Magical place!
superb. Excellent big site with lots to see and you should allow 2 hours to do it justice. Completely lived up to our expectations
Great Capital City. The capital city of Angkor era, so great place for relaxing and have looked, was perfected. something is better, people are so friendly.

The biggest temple district of Angkor. The huge Angkor Thom area is a must see while in Siem Reap... you should not miss the Bayon of course, but also the Gates to the Angkor Thom, the Elephan Terrace and the Leper King Terrace should not be missed.

Phenomenal! But Overridden With Tourists.. A definite must see. The temples and ruins are amazing. The details are incredible. The only thing that prevented me from giving five stars was the overwhelming crowds. There are areas where it is bumper-to-bumper people; making it very tough to get a good photo, let alone walk. The administrative organization that runs this place needs to hire someone (Disney?) to help deal with crowd control. I'd have been happy to pay more (a one day pass is $20) to get a little more exclusivity. Machu Picchu limits visitor numbers. Maybe they should do the same here. I don't want this to turn you off from coming. It is definitely a place you want to see. Just be forewarned about the crowds so you are not surprised.

Excellent site with multiple temples/ruins. Angkor Thom provides so much to see besides the beautiful Bayon. Definitely plan to spend 2+ hours looking over the various temples and other structures. Some to have dress codes that require longer shorts and that shoulders are covered.

You really get the big picture here.. Angkor Thom is very close to Angkor Wat, and in my opinion it really displays the essence of how these temples were built and what the symbols of the statues mean. We entered one gate and an incredible world of differing temples was contained within the walls of this place including the Elephant Terraces, and different symbolic temples. We rode Elephants here, a lovely experience and something that really evokes the feeling of what it must have been like living like royalty here! All that is contained with in the decorated walls of Angkor Thom were quite beautiful and worth a day of exploration. Don't miss this.

Huge, ancient, amazing!. This is one of the bigger temples with smaller ones around the precinct. Love the ancient architecture and most of them are conserved pretty well. Must visit other than the Angkor Wat.

Great First Site. Our tour guide took us to Angkor Thom first to help us avoid crowds at Angkor Wat later. There is a ton to see within Angkor Thom! As you enter the southern gate, appreciate the gods on the left and the demons on the right and the fact that many of them have been restored so we can still see them (they're a lighter color)

Fascinating and Beautiful City. Angkor Thom held true to its' name as being the Great City - the last and most enduring capital of the Khmer Empire. Angkor Thom was established in the late 12th century or early 13th century as the capital of Jayavarman VII's empire. Angkor Thom was a fortified city that covers an area of 10 square kilometers. The entire area was surrounded by a wall in the shape of a large square with four gateways and wide moats. The Bayon Temple (perhaps my favorite temple we visited while in Siem Reap) lies in the middle of the Great City.Prior to making it to the Bayon Temple, we made a quick stop to admire the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leper Kings within the Angkor Thom. These terraces were once the venue for public ceremonies and parades. The palace of the King at the time was immediately across from the Terrace of Elephants, but the structure of the palace no longer exists. Practically across from the Terraces was the Baphuon, Royal Enclosure and Phimeanaka.The Bayon Temple (the temple with all of the faces), located in the center of Angkor Thom, was built during the same time period as the Elephant Terraces, and is one of the most popular and compelling.As we exited Angkor Thom, we passed through one of the five entry/exit gates. I believe it was the south gate. The architecture of the gate was impressive and stunning. Through the gate was a causeway that extended approximately 50 meters across a moat. On either side of the causeway were railings decorated with 54 stone figures on each side. One side was a series a 54 stone asuras (demon gods) statues, and the other side was a series of 54 devas (guardian gods). Each side was holding part of a giant naga (serpent) and pulling it in opposite directions. According to the Hindu myth, the body of the snake is wrapped around the central mountain, Mt. Meru, with the asuras and devas pulling on its' tail in opposite direction. As the asuras and devas continued to pull on the snake in opposing directions, the ocean began to churn, and, as the alternating continued, the ocean was "milked" and the earth and cosmos were formed anew. Mt. Meru is located in Tanzania in close proximity to Mt. Kilimanjaro that Michael and I saw often during our climb to the summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro at 19,345 ft the year prior. It is believed that the central Mr. Meru corresponds to the Bayon temple, since the Bayon temple is located in the dead center of the site.Some of the heads of the demons and gods along the railway had been restored, which was noticeable because they were white. Overtime, the white turns black like the original structure and it will be difficult to notice which is new and which is original. Parts of the statues' noses or ears or other parts were purposely broken off to make them resemble their older counterparts once the white stone turns black.
Angkor Thom:. Our first temple visit; it just blows you away!Visit in the afternoon and you'll get fantastic photos.

Huge ancient city. Hard to imagine this walled complex (that includes the Bayon Temple in the center) was a city filled with wooden houses and home to a thousands of people. Engineering marvel and artistic triumph.

Wonderful. One of the most impressive archeological sites anywhere in the World - simply amazing. We had a brilliant guide who took us through the site starting at the exit so we missed most of the crowds.

Great visit, the capital city of Angkor. This place is a must have if you go to Angkor, the diversity of the constructions and temples is amazing and in many ways more accessible than Angkor Wat to imagine the full size and scope of the constructions
Stunning. Quieter than the Angkor Wat complex our guide took us in through an ancient gate and we encountered very few other visitors. One of the most amazing places i have ever seen.

It's like stepping back in time. Very well preserved and maintained temples.
Be sure to have good walking shoes and water with you. It's hot and there is a fair amount of walking to be done.
amazing. we traveled here after angkor wat.. i really did not think anything could be as beautiful but i was wrong....the trees are growing out of the temples. its breath taking and a true gem
Unique. Must be extra careful as you could see those stones in some part were collapsed and get yourself ready for more awesome pictures!
Just simply Great. Another fantastic temple it is just amazing what they built and how impressive the structures are another must see

Don't Skip This. While not as famous as Angkor Wat, I found this to be just as enjoyable, with lots of fascinating rock carvings. Wear good shoes for scrambling up uneven rock stairs. This is quite a large area so you will either be walking a lot, or you need a car or some transportation if you plan to see everything.

Impressive entrance and surroundings. All the temples are something not to forget, but this one has a distictive entrance and surroundings. You will get impressed by the grandiosity of this temple, that you should include in your package. May I suggest Thom, Prohm, Wat, Banteay Srei for your baseline temples not to miss? You get to know different types and will not regret.
How many heads are there?. Amazing temple with a 'don't miss' central circular shrine with many passageways. The wall carvings near the entrance are well worth spending time looking at.
Awesome.. Go to the museum first. To get the history of the area. Without that base you might be lost and might not understand the historical significance. Worthwhile.

Should be better known than Angkor Wat. Angkor = grand / big, and Thom = city. This was the royal city. Angkor Wat may be the largest temple, but Angkor Thom is where you learn more about the Khmer history, while strolling along the different smaller temples. Bayon is the main temple in Angkor Thom, and it is magnificent by itself.

Beautiful city. This is not actually a temple, but a city that contains temples. The main temple in Angkor Thom is the Bayon temple which is quite popular. A lot of the temples are under restoration so it can be a bit difficult to fully appreciate their magnificence. However I would still recommend visiting Angkor Thom when visiting the archaeological park.
Wonderful!. Just like Angkor Wat, this place is very historic with many ancient statues & carvings. Very well kept place. Drinks & foods are available.

Better than Angkor Wat!. While most people vsit Ankgor Wat and the temple in the jungle this place is not to be missed. Have your tuk tuk driver go around the ring road first to get a view of the entire thing. Then ask to be taken to the washroom before proceeding on foot. There are no washrooms on site and it is very far away. Also buy water before going in. finally ask to be taken to the large gate with beautiful carvings and a calm lake surrounding it.

Truly a city. You need to pause, close your eyes and imagine the hundreds of thousands of people who lived in these nine square kilometers in the heyday of the Khmer empire, crowded into long-gone wooden building of all shapes and sizes. The stone temples may remain but in a moment of quiet the echoes of the people who built and serviced them can be felt just as powerfully.

Wow wow!. We only visited three temples here (first Ankor Wat, second Ankor Thom, and third Ta Prohm). Viewing them in this order, in our opinion, was one being better than the next, thus ending with the best one. Visit the park for a day or week. Up to you. Lot's to explore but after a while you will be "templed out", so pace yourself. Rent a private car as well. Distances between temples is too far to walk in the heat (and the air con is very nice). The dirt roads also make it a little challenging (dusty or mud depending on season).
Worth the Visit. After seeing Angkor Wat this is a great follow-up. It was truly amazing to see the size and scope of the temple complex.
Quite a monument. Always overlooked because it is so close to Angkor Wat, but just as beautiful and worth the trip to visit.
Beautiful. This temple is gorgeous and definitely worth a visit. We spent half the day here and half the day at Angkor Wat- make sure you get an English-speaking guide. A must-see for Cambodia.

Spectacular temples. This was the first group of temples we went to see, and in many ways it was more spectacular than Ankor Wat. Bring good walking shoes because the visitors trail can be quite long, and there are many steps to climb. Don't take too many photos because they will never do the place justice. Focus on seeing it with your own eyes. Spot the reclining Buddha if you can!

Absolutely Stunning. Angkor Thom is only a short ride further up the road from Angkor Wat, and it's much quieter. There are still plenty of tourists, but as the smaller, less famous sister to the Wat, Thom is a little less populated. The towers, carvings and giant faces are stunning. If you keep your eyes open, there is so much to be seen here, it's amazing what you can find. There are many purveyors of cheap guide books, postcards, magnets and so on hanging around the entrance, and the guide book sellers can actually be found on the grounds. Just be polite and firm if you don't actually want to buy anything.Be aware that it is extremely hot at Angkor Thom and there's not much in the way of shade unless you're actually inside the main building. There are also monkeys on the site, so watch out for them as well. I didn't hire a guide, because I tend to spend forty minutes doing a drawing when I visit temples, but they are available, and I heard a myriad languages being spoken, so pretty much everyone should be able to find a guide who speaks their tongue.Absolutely worth the visit.

Definitely must-see. Angkor Thom is an ancient city - you have to visit it when you go to Siem Reap. But then again, I am sure that those who go to Siem Reap go there to visit Angkor Thom.Inside Angkor Thom, one can find the following temples - Bayon, Phimeanakas, Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Prah Palilay, Tep Pranam and Prasat Suor Prat.So yes, it is definitely worth the visit. Just being there brings you back to the time when Angkor was a great city and you can almost imagine how things were as you walk around Angkor Thom.

The Great City or Angkor Thom. I liked this much more than Angkor Wat. Somehow the face temple towers spoke to me. I spent a great deal of time exploring this large area and especially the bayon temple. Even the access road with the Samudra Manthan carvings on either side bordered by the moat are spectacular.
Brilliant!. With its stone faces and smaller crowds, we actually preferred this to the madness of Angkor Wat - very hot, though, so take lots of sunscreen and plenty water. Loved it!

Simply stunning. I live close to a world heritage centre in the UK and it can not complete with this place, simply stunning. The rule of thumb is temples are all the same, simply not true, so much variation, so much history, you must go
Quite serene. I enjoyed Angkor Thom as much as Angkor Wat, it is not quite so busy and more natural, with not so much restoration.

May be better than Angkor Wat. Wonderful entry causeway lined with good and evil statues pulling on snake in symbolic depiction of struggle of man. Main ruins are well excavated and preserved. Large Buddha reliefs are impressive. Less overwhelmed by crowds so go here if Wat is crowded.
Amazing. Great to see up personal. Very busy with many bus loads of tourists.. Get a guide as they will explain more than you except

Impressive. Clear to see why most people come away from Siem Reap realizing that there is more to see than Angkor Wat. Along with temple experiences like Banteay Srei and Beng Melea Angkor Thom is a "must see."

Amazing Temple. One of the coolest there. Really cool temple, awesome view. Just be careful when walking, I sprained my ankle because of the ditches around the temple. Regardless really really awesome temple to visit. Def recommend
Beautiful Bayon. this cluster of temples were very beautiful, each with its unique characteristics. The bayon was beautiful with 4-sided face. I was so blown away by the architecture.

big multi temple complex. Angkor Thom is actually 10+ temples. After visiting Bayon, walk north on the path through the woods and you can see a lot of great temples. We did so around 8am and there were not many people at all.

Amazingly Stunning. If you don't have a tour guide it's ok. I didn't have one but there are a bunch of local Cambodian "boys" waiting for the opportunity to share with you the history and background of this place (all for a decent tip). It was perfect. He showed me some good places to take pictures. Although his English wasn't the best it was good enough for me.

A day on this alone. Another mind-boggling day!! The craftsmanship, the complexity, the ambitions. The moats are all man-made. Puts stonehenge, the pyramids and the cathedrals to shame. Should be on everyone's bucket list.

Very impressive. A vast ancient city complex of the earstwhile rulers of Cambodia.Go with a good guide who can explain the historical aspects of the various locations and structures inside this huge complex.

Fabulous place to vist. The history wrapped up in this place, and the fact that it once functioned as a whole city within itself is just amazing. You get a sense of the history from the very entrance, with the Buddhas' heads, and you see where they were removed by the Vietnamese Army - many of them have been reinstated. The whole place has left a really lasting impression on me. I will never forget it and have some amazing photos to remember it by. I managed to get pictures with no other people in them so they look amazing, but that was all about patience and perseverance as it really was jam packed full of tourists. Beautiful and should definitely be on everyone's bucket list.

This is a must see. We travelled by tuk tuk and loved this temple. We found a English speaking guide which gave us great places for photos and a great outline of the history of the temple. We loved the trees growing over the temple and the elephants face. Well worth the time to visit.

Beautifully imposing.... Angkor Thom - the Great City (at the height of its power and wealth supporting some 1 million people) is beautifully imposing with its 5 monumental gates (entered by causeway over a moat) and flanked by 54 huge demon statues and 54 gods!Less busy than Angkor Wat itself :-)

Beatiful Gate.. In the morning lots of car were block at this gate as the entrance is narrow and most of the tourists were taking photos.The gate is beautiful and the sculpture on this side of the gate have mostly head intact.The Victory gate itself is beautiful but most of the sculpture were headless.

Better than Angkor Wat. I personally like this temple better than Angkor Wat. It's smaller and less crowded, and for some reason feels more authentic and peaceful. I took so many photos here, I was simply taken aback by the beauty of it. A must do if in Cambodia.
My favourite site we visited on this magical day!. This was a great place to visit & my favourite as we beat the crowds & had a chance to savour the atmosphere without all the tour groups.
Favorite. Our favorite part of Siemp Riep. The temple's are incredible and the bridge entrance to this one was fantastic. One of the highlights of Cambodia.
Worth a look.. Angkor wat was far too big for me. Angkor thom was a shorter trip but still gives you a feel for Khmer architecture. I would do Angkor thom BEFORE doing Angkor wat.

Superb!. Of the three temples we visited (Angkor Wat, the Tomb Raider Temple ,and Angkor Thom) this was one of my favorites. You only need a half hour here as it is not so busy, but there is places to explore and many photos to take here! If you have a group of you, sit down on the steps in front and have each person stare out in different directions for a unique shot!
Better than Angkor Wat.... I prefered this one to the Angkor Wat. Less crowded, more charming, and you get to climb the very steep stairs, thus more exciting and explorative.

Angkor Thom. Enjoying the different temples and temple carvings at Angkor Thom is mindboggling to say the least. This is in the vicinity of Angkor Wat and,a must if you are in this region. Just walking up to the Angkor Thom is very exciting and you walk thru a beautiful forest of different kinds of tall trees. It's very serene and historic

The best temple in Angkor. This is amazing. The many craved faces of the temple need to be seen to really appreciate this place. Try to go early morning before too many large tour groups arrive. This is a really special place.
One of the best 3. My top 3, I love this site. The entrance gate is beautiful, so take a lot of pic here. This site is my favourite in term of artistic, so much details and craftsmanship.
Great temple.... A must see if visiting Angkor Wat region, the area has many temples but make sure you see this one as well...

Fantastic. This was an unexpected surprise and an absolute delight. I enjoyed Angkor Wat but I loved this group of temples, I liked the fact that they were not as busy but also there were corners you could disappear into and really feel the tranquility of the surroundings. I particular;y enjoyed walking through the the forest and finding temple and temple. Most enjoyable afternoon. I would highly recommend it. The family aslo enjoyed it.
Amazing!. Amazing towers with 'Happy Buddha' carved reliefs facing in all four directions. Stunning stone bas-reliefs all over the site. Less crowded and more atmospheric than Angkor Wat.

temples temples temples. well this is why people come here but seriously over temples by the time we left. some were amazing yet the heavy earth moving equipment spoilt it a bit. iknow they have to do maintanence but it did spoil the atmosphere. so many people visiting the temples you could not get a good photo without heaps of people in it. go at sunrise or sunset for great pics.costs a lot to get in and there are heaps cheaper less known places south of siem reap. every time you climb up a stair case to the top of something there will be someone up there asking you for money. there are some spots they wont let you in if you are not dressed accordingly. sleeves covering your shoulders and legs covered.
great spot. place to be! go there and enjoy the big temple! If you book in the city, compare the price, big gap!

Make Sure this one is on Your List. There are ample temple sites that are all must-see's around Siem Reap, make sure this one makes it to your list, it is spectacular and the carvings make for great photo's. If you can swing a private guide with a car you'll have no problem making it to several sites in one day.
great temples.... lovely temples. it is a worthy visit, visited 3 times and each times always felt different but good different.

Angkor Thom. A visit to Angkor Thom is a must for visitors to Cambodia, besides off couse visiting Angkor Wat. It was a memorable tour of the ancient temples in Siem Reap. Our family of 6 benefited by using the services of a travel agent that saved us lots of time and energy. The travel agent's tour guide during our 5D4N in Phnom Penh and Siem Reap, Mr Yusoff Akob was very friendly. He speaks our mother toungue (Malay) apart from English. Took us to the right places of interest with no fuss. Although the 7 hr trip from Phnom Penh to Siem Reap by van on not-so-good road (dust road under construction for about 200km of total 350km) was tiring, but was an opportunity to see the countryside with several stops. Unless visitors wish to see the the countryside, it is advisible to fly from Phnom Penh to Siem Reap or vice versa. Anyway, the trip to Cambodia was wonderful. The people are friendly. Kudos to Cambodia.

Beautiful. We started with this temple, which had beautiful lookout points and some steep rock climbs. The views were fantastic. By starting here, we avoided some of the crowds, but still, go very early.

Even Nicer than Angkor Wat. I like this place better than Angkor Wat. The carvings are more details and it consists of many different temples. I'm very impressed that it's still in pretty good condition.

Stunning and mystical. An exceptional temple from what seams surpasses history. You relive history as you visit all the Temple's in Siem Reap. One is more exceptional than the others, depending on your perspective. Not to be missed!

Temple of Doom. My wife and I first visited Angkor Thom nearly 13 years ago before any restoration work had begun. It was a great adventure climbing over, under and in between the hugh blocks of fallen masonry and the entangled roots of the giant fig trees. Now visitors are restricted to board walks. While this is probably a lot safer, much of the romance and adventure has disappeared.By the way, Angkor Thom is better known as The Temple of Doom, made famous by the Lara Croft movie.

Beautiful Palace Only Eclipsed By Bayon And Angkor Wat.. Simplistic design and majestic setting dominates the entire palace compound. Interesting ancient trees located in the vicinity of the palace should keep most tourist busy. Great location to spend some time and savor the local food stalls located there.
Majectic but sad.. Angkor Thom represents the beginning of the end of the Khmer empire and it is sad to see that aiming for peace actually led the defeat. See the site with a good guide.
Angkor Thom was my favorite. This temple was my favorite because of the sculptures and layout. We did this after Angkor Wat and this site, although not known as Angkor Wat, doesn't disappoint.

Huge Area; Must See. Angkor Thom is huge and requires lots of walking on uneven ground and climbing up steep steps. I enjoyed my visit and think it should be on every Siem Reap itinerary. I would definitely recommend sunscreen, deet insect repellent, water, and good walking shoes.

The Search for Enlightenment Part 2. Angkor Thom City. We started our search for enlightenment with a visit to Angkor Thom. Because of unfamiliarity with the Khmer names, it could be confusing and easy to interchange names of attractions. There are throngs of tourists in the area. Tourists also have to endure humid temperatures during their visit.Angkor Thom is a city. It is the former capital of Cambodia. Inside the ancient city are various temples with Bayon as the most prominent. A good place to take a picture before entering the South gate of Angkor Thom city is the causeway or bridge that spans the moat in front of each tower. These have a row of devas on the left and asuras on the right, each row holding a naga in the attitude of a tug-of-war. A good guide is truly helpful. But it might be difficult to comprehend because of the crowd and heat. So it might be better to do some reading beforehand.

Huge temple in serene surroundings. Angkor Thom was built in the Bayon style with the entrance marked by rows of demons (on right) and heroes (on the left). The faces of Prasat Bayon and the Terrace of Elephants are great sights to behold!

Awesome angkor thom. Built in the ninth century ad as a capital for cambodia and abandoned for reasons unknown.angkor thom still captivates visitors with its stark majesty.four gates ornately carved.each gate has an elaborately carved walkway flanked by huge nagas on each side and then you have devas on one side and asuras on the other.eternal celestial guardians.you walk in through the gates and you come into a complex of temples built centuries ago and you are lost in wonder at the labour and effort which had gone into building the whole complex.awesome.truly a world heritage site.

Stay away from Elephant rides at the Park.. I was at the park yesterday. And had seen with my own eye how these elephants are treated.The Mahoot had a stick with a large nail in the end and hit her in the head to move besides a hooks. We all gasped the Mahoot gave us a dirty look like saying so what.They look so mistreated blankeyes, hungry. No water.All about money here.If you love Elephants stay away from this attraction. It's sub human slave labor.I walked away crying! So disgusting.Elephants have bones on top of there back not made to be ridden like a horse.They use them till they break down. They buy another'.
Awesome. The angkor thom complex is huge and contains many sets of ruins. It is definitely at the top of the list of ruins to see if you are limited by time in the park.

Walking is good for the heart!. Seriously, if I can choose our tour, I would have chosen this as our first destination. This was last on our list and we were probably exhausted. I did not enjoyed much since my foot were aching. I should have stayed on the entrance because the view was fantastic rather than the walking tour. But I recommend this place simply because it was beautiful.
Hire a guide. There are so many hidden treasures you miss without a guide. Don't get stuck like I did with no extra camera battery

Scramble Away!. This was our favorite temple that we visited. It is large, unregulated, and surrounded by more and more unregulated ruins, and has easy elephant rides right on the property. We started with an elephant ride around the temple, which our kids loved, and we are probably in about 800 photos from other tourists. The driver made a whistle out of a leaf and played fun songs. The back of the elephant drivers' shirts has a little pocket for tips , so take a couple bucks for that. You can also buy pineapples to feed the elephants and the kids enjoyed that almost as much as the actual ride.This temple was the best suited for letting the kids lead us around wherever they wanted to go. It's enough like a maze that they had a blast, and there are plenty of places you can climb up that are just adventurous enough to make mom nervous and dad laugh.Pack your own water, because it wasn't available for purchase around the first three sets of ruins we saw at this site, and we were dying for a drop of water by the time we found the folks selling it.Definitely make time for this one-it was the best.
My least favourite there. Don't get me wrong: it is very very good, just if there is one you need to skip I would chose that one as the other 3 I did were simply fantastic
Trip of a lifetime. December is perfect to travel here. Not too hot and a light breeze in the air for added comfort.Get a guide. Without a guide you'll miss out in so much interesting stuff.
Have to see. Angkor Thom means in ancient Khmer "Great City". And this is the another ancient places in Siem Reap have to see and visit

Worth a half day of your time. Initially I was rather confused as to how the temples were structured (especially since Bayon has got a separate mention in TA when it technically belongs to the Angkor Thom group of temples).I spent a lot of time here and one of my favorite temples was the Baphuon temple, it's a steep walk up the stairs (as it is with all the other temples) but the view above is great and it was fairly quiet when I was there (early afternoon). Everyone will have their favorites and perhaps why I like Baphuon is because it's fairly quieter than it's neighbour Bayon.

Breath taking. A must see, photos we have seen do not meet the real place. A guide made all the difference. We used Trails of Indochina, the best. We avoided the crowds and had great photo ops. A bit of walking.

Nice walk. Great place for a nice walk from terrace of elephants till the bayon temple. Shady place but may need long time to venture to all places. Make sure you have good shoes to walk around as the ground is not even. Just make sure you go to toilet first before visiting any temple. Toilets are scarce around there, Only available at certain stops and it is free for tourist.
A must !. Amazing site you can't come to Cambodia and miss this! We went by bikes and the whole family loved it .

Once the World's Biggest City. 750 years ago, at the height of the Angkorian Empire, this was the world's biggest city, a perfect square 2 miles by 2 miles, with one million inhabitants within and around its walls. What remains is still magnificent.
Ok ok...... if you have time to go around and see the whole place, definitely do it. Best is to just get your tuk-tuk driver to drive around the whole place

angkor wat is so very great but nice to see.. we stay for one day this time in angkor wat. it was our second visiting.
it is so very great. to see all you must go 1 week there.

The LAST angkor. Angkor Thom is the last Angkor in Siem Reap. It was originally build for the Buddhism element and until the last king very much into Hinduism and some of the statues and art on the wall has been destroyed and modified into Hinduism influenced. It is a beautiful temple and can comparable with Angkor Wat. There are many tourist spots where you can take photo as if you are touching the Buddha statue's nose with your nose.
One of the "must go" besides Angkor Wat. If you do not have the time to cover enough, this 1 temple will do it all. Personally I would recommend it over Angkor Wat
khmer temple..... the first khmer temple that we visited. it just like a very big city which surrounding by various type of temple....

Best temple. In ny opinion this is the coolast and greatest temple in all siem reap! Will all the faces and buildings! Just great!! One downside is that there were people trying to Scam you there ( donate to children-schools )

Go the west gate!. we had a guide and entered via the west gate. far from the tourist crowd and its the only gate still standing . a pleasant walk then to Ta Prohm amongst the tourists but via the back door. brilliant no less

Worth the visit for sure.. We traveled to the outside of Angkor Thom by Sam's Tuk Tuk which was a huge pleasure, meandering along the dusty road we felt like Agatha Christie must have felt on archaeological sites conjuring up her stories using local characters. Only access to Angkor Thom is by foot, easy walk, flat and not too far and certainly most people could manage the terrain (not sure about wheelchairs however.) This would be a great location for setting up a watercolor painting day.

Well worth visiting. This is a must see for anyone who like historical places and religious temples. One of the great things is you can walk up and touch everything- nothing is off limits. Definitely hang around for sunset and get a magic photo op

Absolutely wonderful. In many ways, this is better that Angkor Wat. The stone faces are majestic, and haunting, and you get a real feeling of the impact this place must have had. The entire complex is a must see in Cambodia.

Better than Angkor Wat. If you have one day in Siem Reap, Angkor Thom is the place to spend it. It's a lot less crowded than neighboring Angkor Wat and there are a number of ruins here. If you're seeking the sort of magical feeling of coming upon an ancient, ruined temple in the middle of the jungle, Angkor Thom is the place for you.

Not to miss!. This was my 2nd visit to Angkor Thom in 6 years, and I left again feeling that it was still my favorite set of ruins among all of them in the area, even over Angkor Wat. Though not as grand as its impressive neighbor, Angkor Thom felt more mysterious and intimate with all its intricate towers and carvings under numerous towering trees and their complex roots. Compared to Wat, there was also significantly fewer tourists on both my visits. Thanks to Mara Long (our licensed tour guide), he slipped us into some parts we wouldn’t have known of climbing or going into. I could only imagine what it must have been like for the ancients to have stepped into this architectural and artistic marvel.

The bayon temple in the Angkor Thom campus is a sight to see. This place is a 10 Square Kilometer gated city with a huge moat around it. The Bayon temple of 200 laughing Budda is a very unusual concept. Usually the sanctum santorium houses the Budda statue. Here every gopuram is made of 4 laughing Buddas.
Crowds by 9 am. Angelie Jolie heard in every language. Buy the 10 for $ post cards for pictures without a crowd but enjoy the beauty of the site.

Give yourself plenaty of time. This site is really sprawling and lovely with lots to see. We spent a full half day here and really enjoyed our time. Some of the area is in the jungle so it is nice to get in the shade for a time as it is quite hot there.

Incredible!. While many visitors will either begin or focus on Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm may actually be the better experience. The way the ancient temples are embraced by root systems is amazing. While we began our day doing sunrise at Angkor Wat, I wish instead we had begun at Ta Prohm and missed the sunrise crowds at Angkor Wat.
Again, a fantastic trip into the ancient world.. Again, no words to describe this excellent area of historic values. In fact, I may rate it higher than Angkor Wat.

Fantastic Site. Part of the Angkor Wat complex and worth a visit. You need a lot more time than you think to take it all in. Avoid the local sellers. The only way to deal with them is to totally ignore them and do not stop to look or touch their goods because you'll become surrounded.

Toomb Raiser Temple. There is just so much work to be done to make it a safe visit, like other temples, its a ruin and moving about must be very slow and very careful. Inside this and other temples you will find passages hindered by little Buddhist shrines. As we did not want to be part of their worship, looked for alternative paths which are easily spotted. Most tours go Ankor Wat, then Bayon and last Angkor Tom. To avoid the crowd see Angkor Tom before Bayon. You will still catch up with the masses at Bayon.
4-Face Temple. You will see the smile of this temple from any angles, It's very peaceful and relaxing. You will enjoy seeing the elephant walking around the temple and it's actually for ride.
The Tomb raider scene. a beautiful combination of nature and ancient building. you can blend it to the ruined with restoration still on going

One of the wonders of the world. We visited Angkor Thom after seeing Angkor Wat. It is equally impressive and well worth the taxi ride. We visited in rainy season and managed a bargain with a driver around midday. We arrived mid afternoon and were amazed. Its one of the wonders of the world.
What phenomenal carvings. It is still in the ruins shape, but gives an indication of its GRAND past.Looking at the huge and tall building with massive stones and trees was indeed remarkable.

The best and most interesting for photos. Great temple to visit in afternoon or early morning. Fantastic light with great photo angles.King Jayavaramen VII precided over the building of this magnificant Wat. Many well preserved reliefs and large quantity of sculptured heads.

Faces everywhere. Loved the south gate with its huge face and the monkeys who hang out there-just waiting for something to grab!.Angkor Thom means "great city" in Khmer , and it really must have been in its day . Amazing architecture, lots of lovely peaceful faces and Buddha-like images - well preserved from the 12th century. No matter wher you are you can turn and a face will be there watching you!Not as big or as well known as Angkor Wat, but just as beautiful..Take time to visit this too

A must see. Angkor gets a little monotonous after a while, but I would still recommend this site. I would recommend a guide, there are subtle details that we could learn about which you wouldn't see on your own necessarily.
Breathtaking. Visit it early morning or late afternoon to avoid the masses, got here at 5.00am , had the place to myself untill about 7.30, after 7.30 the masses arrived

A must in Siem Reap. Enormous city area. You wuill have to spend at least 2 days visiting the whole area. It is easy to get tuk tuk from Siem Reap city to get around Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. We paid $15 per day for the whole day including sun rise and sun set.

Bayon temple is part of this. We hired the tuk tuk that picked us up from the airport , If you are comfortable walking then he will take you to Angor Wat , Angor Tom ( Bayon Temple ) , Ta Prom and Banteay Srei all in one day , so you can complete them in a day pass ( $20 per day ) and the next day you can do Beng Mealea the next day . The tuk tuk rental for the first day was $39 and I think it is $ 40 to visit Beng Mealea . The price list for tuk tuk will be in the room or the font desk can provide it., if you are solo you have the option to take the mini bus etc .. check with the front desk.The name if my driver was Toluah and his number is 0886644479. I stayed close to Pub StreetWe had to leave early to see the sunset ( 5 am ) at angor wat , it will be crowded but I think you can miss this if you don't want a sun rise picture with the temple in backdrop , its mostly a photo event.However get there early say around 6 am before the crowds start.Read about the temple , may not need a guide
Another amazing temple. It starts to become repetitive, but there are soooo many stunning temples in Cambodia and this is another. One on the must do list for sure.

Fantastic site to visit. Amazing site to visit, it is fantastic. However, unfortunately not recommended for people with mobility difficulties. The site is vast and one has to go from one place to another to appreciate it all and there are plenty do steep steps to climb.

Wonder of Khmer civilisation and the world. Angkor Thom is a not just one place to visit but a large ancient city centre at the heart of the Angkor era Cambodian capital city. It takes a while to get used to its spread and nature of the structures and their styles.A good tourist guide would be helpful, especially if you do not know the history of Angkor era Cambodia and Hindu and Buddhist mythologies.Get a 3-day or 7-day pass the first time from the APSARA Foundation ticketing office on the Siem Reap - Angkor Wat road. This pass is valid at most of the Angkor sites including Angkor Thom.

Don't miss this temple. This is the last set of temples that we saw during our Cambodia trip and they were amazing. The 50+ towers with the 4 faces each make you feel as though you are in a different world.I suggest getting to this area as early as possible as it gets very crowded and many of the stairways are very steep. Some groups of toursit can be very pushy so watch your children, especially on the stairs.This is definitely a "don't miss" set of temples. Just FYI, children under 12 are free entrance into all of the temples. Adult tickets are $20 for a 1 day pass to all the temples in the area.

A magnificent collection of temples. This is an amazing temple complex that is very easy to get around - you can move from Bayon through a number of other sites very easily. Truly one of the wonders of the world - despite the very heavy tourist load.

Appreciated with a tour guide. We saw many tourists walking around without a guide. A guide makes it well worth the price. Our guide had walkie talkies and provided key and private stories and advised where the best photo opportunities could be had. He provided historical detail, not readily available. Without a guide, one temple can look very much like another, which they are not. We saw and heard guides speaking just about any common language, from Korean, Mandarin, Japanese, English, German, French, etc. This was also observed in other attractions.

Great City of Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom or the Great City has a most striking entrance with its 10km size protected by a great wall and moat. The temples are magnificent and the temple of Bayon was to my mind the highlight of my trip to Cambodia. A truly magnificent edifice with over 50 towers each with 4 faces of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara pointing to each compass point.
jia. A big temple for vishnu god , it means you must walk a lt but really great with lots of apsara different to angkor wat , really reccomend

Temple Circuit got very repetative. Might be good to get a guide. We opted not to have a guide and the temples eventually started to all seem the same. We had a detailed book from the hotel explaining them each, but it still left us feeling "Templed-out" at the end.

Best at early morning. Bayon, Baphuon, Ta Prohm - these are a must see. I actually enjoyed these more than I did Angkor Wat.
Tip: Best to visit here early in the morning when there is not much heat. You don't have a lot of cover at Bayon and Baphuon to shield from the sun.

Huge!. The temple is huge and contains other temples within. Restoration work is ongoing, so while the workers toil, enjoy the heat and keep hydrated. So much to see, but take a leisurely pace. A morning visit is cooler, but don't let the heat deter you.

Beautiful but crowded. We went here in the afternoon. The heat is intense and there are huge crowds. Kind of like Disney World at Spring Break. It is a beautiful site but go very early or later in the day.

Excellent. Not as busy as angkor watt. Definitely worth a visit if you have time. Angkor watt is definitely the pick but this is a relatively close second. Take an elephant ride around the grounds or watch the japanese carrying out restoration works.
Amazing!. Almost every inch of the walls is lined with the most intricate and skilled carvings. Highly educational and simply beautiful.

After Ankor Wat, visit Ankor Thom. ANkor Thom is after Ankor Wat the other important complex of Ankor ruins, and is one of the principal attractions for visitors, you can ride elephants early at the morning (before 10:30), it´s capital is Bayon that is also a must along with the terrace of the elephants. Bring a lot of water!
Just amazing. As spectacular as Angor Wat is, Angkor Thom is better. You will simply be breathless seeing all there is to see
So much to explore!. Buy a 3-day temple pass, and head beyond Angkor Wat and Bayon, as Angkor Thom has so much more to offer beyond this!

Just as great as the more well known wat. Not as famous but just as interesting and awe inspiring as Angkor Wat. We split part of out time here and found the detail as well as some of the monuments just as great. There are photo opportunities everywhere. Some of the small detailed carvings here really got me.

"Must-see temple". "Angkor Thommy is definitely worth the long walk even under the hot midday sun." It's the one grandiose temple you can't afford to miss. It shows the ancient Khmers, or whoever were responsible for building this temple, were truly amazing stone builders! How those ancient masons with their crude tools came about building this unique, intricate architectural masterpiece and all the other equally stunning temples of Angkor,still boggles the modern mind.

Fun to explore. The area of this temple is huge, as the largest element in the city. There's rubble everywhere, with exposed volcanic rock underneath the ornately carved stones. There are so many little walls, bridges, ramps and other temples surrounding the main one, you can spend hours here. Inside the main temple, at the top there is a shrine (need to take your shoes off to go in): above the shrine is a narrow shaft to the very top, where there are hundreds of wild bats, hanging, squeaking and flapping. Definitely recommend spending an afternoon here.
Great temple to visit. Not as packed as Angkor Wat, but still a can't miss attraction in Siem Reap. Be ready to walk though!

Amazing. The architecture on the temple is amazing. They call it the face temple because of all the faces everywhere. I took an elephant ride around the temple which I will never forget. Its a must see.

don't miss the elephant wall. I loved the elephant wall in particular. I can understand why there are so many loose trousers and blouses in the markets with elephants on them. The carvings with the three elephant heads are iconic.Its easy to transport your thoughts back a thousand years when the place was originally built. Don’t forget to take photos on the way out over the bridge towards Angkor Wat

Just Beautiful. Despite having many tourists walking about, Angkor Thom afforded me a quiet peace that I was expecting of the temple tour. Its entrance is imposing, yet gives the traveler a glimpse of the beauty that is to be seen in this ancient capital city. At the heart of Angkor Thom is the Bayon, which is exemplar of the impressive architectural style of the Khmer. I had so much fun walking around the complex, and the walk in between temples where trees were abundant. I would love to go there to explore it again, but next time I will bring a map.

The Great City. Beautiful crumbling ruins, towering trees, magnificent terraces....there is much more to Angkor Thom than a fleeting visit to Bayon. The site of the former city is pretty vast so a bicycle or tuk tuk is needed to explore fully. The Elephant Terrace walk leading up to the Terrace of the Leper King is beautiful but bring an umbrella or avoid the hottest part of the day if you wish to appreciate it fully as there is no shade along the way. We could have spent a whole day wandering around the area but were unfortunately short on time, however a couple of hours is enough to give you a good taster.
Special...... YES!!!!!. Really incredible. Just loved it here. Had a great local guide. Learnt so much about this beautiful place. Really so glad that we visited.

City in the Angkor Temple complex. Angkor Thom is an ancient city at the heart of the Angkor temple complex - you will need a ticket to visit the temple complex and we got one for US$40 each for admission on three days during the space of one week.We entered through one of the city gates, which you still drive through and saw something of a traffic jam when we arrived! Leading up to the gates you have on either side either the gods or the demons all pulling on a snake in a mythological scene. Once inside there are temples to visit plus the terrace of the Elephants. Several towers remain and nearby we observed some water buffalo. Definitely one site to take in during your tour.
It's more than just the Bayon and the Elephants Terrace. The whole Angkor Thom complex deserves some time and attention. The Baphuon with its reclining Buddha wall is a gem.

Unforgettable Place. Such An Amazing Place. I Love Every Part Of This Place. While I Was Visiting, There Was A Renovation Going On, It Somehow Couldn't Stop The Magic Of This place. Stunning Even Inside And Outside. Worthwhile To Visit And You'll Never Forget How Beautiful It is. Love it

Great complex. Along with Bayon and some other small temples it composes a sub complex inside the Angkor temples. The images you you get touch your heart for their beauty and history. No to miss it, of course!

Must see! So much inside. Angkor Thom was the capital city and it included some of our favorite sites. The Victory Gate / Way was one of our favorites. There are statues of demons on the left and statues of gods on the right, depicting the churning of the sea of milk and subsequent battle between the two. (The gods - the Devas - win). Very cool, especially the many faceted head on top of the Victory Gate. Bayon was very cool, as was Baphuon (a little further in). There are monkeys resting on the side of the road as you ride up to Bayon. If you don't bother them, they won't bother you. It's busy, but there is plenty of tree cover so it feels cooler. Also, there is so much to see on Angkor Thom that the tourists are more spread out. We recommend renting mountain bikes to go through Angkor Thom. It's cheap ($6 a day) and you can ride all the way through the gate down to Bayon, the Terrace of the Elephants, Baphuon etc. If you don't, you'll have to wait for your vehicle to make it through the gate and/or walk across and take a tuk tuk on the other side. You can bike your way around all of the temples but we especially appreciated having them in Angkor Thom!
Beautiful architecture and great views... Perhaps the most interesting . Just be prepared to walk . This was the capital of Jayavarman VII empire.
Beautiful ancient temple. Perillulous steps and plenty of them, not for the less than agile. This temple is much smaller than the mighty Angkor Wat and is even more impressive if that is possible.

Not to be missed. Make sure you leave enough time to visit this city and explore all the various sites within. It was even larger than Angkor Wat and one begins to appreciate how advanced the Khmer civilisation was back in the10th/11th centuries.
Huge. I liked the temple there and the Elephant Terrace and the 12 towers on the ground. A must see. It is a very big area to view many different structures.

Awesome!. Considering the construction techniques available in the 12th century, one has to be struck by the amount of work that went into not only constructing the temples and other structures in this site, but also the intricate carvings. Be prepared for lots of walking and climbing. Go early in the day. By 3pm, we found the heat and humidity exhausting.

Wearing away. This large city space is now quite devoid of its original buildings so you need a bit of imagination to fully appreciate it. The city walls and moat remain impressive as well as the 5 gates, albeit they are only shadows of their former glory. Same for the 2 terraces.

One of the most special places in the world to visit.. Here, in the middle of the jungle, where no restoration has taken place, stands the most spiritual place, where nature and buildings stand hand in hand and where the imagination can run riot at the naturalness of it all. Again, shame about the humans climbing all over it. Close your eyes, and then try and look above them!

Atmospheric. we did this tour with our own personal guide who was very knowledgable and pointed outsome very interesting things that we would have missed on our own. The carvings and sculptures are some of the best I have ever seen. Not suitable for people with disabilities or motor probles as the ground is very uneven and dangerous in parts.

My First Stop In This Historical Mosaic. First impressions - lives up to its billing as the eighth wonder of the world. Largest of the walled cities in the area, Angkor Thom's entrance is a story in itself - the struggle between the gods and demons played out on the bridge over the moat in the scowling icons on the right, and the smiling on the left. As you are crossing the bridge, reflect on the fact that all you see was created by hand.This was my first stop of the day - start early to avoid the heat - and the crowds were not excessive. Note that you need to buy a pass which must be presented as you travel from major temple to the next. Consider hiring a personal guide - know the best photo opps and offer historical perspective on whatever you may be viewing - around $40 US for the day.Once inside, bayon temple and baphoun are mandatory stops. Surprised that Cambodia allows tourists to climb on and over the ruins - eventually this will compromise the structures. That being said, might be wise to visit before anyone contemplates access restrictions.

Beats A/Wat. To most of our group this was more interesting and impressive than Angkor Wat particularly the wall carvings with the 4 faces. It was however very crowded and certain noisy fellow tourists detracted somewhat from the experience.
Fabulous setting. atmospheric and I believe the setting for tomb raider... I really must get round to watching that some time

Extraordinary!. Our Nat Geo around-the-world trip had already seen Angor Wat and Ta Prohm. Who knew yet another temple complex could confound us with its beauty and mystery. Our guide was a survivor of the Khmer Rouge whose hard-won serenity shone through his narrative of the history of his people. This was a deeply moving experience I hope someday to repeat. Truth be told we were here several years ago in February and I am just now reviewing this site--but I can't help but believe that it is remarkably the same.

Speechless - it has to be seen to be believed. Every temple at the Angkor Archaeological park really have different unique features! Love all the charming faces of Bayon smiling to me everywhere I visit it.

loved it. we loved it. we spent 5 hours here. at one point a guard gave us incense to do and we donated a dollar... then somehow he ended up taking us on a really long photoshoot- putting us in all these places and taking our photo with our camra (about 9 locations for like 15 munutes) it was sortof awkward and funny because we had no idea what was going on. after we figured we should tip him but he instead suckerd us into paying him 20usd for a silly police badge and a shirt button thing. the resteraunt we went to was expensive but when they saw me looking at all the menues for the other stalls they sayd they would take 2usd off our food and 1usd off our drink!
Marvelous Historical Place. It got too many congested temples complex with every where with big faces on top of the temples. Great stories sculptured on walls. Glorious temple of 1000 years old.

Surreal. In the hot, misty morning, it feels like you've stepped back in time. The stone work is remarkably well preserved. Not a fan of elephants being used for human entertainment, but they do give the impression of time travel in history.
History. Tricky for people with mobility issues but an experience of walking around such history that was only recently found by locals was humble.A must go to when in the area

Wish I could spend more time there.. Love the architecture, espicially at the Bayon temple, the center of Angkor Thom, which have many many pagodas and each one has 4 faces, giving me that there are always someone watching you. It was raining when I was there, creepy yet elegant.
big. This is a big temple , takes a while to walk it , has beautiful reliefs and apsara caevings , a top awesome site .

54 stone figures welcome you. This beautifully crafted ancient ruin is amazing. The figures on the bridge as you enter glare at you as a dare to enter - quite spectacular, and then you go through the South Gate to see the 12th century Bayon. Its central towers are decorated with extraordinary bas-reliefs, incorporating over 11,000 figures. The faces on the four sides of the pillars are striking, and worth a few photos! Climbing through the thick doorways and seeing the intricate set up of the temple is impressive. The figures on the walls are all different, and tell the story of the times. There are steps, and also a wooden step system to aid those less able to enter. Great historial place.

Tick it off.. If you don't know much about Angkor Thom, it's more of a cluster of temples than one specific temple. There are many places to see, stop for photos and to eat. A review of "Angkor Thom" might be a little unfair because of this so I'll keep it simple. Make sure you go to the four gates, even if that's all you "do" for Angkor Thom. On TripAdvisor anyway, all the separate temples in Angkor Thom have their own entry. The gates are actually quite impressive and there are good photo opportunities with the moat as a background.

Outstanding of all the temples. Better than what is advertised in the travel brouchures a unique experience which fulfilled our life long dreams of seeing even "knocked the socks off" my children (8 and 13yrs)
"The Great City" of the past. It covers an area of 9 square kilometers. It inhabits the faces of prasat Bayon, the terrace of the elephants, the terrace of the leper king and many other temples.

Peace of mind.. Excellent creation from our forefathers, though this is currently in ruins and being repaired, the whole time I was wondering, what a beautiful place wud it have been.Would definately visit again post restoration.
Beautifull. Beautifull the way the tree roots have wound their way and the rocks. Amazing the way every stone was placed.

Unbelievably Big. Leave yourself a lot of time for Angkor Thom because it of immense proportions and there is much to see. Even if there are a lot of other visitors, you can still lose yourself in it.
Ankor Thom. Fabulous site and ancient temples. Amazing the age of all of it. Catch sunrise or sunset - spectacular.
A must see. If you go to Angkor go to Angkor Thom-not that far away and worth the visit if you have a limited amount of time-skip the sunrise at Angkor Wat but still do both.

12 years on.. It was 12 years ago that I visited and "Tomb Raider" had just been released so everything was quite natural. Now due to vast number of visitors the site has been controlled to funnel you around, still a great place to visit.

okay. We temple-hopped so sometimes I don't remember the name of the temples where we went. I don't remember this one so much. I think this is one near the elephant terrace??
Really, the temples kind of looked the same after a while...

Jungle versus Sandstone. This is a reminder of the power of the jungle over ancient blocks of sandstone. Some of the tree roots have to be seen to be believed. Plus...the crowds were not as heavy as at Angkor Wat.
This is one of my favorite temples. Our advise is get here before the crowds so you have time to study and enjoy the temple. We went around 7 AM and it worked out fine.

Not to Be Missed. If you are in Siem Reap, there is absolutely no reason not to see Ankgor Thom. It is a large and fascinating complex. My suggestion is, just like nearby Angkor Wat, is prior to going, do a little reading and research on the history of this magnificent site, it will make your visit all that much more enjoyable and rewarding.Your admission ticket to Angkor Wat, $20 US, covers the admission to Angkor Thom.

Beautiful, but ridiculously crowded. Ankgor thom is a gorgeous complex. You enter through massive gates protected by rows and rows of gargoyles and khymer guard statues. Its an incredibly beautiful ruin and you can explore pretty much all of it - the view from the top is quite something!However, there were SO many people here it was a bit too much for us. Angkor Watt was busy, but nothing like this. Inside the ruin we could barely move for hundreds upon hundreds of travel companies herding their crowd of hungry irritable tourists around the place! Still an incredible site, with so much history and heritage, but spoilt a bit by the crowds. If you are pushed for time, you should still come here - but consider going through it at a quicker pace and getting to some of the smaller, less visited ruins

Awesome Angkor Thom!. Angkor Thom is an amazing complex. On entering, you will pass through any of the 4 gates with khmer guard statues carrying a naga flanking the sides. I love the face of Avalokiteshvara high up on the entrance pillars. This, to me, is what marks the beginning of an Angkor journey. Bayon and the other temples are inside. Picture taking is quite difficult in some busy gates... Worth the patience. I just love it. Awesome!

Beautiful and great for photo's. Angkor Thom has some of the more exceptional backdrops for photo's but the history of how everything around it was built, and why is equally amazing. Take the time to visit -- you will not be disappointed.
Go and see, now!. This is another great must see site. More ruined than Angkor Wat it remains a top spot in Cambodia. hot, humid and stunning, be prepared.
Yet another great temple. After reading about the history the Khmer people and knowing the significance of Angkor Thom as part of that history, was great to finally see it in real life.
Enormous. Cannot see this temple and surroundings in a day or even two. Probably my favorite, truly beautiful.

Another temple. Looking back is great and imagining what was appeals to us.
Again toilets are an issue so be prepared
Every temple is soo different. Great experience, although a bit crowded. Take your time, find your angle and get good shots. Make sure you explore all corners.

Adventure places to discover. Its like a huge jungle inside and you have to walk across the jungle to find each of temples. Each temples is very far-off and not easy to find. We got lost inside and spent 40 mins to find our way out.

Majestic temple. This temple is one of the most impressive temples we visited in Angkor. Many great photos opportunities. The buddha faces are majestic and impressive.
This is a temple not to be missed if you are visiting Angkor.
Very interesting gate. It's worth a visit to check out the ruins. The gate is a preview to the stunning Bayon temple. Try exploring the place by bicycle

Its not just one thing. Angkor Thom is not so much a temple, but rather a large complex containing many temples. Its difficult to rate the complex as a whole given that the experiences of the various components are varied.For example, I would go to Baphuon again, but would rather poke my eye out than go see the Elephant Terrace: both of which are in Angkor Thom.

ruined but historical. Angkor Thom is slightly less crowded than Angkor Wat, yet it still have their own charm. I found myself more enjoyable in this temple. Be careful if you travel with kids or elderly, there are lots n lots sharp stairs and its quite dangerous.

Surprisingly More Beautiful than Angkor Wat. I was pleasantly surprised to discover that Angkor Thom has a plethora of gorgeous sites across the massive expanse that is Angkor Thom. Bayon temple is certainly the highlight although there are other sites of interest within the walls. You could easily spend a whole day visiting all the sites in the Angkor Thom area. Make sure you bring sunscreen and water as there are many areas that are without shade.
jo. A real big temple , Buddha carvings and apsara , it is a cruciform temple , really awesome , a lot of people , would go early next time .

Still a great experiance. These temples are great ,to be still standing is remarkable.
So much history. We spent the complete day exploring the whole
Building . As I said these temples are Great.
