Good place to start your tpur.. We started at Angkor Tom and then saw Bayon Temple before finishing at Angkor Wat. Amazing carving in the stones and too much to see at the Angkor World Heritage site. .

Of course it is a 5!. The majesty and the grandeur have lived through the abandonment so very long ago. The architecture and the construction awes you as you look up to the towers and concentrate on the fine carvings. The hugeness is timed by the intricacy of the galleries. So beautiful.

Great complex. Containing the Bayon temple, the Angkor Thom complex is great. Loved the long walk round the grounds of Baphuon and Phimeanakas as well, these were really quiet and after the busy Angkor Wat and Bayon, its a nice chilled stroll to relax you!Watch out for anyone who says 'hello, where you from'. They won't let you go for ages and are trying to get you to buy/donate etc. Just make your excuses early and go. We encountered 3 guys on 3 separate occasions in the Phimeanakas grounds in a very short space of time.

Amazing.. While the Normans were building the White Tower at the Tower of London, on the other side of the world the Khmers were building the city of Ankor and the temples therein. What a difference.This is one of the four temples/temple complexes we visited and being here truly does transport you back in time. In general it is worth doing a bit of reading about the whole city, it's buildings and history; it helps you appreciate even more just how wonderful the whole area is and what a greta achivement building it was.
Mind blowing. To walk through the gates into another world is not to be missed. Be taken back in time to witness how life was. To see and wonder how these magnificence structures were built.

Crazy temple!. Loved this temple, the faces in the walls make this very unique and a must see, wasnt too busy so plenty of photo opportunities, there was a nun in there when we was there and she blessed us and gave us a bracelet, do not miss this place!
Awsome. Amazing four faces of tower of the temples are just incredible and carving on the wall of the temple. I have no word to describe enough about.

Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven.... Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven...Perfect scenic gate before entering Bayon and the elephant terrace, and the old angkor palace..
Fantastic. An awesome place to explore and marvel at. Would love to visit it again, this time taking more time to take in the majesty of it all.
Just as impressive as Angkor Wat.. I enjoyed visiting here as much as Angkor Wat. Best to visit before there and early in the day before it gets too hot.
Breath taking.... This is a huge place with lots of temples. You can easily get lost in this place. Really awesome! I would love to visit again and take more time to see this majestic compound.

What a city. Angkor Thom is the ancient city that houses Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple among many other remains of the ancient civilization that ultimately abandoned the area. Very impressive! We walked throughout many of the distinctive areas of Anglor Thom and found them all to be incredible.

Amazing architectural wonder. Visited Angkor Thom after Angkor Wat. Smaller temple and stairs to climb sometimes with loose stones. Gets quite cramped with all the tourists vying for the best photo. There are over 50 statues of the 4 face Buddha and areas of the temple have been destroyed when they tried to convert the Buddha images to Hindu gods. Apparently a week prior some tourist destroyed one of the Buddha statues and was arrested. Go visit before its all gone!
Better Than Angkor Wat. Big call I know but we enjoyed visiting this temple more than Angkor Wat. The towers with faces carved into the four sides were wonderful.
amazing... Like angkor wat, this place is stunning, although smaller than angkor wat i think it has more features to it, magnificent. There are elephants you can ride on too, i think it's 15 dollars.
Fabulous. Inspiring and together with Angkor Wat is a must see of Cambodia. Go with a guide is my recommendation

Don’t miss this beautiful temple complex. Another stunning very big temple complex beautiful, the scale of temples keep you puzzling how they build these temples in the old days. Again taking a tuk tuk with a guide for the day is definitely worth the money, without the explanation it’s just another ruin

Huge beautiful area. take the time and explore the whole area of Angkor Thom before going into Bayon! With it being so spread out, you rarely see other fellow tourists and you can really just sit down and take in the views and nature.
Serene Peaceful & Amazing. A quiet oasis and good shade opportunities as the sun can get scorching at times. Well worth the visit

Improved paths into it.. I noticed that in my second visit of a couple of weeks ago, versus eight years ago. Old temples and tree roots are one structure, and if either is modified, both will go. Let's keep it as it is, a witness to the grandeur of the old Khmer Empire !

Excellent. This is a place which needs no introduction and should be on the list for every traveller. Situated in the middle of a clear patch of land and surrounded by greenery on all sides, this beauty is breath taking. You have not visited Cambodia if you have not visited this place.
great place. What a place to visit, great place to take photos, outstanding history. this a fantastic visit and would go back again.
ho hum. same as Angkor wat.nothing left by many invaders.no artifacts,just the same rather boring architecture.

Go see it. Angkor Thom..think of the jungle trying to reclaim it's space. Ancient temple stonework interlaced with tree roots. It's got a different atmosphere to Angkor Wat so don't think that if you've seen Angkor Wat you've seen the best.

Amazing. Great temple to see, even after seeing Angkor Wat. This site is a bit more run down but just as good to see. Having a tour guide will help a lot as there is not much guiding you around; with a guide you will get stories and information which will make it more interesting.

Hire a bicycle in town and cycle out!. The temples are phenomenal, particularly Bayon. Walk down the long walkway to Baphuon and then climb down the back and walk around the back. Get a little bit lost (hardly) in the run down temples at the back and emerge at the Terrace of the Leper King. But what made this experience utterly phenomenal, was hiring a bike in town and cycling out for the day. It's an easy cycle, the route is literally straight down the main road and it Allowed us to go at our own pace, for cheap. Bring a lunch with you as the restaurants around there are expensive and not great.
Stunning. So many temples within the Angkor complex area that you run out of words to describe them. Another stunning setting, very mysterious. Got to go to the whole area

Beautiful. Go early in the morning, after catching the sun rise at Angkor we were the only ones there and its was a spectacular sight to see, all covered in amazing trees, this is a must - was also the site for tomb raider movie
Worth of visit. I think this side of historical area much more exciting and terrific.Very green area and exciting workof art! I really like it ;also you can do a tour by elephant. that's was cool.
fabulous. Angkor Thom is fabulous, but too many tourists as any famous place in the world, even it was not the high season

After Angkor Wat. Heard of a person with "many faces", but ever heard of a stone with many faces (and I do mean LITERALLY, not metaphorically as in a person), well that's the Bayon in Angkor Thom :). Not too many stairs to climb which comes later when you get to the nearby Baphuon, and there's an outdoor Buddha statue between the two temples as well. The top flight of stairs at Baphuon were off-limits when I was there, still the views of trees and forests out to the horizon were great from as far as you could go up, and the climb I'd like to mention was not too bad since it was all wooden stairs from the bottom to the top (even the closed-off part was wooden stairs) unlike at some temples like Ta Keo which I got to later where I encountered some stone stairs which I found them considerably more strenuous than wooden ones.After coming down from Baphuon, head out the pathway on the lake in front of the temple, then left and you're on the Elephants Terrace (so named I guess because of the carvings of elephants on its wall facing the road beside), and going further the same way, you'll get to the Leper King Terrace (also so named because of the carvings of some figures, whether human or otherwise, with their arms raised as if they're supporting the terrace above, so maybe those figures represent the Leper King, the namesake of the terrace).Angkor Thom consisting of the Bayon and Baphuon was the second stop on my Angkor circuit tour starting at Angkor Wat, then Angkor Thom, then Preah Khan, then Ta Keo, then Ta Prohm, then Banteay Kadei & Sras Srang reservoir, then Prasat Kravan and finally Phnom Bakheng the temple on a mountain. If you're coming by minibus from Poipet to Siem Reap and when you get off in Siem Reap and meet the tour operator named Vara, I highly recommend his services - honest, timely pickups and no hidden charges except some small tip to your driver at day's end after the tour.And, one important advice during the tour is not to lose your admission ticket that you obtained at the entrance (the main ticket entrance at the start of the tour - before getting to Angkor Wat) because they do check people for those tickets at each subsequent stop, so be sure NOT to throw your ticket away or misplace it and have it with you at all times during the tour.

Defintely a must-see. If you are here in Siem Reap to see Angkor Wat then you also should see this location. The quiet and forest all around make you feel like you're in another world. Take in the whole area. Lots of neat pictures too.

Loved it. It's a 5 star place! Have a good tuk tuk driver and maybe a book or leaflet and wander around! Don't cycle it, get a tuk tuk to drive you, see something magical rather than sweat it out in the heat on a bike!! All the 'gate' entrances are amazing and the elephant terraces!!
Lots to see here. Its so large that you don't realize that you are within a separate city complex. Many famous temples are within this walled city

Magnificent. The scale of this area is amazing. The outer wall is 3km along each side with the moat outside this.. The moat itself looks like a river it is so wide. The gates are beautiful with their elephant carvings and within the grounds are Bayon, the terrace of the elephants and the temple of the leper king, all worth seeing.

The Bayon inside Angkor Thom is a must see. If you have only one day to see the temples, do the small circuit and don't miss Angkor Thom. The Bayon in the centre is one of the best sights of the area (after Ta Prohm) in my opinion. It is an incredible structure of many faces, and nooks and crannies to explore. Outside the Bayon, the large temple and the Terrasse des Elephants are also well worth seeing. Do be aware, there are restrictions on entering the temple (the same ones as the temple inside Angkor Wat). Your clothing must cover your upper arms and to your knee; children under 12 and pregnant women can't enter.Remember when seeing any of the temples, the weather can change from hot to wet within a short time, so be prepared for all conditions.

Beautiful. This is the Angkor Temple that has all the faces carved into the columns and is a must to see with Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm . Our tour guide Mr. Mony pointed out that this temple was constructed much more quickly that Angkor Wat which is evident in the fact that the stones at this site are not as closely matched as Angkor Wat. Still a beautiful site

Better than Angkor Wat. Although this is the more ruinous temple, we enjoyed exploring it much more than Angkor Wat. You need to wear shoes with well-gripping soles as the climbs up and down between rooms can be tricky. Well worth the experience.
Impressive. One of the reasons to visit Siem Reap. Impressive to see and experience. Go there by tuk-tuk and take a guide with you. You will learn a lot more,
awesome. Had this on wish list, did not disappoint me though would add you make need to be a bit geeky or interest in history etc.

Massive site!. The site is large and has variety of sections to explore if you make the time. We only zipped in and explored Bayon, but did not really see the other parts. Quoting my 14 year old ... "it was fun!"
Angkor Thom. The best way to visit the site is to enter the Southern Gate of Angkor Thom, then proceed to see Bayon, Elephant Terrace and Leper King Terraces

Great place!. If you are in Siem Reap, I would recommend to visit all the temples. But if you can't, you should visit Angkor Thom, it is a place with different temples and you can also take an elephant ride. It is close to Angkor Wat so there are a lot of tourists.
Great City & A Great Place to Visit. Take your time, take in the atmosphere of the ancient world and enjoy the carvings. Not too crowded.
Fantastic. A great place for photos and history of the magnificent kingdom of Angkor. We enjoyed this one very much as it was smaller and easier to access.
Amazing - again!. As everyone has said "Amazing". Well worth the visit, always lots of tourists apparently but understandably so. Be sure not to miss it.

"Great City"...best visited with a guide & when cloudy or early. Angkor Thom is quite impressive...the size is much larger than I thought it would be which makes the translation ring true (Great City) which at one point held over 100,000 within it's walls. As the largest of the temples and one of the few where you can actually see some differences in carvings and construction between a Buddhism and Hinduism (another great reason to have a guide). Like many other temples, there are quite a few stairs you can climb to get to the higher levels of the temple and if you are physically able, they are definitely worth it. Also, Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat will require shorts/skirts beneath the knees and shoulders covered so be mindful of that or you will be going into the shops to buy the traditional pants and cheap t-shirts or scarves.
wow!!!. Amazing temple.Recommend going on the elephant ride round it,you get a different perspective Then climb up and wakk round inside.

Just amazing!. We visited this on a day when the temperature was almost 40 degrees, but despite this, it was absolutely fabulous. Everywhere you looked, took your breath away. It was like being in the Tomb Raider film (which was filmed here). The trunks of the trees which had almost taken over the buildings were absolutely amazing. No words can describe this place - just go and see for yourself!

Angkor Thom is a must see and do.. Along with Angkor Wat this a must see and I suggest either a guide or a bit of research so the significance can be appreciated.
Check out the Terrace of the Elephants carefully as there is a lot of detail you can overlook and it is beautifully carved.

Angkor Thom. Less well known than Angkor Wat but equally impressive is the walled and moated city of Angkor Thom ,still mostly untouched .
Visit if you have the time.

Possibly in the top 3.... I gave up partway round and sat down waiting for my wife whose stamina when faced with piles of old stones is greater than mine, I just had a quick look, yes, very nice, and old carvings always have interest, but then I was all templed-out after already having trogged round Angkor Wat and Bayon. 'er indoors said the bits I couldn't be bothered to look at were very nice indeed. Who am I to argue? Steve Riches, Northampton, UK.
Stunning. The ruins are actually better than Greece! I loved this entire place and all of the amazing ruins. Remember for women to have appropriate dress.
Big area!. Bigger than Angkor Wat and we could not possible cover the whole area. Beautiful big structures as well and if you can manage to find a quiet spot, it is really quite serene.

Even better than Angkor Wat!. Angkor Thom is much larger and more majestic than Angkor Wat. Physically exhausting to complete so wear good walking shoes as lots of climbing, and uneven surfaces. Truly a wonder of the world, still get goose bumps at it's sheer size and grandeur. Definitely worth visiting as well as Angkor Wat!

Probably the best of the temples. Whilst Angkor Wat is massive and mind-blowing for the sheer scale of the temple layout, Angkor Thom probably contains some of the best temples. They all have their own style and features that make them unique - Ta Prohm for the Trees, Bayon for the faces and they are all on everyone's bucket list so don't expect to have the place to yourself. Whilst getting up before dawn to see the sunrise may be disappointing due to the overcast and cloudy skies which are common, arriving at 0700 - 0800 is worth the effort to miss most of the crowds. Soak it up and enjoy. :o)

Another Essential Temple to Visit in Siem Reap. This is the temple with the many large stone faces. It is very impressive and inspiring to see in person. Anyone visiting Angkor Wat, this plan to visit this temple which is close by.
Tomb Raider. This was fantastic. Can't believe that this temple still stands against the pressure of the jungle trees.

Great place to buy hardwood souvenirs at a fraction of the town store prices!. This is the film location of the movie TOMB RAIDER starring Angelina Jolie. One of my favorites bec the cheaper priced quality authentic Khmer woodcraft souvenirs I am so fond of.

beats angkor wat!. This site is huge! as such you need to plan to take your time when exploring the site, the carving and the towers with the four faces are amazing, the site is a current working site which is why I personally rated it better than Angkor wat. The wall reliefs are as good as you can see in the Nile valley and are as detailed in what was the major events for that period. This place is worth a good day as it is quieter and holds a more serene feeling though this would not be the case in the main dry season.
hands down my favorite. this was by far my personal favorite temple structure. We had a guide this day and learned so much! It made everything so much better. We saw monkeys!

Ride the elephant. The elephant ride was $15 for roughly 20 minutes of riding but the higher vantage point gave me some of my best photos of Angkor Thom -- well worth the money. Otherwise Angor Thom is a pretty cool place and well worth the visit

Loved the most!. Even though Angor Wat is the famous one we loved this one the most. It was amazing from every angle, some parts felt like a labyrinth and made us wonder how did people used to move around there. The other amazing thing is original stairs which for us was very hard to use, but they have built new wooden stairs so it was much easier. You can also get there by riding an elephant whicg I found pretty nice!

Stunning. Anyone can take photos here to rival the best National Geographic cover shoot. 360 degree breath-taking. NB I visited around 6 - 8 years ago not 2014 so look at other reviews for more up to date facility info. The historical structure will never change is it is this that I am giving top draw marks to . Mark it personal - avoid the crowds - take your time - and don't forget a spare camera battery and memory card! :)
lovely walks. the areas was great to walk around under large tree shade. many small temples that you can see from a distance. The grass areas as just so clean and lovely. Peaceful and relaxing.
Another amazing place.,. This was the place made famous by Angelina Jolie's movie Tomb Raider. Great place so many monkeys apparently watching over the place.

Amazing beauty. This is one of the most famous temples in the Angkor Archaeological Park thanx to hollywood.Though it might be crowd and you've probably seen it in the movies or see pictures it doesn't disappoint you at all. I can even describe how amazing and beautiful it is in person. This is a must see if you don't have alot of time to visit all the temples in the park.

Still crowded, and the necessary restoration isn't pretty. A sprawling complex that includes more than just the Bayon. The climb up that and Baphuon is very steep. A pity the restored sculptures at the South Gate don't match the original stone - it will take a lot of time for them to age and acquire a similar state of wear.Take the time to explore the structures and temples of different styles, such as Phimeanakas and the terrace of the Leper King, if you're interested.Go ahead and ask the driver to stop by the quieter North or East Gate (not the Victory Gate that everyone goes through to get to Ta Prohm) for photos. It's worth pointing out that the South Gate features a three-headed elephant.

One of the top temples.. Personally, and according to many people, Angkor Thom is the main attraction of the entire archaeological site, maybe even more beautiful to the same Angkor Wat. Obviously the size of Angkor Thom are exceptionally larger and include a large number of temples and it is for this reason that you must visit for a long time and above all a guide and a way of transportation it's necessary in order to reach and cover every corner of the immense area. Not to be missed.

Amazing, my personal Highlight of all of Cambodia. It's really hard zu describe, but Angkor Thom was my absolute favourite of all the temples. I stayed in Siem Reap for four nights, but if i had to melt it down to one day, i would spend it at Angkor Thom, even if Angkor Wat is equally impressive.Angkor Thom is very extensive, so be sure to get a Tuk Tuk driver (or a bike, if you think you did not sweat enough already), which should not be a problem ;-)August 2014 the price was around 15$ a day.Oh, btw, do NOT go to any of those floating market/floating villages rip of tours near Siem Reap, they are not worth your time or money!Better spend more time at Angkor Thom, where you can find smaller temples where you are alone, watch beautiful butterflys or the Mimosa pudica growing everywhere.

Freaking big!. This is a city not temple. Consists of few other temples which has two circuit. Big and small. I did small on 1st day n big on 3rd day yet I feel I missed out most of the small temples. There are like 10 big or main temples must visit within angkor Thom.

Another amazing experience. To see this wonderful temple still covered in parts in jungle is amazing to think how much of it has been salvaged.Another piece of Cambodian history it was privilege to see.
Restoration on going. Didn't see much. The temple was not in a good shape. Restoration on going. Good for historical and cultural experience.

Must see. Angkor Thom is a walled area that has quite a few temples to see. It is just a short distance past Angkor Wat and is worth going to see. The area itself is massive. We rented bikes and it made it much easier to cover more ground and see more. You can actually walk or bike along the original walls which will get you away from the crowds and give you a different perspective. If you're here to see temples, this is a must see complex.Tip: we went early, like right after sunrise. Because of this we got the chance to be practically alone in front of the main gate and inside many of the temples that were really busy later in the day. If you can, do Angkor Thom on a different day than you do Angkor Wat so you can start here and enjoy some quiet time before the tour groups show up.
A must to see. We did it with a personal guide and driver, words cannot describe, just do it. Out of season means that the crowds are not an issue. Bucket list stuff.

The last capital of the Angkorian Empire. Like Angkor Wat this is a must see attraction if in Seim Reap. Remember to wear sensible shoes as the ground is un even and there are plenty of stairs, ensure to take drinking water and as a side note please don't touch the sand stone structures as sweat and acid from your hands will damage the Sand stone. A world marvel and worth the effort. There are heaps of great photos to be taken so take a spare camera battery with you.

TANTALISING TEMPLE EXPERIENCE. This was the first of the temples we visited at Ankor and it was amazing. You were able to wander through nearly all parts of the complex at your own pace (some restoration work is in progress). The temple is in good condition but is uneven, is built over a number of levels, has stairs and is probably unsuitable for those who require a flat surface walking area. The carvings and statues were quite amazing and are easy to see and photograph. There were plenty of local guides (if you wanted to access them) available to answer questions - their English was certainly better than my Cambodian. A great introduction to the Ankor complex, not to be done in a rush.
Elephant riding. Don't miss the elephant trip up the mountain. It is so exciting. It gives you a real taste of Cambodia. The elephants appear to be well treated and are very gentle. I loved it.
Awesome. Another awesome temple. Just magical. A lot of photo ops. Take water as it gets very hot. Wear comfy shoes and hat. Some stairs. Friendly guides.
expected a bit more. Not as large as the two main sites. We stopped here for a very short time for photos by the walls which are all carved elephants

Angkor Thom, A Temple with Five Gates. Angkor Thom was constructed 100 years after Angkor Wat from 1115 to 1130. It was the last fortified city surrounded by a wall covering 2,000 acres. It had five gates--two facing east. There were 54 statues of gods and demons about three meters high.

Simply Wonderful. The site is well laid out. You can spend as much time as you like going though the temples. I was impressed with the size and condition of this site. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes. Take some water.

Breath taking. Angkor Thom is one of the many surprises Cambodia has to offer . The amazing temple is pretty close to Ta Prohm which is one of the other attractions of the vicinity .. The sheer beauty of the massive stones carved into statues is mesmerising and on a clear day the whole place presents perfect picture view. A must visit to all going to Cambodia.
Climb, Walk, Take photos, Be amazed. It's massive. The artistry and dedication of people to create such a place is amazing. Photographs mean nothing. One much experience Angkor Thom.
great. Although I'd never really heard of this place before I was really impressed with the size and all that was in this gated former city
Excellent. Just excellent. Just go and see it, along with all the other temples around. It's another world. Just remember, you won't be the only people there.
This can be a pretty short trip. This temple is pretty close to Ta Prohm, there's a shortcut that you can take to get there quickly. Neat temple that you should stop by to see if you're in the area.
Includes Bayon Temple. A huge huge area, too much to see in the time we had. Stop at Bayon Temple & at least one of the gates of the ancient city.

You're in Siem Reap, so why miss any temple?. I like the temples because its really incomparable with the design, structure and basically, its really a huge place that if you'll visit you'll be wondering how the people and the monks pray and live there. Always take note to wear rubber shoes or comfortable shoes, because it is so tiring and really perspiring. Also, do not forget your water and pictures!

Ensure you have a great Guide. This Temple City is just fantastic. You really do need a great guide to help you thru this place and to understand just what everything means and what has taken place here. It really amazes me how the intricate the carvings can be and how uniform they are. Allow your heart and mind to be truly open while soaking up the atmosphere. A certain "Must Do" place.

Breathtaking. When u pay the $20 daily ticket to get into the Angkor Wat park you can see Angkor Thom Bayon Temple. I had seen many pics before going but OMG this is soooo beautiful I loved walking around seeing all the different carvibgs in the walls and also the amazing doorways and wibdows all in a line. Must see if in Siem Reap its just astoundingly amazing.
Buddha Images. The image of Buddha's face on the top of the Wat is amazing! Just walking around the grounds and through the ruins & corridors is an adventure.

Faces of Thom. Stunning backdrop for my favourite photo from Cambodia. intriguing temple complex. So pleased to have a guide explain the history, share some stories and show us where to stand and how to pose to 'kiss the Buddha'. The faces and the depth of architectural detail made for some great photo moments. A must do and must see.
Loved it. So many temples & so much history, you must have a guide with you to explain what you are seeing to get the full benefit. Allow plenty of time so you can absorb it all.
Stunning!. Stunning ruined buildings blend with spiritual and symmetry. Don't be stingy to shoot, all these pictures are valuable and memorable!
Just fantastic. Went early in morning to avoid crowds and heat.Had guide which filled in history and was essentialNot as far out of centre town as advertised

A true lost city. It's almost surreal to walk around this place and think such detail still remains after over 900 years of being exposed to the elements. There are large temples, as well as the remains of small stone houses and elevated platforms where a building once stood. Bayon temple is in the center of it all, which is just as awe inspiring as Angkor Wat.

Wow. After Angkor Wat, we didn't think anything could beat it... And then came Angkor Thom. It was a breath taking sight, especially early in the morning. We thought it was the nicest of the temples we saw (we only went for one day and saw the main ones on the short path). It was a tremendous sight, something you think only exists in movies, and felt that this was really worth the money to see.

Incredible afternoon tour. We started with Angkor Thom and boy am I glad we did. Absolutely incredible. Go with a good guide who speaks your language well. There is so much to learn and see. Angkor Thom is amazing. We got a late start and when at 1:00 in the afternoon. We lucked out and got a cloudy day so the heat wasn't so oppressive. I'm glad we did the ruins were almost empty. No waiting in lines or bumping into people. We got the opportunity to walk around and really take it all in at our own pace.

Bigger temple area the Angkor Wat. A large area filled with different temples (Bayon, Phimeanakas, Baphuon etc) and many, many small ruins. The higlights are Bayon and the Elephant Terrace. Walk up through Baphuon to get some great photo-ops and to watch the huge reclining Buddha at the back of the temple. The Terrace of the Leper King has some great carvings along with the Elephant terrace. Enter through the south entrance. Come by bike or tuk-tuk as the grounds are huge.

One of the many great temples in Angkor Wat. There were so many great temples in the area and this is one of the many good ones. We had a great trip and each temple revealed something new and different

The gate was a good prelude. Approaching Angkor Thom, I kinda expected greatness. Nearing the temple, I was awed with its massiveness and its intricate design. While some slabs are all over the grounds probably waiting to be reinstated thru the massive restoration work, th whole thing nevertheless awes visitors, and photography hobbyists like me. On this spot alone I must have taken 100 shots.
Buyer beware. Excellent,again if you are not able manage steps, stairs or walking on uneven surfaces, reconsider particularly in summer

The area around Banyan. Angkor Thom is composed of Banyan and the area immediately surrounding it. It was cool to visit, but personally I found the major temples more enthralling. Also, we went during early rainy season. Because this area requires so much outdoor walking, the humidity got to be a bit too much. We called it an early day and went back to the hotel after exploring Angkor Thom a bit. I especially liked the elephant wall.

One of the Best Days in Cambodia. This temple was just simply amazing and another must see, its so close to Angkor Wat, and if you have a tuk tuk , or even if you don't its still worth the visit, when you buy the tickets at the start it includes entry to both of these and this was a lot bigger to begin with and the restoration work being carried out is marvellous. We walked around for hours, the best photo opportunity is when you can get one kissing the statues.
Excellent. A great temple which is a little different to many of the other temples in the area, however I saw this towards the end of my tour and I was a little templed out!
Essential to visit. Even now, one can see the amazingly intricate workmanship that went into making this the impressive place it was and can still be seen to have been.

Temple in the best condition, and was the largest of all. This temple is best preserved of the lot, and also the largest ("Thom" means largest). Make sure your guide allows at least half a day just for this temple, preferably even more.

Fascinating !. Where Tomb Raider was filmed ! Its like walking into ancient history. Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me ! Words fail me !

Stunning place. This is one of the most stunning places I have visited. My advice would be to get your own tuktuk driver and explore it on your own. Be careful you don't get "templed out" it is too easy to try and do everything, better to leave wanting more so to speak.

Amazing.. Exceptionally beautiful, the ruins are wonderful. Go now whilst you can still walk around them with relative ease, I think that Tourism will catch up with these temples at some time and that conservation of them will demand that the tourist numbers be controlled.

The big Angkor. We were awestruck by the Angkor Thom’s vast structure spread over huge area. It was built in the late 12th – mid 13th century by Jayavarman VII. It is characterized by the iconic towers with four faces. It has 4 entrances with giant faces, the south gate being the most familiar and the usually tour begins from here. Other most beautiful attractions are the royal palace, elephant terrace and leper king area. This is a no-miss site to be visited in Siem Reap.
part of the same day trip with Angkor Wat. The only thing that is super annoying ..you can not get a picture on your own ..but un avoidable ...otherwise enjoy it

Extremely huge place. Not recommended to walk. Best to engage a tuk tuk to tour around the temples.. It should only cost around US10-12 for the Angkor temple areas.. We rented 2 mountain bikes instead. We for the mountain bike trail, Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, lunch in Angkor Thom, Royal Palace, Leper King Terrace, Elephant Terrace. With our cycling speed could have consider pretty fast but we didn't manage to have them for Ta Prohm & Bakheng hill for sunset which was a pity. Therefore we cover sunrise the following day & Ta Prohm before we head back home on Sunday.. Ultimately, we still missed our sunset at Bakheng hill. Basically you gonna reach Bakheng hill at 4pm. Only 300pax are allowed to go up the hill. Hiking up the hill takes about 25mins. So if you plan to cycle around especially in Angkor Thom, you're unable to complete it in one day unless you decide to forgo some of the areas in the temple.

My favourite temple. The famous tree in the temple from Tomb Raider. Some great photos to be had. Alot of shade for hot days. Makes you feel like you're back in time. Was there in the quiet, hot season and the lack of tourists makes it even more tranquil
Blown away. its so big and the History...amazing....your mind just boggles to think when these temples were first built then to be lost in the surrounding jungle for 100's of years... so cool

great place. all the temples in Siemp Reap if you have the time you have to see. This was like a big pyramid . You are able to see some beautiful sculpted of elephants and more. The humid and the head was not the best but you can keep in your bag ice and towels. You can continued enjoyed this place.

A fantastic place!. Angkor Thom is not just one place, as might be assumed by seeing it as one attraction here on Trip Advisor; it's a complex of many wonderful sights that can be seen enjoyed piece-by-piece as time allows. My particular favourites in the Angkor Thom complex are Bayon Temple (of course), Baphuon Temple, and the Terrace of the Leper King. Look at a map before you make your plans - there's a LOT of ground to cover, but it's definitely worth it!

Still wowing us!. We are back in Angkor Thom and this city never fail to amaze us.Entering through the south gate, we see work being done to restore the 54 demons and 54 gods flanking the walkway. Lots of tourists taking photos here. A moat surrounds the walled city. Plan to spend a whole day here to marvel at the architectural structures.
Stunning!!!. Amazing! Large old ruin, perfect picture opportunity! Beautiful architecture and history. A must see when visiting all the temples.Breathtaking!!!

One of my favourite temples. Loved the intricate faces and climbing up and down the levels of the temple. Simply must see. Get here early and straight after the main temple to avoid the rush. Also go to Bayon temple afterwards.

Great City!. That's what Angkor Thom actually means in Khmer and they meant it when this city was built. Wide moat, very tall walls and five gates encase another Khmer marvel. Don't miss the massive smiley face on the south gate. or the bas reliefs and figures at the Terrace of Elephants.

Fascinating. In some ways this was more impressive than Angkor Watt itself. You can explore the grounds more easily and almost every angle offers views of the numerous faces carved from blocks of stone, especially if you climb the steep stairs to what was once a library library where it is less crowded.

Go see both East gates ( one is called Ghost Gate). We asked our guide to drive us to the East gate (Ghost Gate) which was clearly not on the itinerary. It was beautiful. It was where the war dead were brought in to Angkor Thom. The East Gate north of the Ghost gate is the Victors gate and it is the East Gate proper ( I think). Both of them are great but North gate is the best!
Another Amazing place ... It is really fantastic what a amazing place. Lots to see and just beautiful. After you finished your tour you can also see monkey around the temple..
Wow. Really fantastic what a magnificent temple amazing sight, really need guide to go around with which we had.

Simply mesmerizing. just beautiful.. and mesmerizing.. simply majestic!!But yeah, I suggest you to go here in the morning / before afternoon, maybe around 8-9 am, as it will be very crowded later in the midday & afternoon, you know how it won't be very enjoyable anymore if your view is distracted by many other visitors keep spawning around the place.

Great site...lot to see!. Lots to see - from the Bayon temple to the royal palace, monkeys and elephants rides. Went with own tuk tuk driver but v.easy to pick up tuk tuks there to get you back to town.
The big city!. The highlight is the Bayon, the sheer scale of Angkor Thom is mightily impressive, take your time and take a bit more time ... majestic!!
average. The temples and other sights in Angkor Thom are only ok after I saw Angkor Wat. Only Bayon and Ta Prohm were special to pay visit.
Nice to walk through this gate. But be aware it is very dusty and very crowded. It is not easy to get clear pictures without dozens of people in them as many are on their way to the temples.

Even Better Than Angkor Wat!. I think I enjoyed Angkor Thom even better than Angkor Wat. It was absolutely gorgeous, although much more "ruinous" than Angkor Wat. All areas were accessible for children of all ages.

Great City. The entrance itself is already enough to amaze you of this grand architecture. The moat around the city is 3km in length on each side is able to tell you how big is this place.
Make sure you check out Bayon and opposite it where the Terrace of the Elephants and Ta Prohm

Awesome temple ruins. Angkor Thom was amazing, the faces carved into the rocks were incredible, amazing that they managed to do this so long ago! Definitely worth the visit after you have done Angkor Wat (we fit the whole of Angkor in in a day and didnt feel rushed)! Cycling is the best way to get about

disappointment visit. the site were so old, not much to see except climbing up and down the stair case which I think is good for traveller who lack exercise. The Nearby Kher Angkor Restaurant was not as good as their other restaurant in Siam Reap.
Amazing. Hire a professional guide from a well respected tour company. Pay the extra few bucks for a real guide. And remember to tip.

Amazing temple. I was to visitors temple very amazing temple I do love so much
I wish the best number one temple in siem reap
Different from Angkor Wat. Different style from Angkor Wat and certainly worth a visit - the carvings on the walls were really special.

The Ancient City. This is actually the whole ancient city and contains the Bayon and Baphoun temples, the Royal Enclosure, the Terraces of the Leper King and Elephants etc. If you are going to Bayon first, then you will have to enter the city through the Victory Gate. The two side railings/balustrades of the road are designed to resemble a giant snake. On one side the demons are holding it, on the other the gods. The demons are frowning, the gods have calm, serene faces. Its created to resemble a Hindu mythic scene - the churning of the sea. Just before reaching this gate, keep a lookout for the elephants, you can ride them also. On entering through the gate, you will first come across Bayon, then Baphoun, then the Royal Palace area and the Terraces of the Leper King and Elephant.The ticket for Angkor Vat is also valid for all the sites in Angkor Thom.
Th best temple in the area.. We preferred Angkor Thom to the more prominent Angkor Wat, it's more ancient looking and with fantastic carvings.

Good to see. This temple has one of the best preserved entrances with the naga (snake) for the balustrade and the gods on one side, demons on the other. Other temples have some more impressive aspects but this has the historical significance of being the previous capital city, etc.
Just go. I cannot imagine being in Seim Reap and not going to the world's largest religious structure. Amazing.

Nice setting. It is not a member of the "big two", but this Buddhist structure should be a stop on any tour. It is actually the remnant of an entire city that was walled with four ornate gates guarding the royalty within. Many of the faces have been destroyed over the centuries, but most of them have been expertly restored.

Another breathtaking sight. Minus the tourists, this would be another breathtaking sight. Being in the temples in Siem Reap alone is mesmerising enough but when you think of how they built everything (which remains a mystery), is just fascinating.

Wow.. It is hard to imagine any building that is bigger or more beautiful than Angkor Wat but the detail and experience of Angkor Thom add up to equally rival Angkor Wat in my opinion. Gods on one side and demons on the other, be prepared to get out and snap some pictures! There was some construction going on, but nonetheless was a beautiful and mesmerizing place to visit. A must see if on a limited itinerary.

Nature and temple magic. Definitely one of the most intriguing temple and mystical one. As a younger adult, I always loved Indiana Jones and films alike Tomb Raider. Being there, seeing those magnificent trees reining over those centuries old temples was completely breathtaking.If you do not have much time to visit the many temples in Angkor, this one is one to put on your list. It's not the biggest one, but definitely one that brings emotions.
City walls surrounding the old capital. Beautiful stories of the wonder that is Angkor. Along with Ta Prohm, Angkor Wat and Bayon, the crown of the temples.
Awesome temple!. Bit of construction going on at the moment which means you might not be able to take a perfect temple. Never the less it is a magnificent place to visit.

Thom reclaimed from jungle. Probably a separate day is needed to see this second wonder of Cambodia. After Angkor Wat it's a lot to take in, but if you have to do it in the same day then be prepared to be gobsmacked by the work to reclaim this series of buildings from the jungle. We liked the trees still growing through the structure, the rainforest roots claiming whole buildings from the top down, and the feeling of being lost in its corridors and passages.The carved heads, the faces and the sheer size if decorative work is again impressive and the work to keep it from being lost to the jungle again is obvious but essential to restore this valuable piece of world history.It rained heavily when we first arrived. It was the perfect way to see this jungle forest surrounding Angkor Thom and the rock does seem to come alive with its images when wet.

Wear comfy, non slip shoes, bring water and a hat.. An excerpt from my blog The Mediocre Wanderer: Before entering the ancient city of Angkor Thom, we stopped at the bridge and checked out the headless demons (right side) and gods (left side) guarding the pathway. Our pictures were taken beside the demons, with the guide romanticizing the act, saying that gods belong on the right of the demons.Being the last and most enduring capital city of the ancient Khmer world, there are several temples that have mostly withstood the test of time. Inside it's walls, you will find the following structure: Bayon, Phimeanakas, Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Prah Palilay, Tep Pranam and Prasat Suor Prat. You could go through all of these in half a day. The first on our adventure was the Bayon temple. Expect to climb steep wooden steps, and rough, uneven sandstone blocks. We entered it through it's east gate, where the short walk from the tuktuk parking area is probably the easiest path you'll walk on in the entire structure.Built 100 years after Angkor Wat, it's the next most amazing temple to see after the former, with it's 2000 faces carved on solid rock and 54 towers rising to the sky. It is a Buddhist temple, with pillars, surrounded by 4 faces, representing the omnipresent god. Bas reliefs at the first 2 areas tell of the battles, of a history built upon the blood of it's enemies, and it's people. Personally, it's my favorite temple. After going back to where we started (but not before Phil took pictures of the Terrace of the Leper King, Preah Palilay and Tep Pranam)), we walked through the woods and ended up in Baphuon. An impressive bridge leads up to this temple. Our guide, however, felt compelled to walk under the shade, though the heat from the sun was still quite mild.Baphuon can be a steep climb. So steep that children are not allowed inside the structure. After the carrying and climbing, MAX and I decided to sit this one out, with Phil and our guide, to be the only ones to enter it. After what seemed like half an hour of resting on the giant cut stones at the grounds of Baphuon, Phil and Senchey ushered us to walk once more, into the woods. After walking down a short yet steep slope, we came upon a wall. Entering a small foot gate, we were surround by so many huge trees. We were now in the shadow of the Hindu temple, Phimeanakas. I saw the stairs and thought that carrying MAX through and up this structure, would not do my back any favors.Walking a few more yards, we entered another gate, that led to the Terrace of the Elephants, or where the ancient kings would watch processions and where elephants would perform for royalty. From this vantage point, one can see Prasat Suor Prat, or a series of twelve, nearly identical towers spanning south of the eastern wall of Angkor Thom.After MAX slipped on the muddy elephant grounds at the bottom of the terrace, we were just happy that we had reached the end of part 1 of 3 in our temple run.

The sheer scale baffles. I never understood how large a complex the park was. It boggles the mind how structured, mathematical, tidy and rich it is. Also, how they used water so well. It greatly increased my humility for past civilisations and that perhaps modern humans are not the pinnacle of design as we destroy much of the Earth to try and get where we are. We don't create with harmony; we create with discord.
Less impressive. There is a long walk way to the entrance surrounded by god and demon faces on both sides. This is your first view of the famous stone faces of Angkor Thom and Bayon.
another superb temple. following the story of the sea milk was an absorbing feature of our visit with a guide. Well worth having a guide for the first visit to temples and then go by yourself

Impressive Faces, Many Tourists. Angkor Thom was thoroughly impressive with the large faces covering its facade. I am glad we made the stop but there were a lot of crowds to fight our way through and it felt like we couldn't walk anywhere without photo bombing a photo op. Angkor Thom is a complex that includes quite a few temples and terraces so prepare for walking in the sun and be sure to look around. One of the temples requires you to cover up while the others are more relaxed about dress code. My favorite part was the Elephant Terrace, don't miss it!For more photos and info you can check out my post at http://www.togethertraveler.com/2014/07/angkor-wat-temples.html
Nice place. One of the best building in the complex. Maybe my favorite. Can take a couple of hours to enjoy that construction.

Girlie trip. Spent 4 days in Siem Reap and visiting temples. Been on 3 occasions before but over 5 years ago. Still breathtaking and always something new to see. Take your time . 3 day pass valid for five so use the rest days in between if you can.

A must see. Just when you think Angkor Wat is amazing, this other temple is just as fascinating with its range of extraordinary history and the beauty of its architecture. Why hadn't I seen this before on my many trips to Asia?

angkor thom best. angkor thom it is very nice temple . angkor thom smile temple . angkor thom it far from siem reap town 12km . angkor thom had a lot of caving on the wall . it is very nice in siem reap angkor.
Fabulous. Like Ankor Wat- go now before it is completely overrun by the hordes of tourists. Its the beginning of the end when you see Chinese script graffiti on the walls of 1000 year old temples

Not just another temple. Beautifully restored stonework. An excellent example of the skills of the stone masons. Go to this site before Angkor wat and you will not be so overpowered by the size of Angkor Wat. Best advice is to go withy a local guide. They can give a far mor extensive insight than any guide book.

Arguably the best of Khmer temple..... I visited this temple complex as a prelude to Angkor Wat, but in my opinion this has greater appeal and is more spectacular. Known as the temple of smiles it displays happy smiling faces on all aspects of the towers although one has to look hard and use some imagination to discern the figures as centuries of erosion has degraded the detail.I would most certainly recommend this as an additional tour to Angkor Wat, if not as a replacement.

Beautiful place..... This was a whole city and palace wen it was bulid. its so huge that from going to 1 place to the other, u need to take the car. there are many temples inside it. the main entrance of the south gate has statues of angels and demons... its really beautiful...

Amazing. From the little details to the stone carvings. It's so hard to believe that it's over 700 years old.It can get crowded but just don't be in a rush and everything will be fantastic. However the sellers outside are VERY ANNOYING SO DON'T talk or look a them and just walk.

A must do. I am pretty sure that every traveller going to Cambodia knows that this is a must do on your trip! Please don't be silly and climb on the old stones as conservation efforts are already huge!

Historic, interesting , and beautiful. Again a beautiful temple worthy of much adoration and attention. I loved it. It was smaller than Angkor Wat but that added to it's impressiveness. Again it was obvious that this place is special. As with most of these temples walking is difficult for the physically impaired.

Temples galore. This is so well organised, you must take off your hat to the Cambodians for the organisation for the tourists. Must see complex, do yourself a favour though and take a single day to se each three areas.
A must do!. All of the buildings are so amazing and this is one of them. It just blows me away how the structures are so old and so detailed. Fascinating!

Historical. Angkor Thom was the capital and our guide explained its history. The different archaeological sights in Angkor Thom give an insight into the lives of royalty in that era. It is definitely an integral part of the Siem Reap trip.
Favorite temple. I loved the high stretching trees, the wonderful location and the ride out to this temple. I would highly recommend this temple for those who like the scenery of the forest
Big enough to get lost. Lots to see here from walls of figures to elephant terrace to the main temple to the lakes... Good place for that middle of the day tourist crush.

Insanely good!. Another gem in Cambodias crown. This is one of my favourite temples based on its design. You will see four faced 'pillars' that jet out of the stone work. I found the craftsmanship insanely good considering it was built all those years ago. Again another massive temple so there's a lot to take in. I felt like a child on an adventure whilst wondering the temples of Siem Reap. One tip: It's worth getting up early to visit as it does get ridiculously hot! Overall absolutely loved it, not seen anything quite like the temples in Cambodia.

Wonderful. Take time to look at both sides of the bridge. The guardians of good and evil are all different and some of the faces are great. Beware the monkeys by the entrance. Personally I don't find monkey cute, rather the opposite. Just be aware they are around, are wild and will attack if provoked.

wonderful. this site is enormous - you would probably need a day just to see this amazing city completely. It is good to go with a guide as he will explain all the carvings and how the life was led in this city so many centuries ago
One of the Main Temples. This temple is huge. Unfortunately it is is poor condition.There are many stairs and uneven surfaces to negotiate.The history is interesting.
Does not disappoint. Each temple / site is different. Each has its own character and attraction. We were four of us and we each have our own favourite.
Wonderful. What an experience even in the pouring rain and heat! Just in ore of the size of the tree roots, truly amazing experience.
Fantastic. again another beautiful structure - if a little more in ruins than some of the others though, you can still picture what it would have been like

A Must!. The walled city of Angkor Thom is awesome, and I liked it better than the more famous Angkor Wat. It encloses wide stretches of jungle and many temples, including the Bayon and the Ta Prohm, and the day I spent walking and cyclying there, from one site to the next one, is the the highlights of my stay in Cambodia.It's possible to buy 1-day / 3-days and 7-days tickets to visit the area, and I think that 1 day is ok for Angkor Thom, but not enough to pay a visit even just to the main sites in the valley (and 7 days is ok just for archaeologists). Anyway it's easily possible to couple it with Angkor Wat in a single day, covering all the main sites.Angkor is very close to Angkor Wat, and just a few Kilometers from Siem Reap , so I got a bike from my guesthouse and went there by myself at sunrise to avoid the crowd and the scams of tuktuk drivers, who asking insane prices to take you there.It's possible to get food and drinks from local shops along the road, anyway food, drinks and maps are cheap and easily available within Angkor Thom itself.
Many faces to love. Very cool temple with all the faces! Loved this temple for the many faces and engraved walls. Got crowded quickly, but well worth it!!
Amazing!. Compared to Angkor Wat, I enjoyed this site much more. It is basically ruins but the way the trees have grown up through the stonework is quite amazing - spectacular.
Awesome reminders of the Past. This was by far one of the most awe inspiring places I have visited on Earth.The spiritual power is enormous.A photographers dream.A must see if you are in Cambodia.

Angkor tom. Beautiful again see my review for Bayon as we used same guide. same applies. once again I would highly recommend mrs Muth Phalin , pronounced Pauline Vido tours hired her on our behalf both her and her driver Savie were superb we used them for three and half day tour of historical and cultural Siem Reap.
Very interesting. Enjoyed our visit very much, lots of great information from the tour guide. Memorable and unique. The tour guide was very good.
vast. this place is so huge, we spent 5 hours here and did not see everything. The angkor complex is expensive, but get the three day pass as a minimum - three days well spent!

The royal Khmer city. Just a short stroll from the Bayon, lots of temples and the royal palace to explore, and don't miss the Elephant terrace. Have a drink and snack at one of the local cafes to cool down between temples.

Lots of walking. Lots of walking up and down but certainly worth it. The trip would not have been complete if you have not visited this part of Angkor Wat. The different faces of the Buddha are interesting.
Beautful temple. One of the most suggestive temple in the area .A guide, good shoes and a camera are highly recommended. Best hours to take pictures early morning and late afternoon

Beautiful Temple. Incredible history, beautiful carvings, well worth having a guide with you to explain all the history. Highly recommend visiting Angkor Thom and all the temples in this region - they all have their own unique history and carvings. I will definitely be going back.

Beautiful. Yet another marvel of architecture and worth a visit too. My wife and I did not tire of visiting yet another temple and this may not be as amazing as Angkor Wot but a must as one of the few temples which still retains some of the glory of days gone by.

Angkor Thom. The site though similar in structures to the others, is still unique in the sense that its layout is peculiar. The tower structures are more defined than the others. Again, you can also feel the intermingling of man's structure to that of nature. As in the other ruins, the site offers a lot in terms of chronicles of the culture which are captured in the walls. Can take you a lot of time to appreciate each and every event depicted in each wall.

Angkor Thom. I have been to Siem Reap twice in the last two years. Both times I have been knocked out by this awesome place. Angkor Thom is my favorite Temple. Those stone faces provide great photo opportunities. You could spend many hour exploring every nook and cranny. There are many surprises inside, fine detailed carving, monks praying etc. I would advise visitors to arrive early to avoid both the extreme heat and the noisy crowds. An early morning visit is a sublime experience and one you will remember for ever! Remember go early, take lots of water, a snack, a hat, your camera and enjoy this wonderful never to be for forgotten experience. Hire a Tuk Tuk for the day, they are very cheap, it will add to your experience.

Awe inspiring. The entrance gates with the 54 demons struggling with the 54 gods on the causeway set the scene for this truly inspiring complex. On reaching the Bayon, there are 1.2 kilometres of bas reliefs, much of it depicting everyday life in 12th Century Cambodia. Not to be missed.

excellent!. You have to see it! Why else are you there as a tourist? It's hot in June, though. I mean, really hot. And, there are children that would like to sell you things as you approach the temples.

Worth a day. You could easily spend a half day or more here easily. The city complex housed a million people at its height when London was still a village. There is so much to see here, take food with you for a lovely picnic on one of the green areas around the area or around the ruins. There is so much history here - stop to look at the reliefs of the elephants on the Terrace of the Elephants

A must see. I think this was one of my favourites if not my favourite it is so hard to decide. I am a little obsessed with photographing Buddhas and Monks, so I was in my element here. There are certainly some great temple shots to be had here and fantastic views.I would go with a guide so that the surroundings are explained to you.If you only choose to do a few temples add this one to your list, you won't be disappointed and you can do it in one day with Angkor Wat.
Better than Angkor Wat. I enjoyed Angkor Thom a lot more than Angkor Wat. It was a bit less crowded and we had fun climbing on the steep steps in certain areas. It was very beautiful too.

Really lovely and varied. This and Bayon were our favorite Wats. Maybe because we went there first, but we really liked the scale, and variety of this compared to the impressive Angkor Wat. A nice wander around. Saw monkeys and elephants too which was cool.

Last Explosion of Khmer Monumental Architecture. See my review of the Bayon, the central temple complex of Angkor Thom. A.T.is well worth several hours. It was the last great capital of the Khmers. Who knows? Perhaps it was so megalomaniacal that it triggered the Theravada reformation in Cambodia. Maybe the people said "enough" or the treasury went bankrupt.It is neither as harmonious as Angkor Wat nor as dazzling in detail as Banteay Srei. But if you're here, it's a must-see, if for the Bayon alone.
Mesmerizing Angkor Thom. From the Elephant and Leper Terraces to Bayon and other small temples in the area, Angkor Thom is a must-visit when in Siem Reap!
Temple Complex. We visited during the same two day period we spent visiting Angkor Wat plus other temples, Wonderful experience!

Pros Paller. Angkor thom is the name of the capital city,there are many temples insite like:Bayon,Baphoun,Terrace of Elephant,Leper king terrace,Sour Prat,Phimean Akas,Prah Palilay,Prah Pithou etc.,so Angkor thom there are five entrances,all the entrances was decorated by Naga balustrade with the statues of Gods and Giants are pulling the serpent that had entwined the mountain of the churning of Sea of Milk,so the Gods are symbolized of good spirit and Giants are symbolized bad spirit.All the gates were decorated by the head of Lokesvara,with four faces symbolized of four divined states of the mind of king like:1-Loving Kindness 2-Compassion 3-Sympathy 4-Equanimity.so the Bayon is main tenple in the Angko thom was build at the end of the late 12th and early 13th century in the reigh of king JayavaramanVII and dedicated to Bhuddism.

Angkor Series: Thom after Wat. Angkor Wat made me wonder what on earth did ancient Cambodians have that enabled them to build such majestic structure. Angkor Thom, on the other hand, healed me. Its peaceful, energetic environment relieved me from stress and worries. It was a rejuvenating experience. One day, USD20-worth of Angkor travel was worth it. If not for tight schedule, I would have paid for additional day and avail of discount. We stayed for about two hours, more than half of it was spent just sitting on the stones under the shady portions of the compound. The other 30 minutes or so was spent taking pictures and strolling.

Tomb Raider fame. We bought a book as we left Angkor Wat for $10 after chevking it to make sure it had all the photoes etc.This has all the temples in and lots of pictures.There is a walk to get to thetemple but it is shady and there were a group of musicians, some disabled, playing the local music.These ruins are spectacular with the famous trees growing over the walls.If you are prepared to wait your turn you can get some great photos
very interesting. Was wonderful to walk among this, to see something so old.... the carvings are great... i would recommend going in the morning as it does get very hot and take plenty of water

Make way for Angkor Thom!. The entrances alone to this so-called "Great City" were stunning. Try to imagine a film scene depicting the ancient Khmers approaching this Victory Gate in a triumphant return from Siam. There is an elephant ride to tour you around and see the ruins of this massive temple complex. Enjoy the scenery.

The newest but still as amazing. Right from the onset you can see the difference in comparison to the other temples. The faces that look out at you from every angle make you feel either unsettled or very happy as they all smile and there is a legend that goes with the building of the temple. King Suryajayavarman VII is its creator and what a great job he did. You simply must go with a guide to this temple to understand the bass relief walls and the stories they tell. My first suggestion would be tohad to the Archeological Museum first to get a grasp on the history and therefore making it more understandable.

How to make a grand entrance. This approach to Bayan is so cool. The bridge has on one side the good guys, on the other the monsters, pulling in the tug-of-war they had back at the world's beginning. Pretty much the way it still goes. And the gateway is stunning, with powerful god looking down; dancers; elephants; so rich in imagery. Lovely setting, too. What's not to like? (Note: a great guide, like Phay Sophy, intelligent and very nice, brings all this to life for you. Every carving is meaningful, and the way it was accomplished a tale in itself.)

Don't miss Angkor Wat Ruins. You have not experienced historical sites till you have been here. These ruins like many others at Angkor Wat are one of the wonders of the world and not to be missed. You think you will tire of them, but not one is alike...you won't be disappointed.
another classic. still in the ankor what area another gem.. can be taken in with all the others inb easy one day trip.. gop and enjoy
history. The history is amazing, from hindu to buddism. I enjoyed to listen to our guide the area gave more 4o me with an guide. Loved it

A must whilst in Cambodia. If your out enjoying the temples make sure you don't miss this one out as they all have their own charm - again wear good shoes and appropriate dress. Take plenty of water and tip money as you will need it

A Perfect Follow Up to Angkor Wat. probably the 2nd most amazing temple in the Park, this ruin is something completely different to Angkor Wat, and leaves you with a completely different taste from the previous Temple.
Loved it. This is a great ruin to visit and is a must even if you miss a few of the smaller ones - watch for tour guides and Tourist Police
Tomb Raider!. This is an area that has not been restored, and has huge trees growing from within the rubbled buildings. Quite interesting.

Simply Magic. This is a must see the first light of morning. As with all things in Angkor get up early to beat the heat and beat the crowd. I was just here last week and now thinking back this was just awesome and simple in a raw and silent way these things in the jungle seems to me. Unforgettable and you will think about this and the other temples long after you have gone home. I would walk slowly across the grounds, smell the air as only Angkor has this smell. If it's only one time in your life be happy you are here. I am.
lets get templed. Another of the beautiful temples at Angkor, just amazing well worth spending a few days to see them all.

You can't visit Angkor Wat without visiting Ankor Thom. The two temple sites are fairly close, so you can easily do them in a day. Within Angkor Thom, you'll find the Bayon Temple and Elephant Terrace.What can I say? The site is beautiful and full of history. Go.

great town. An old ancient town where you can visit lots of temples..and its a huge place so make sure you have enough time to visit. Impressive how they could build this, and surrounded by lovely nature..but be aware it can be hot there.
Amazing sites. Quite crowded when we were there despite being in off season but still an amazing feeling walking around what was one of the most important civilisations of its time.

Best area. But don't miss others!. Be sure to walk around and climb through the trees and walls and temples! There are so many. Bring water and wear sunscreen. A guidebook will help make it a good experience- otherwise the ruins all just blend together after a few hours.

My favourite area. Angkor Thom as a whole is just wonderful! The city within the walls holds quite a number of temples - the great this is that they're all fairly close together so easy to walk around.I was taken there by my TukTuk driver, who entered through the South Gate - this is the most spectacular as the sculptures all have their heads (albeit replacements after the originals were stolen). A great photo opp if you can stop on the bridge on the way in.If you're coming in on tuktuk, get your driver to drop you at Bayon & to go wait at the Terrace of the Leper King. Most of this complex is best done on foot. If you can, go early in the morning to try to avoid the masses.Bayon is by far the most impressive of the temples in this complex, though a fairly small one compared to the likes of Angkor Wat. I loved it so much I came back twice!After Bayon, head on foot to Bauphon & climb to the top to appreciate the scale & the view. Be aware that its actually quite a tough climb up - the "stairs" are actually more or less a ladder!Once you're finished with Bauphon you are able to walk around the back (avoiding the busy road & keeping the atmosphere going!) to the Phimeanakas complex. Honestly, this is less impressive than the other two before I didn't bother to actually climb the temple here, but its a great spot to sit in the shade of the trees & have a drink & a rest!After this, head back out to the road & look at the Terrace of the Elephants & the Terrace of the Leper King. Both are pretty impressive!This is all that I did or Angkor Thom - the rest of the pieces in the complex looked much smaller in comparison, and I was pretty pooped by this point! I'd recommend leaving yourself about 2 hours to get around this route, with plenty of time for photos :) Its about a 30 minute tuktuk ride to & from town on top of this.

You will remember this place for a long, long time. Better than Ankgor Wat. Go early morning as it is a much better experience when no people are around. You can easily go through this in less than 2 hours...save the afternoon for the pool at the hotel when it's blazing hot outside.

Angkor - South Gate of Angkor Thom - Wonderful way to enter history. After visiting Angkor Wat for sunrise our next stop was the entrance into the huge Angkor Thom complex. Across the short bridge to the splendid and impressive south gate of Angkor Thom. Lines of carved figures, many now being restored, guide you to your first experience of the huge faces. The entrance is wonderful. Quite narrow and a little dangerous with all the traffic flying through so keep an eye out. But is sets you up very nicely for what's beyond, particularly the Bayan Temple.

Beautiful complex. It is more a city than a simple temple complex. The gate to Angkor Thom is a very interesting site on its own, as it features rare carvings of hindu god of lightning, Indra atop his three headed elephant.
Beautiful temple. It is probably the second most visited temple complex next to Angkor Wat but very spectacular and different from Ankor Wat. Go to discover it !

Bayon and Bakheng for Sunset. Angkor Thom houses many temples and Bayon is the one that you shouldn't miss. Bakheng is where you can see the sunset from atop a hill.The other temples like Phimeanakas or Terrace of Elephants etc are good to see too, but if you have limited time, these can be skipped or you can just at least walk by to see the exterior. From Bayon, you can walk across the street to see Phimeanakas and other temples and end in Terrace of the Leper King.

Good but not great. Angkor Thom (meaning ‘Big Angkor’) is the old royal city of Jayavarman VII, and was the last Angkorian capital of the Empire. It was once claimed by the Cham Empire from modern day Vietnam, but when King Jayavarman recaptured the city, he began building a wall and a moat around the most important structures within Angkor Thom, including Baphuon and Phimeanakas. In addition, he built the grandiose Bayon temple at the centre of the city, which was used as his state temple. Angkor Thom nowadays is perhaps best known for the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrance of the Leper King. Most visitors will enter the city of Angkor Thom through the South Gate, but there are four other entrances: North Gate, West Gate, East Gate, and the so-called Victory Gate.
Loved angkor thom. we were there at sunrise with almost no one else there. A magnificient sight. We loved it so much we went back two days later.
Added bonus!. Visited Thom after Angkor Wat. Much smaller but equally impressive. Be aware, it gets very busy, if you've got kids, keep them close.

Must see. In essence, the temples are the reason to come to Siem Reap. So, reviewing them in Tripadvisor is probably a bit of a waste of time, since anyone will go there anyhow. Hence some hints: Entry fee is US$ 20 per person per day. Quite a lot but think what you will see and for what the money is. Go there in the morning before sunrise. Still thousands of people but less than later.There will always be people there, get used to this, it is still ok. During dry season, the lake in front of the temple is nearly dry (so don't be disappointed). Don't forget the backside of the temple, gives nice pictures, too, especially since you have the sun in your back.Even with a guide, you should be done in about 3-4 hours, unless you really want to go "story after story" (bear in mind that 1 hour you just wait for the sunrise).

A superb experience. An excellent site to visit. The various temples and the Elephant and Leper King terraces are superb. An elephant ride around Baphoun temple is a must. Plenty of monkeys to be seen, but they can be a little demanding. Beware!!

Happy Face. If you like to see a happy face on the wall this is your place. I think it was beautiful. There are 4 faces looking 4 directions of the stupa (conical structure). My travel advice to anyone is good place to go but maybe try visiting this first than Ankor Wat as this place is more beautiful and it gets really crowded as the place is small. So not to have 100's of people on your photos you can choose early morning or late afternoon to go there.

starting to get templed out. As this was our last stop, I was starting to get "templed" out, seeing so many temples. This was attached to several others, all the way to the Terra of the elephants and Terra of the Leper King. This one started to look ordinary after seeing the other main temples. But at least our guide provided some 'modern" photography techniques, where we can have pictures taken as if we were "nose to nose" with some face statues. Another curious thing here are the presence of the monks. There was a huge sitting buddha outside this temple, and what was curious is that in one of the towers, I accidentally saw a monk lying down on his side, as if he was a lying buddha, except the monk was alive, in his orange monk suit, asleep. It was a very unique sight to see, as if the temple came alive!
Hard to match up to Angkor wat. Having read up in advance expected a bit more ,didn't appreciate in effect it is "just" a temple, the entrance bridges and gates are impressivethough

Must see attraction. I totally loved the whole Angkor Wat experience, and Angkor Thom is equally impressive. The. Last capital of the Angkorian Empire. Like Angkor Wat this is a must see attraction if in Seim Reap. Remember to wear sensible shoes as the ground is un even and there are plenty of stairs, ensure to take drinking water and as a side note please don't touch the sand stone structures as sweat and acid from your hands will damage the Sand stone. A world marvel and worth the effort. There are heaps of great photos to be taken so take a spare camera battery with you.
Magnificent. WOW! How were they able to construct this temple in the 12 century?! I was in awe from the first gate. Seeing the sheer size and detail in all the carvings was magnificent.
Bayon, Hidden Wall. Recommend observing all the faces on Bayon temple, climbing steep steps of Baphoun and walking down to see the Hidden Wall at the terrace of leper king.
spectacular. The main temple , i really loved it , had a guide who explained all about it .A lot of tourists , but thet didnt stop me enjoying .

Jungle Book came alive for my son. monkeys, elephants, pools and temples. It was breathtaking. Get a guide through your hotel or at the ticket counter. Women must cover there shoulders and knees in some parts. If you have kids under the age of 12 they cannot visit one area but its not a really big deal. You do not miss out on anything. The grounds are amazing.

Much larger than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is the name for the ancient city which is just north of Angkor Wat. It was surrounded by a 12km long wall with gates at each point of the compass. Most of the gates and wall still remain. Its best to cycle or get a Tuk Tuk because it covers a large area, you can even visit by Elephant. Highlights are the Bayon - right at the centre, also known as Four Faces Temple. There is the newly restored Baphoun, and nearby Phimeanakas (pyramid structure) which you can climb. Also noteworthy is the friezes called Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King. You could easily spend a couple of hours here.
Magnificient. Enjoyed my trip to Angkor Thom. Superb temple and I was amazed on how it was built. I am still wondering how they managed to build that.

A must see if your visiting Siem Reap. Angkor Thom is the bigger more spread out temple complex to visit when in Siem Reap.It is easier to find some space on your own in this complex with lots of different parts to see.Highly recommend.

Bayon was our favourite. Bayon temple with its gigantic faces was unique in every which way. From far it looked like a mess of stones. The mystery unravels as you get closer. How many faces can you count?

Remarkable. This is a great place to walk and climb around and be amazed at the fact it was built by hand over a thousand years ago. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes, bring water and wear a hat as it can get very hot. While your there, make sure to take a "nose to nose" picture.
Beautiful. Really beautiful even though lateron we saw that ta prohm was even nicer :) Definitely a must see in this big choice of temples :)
Temples. we spent 2 days trawling around the temples. they are well worth a look. we also went to some of the less known temples as well.

Magnificent Site. The walled city of Angkor Thom was once populated by more than one million people. You will marvel at the eerie stone heads and the evocative bas-reliefs of the Bayon temple, the central structure of Angkor Thom. Move on to the Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King.
