It is well worth having a authorised guide who will decipher the myriad of stories behind the bas-relief carvings and give you a much better insight into the Khmer empire.

Great to explore. This is the site of the ancient royal city and consists of a few main temples and many smaller ruins within the city walls. The city is around 9 square km's and makes for excellent exploring. The main temples are great, but start wandering away from the masses and you'll find some hidden treasures with no one else in site. Just watch for the lone people giving you free advice then asking for donations, they're all very pleasant but don't feel obliged to give, it's most likely a scam.

A huge site!. This site contains the Bayon temples, the Elephant terrace and other interesting constructions. It is probably the second most visited temple complex next to Angkor Wat. Go early to avoid the crowds and be sure to check out the other temples in the surrounding area.

Lovely historic place. Amazing place where visitors will take hundreds of photos. Loved it. Like at Angkor Wat, we were pestered with unofficial guides that charge extortionate amounts of money for a poor service. We never used a guide but suggest if you want a guide use an official one...
Beautiful face temple. This is the temple of the faces. You'll love the contraction of it all. Very spectacular and different from Ankor Wat. Since its a Buddhist temple.
Loved it. An amazing site that must not be missed. The craftsmanship just blows your mind. Take your time to absorb the history and serenity.

First one we saw , lots of hidden faces. This was the first temple we looked at on our first day, from the outside it does not look that impressive, but that was the side we approached from, once inside you have to just keep looking around and you see more and more little nooks and faces.

Was expecting more, some sights still worth seeing. A good friend always told me not to miss Angkor Thom, that it was even more worth seeing than Angkor Wat. Of course my hopes were all up and I was quite disappointed. Besides Banyon the rest of the temple complex (it's huge, consists of mores sights) was OK. Considering that there are some really fabulous other less known sights to see.
A must see. One of the 3 main temples to see in the park, would be a shame if you missed this as it brings more history and stories.
Great temples. Some more amazing temples. The whole complex is just incredible. The views from the top of the temples are amazing.
A walk through this ancient city is beautiful. Make sure you don't allow your guide to convince you to skip the remaining ruins of the palace and the temple behind 'The Elephant Gate'.

Great Temple. This temple is pretty close to Ta Prohm, there's a shortcut that you can take to get there quickly. Neat temple that you should stop by to see if you're in the area. This can be a pretty short trip.
Must see. It is on top of my "must see" places.It is absolutely wonderful.One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen.

Lovely. After we had visited Ta Prohm, our guide brought us to the East Gate of Angkor Thom. Here we stopped for a short while to admire this old gateway with its carvings of the Buddha and the balustrade across the old moat in the form of a seven-headed naga (cobra) - although this latter was somewhat damaged.

The next most popular site next to Angkor Wat. Against Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, this must be the third most visited site within the Angkor Wat Park.This site contains The Bayons, Baphuon, Elephant Terrace etc and you should allow a good 2 hours to explore and experience the complex in it's entirety. Again, you will need to use a good guide to organise a visit when the crowds are low, especially to benefit from the great photo opportunities at The Bayons.Elephant rides can also be had, and there are groups of native monkey's roaming around freely (take care of your food stuffs as they will snatch and can become aggressive).Likewise with the other two complexes previously mentioned, this should be on your to see list to make the most of your Siem Reap experience. Especially if your time is limited and you cannot get out to the remote ruins (Beng Mealea, Benteay Srei, Kbal Spean).

Fantastic . We really enjoyed the early morning cycle here from siem Reap. The trees were full of yellow blossom and the air full of butterflies as we rode there. One of the main advantages of arriving before 6am is how cool and quiet it is. The bus loads of tourists arrive on their temple tours at about 8am. It was beautiful to see the early sunlight hit the carved faces. You can climb to the upper levels easily - these close when it gets busy.

Stunning. Rode here on bicycle as part of the 30k Temple circuit. All the Temples were amazing.It was really hot and without the breeze on the bike to cool me I powered through the water.Ate lunch with the Tuk Tuk drivers in the carpark - all in all a great experience. The people that built these Temples sure were rich!!

A Remarkable Vision. The Sight of the Enigmatic faces which has four huge smiling faces is awesome. The Bayon is another area which has more than 200 stone faces ,loved also the Terrace of Elephants they look so real will never foget this day.
great. A great temple again with lots of the same kind of structure but the carvings and tall buildings were fantastic.

gorgeous world heritage. Incredibly World Heritage, I visited the Angkor in the early morning as my friend and I want to get a great shot for sun rising. After passed entrance fee we walked in the dark, there was only light from torch and keep waiting for the sun. Once the light from the sun is coming and we turned around, we had a bit shocked as many people were around(not sure up to ten thousand or not). Eventually, the gorgeous light was coming behind the Angkor and reflected on the water in the front. Well, after got a great shot we explored around and found that it's very huge more than our expected.

Gorgeous Temple - Must See. These temples are all so gorgeous and this is yet another MUST SEE. It's ancient history and sheer size is incredible. Make sure you take water with you to these sites as there is nothing to purchase etc. and also have great shoes! You'll be walking all day through these ancient but incredibly fascinating ruins! Take camera for some incredible photos...you feel like you're walking through history.

Incredible and so much to see and take in, be sure to have good walking shoes !. You are overwhelmed by the beauty of the ancient temples and you are in awe trying to figure out how were the temples built. There is so much to see and not enought time to take it all in. The terrace of the elephants, the terrace of the Leper Kings Bauphuon and the Royal Enclosure are a few of the major structures you will see. It is advisable to read up on Angkor Thom so you can keep up with the tour guide's explanation. There are wandering photographers availble who will take wonderful inexpensive photos of you with a backdrop of the temples. They also have a number of pedi carts that are available when your feet start hurting. In addition to sun screen you must also have bottled water and excellent walking shoes not sneakers. There are small shops scattered about. Fortunately, all the vendors and pedi cart drivers all take American dollars. In the afternoon you need to take a break, take a shower, and take a nap so you can get energized for the afternoon tour. You could spend several days at Angkor Thom and several days at Angkor Wat. There is so much to see and so much to learn.What a wonderful place of learning and beauty.
Amazing. its like being in Toom Raider or Raiders of the lost Arc. It has to be seen to be believed. My favourite place in Anchor Wat

My Favourite. This really got to me. I had already visited Angkor Wat but this blew me away. Loved the entrance with the 54 gods and demons each side but loved most of all the heads Bayon.
Don't miss this one. Should be top/2nd on your list.

Incredible experience.... Simply amazing to visit this extraordinary place. It's humbling to walk through this complex and marvel at the age and condition. There is constant restoration going on, but necessary to keep the jungle at bay. A beautiful place and truly a wondrous experience.

Historical sightings. All the temples in ang kor wat look almosit the same haha its is in the state of renovation when i was there , every temple is different with different gods etc, its worth to visit

Grand!. Wide fields, the Bayon, magnificent gates, grand terrace, etc... all these are at the Angkor Thom.... i've heard that it was the capital of the ancient Khmer civilization... Here, like that in Angkor Wat, you will find a big area for souvenir shops, and restaurants... if you are fortunate enough, there are elephants for riding too... sure you dont want to miss them.
Fantastic. This third temple site was, like the others, so well worth visiting. Each temple is different and each in its way, worth the visit.

History Oozes. Angkor Thom is an amazing collection of temple ruins in varying states of disrepair and renovation. The four main tourist areas are Bayon Temple, Baphoun, Elephant Terrace, and Terrace of the Leper King.The Bayon Temple is stunning, and the history is fascinating. You can climb all over the structure, as long as you don't stray off the designated tourist areas.You must dress appropriately because this (and all ancient temples in Siem Reap) are active religious shrines. No bare shoulders, cleavage, short shorts or short dresses. Dress code is enforced.It's unbelievably hot in Siem Reap, even in early April. (And I'm from Florida, so I'm saying this as one who might have a higher than average tolerance for heat.) Go very early in the day, or wait till after 3:00 p.m. to avoid heat exhaustion or worse. It's wise to carry a parasol to keep the direct sun off your head.You'll need 2-3 hours to see everything in the Angkor Thom city complex, and you'll want to be done by 11:00 a.m, if you do a morning tour. Between 11-3 the heat is just too intense. Bring lots of water and wear very light clothing. And wear sturdy shoes because you'll climb hundreds of stair steps on unsteady surfaces.There's no formal concessions area in Angkor Thom, but hundreds of local vendors hawk their wares from tents at the entrance and far inside the city walls. You'll be literally thronged with people begging you to buy water, postcards, scarves, etc. Admission to the temples is $20 US per person per day. Or you can buy a 3-day pass for $40. This includes admission to ALL temples in the Siem Reap area. Each pass is personalized with a photo ID, so don't plan to purchase a partially used pass for less.History and archaeology fans will love this attraction. It's well worth the time and the price of admission.

A paradise for tree lovers.... This was one of my last stops at Angkor Wat and again it was gorgeous. I love how nature intertwined with man made buildings/temples. Obviously the trees are the main attraction here. You should definitely stop by here after Angkor Wat and Bayon.

Don't forget your shoulder wrap. Angkor Thom was the only place where the modesty rule was enforced and also the only place where I left my sarang in the tuk tuk. Angkor Thom is a large and vast complex with many different temples, a cool colonnade, and a long wall surrounding it.

As good as Angkor Wat, but not as large. Our group visited Angkor Thom whilst staying in Siem Reap for a few days, and whilst its very easy to get completely "watted out" in Siem Reap, I really would recommend that you try and fit this one in if you have the time. Its as beautiful as the main Angkor Wat temple, but the site is nowhere near as large, so you can see the whole site in about an hour or so. Its also nowhere near as busy as the main Angkor Wat temple.
magical magical magical. do not leave your camera behind. you may need to utilize your handphone camera too coz there will be so many views to capture.
Great Temple Complex. We went to Angkor Thom by tuk-tuk, and spent several hours exploring. Not as restored as Angkor Wat but still worth visiting.

Happy smiley Faces.. Angkor Thom is vast & you can spend a day just in this area alone.
Try to entry via the East Gate. Yes South Gate is the picture perfect location, but East Gate, watching the sun rise is so much better.

Incredible and untouched ruins. We had an incredible time exploring the ruins and climbing over massive ancient stones that were pushed aside by growing trees. This was a truly unique site and we preferred it to the over-crowded and reconstructed Angkor Wat

City area. Obviously more a city with a series of sites that just one large temple like Angkor Wat.
It includes the Bayon, Entry Gates, Terrace of Elephants, Baphuon and Phimeanakas plus a lot more. You could easily isolate a whole day and wander through this area

Someone's Watching. There are faces all around and if you look closely, you'll note that it is the same face carved in the various temples on this site. Built in the later part of the 12th century, it is an amazing site to visit and, with Angkor Wat, well worth spending a day seeing these temples.
Magical temple. This is what you've come to South East Asia for. An incredible structure unlike anything I've ever seen. Those faces...
Large complex - worth the visit. This temple is a must on your trip to Angkor. Great carvings. I recommend a guide to see all of the temples.
Really worth the visit. I loved it and visited all temples in three days, if you want some advises, check my Angkor Archaeological Park review.

Magic and mistic place. Magic, mystic and historical place in Asia.
Sorrounded by a beatiful forest.
The Baphuon pyramid is unique and spectacular

Catch it early. On the advise of our guide we arrived at this temple early,6-30 am,to beat the crowds
Definitely the right decision as we could imagine this compact site becoming very busy
Very impressive,loved the whole feel of the place
A must to visit whilst in the area

Faces of Buddha. This ruin is unique in that you have so many faces of Buddha on so many of the spires. It is a great one to crawl around and small insets for great pictures. Certainly one of my favorites as well. Hated seeing the elephants though. Those carriages on the back hurt the elephants spine. Don't ride them!

The last capital of the Kmer Empire. This city is surrounded by an 8 metre high wall forming a perfect square. At the exact centre is the amazing Bayon Temple. Enter the city via the South Gate to view the carvings.

Take your time. We got so many nice pictures at Angkor Thom. The towers and faces make for some great photos.
Make sure you give yourself enough time to really enjoy this site.
Wat yourself out. The whole Angkor complex it truly remarkable one can only imagine what it would have been like in its prime

A unique place. Very fascinating, not to be missed!
We would advise getting to Angkor Thom early in the morning or late in the afternoon, if possible with a tourguide to avoid the crowds.
It's absolutely worthwile!
Beautiful. Angkor Thom is only a short distance from Angkor Wat and both can viewed in one day. Angkor Thom is over a big area so be prepared to walk and climb a lot of stairs to see it properly.

Immense. So much to cover here, but the temples and adjoining little village were the highlight. Don't miss the elephant and Leper King terraces and brace yourself to climb to the top of the temple across from Bayon.

Simply stunning. Another one of those places that we just had to visit, and looking back at our photos it was well worth while. A great experience. Left me wondering how on Earth they did this so many years ago. Not quite as good as Egyptian antiquities, but not far off!

A must to visit. We started our visit at the Southern Gate of Angkor Thom, then to the famous Bayon, Baphuon, and Phimeanakas temples, plus Terraces of the Elephant and leper King. We then went to visit Ta prohm. After lunch we continued to visit Neak Pean and Preah Khan and back to explore Angkor Wat temple, the 7th Wonder of the Ancient World and climb up to Bakheng Hill to watch the sunset over Angkor Wat and the surrounding area. A very exhausting day but well worth the visit.

awe inspiring. Yet another absolutely amazing temple complex. The size is a little overwhelming at first, coupled with the crowds and the heat, but my advice get a good guide, take your time and truly enjoy what is in my opinion the most amazing complex in Angkor. Oh and bring a spare camera battery and a big memory card cos its a photographers dream!
A MUST see!. Angkor Thom was a surprise to us both. The beautiful temple consisted of many of the carvings that we thought were at Angkor Wat. We also did the elephant ride here, and LOVED it!
Impressive!. The collection of temples speak of times of glory. Make sure to find a good tour guide to learn the history behind the stones.

Huge and amazing architectural feat. This is the ruins of a huge city with many temples and other buildings. It has a moat and a wall surrounding it, which shows that it was fortified when it was built. When you enter through the most-used South Gate, you see over 100 statues of gods and demons carrying huge snakes. The gate is huge, and is topped by a rower with four stone faces facing N, S, E, and W. Don't miss the Terrace of the Leper King and the Terrace of Elephants.
Great. Do not miss this amazing temple if you come to Siem Reap. I love this beautiful temple the most during my holiday in Siem Reap. Highly recommend to everyone who plan to visit Siem Reap.

A must see. Have to go here as it is amazing, again the tourist get in the way of your photos as there are so many of them and 36 degree heat doens'tt help. ensure your tour bus has air cond as you need it.

Ancient city full of surprises. Entering the city along the bridges flanked with the guardians of good evil on each side holding onto the Naga and then going through one of its five gates takes you into a serene forest dotted with temples and structures. The tree lined road full of tuk-tuks but not maga tour busses made the journey around Angkor Thom a great experience. The elephant and baboon terrace was spectacular for their carvings and our favourite temple The Bayon was located within.

The old capital. Huge. Get a tuk tuk to drive You through a massive area of lost and found temples. Bike? forget it, too hot. There are few temples worth watching, the rest is 'naaah, the same'. Take some lunch with You as there is no good place to eat in there. And they overprice You very badly (two continental breakfast and drinks for 12 USD - for the price of full dinner in center of Siem Reap)

A great surprise. Huge complex of temples, with some of the largest in Angkor.The entrance gates are very interesting, super high with huge faces carved in the black stone.The Bayon with dozens of these faces carved in even higher towers of black stones are just amazing!

Another amazing wonder of the Khmer empire. I loved this temple complex! We felt like explorers in "the great city"! The Bayon temple was spectacular! Much has been written about it... I went in the afternoon and it was over 100f - pretty hot.. So you may want to get there as early as you can. Just remember to visit the Bayon temple for an explorer like a experience. This place is great!

Ancient City. Angkor Thom covers a vast area with many interesting structures and ruins and is a complete ancient royal city. As such it takes a long time to visit the whole site and appreciate the grandiose scale of everything. The most impressive structure is the Bayon Temple which is the subject of its own entry and reviews, and definitely should not be missed, but there are numerous other structures which are worthy of attention if ytou can afford the time. In this category I would particularly mention the Terrace of Elephants. Make sure you have a good plan of the site, a decent guidebook, or a guide before visiting this site.
Perfect view. If you are someone who love to take picture...Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom is the place to be. Got a lot of extra ordinary shot in this place
Huge complex. Angkor Thom is a huge area with a variety of structures, ponds and terraces. Of course the highlight is the faces of Bayon.

Faces and towers. An incredible city. The faces as you enter are wonderful. Built my King Jay V11 who appeased the people by retaining the Hindu symbolism together with the Buddhist. Go with a guide as the history is fascinating. The size and number of the towers is quite remarkable. The wall within gives a real incite into the life of the people in those times. If you are not one for too many temples, this one must be on your list

Unbelievable. One must be prepared to walk through vary rough and uneven levels of the part of the ruined temple but the grandeur of the place that might have been gives one to think how magnificent everything must have been.

Colossal buildings. Be observed by hundresds of siling Buddha faces all over the ancient fortified city. It is the remains of the glorious and powerful Khmer empire. Star the visit through the South Gate- the most preserved one. Find Gods and Demons statues lining this gate. Visit the many galeries, low engravings and calm, smily faces in the Bayon temple, the highlight of this city. Climb and be astonished at the top of the Baphuon temple, one of the most importanat hindu ones. It is a pyramid and represents the Meru Mount, house of the gods. Pass by palace-temple Phimeanakas, or climg it if you still have your breath. At the end of the tour, do not miss the Elephants arena, with elephants engraved in details.

Should visit before not after Angkor Wat. A visit here should precede your visit to Angkor Wat. It will give you a better perspective of the scope of Angkor Wat. The history out classes anything we've seen in our travels. Lots of stairs no elevators.

Awesome. The Angkor Thom area alone is 9 sq km. The access roads through the impressive gates all lead to the middle temple, The Bayon. around which numerous temples and sites are situated. You could spend 1-2 days in this area alone without doubling up on temples.
Home of the Bayon. It is simply stunning, home of the Bayon. Just let the atmosphere soak into you. Everything you expect and more.

A rich history. This site puts European history in perspective. With most structues dating about the 10th century it is an impressive site for such a time given its scale. Not only is there the challenges of the structures but the decorative design is impressive. It rivals Egypt in its magnificence.
magic site. we went by tuk_tuk , a great way to see it , best in the morning , a really magnificent site . certainly the main attraction

A one of a kind. This place needs money spent on it Needs restoring Parts not safe Lots of steps to climb A great place to visit & you need plenty of time If you like history you will love this A beautiful place for sunset photos
Known for faces. Faces were carved right into the stone, and it was amazing. As impressive as Angkor Wat. Really enjoyed our time there.

Extended site. I preferred this to Angkor Wat, although both were very popular and thus crowded. Angkor Thom is massive and it deserves more than a 1/2 day visit. Make sure you walk round the outside of the Elephant Terrace wall and not just on top of the wall.
One of the better temples. The faces are great. They made for some great photos. This and Ta Prohm were my two favorite temples.

Great temple ANGKOR TOM. I had been Siem Reap few time but this time i went to Angkor Thom. Because before never gone. Very big temple and old but very nice designed. Really good building. Dont forget going to visiting when you are in Siem Reap.
Beautiful. Another fabulous temple...not as large as Angkor Wat but also amazing. Try not to go during the lunar new year, as there are lots more tourist during that time

Old capital city Siem Reap. This visit was well worthwhile. The site is huge (9km square) and so you need several hours to get the feel of it.
There is a roof area at 55m which is worth climbing to as you get the chance to see the full aspect of the site.

Excellent experience with Khmer Angkor civilisation. It is very romantically to go to forest and find some forgotten and hidden temples. Best days are in the period January-February. Go up to Pimeankas temple and see some strange parrots around. Wonderfull...

Great for kids. Great temple for kids to run around, our 2.5yr old loved it.
Good wildlife and photo opportunities.
Get there in the early hours i.e before 830 to have it to yourselves. We did this after Angkor watt, and timed it such by not viewing the sunrise at Angkor watt.
Impressive gates. The gateways to this temple area are extremely beautiful with good and bad creatures guarding the entrances.

wonderful spectacle. This is a beautiful spectacle, with a wonderful rich history - not to be missed by visitors to the region.
It is worth planning the time of your visit to avoid the busiest parts of the day, as the atmosphere when quiet is amazing.
Spectacular!. We loved Angkor Thom and this place is massive! Bigger than Angkor Wat so make sure you allocate a good amountof time for this place.

Great site. The old capital of the Khmer empire dynasty, with the bayon, ta prohm, the victory gate and all those bridges leading into the site were all amazing. There's basically no way of you walking from spot to spot so remember to hire a tuk tuk or get a bike.
A must do!. Everybody knows of Angkor Wat, but don't miss Angkor Thom! What a great place to visit. Grand and impressive but at the same time fragile and delicate. What a fantastic monument!

This is the name of the largest site. The Bayon temple is found in this part of the complex, and is as mind-blowing as the others, albeit more accessible, and gives easier access to the carvings of Buddha's four faces on each tower

Beautiful. Angkor Thom is a complex of temples - a city in ancient times. You can only cram as many temples as you can in a day so if you have limited time, you can skip the others as generally, after a while, they will look pretty much the same. The noteworthy sights here are the Bayon with its mysterious carved faces, the Terrace of the Leper King and The Elephant Terrace, as well as Phimeanakas and Baphuon (notable for how long it took for it to be restored), both three-tiered pyramids.

The faces are staring at you from all directions. It's USP are the carved faces on the edge of building. They seem to look everywhere and miss nothing! Take care when walking as some surfaces are a little uneven. Well worth a visit.
Amazing, huge complex. Not just one temple, but a complex. The terrace of elephants, the gates to enter, all stunning. Worth having a guide (for all the temples)

One of the best temples. This temple was very interesting and had a lot to see however was very popular with other tourists. I would recommend to see this temple at a quieter time. There was lots of photo opportunities including the 'kissing king'. This is not a good temple for those with mobility issues.

Impressive. Angkor Thom is impressive with the eerie stone heads and evocative bas-reliefs of the Bayon temple and the terraces of the Elephants and Leper King.. A lot to see in one day with Ankgor Wat, but well worth the visit, and is unique to Cambodia

Our first temple.... This was our first temple and I think you'll always remember the first one you see because they are just so awe-inspiring. For some reason, the crowds were not in evidence and we were able to take our time and have our guide explain things as we wandered all over the temple and take some fantatsic photos. The sun was going down slowly which gave the whole experience a mystical feel. As we wandered past the Elephant Terrace we saw a party of locals enjoying a picnic- I pointed out to our guide that the car they were with had no number plate-he told us that the owner had probably just taken delivery and was out celebrating and showing off his newly imported vehicle. We also came across two little boys collecting empty plastic water bottles- sometimes the children you see around the temples are actually looking after the area-their families may have the ancestral right to live there and they take pride in maintaining it. Enjoy!

More memorable than Angkor Wat in my view. I really, really enjoyed the visit, and if I had to choose only one temple at Siem Reap to visit, this would be it. The faces of the Bayon Temple are iconic, but it is a huge structure with masses to see.My one main criticism is that there were no guards anywhere in evidence to stop thoughtless (selfish) tourists from climbing over the guard-ropes and climbing on/touching the stone statues and carvings in their desperation to get a photo of themselves with a 'head'. If the authorities let this go on for much longer, little will be left for future generations as this damages the structures and ruins the carvings. You know who you are ... be ashamed of yourselves.
Huge City. With Bayon as it's centre piece the gates and walls give some idea of the sheer size of the original city
Another temple. This temple is impressive, and one worth seeing, but if you see too may in one day it gets confusing which is which!

A must on your sightseeing list. An evocative environment of unique distinction very different from most other tourist destinations. There is little more to add that you cannot find in one of numerous guidebooks.

Another amazing visit. Somewhat spoilt by the cranes and renovation work but a necessity judging by the collapse of so much of this temple. It is worth an hour or so of your time though so don't miss it from your tour. So many red-breasted parakeets screeching overhead, and too many people so mid-day didn't alleviate the crowds but it was an overcast day, so more people out and about. Incredible sites of the trees and nature reclaiming was swans once hers.

Magical Temple...Angkor Thom. A city not far from Angkor Wat inspired by Buddhism whose impressive site is the huge four faced Buddha. Surrounded by walls and five gates built in the 12th century. Enter by the south gate and visit the Terrace of the Leper Kings and the Terrace of the Elephants a place for public ceremonies.

Fascinating. So large. Who would of thought that so many years ago, an area of this size could be developed form the 12klm moat and walls to the temples inside. Take your time and take in the moment as you walk around the area. If you are in a small enough vehicle (van or Tuk-tuk) you can go through the main gate. Magnificent in itself. Then you drive further in until you reach the temples. Walking sure and water are a must. Don't forget your camera.
amazing. More than one attraction at this location. The carvings and the different buildings to walk thru and the jungle setting made it worthwhile
a must see. this ancient city is wonderful to explore. you can probably spend a full day just in this area. Don't miss it.

World Heritage Wonder. Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat are why people go to Siem Reap. Where as Angkor Wat is "self-contained" Angkor Wat is laid out over a vast expanse so you have to budget enough time (at least 3 - 4hours) to see the highlights. Pick up a guide book and just start walking. You will be continually amazed by the temples, structures, gods, demons, moats, and overall layout of the city. Don't miss the causeway as it enters the magnificent gates, Bayon Temple, the Terrace of Elephants, Temple of the Leper King, and the many other smaller structures as you walk around.
The best one. For sure this is the most amazing group of temples of Angkor civilization. Try to visit these templos early in the morning due to hot weather and lot of tourist groups.

Fascinating in all respects. I'd compare the whole Ankgor Wat, Angkor Thom and all the other many Khmer temples from the 8-12th Century as being as important and as interesting as Pompei, Macchu Picchu, Great Zimbabwe, the Egyptian pyramids, and other such remnants from old civilisations.

VERY BEAUTIFUL AND UNIQUE. the beauty of the city is its amazing design and the huge area of which it lays , all the indian travellers will like this place as they would be able to connect it with mythology and local folk lore of INDIA. For others it will be a new experience amazingly preserved like the old times

City from the past. the Entry of this city is probably where temple run got its graphics from. Simply amazing, and Majestic. Wish I had a timemachine to see the city in its glory. It needs to be restored in several sites, but the overall area is expansive and beautiful. If you are a history buff like me you will LOVE this place

Ancient temple. A visit back in history. Huge, filled with fascinating carved stone pillars. It was easy to get lost - try to remember where you entered. We went during the morning to avoid the excessive heat of the day.
Must See. Agree with the other reviews that this is a must see, and I enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat. Take your time as there is a lot to see, and take lots of water in the heat.
not to miss. We very much liked this temple site. Impressive entrance , you can make very nice pictures here. A lot of restoration still to be done, but it is absolutely impressive

More interesting than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is a great way to spend 4 hours of your day. Just rent a bike and take a look at all the temples in the city. Personally, I found the individual temples to be much more interesting than Angkor Wat. My personal advice is to either go extremely early in the morning at sunrise and go to Angkor Wat as soon as they open or check out Angkor Thom until about 4pm and then go to Angkor Wat when the crowds have died down a bit.
Bucket List. Impressive. It looks like the setting of some Sinbad movies from the 30's. Go early to avoid crowds.

Wonderful place. We visited here the day before Angkor Wat and I must say that I found it just as as entrancing, although some might see it as the 'poorer cousin' of the two.
It was of course much more than 'just' a temple and there is so much to see - don't under-allocate the time for your visit here.

Liked these Better than Angkor Wat. We went to Angkor Thom first as the tourists were swarming over Angkor Wat.Good choose by our driver.We were able to get great photos with no people in our way and it was very relaxing.A MUST do stop in Siem Reap.Just loved it

Fantastic. Be there in the morning when the buses are not yet there! Especially at the Bayon. 216 stone faces look at you from every angle possible and it is good to have some time without the crowds to study and enjoy this special place.

Lots and lots to see.. There is so much to see here trying to do it in one day won't work. Try and work your times around the loads of busses that head here. Pick a top site and head there first before the crowds. Later on in the day it gets packed. Some sites don't allow children under 12 years due to the steep steps.
Interesting Tempel. Ankor Thom was also a interessting Tempel, but after Angkor Wat its just anotherone. Very nice place next to Angkor Thom to walk around.

Well worth the time. Our favorite site, Bayon Temple, is inside Angkor Thom. It's the one with the faces. Not nearly as crowded as Angkor Wat and smaller, it's well worth an hour of your complex visit.

Sorry for the ruins. It was a pity that this heritage site was in such a seriously ruined state. It could be a steady source of income for the country if all these could be preserved and restored to boost the tourism industry.

Huge. This was our first temple visit in Siem Reap. It is really a City and was just huge. There were a number of tall temples with extensive steps that are fun but a little dangerous. Some of the steps are concave from weather and use and one set of stairs was so steep we had to hold onto the eroded lava rock on the sides to get up. Getting down in one piece was a challenge

WONDERFUL!. I went in Angkor Wat 2 years ago for 3 weeks with my husband and two children.Wow! Just WOW! Amazing ? Fascinating ? How on earth to describe it?This place IS the place to visit! ( temples, architecture, history ).People are very very nice, food excellent, cheap jewellry to buy, great night market, etc ...Fascinating place for the children aswell! ( they loved going around town in ' Tuk Tuk ', discovering temples, learning so much about their culture and they learned how people paint with ' rice ' and how carving is made ).We had no time to be bored! Just wonderful!

Goes without saying.... If you are in the Angkor area, this is a must see. The architecture is totally different from Wat. Though this is more ruined, it gives you a different feel from Wat as this king wanted to distance himself from his father-in-law who built Wat. Be sure to see the nearby palace. As our guide said, Angkor Thom is a great city and Angkor Wat is a great temple.
Gorgeous. Would highly recomend going with a guide. Best to go early to avoid the crowds and day's heat. Your hotel will likely be the best place to find a suitable guide.

The Temple of Compassion. As we approached this temple and approach the naga figures that precede the majestic gates in our Tuk Tuk we felt like royalty. An amazing city that must have been truly magnificent in the time of Jayavarman VII. Once again how I'd love to be able to look back in time. We entered one gate and walked to the opposite gate to be collected by our Tuk Tuk Driver.

Massive. This complex is huge and encapsulates so many different sights. I think we only scratched the surface of this place. The gates and soldiers protecting each side of this complex are really wonderful.

WOW. Second stage of a two part visit to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Hired a tuk tuk which is the way to go, cold water, cold towels, pick up & drop off around the site, etc. Best way to maximize our limited time. Easy access to the site with limited stairs. Great photos opts through out the site. Do not miss the Elephant Terrace which can be difficult to find due to a limited amount of signage on site. We much preferred Angkor Thom to Angkor Wat although both are a must see. Go early to avoid the heat and crowds. A good hat and walking shoes are a must given the lack of shade and distances travelled. Another item crossed off the bucket list.
Amazing place. Every temple is great and every temple is worth visiting. A definite place off my bucket list! From Angkor Wat to Angkor Thom, the place just amazes you.

Great and some parts well preserved. There are lot of temples in Angkor. I liked this one. Anchor Thom was constructed as a capital by Jayavaram VII . It was the last capital in Angkorian period. The large four Buddha head victory gate is very impressive . There are I believe five entrances to the walled city. Well worth a visit
A whole day's worth. If you have the time and live to stare at murals, you could spend a day here. I've not managed to do it all in two seeings.

What a place!!. 55 years ago my Mother told me stories about this place and now I have been blessed to see this great temple structure. A Buddhist capital city build in the Khmer jungle. The 3 square kilometre walled city is beautiful beyond emagination. A must for everyone!!
Great visit. The first temple that we visited on our trip and a good place to start. The towers with the buddhas were just amazing. Well worth having your own guide for the day

Anker Thom. This was the high light of my trip in Cambodia. I could of stayed all day just looking at the amazing faces on the temple towers. Just blew me away. The reliefs of monkeys and elephant were stunning, the whole thing is astounding, to think it was built in the 12 century is crazy. Would love to go back and spent some more time there.
So many fantastic attractions.. This place ranks number two if you can only see two places . The problem in Siem Reap is a surfeit of attractions. But this place is well worth the time. Go for it.

First day Eirst temple we visited. This is the first temple we visited on the first day. We took 3 days pass 40USD each but to cover 7 days.
We went to Angkorewat the last day(reserved the best for last to keep the best impressions).

Another Spectacular Temple Complex. Hard to distinguish which temple complex is better. The temple complexes in Cambodia are amazing. Ankhor Thom is no different. It is a little smaller than Ankhor Wat, but just as grand. Well worth the time and effort to see this temple.

We got there early and enjoyed the uncrowded serenity. We really enjoyed Angkor Thom as we were not crowded by large tour groups, who appear to feel they have right of way...
We climbed and wandered in relative solitude, which allowed us to spend time on the details. This is a large and beautiful complex.

Stupendous!. More impressive than all the photos and movies taken here! Loved seeing the ruins in the niddle of a jungle of ancient trees and roots--it looks as though it's been barely disturbed over the centuries.

The Great City of the Khmer Empire. This temple complex is huge! it is about 3 kilometers from one end to another. Here you will find many famous sites such as the Bayon, terrace of elephants, terrace of the Leper king, and Baphuon. You will want to schedule a chunk of time for this place because there is so much to see. Other than the Bayon, other places where not that crowded which was a relief. Also there are other minor temples in this complex such as the Preah Pitu Group which are fantastic. I took some time to explore them it was ridiculous. One thing i really enjoyed about them is that these are practically empty. I was there literally with the whole temple to myself which also made for wonderful photography changes.
A Must See. I found Angkor Thom to be more impressive than Angkor Wat. The Buddha faces are outstanding. Have your guide take a picture where you can go nose to nose with one of the faces
Great. One of the 3 in the small circuit, love the faces in the spires and easy to get around. Makes great photos

Mind boggling!. One more thing to cross off our bucket list! Truly fantastic, not to be missed spot! I was so glad that I chose sneakers this day...too much climbing and uneven ground to risk anything else. Take extra battery and cards for your camera!!

Yet another incredible area. This should be taking in on a separate day from other attractions in the area, there is just so much to take in. Do not be put off by the crowds of visitors you will inevitably be sharing space with, you can always find a peaceful space among the stones. A wonderful and awe inspiring experience.

Tour Guide Exceptionale!. Knowing we had a very brief time in Siem Reap to visit the Angkor Thom area, we decided a guide could be of some benefit, cutting to the chase with the facts, figures and other pertinent information. Our guide was just so much more! Kanha (of Kanha's Tour Guide Services) had previously emailed a suggested itinerary of our day which transpired to be 'spot on'. It contained enough touring and sufficient detail we could absorb in our one day together, along with other handy tips. Greeting us at our hotel with a kind and beautiful smile, Kanha kindly presented us with a gift. Her transport was clean and comfortable and, very importantly, airconditioned! Kanha was very mindful of our physical abilities in the hot climate; her supply of cool towels and drinking water was plentiful and generous.The tempo of our tour was comfortable and, her experience steered us away from the hordes of other tourists visiting the temples. It was almost as if we were the only one's there! The tour and the region did not disappoint. Though, I'm sure that was due to Khana's good management rather than our good fortune. Our experience was exactly as Kanha had promised; unforgettable. We will cherish our memories of the day forever. :)

Magnificient temples. Make sure you go early as the day can get very hot and tiring to climb up and down the temples. Practically a whole day here. Really interesting and obviously a must see in Siem Reap.

The essence. If I had to pick just one complex to see around Siem Reap, it would've been Angkor Thom. It has a little bit of everything. I found Bayon to be a more interesting temple than Angkor Wat, Preah Palilay temple though can't match to Ta Prohm, but the trees on top of it do inspire imagination no less, and when you think about the whole complex as of a huge ancient city... Don't believe tuk-tuk drivers that say two hours is enough for the whole Angkor Thom. We've spent 1.5 hours only in Bayon, and could've spent twice as much, if we didn't have so many other things to squeeze into the day. The whole Angkor Thom took us ca 4.5 hours.

Angkor Thom a must see. Organise your tut tut boy early as they have a tendency to sleep in as you want to get in early before the crowds and the heat of the day. Like all of the sights in and around Siam Reap you need time to take them all in and it is a must to have in your possession your three day pass, lots of water and charged batteries in your camera as if your a keen photographer like myself you will take lots of photos. So enjoy, like we did.

The center of it. Angkor Thom is an area where several temples have been built, including the magnificent Bayon. The whole area is a continuos WOW, especially the Terrace of the Elephants....a beautiful walkway with awesome carvings.

an impressive complex; a ‚must’ to see. Angkor Thom is a kind of wall around the ruine complex of Angkor Wat in the Cambodian province Siem Reap. the big stoned face on each corner or wall are impressive

Angkor Thom. The first temple we visited and we ended up spending almost the whole day there, completely unaware of how time was flying. There is a lot to see so if you plan to visit this one, make sure you have a 3 day pass and a whole day to spend here. Flat shoes with grip are recommended and be aware that there are LOTS of stairs to climb. If you're scared of heights, this is a great time to put that fear in your pocket or else you will miss out. I promise it will be totally worth it!
Favourite. This was my favourite of the temples had great vibes from this place loved the monkeys roaming around and the jungle feel of it lot of character in this place !
Amazing. For a while now I have want to see the temples in Siam Reap and they didn't disappoint at all. It's a amazing a bit of history and if you get a chance to see them you should
Amazing!. We toured here in the late afternoon with lovely light to show the temple off. It was simply amazing and to think over 900 years old! A must see.

Visit Ankor Thom before you tour Angkor Wat. In order to get a feel for how Cambodian temple architecture and sculpture evolved, our tour guide suggested that we start by visitng the temples (Bayon and Baphuon) in the walled city of Angkor Thom prior to touring Angkor Wat. It was a wonderful idea. I was particularly surprised by the huge relief of the reclining buddha spanning the entire rear wall of Baphuan, the earliest of the three temples.

The 'face' at Bayon is the prime attraction. The city of Angkor Thom is near Angkor Wat. It has 4 gates - north, south, east, west. Inside are several temples including Bayon in the exact center. Bayon has many carvings of the same interesting face of Avalokiteshvara. The face resembles the King Jayavarman VII. Thom is big enough that you need transportation to get around to all the sights. There are places to eat outside, but I think the food is overpriced and low quality. I had sweet and sour chicken for $6, it was not tasty. The people there are very friendly. I had a guide book but no guide. I had a guide when I first visited a few years ago but the names and dates become a blur. I would not recommend a guide. The entry fee is included in your Angkor Wat ticket.

Brilliant. We loved this temple and the old trees coming out of it. It really did blow us away. Having a guide really does help, as he knew how to avoid most of the masses, great photo spots and lots and lots of information about the temples, what we were looking at etc.

J7's Legacy. Angkor Thom was much more impressive, in my opinion, than the more well-known Angkor Wat. I felt like I could really imagine what life must have been like for the Khmer people during J7's reign when I was touring through the vast areas inside Angkor Thom.
This could take a while.. What can I say. Amazing. Check out the walls, watch out for dodgy cops and have a great time. Do it good sunlight and the photos will be great.

Wonderful temples. What an amazing place to visit, the temples are so atmospheric and a wonderful place to walk around. Take the time to walk through the historical gardens and go back in time, see the Elephant Terrace and wonder at the skills of the local people.Take time to go through the south gate and walk across the bridge over the moat to see the statues of gods and demons holding the Naga Snake from the 12th century.

Awe Inspiring. Nothing more to say about this amazing place than awe inspiring. And you can still find a few little temples where you are the only person there. Spent 2 full days seeing everything. Just take some lollies or candy to give the kids that pester you.

An amazing complex of temples and walks thru history. This is one of the best if not the best complex of temples anywhere in the world because it has so many amazing historical sites in one very large area, ok the Taj Mahal complex is stunning but is not as old. Baphoun & Bayon as individual temples are brilliant but so to are the kings gardens. A wonderful walk thru historical gardens trying to imagine just how these places would have looked a 1000 years ago. As in other reviews I would really love CGI to be used to recreate a vision of how all the temples once looked because like the pyramids there was a lot of colour that is no longer present except on very small sections, clearly in their day these places were magnificent. On the outer wall of the Kings garden there is a wall with a line of elephants carved in to it, when you see the scale of the carving it is mind boggling to imagine how many craftsmen must have been working on these sites at any one time. A note to first time visitors, suggest you arrange with your hotel or guide to buy your 3 day passes a day or so before you commence your tour of the temples, it will avoid a potential loss of 2 hrs at the ticket office which on most days is a nightmare! The 3 day pass is valid for up to 7 days, so buying the day before still gives 3 days out of 6 to choose.

How to Avoid The Crowds. We were with a bicycling group, and after making our way through traffic, immediately upon entering the gates of Angkor Thom, we turned off the main road, headed left up a hill, and in 2 minutes found ourselves on top of the "wall" that surrounds this old temple city. There was no signage to point out that this was a possible approach, and we were just about the only ones on it. Eventually we made our way to the Bayon Temple, and later in the week came back to visit some of the other areas (elephant terrace, sunset hill) - but the highlight was just biking along the wall. I believe you can walk this path and you don't need a guide, so my advice is to find your way to explore the perimeter, and then make your way into the inside of the temple afterward.

Awesome Walk. Angkor Thom is not a temple itself but a complex with several awesome temples. You should include Bayon, Baphuon, and Phimeanakas temples in you list while in Angkor Thom.You can also check the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leper King or have a memorable photo shot while crossing the Victory Gate.There also also eateries within the complex just in case you get hungry during your tour.
Another must see. Ok, as usual, go early. The day we went, we almost had the place to ourselves. The bridge/entrance was so interesting with the different carvings.
Vast but interesting. A very different temple, but no less interesting. Good to see the various parts of the 'estate' and to walk through the grounds....takes about 2-3 hours, but very relaxing.

Great walk.. After the Bayon, head to Baphoun following the little walk way. And from there take a stroll through the forest to all the following sights until you reach the Elephant terrace. There are small flags to guide the way, so you're unlikely to get lost.Most tourists will cut the walk and go from big sight to another big sight. By taking the walk you'll get to enjoy also a few smaller sights and get some peace while roaming through the forest. This little hike was certainly a favorite of mine.

Awesome. This residence built for one of the Kings is so large you need time to take it all in. Worth walking around to get full appreciation of size and take your imagination with you to see it as it was built.Truly spectacular. Take a tuk tuk so you can see the country side and get a feel for Cambodia.

So much more to see.. Angkor Thom is a huge complex and we only had time to see a handful of sites within. It is certainly in the same league as Machu Picchu and Petra in terms of extent and the sense of awe.
Wonderful. A great place to visit, full of interesting carvings, statues etc, certainly a must while in Siem Reap.

Bayon Style. Of all the temples we saw this was one of the most recent (early 13th century). It was especially fascinating to look at the giant faces (there are five entrances-gates- one for each cardinal point and one leading to the Royal Palace area. Loved the giant faces.

Favorite area in the Angkor Wat area. Beautiful. Went for sunrise at Angkor Wat temple, then visited Angkor Thom. We had the place to ourselves - it was absolutely stunning. The Elephant Plaza is a 'don't miss',
Great. Don't miss this is the one with the giant faces. Loved it! CAn climb all over everything and took tons of pictures
Hindu/ Buddhist temple. Amazing architecture great photo opportunities. Again just a ruin so no relics to enjoy but steeped in ancient Cambodian culture

Better temples than Angkor Wat!. The temples within Angkor Thom were great! My best recommendation would be to get a guide that can give you the background of everything so you can understand why things were done and why they are in such ruins today.

Fantastic!. Loved this place. Of course there were ubermilliontrillion crowds on New Year's Eve but it was still worth it. Fortunately we had a great guide who avoided the crowds and knew many tricks for good photos and avoidance of other tourists.
Highly recommended site to visit. It is awesome indeed.

Great with a guide. Take a knowledgeable guide, and take the unbeaten paths. Walk the less known spots as well as popular ones. Go in first half of day or late in day when sun is low for better pictures.
Not Essential. Overall I was not that impressed with Angkor Thom. Perhaps I was templed-out after seeing so many other temples but could have easily skipped it.

A Must on the list. The terrace of the elephants is amazing!!! The good thing about Angkor Thom is it's big enough to hold all the visitors, but pity it's a bit too touristy with tour groups shouting and chatting… Remember to go to the North gate - it's the most beautiful one among all the 5 gates.

Incredible Place!. Venerable and lovely, you can see the love and skill and that went into the creation of such a special place. Unfortunately the huge crowds are taking their toll on it thousands upon thousands of people wear it away. It was wonderful and the opportunities for great photography abound if you can get a shot without some tourist group in the way.

Gorgeous. Angkor Wat is a massive complex and in the heat it can get tiresome and testing. We arrived early at the complex to see sunrise over Angkor Wat and then spent the day going through the temples - hire a tuk-tuk driver for $15 a day it's really worth it! Angkor Thom was truly stunning, it's amazing that it's still in good condition! The views the more higher up you get are stunning so take the hike!

Just a wonderful place. For anyone with even a passing interest in architecture and archaeology, Angkor Thom is a must see. Its hard to pick highlights out of the many attractive temples that are contained within its ancient walls but I would caution anyone from doing too much in too little time. Pace yourself and avoid being "Templed out".
Speechless. This is beyond words, just get along and see it, soak up the atmosphere serenity and spirituality. Peace and calm reign.

Bayon. Really cool place and a fun and interesting visit here. There is a spectacular entrance and the "Naga" bridge leading into the temple is amazing. Lots of monkeys at this location, so watch your wallets and store your food!

Magical temple. The entrance to this temple through the large archway gate is impressive.
The temple is very compact wit so many interesting carvings. Not to be missed!

Next Bestest Thing. After Ta Prohm this is the next bestest in my view.The 2 most intriguing items here being the repetitive images of Bayon and then the stone frieze.The frieze at Angkor Wat is probably better preserved and somewhat more intricate but it is also probably a little repetitive. What makes the Frieze at Angkor Thom so impressive to me is the depiction of everyday events like fishing, cooking, harvesting etc alongside the images of marine war and dead bodies floating in the water and being devoured by crocodiles etc.The other thing of interest was how being so pragmatic when the rulers converted to Hinduism they set about systematically excising the buddha images from the stonework.And yes you can ride an elephant here for a fee. As an early explorer said though an hour on an elephant is about the equivalent of 4 on a horse.And you can also get a shameless selfie if you have a local tourist policeman nearby to set it up for you and then sell you a very nice copy police badge.

Beautiful Temple. This is yet another beautiful temple that we visited. We had an elephant ride and we rode around the temple area. We also went inside this temple and once again, it was so beautiful. All those intricate carvings were just amazing.

Next Stop after Angkor Wat. After visiting the Angkor Wat temple, this is your second stop. Highlight of this temple is the image of Bayon. The ruins are equally stunning. You can also ride an elephant here ( for a fee ) and the animal will take you around the vicinity.
Amazing. Yet another incredible Temple experience . Not to be missed well worth a visit. Wear good comfortable shoes and take water

vast. The complex is vast with fantastic sights at every turn.You will need a fair amount of time and energy to get the best from this experience.We went round the whole temple on our first visit and then returned for a secong trip to our favourite bits
Very interesting and picturesque. This is one of the best and most picturesque of all the temples. Be prepared for a bit of climbing but the views from the upper levels are well worth the pain.

amazing. A wonderful abundance of temples....get a good tuk tuk driver and follow his advice...ours took us from one to another and everywhere you look is a photo opportunity...found this much more informative than Angkor watt....and less exhausting.Definitely not to be missed....it was an amazing experience and would go back because there is bound to be something I missed.

Awesome !!!. This ancient city has a very interesting entrance. To enjoy the beauty of thi ruin ancient city, it would be very nice if you have read about angkor thom before you arrive here or there is a guide explaining you about its magnificence.
A full day for anyone. The many temples kept us wandering the ruins all day. There are many small restaurants with good food for lunch.

The many faces of Buddha. Angkor Thom was the palace of the king and he had 54 Buddha faces constructed for each of the provinces (at that time). Even though there has been much destruction, the faces of the Buddhas are still interesting and intriguing. Definitely an important site to see.

Angkor Thom. It was the last and most enduring capital built by King Jayavarman V11 in the late 12th century.I covers an area of approx 9 Sq Km and requires private transport fort sightseeing besides intense walking.

Great place. When in angkor than you have to visit also angkor thom. next to angkor wat located you have to visit it also. be sure to plan some time for it and see the amazing carvings, architecture .... ! Be aware that you are not alone :-)!

Large temple, like Angkor Wat, but smaller.. Went with group and a guide which was helpful and informative. This is another one of the great temples in the area. Comparable but smaller than Angkor Wat, but just as nice. Bring water due to walking and climbing.
Smaller temple than Angkor Wat. Amazing piece of history. Disappointed that more of the reconstruction was not undertaken by Cambodian government. But still amazing to see.
big. great temples in one big compound so get ready for a lot of walking and climbing hundreds of steps..
Temple vs. trees. It is amusing to see how the trees have overpowered the ruins, seemingly boasting their territorial rights to the land, and the temple.
This was the most atmospheric of yhe templrs.. Like some weird rock formation with faces drawn on its columns. We tried hard to imagine what it looked like covered in jungle.
Not as great as Angkor Wat. but still very imposing and generally part of the Angkor Archaeological Park complex tour. Took the cheap tut tut tour ..only USD$15 for the tut tut that sits max 4 people

A Must. It is a Must going there!
So impressing all the Thinks to See. Wonderfull - indeed. Take a Ride with the Tuktuk or One of the bikes you should not miss.

GREAT CITY!. Angkor Thom or “Great City” encompasses a huge, square area of land enclosed within an 8-metre high defensive wall and outer moats approximately 100metres wide. Each side of the wall is about 3km long, and it has been speculated that, at the height of its wealth and power, the city may have supported as many as 1 million people. The founder and architect was the Buddhist King Jayavarman VII, probably the most prolific builder the Khmer Empire ever produced. (the above is taken from the city description leaflet) it is just a wonderful place and you will enjoy being there to explore it

Plenty to see and do. Many different temples in the complex and I would recommend a tour guide to give you the history. We did watch the sun set from Prunom Bakheng. We arrived up at the top about 2 hours before sunset and had the 2nd best seat there. Lot of interesting things to see and you have plenty of photo opportunities.

Contains some Amazing Temples. Although there are a lot of tourists here, these temples are absolutely breathtaking and my favourite place by far. I would highly recommend trying to go before it gets too hot and bring a camera because it's worth taking photos of!!!

Several great things to see at Angkor Thom. If you are rushed you can do the three main areas all in one day....get up early and do Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm before the tour buses. Go back to hotel for lunch and a massage before heading out to Angkor Wat around 3pm.

Visit to Angkor Thom(Angkor City). After visiting Angkor Wat,our tuk-tuk driver Nak,took us onwards to the other ruins of Angkor Thom means Angkor City. From one ruin to the other was fantastic and amazing and of course tiring and need to have alot of patience & endurance from sunrise to sunset to be able to take or film this fantastic world heritage considered as one of the wonders in the world. So take a breakfast break say from 8.30 to 9.30 then 11.00to 11.30 coffee break;13.00 to 14.00 lunch break, 15.30 to 16.00 coffee break then finally until sunset at 17.30. Make a schedule of your like how you want to visit the ruins lesser breaks & meals if you want to make the most of your visits.

It is worth a visit. It just grows on you . It takes over 2 hours to see it in depth. Need your camera. The same ticket of Angkor is valid. At the entrance of south gate there is car parking. Need a guide to explain this fishy temple. It has a lot of history and so someone is needed to explain you. From certain spots if you take a photograph it looks as if you are catching the nose of The Lord Buddha. The elephants area at the end is worth the visit.

Worth a visit. We went here after Angkor Wat so a totally different place. We walked over the bridge and found the sculptures to be very interesting and then quite a hot and dusty wwalk to the temple. Our guide was explaining the relief wall which was very interesting but it was so so hot that we switched off a bit.
Short and sweet. The visit to Angkor Thom wasn't as grand as Angkor Wat, but suttle beauty was seen through the arch and the structure hallways.

Majestic. Of course Bayon is the gem of Angkor Thom but the secret is to climb up the hills on the outside of Victory Gate to photograph the face with elegant trees in the fore ground. Most groups just stop to see the outside of this elegant gate structure....ask for more.

The last capital of the Khmer Empire. Enclosing an area of around 360 acres, this massive walled city was the last capital of the Khmer Empire.As such it holds an exquisite and varied array of buildings which include monasteries, temples, priests' residences, offices of the palace and military, administrative buildings, ceremonial and entertainment areas of the kingdom . among others.The Bayon, Phimeanakas, Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Prah Palilay, etc are some of the names one might be familiar with. These structures were built of wood whihc has perished as the jungle took over, but the remaining stone monuments testify that Angkor Thom was indeed a "Great City" as its name implies. It is possible to cover the area on elephant back . We decided to walk , and were thus able to explore quite a few of the many structures scattered around this vast complex. Do carry plenty of water as you will be quite thirsty as you walk around -- a wide brimmed hat is also essential.

So Much to See. There are four gates leading into the ancient city of Angkor Thom, with the south entrance being the most popular as it is close to the entrance to Angkor Wat. The city is surrounded by a moat, and the bridges crossing the moat are lined with statues of devas on the left and asuras on the right, Hindu deities representing good and evil.Inside the walls are many fascinating sights to see: Bayon, Baphuon, The Terrace of the Elephants, The Leper King Terrace, Phimeanakas, Preah Pithu and Prasat Suor Prat among them. You can easily spend a full day (at least!) exploring the various temples and other archaeological sites at Angkor Thom. You can walk all of it, of course, but I recommend hiring a tuk-tuk driver so you can cover more ground and also have a little rest and cool down in between each stop.There are places to get hot food and cold water within the city walls, and there are decent bathrooms as well. For an enjoyable break, there is also a spot along the main road where families of monkeys gather, and they are quite amusing to sit and watch for a bit; you can buy fruit or lotus roots from locals there to feed them.I enjoyed Angkor Thom very much, and wish we had set aside more time to see all of its many treasures. It's a fascinating place, and I hope to make it back there again one day.

Wide variety to see here. We liked this complex more than Angkor Wat for some reason. Perhaps because it was more varied with the elephant and leper king terraces and all the other temples in the complex but I found this visit to be the most interesting of our trip.

Awesome. The south gate is dominated by a structure that is four sided, each has side has a face and each face represents one of the teachings of the Buddhist religion that face the four cardinal directions ... it is reached by a long causeway that is flanked by carved gods and demons

Admirable complex of Khmer. This is the first in my temple tours. The area is very large that may take you a whole day if you explore all. Many faces and the most impressive one is 4 great Buddha faces sculptures. We are lucky to have a knowledgeable guide. He told us stories happened in history, the golden age of Khmer, the meaning of architecture features. This have ideal places to climb up and enjoy the amazing views from the top.

Plan to hike around the temple city to appreciate the scale!. This is more an ancient city than a temple with several temple structures and terraces within the long walls.Tip: plan to hike around the site to appreciate the scale and see some of the less frequented spots.

Sunset gondola ride was perfect. Our guide through Absolute Asia Travel arranged for a gondola ride on the moat at Angkor Thom at sunset. Floating on the peaceful water while our guide made gin and tonics for us will be an experience we will never forget.
Large but rather dilapidated. A large site with lots of walking-not as impressive as Angkor Wat,with some areas undergoing restoration.Nevertheless a very interesting site to visit in this area

beautiful angkor. Make Sure you visit the southern gate..a beautiful ancient cityDon't be lazy and climb to to the top of the temples, you won't regret it..Some of climbs can be daunting but one has a hidden shrine where you pray if it's your thing and receive a blessing..Easy access. Vendor area separate. Amazing views..
Another amazing place to visit.. Just another fantastic place to spend some time thinking about what it might have been like all those hundreds of years ago.Well worth a visit.

City Housing Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Terrace of the Elephants and Others. Angkor Thom is the city that houses a number of significant ruins and is a must see when visiting Angkor Archeological Park. The primary temple located at the center of the city is Bayon. Just to the northwest of Bayon is the Baphuon Temple, the Phimeanakas Temple, and the Terrace of the Elephants along with some other smaller ruins. Just northeast are Prasats Pour Prat, the Khleangs, and some other smaller ruins. All of these are within easy walking distance of the central Bayon temple. Also noteworthy are the beautiful and ornate gates at each of the entrances to Angkor Thom. Along with Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom this definitely needs to be on your list when visiting the Angkor temples!
Do Not Miss!. Spectacular, massive reliefs on the walls, huge towers and grounds, elephants passing on the road - the highlight of my Angkor trip.

Beautiful. We started our visit of Angkor at Angkor Thom and loved it. The entry gate alone was spectacular. One building to the next, each interesting in their own way. Loved Bayon, the Terrace of the Leper King, and The Terrace of the Elephants. Everywhere else we visited was compared to Angkor Thom!

Good to learn the histroy closely. My family enjoyed very much here since we can have close look at the real world heritage. But some temples with age restriction.
So if you plan to bring your kids, you better know of that.

Temple of the Faces. Amazing, temple hidden under the trees. Beautifully carved structures with their own story to be told. The never ending story and histtory telling by our guide never bore us. The smiling Buddas calm us. Magnificent views from the temple top is just so awesome. The calming effect is so intense when you set foot in the temple ground. Though it was so crowded yet you can feel the peace there. The rain didn't stop us from exploring climbing furrher and spending our whole day there just in this one temple.

All the faces. We visited to see the temples "with all the faces" as we were told and we were not disappointed. Not a far tuktuk away from Angkor Wat, this quiet temple had a lot of charm with its variety of faces. There are lots of places to climb around and see the views from different angles.
Largest Cambodian temple. You could spend a whole day just visiting this single site. It is huge and contains a huge number of massive 4 faces of Buddah Sculptures. A knowledgable guide is essential.

A true wonder. Different to Angor Wat but incredible all the same. Even there were a lot of tourists around, this place seemed to be so peaceful and calm. This was the best of the temples, with its many faces, carvings, and other structures.There truly are not enough adjectives to describe the temples. I were impressed by the size then Angkor Thom and I think this site is a photographer’s dream space, highly recommended.

So worth seeing. Even though we saw this temple in the pouring rain, it was so worth it. The faces of the compassionate Buddha are everywhere smiling at you. You can see the grandeur it once was. Restoration is going on, but they have a long way to go. It is particularly interesting to see how the temple was altered from it's first incarnation as a Buddhist temple, then changed when the Hindu's were back in charge, then changed back again

Tomb raider. Amazing like the rest of this beautiful place.900 year old temple abandoned and reclaimed by nature creating something impossible to build. As though nature has taken over care taking duties but also sadly destroyed some of it.

OMG.. Just like Angkor Wat this place is well worth a visit. Both places need exploring. The trees are unbelievable. So much history here. Give yourselves plenty of time to see these places as there are no doubt the highlights of the area.

Angkor Thom. This has to be the highlight of a visit to Seam Reap. The Ancient Royal city tells a story that is very powerful and is an excellent introduction to Angkor Wat even though, to my mind it is so much better,
Magical. This is one of my favourite Angkor temples. It's got lots of different areas you can disappear to. Love it! The trees are amazing too, taking over the temple

I´m without words (almost). I don´t know what to say except it´s amazing. The whole experience at Angkor area with all the temples is awesome. I especially liked Angkor Thom with all the carved stone heads. It doesn´t look big from the outside but when you are inside it´s easy to get lost. It took me half an hour to find the place I got in to the temple area. It didn´t matter, got some really nice photos on the way....

Fascinating.. If you have a guide with you, it is amazing to hear the history of this temple and the stories behind all the magnificent carvings.I found the Ankor Thom area to be even more interesting than nearby Ankor Wat.

An important stop for a three day tour of Angkor.. Angkor Thom is a huge, historically and architecturally important site in Angkor, and should not be missed. Absolutely book the best guide you can find to accompany you. There is too much to learn about these sites without having professional input along the way.There are a large number of temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and outlying areas as well. Don't feel you have to see them all. Three full days of touring are important to do this world-class venue justice but these are the Don't Miss sites, in this order of priority: Angkor Wat, of course, the stellar, Number One site; Bayon; Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King; Ta Prohm; Bandrey Srei; Preah Kahn; Pre Rup; Neak Prean.Give yourself time to visit your three favorites a second time within your three day itinerary. Many are so overwhelming in their interest, architecture, and artistry that you must see them at least twice to begin to appreciate them. We had to see the Churning of the River of Milk at Angkor Wat three times, as it was so artistically stunning, and is comparable to the greatest carvings anywhere in the World.

Amazing temple complex. Victory gate, bayon, elephant terrace..... So much to see here. Lots of beautifully restored wall carvings that tell many Khmer stories. Walking the complex with a guide you can truly get the vibe of the hundreds of thousands of people who lived on the grounds outside the temples a thousand years ago. Incredible art and architecture!

Lots of opportunities for great photography.. Smaller than Angkor Wat but very impressive. You get a sense of being watched all of the time, with the faces pointing in each direction on all of the pillars. Lots of opportunities for great photography.
Amazing Place. This was the best of the temples, with its many faces. Both my daughter and I loved this temple the best.

I preferred this to Angkor Wat. This has a sense of space which I did not feel with Angkor Wat, The buildings are slightly worse for wear but still very impressive with the gate ways, the terrace of the leper king: the terrace of the Elephant there is a lot to see. Highly recommend you pick up a guide to talk you through this city. Travelling about in a tuk-tuk is an easier way to get a feel for the space, so when you have to walk you are not drained. I did the early start (5am) for Angkor Wat and then moved on to Angkor Thom. By lunch time I was done in

Best of the Angkor national park. Some much here, I can really recommend entering via either Tuk Tuk or on foot, to make the most of the gates.Good clean FREE toilets with friendly staff. Lot's of places to eat - which are better than they look.Other attractions are covered by different entries on TripAdvisor

My favourite. Absolutely breathtaking on arrival. Even though there were a lot of tourists around, this place seemed to be so peaceful and calm. A drive up to the temple we saw monkeys sitting on the side of the road. You ventured into the temple climbing up onto rocks and taking it all in. If you could manage the steep stairwell you could go to the top level, where the view was absolutely breathtaking. There were performers dressed in costume and for one American dollar you could have your photograph taken with them. There was even elephant rides for 15 US dollars. Of course the usual vendors were there selling their goods. Cold drinks available. And as always don't forget the insect repellent. (Upon entry to the temples you must have your photograph taken - and this ID to be carried on you). An absolute must to see when in Cambodia !!

Angkor Wat. Awsome !. Could have been better if not during the rainy season. But less crowded.A lot of walking and climbing.Steps are very steep and slippery at some places.Despite all those ,I enjoyed myself.
Regal temple. Not to be missed. The approach is wonderful if you can stop the Chinese pushing their way to the front.

A collection of the best of Angkor Wat. I loved the gates, especially in the morning. Looking down the long, straight roads in the misty morning light you begin to see the gates that protect entry to this wonderful collection of temples. I sat at the gates and watched the locals making their way to town and work, on bicycles, motorcycles, elephants..... Watching them pass through the gates, silhouetted against the morning mist was breath-taking.

My Favourite. Huge imposing, but subtle looking faces greet you throughout this beautiful temple. It's hard to imagine how each piece fits in to make this incredible temple. The age of the temple reflects in the adornment of carvings from a Khmer past. Definitely a must on your travels. Can be overcrowded at times so chose a good time to go with your guide.
Better than Angkor Wat. Loved it - Bayon, the Victory Gate, Terrace of the Elephants, Phimeanakas etc - very atmospheric and great to explore.
