As well as Angkor Wat this is a must see place!. If Angkor Wat is a must see place, so is Angkor Thom! Here you get the real Indiana Jones feeling because the temple ruins are actual ruins and you can see bit's and pieces of the temple just lying around.
Magnificent!. One of the highlights of any trip to Siem Reap. Truly monumental. Great for photographs. A must see.

Nature Walk Along Outside Walls. Go to one of the entrance gates and getup on the walls where you will find a good path (locals use them and unfortunately now - bike tours for tourists). Walk away from a gate to one of the corners where you will find a corner building and nice views. Easiest and closest access to Siem Reap is to start at South Gate (inside) Angkor Thom and go up onto the wall walking West with the moat to your left. After about a half-hour stroll you reach a nice corner temple (prassat chhrung) with a good view out over the waterway west. Depending on the season - birds and butterflies.
Angkor's ancient town. This walled ancient city of 9km ² concentratea great remains of the angkor empire... They say you could visit it by elephant, but the day we went there weren't any... :(

awesome. It's a contradictary feeling. I like to see the temples up high but have to tediously mount up flights of steep and narrow wooden /rocky stairs . For some temples , we are required to climb up the irregular , narrow and steep rocks to reach the skyhigh temples overlooking Angkor Thom from height. My conclusion is~ go early when you still have enough energy and before you get too fragile to walking and climbing. It's worth putting it into your bucket list.

A must visit. Loved Angkor Thom! It was a welcoming social place compared to Angkor Wat. It was the end of a Buddhist festival and all the Vietnamese were taking food to the monks. The monks have to stay in the pagoda during the festival. The atmosphere was wonderful and my ride on Ceazer the elephant really made my day! Wonderful beautiful place!

Great place to start your temple visit. First temple I visited and I'm glad as I had time to view many features and then walk to top for great outlook? elephants and female carvings outstanding. went without guide and was still able to find space and solitude. Take a bottle of water with you as it can get pretty hot

Angkor Thom : Poetry in Stone - 1. Angkor : An epic on stone If you love historical and mythological sites with a taste for sculptures and architectural marvels, there is no place better than Siem Reap (Angkor) of Cambodia. Angkor (=Capital city derived from Sanskrit word Nagar) was the heart of the immense Khmer empire that flourished in Indo-China from 9th to 13th century. It is today an awe inspiring magnificent archaeological park. I and my wife visited Angkor in Oct-2013 for 5 days. We are Hindus from Tamilnadu of India. Tamilnadu in India is well known for the temples steeped in history and Hindu mythology, some of them date back to pre-Christian era. So we are naturally attracted towards Angkor. Angkor Thom: We spent two half days at Angkor Thom (Capital city, the Big). It is a huge city which housed 1 million people inside its compounds in the 12th century. It has four gates one each in the four directions and one more gate on the East called victory gate. Each of the four gates have 54 devas on one side and 54 asuras on the other side of the Cause ways holding the big serpent Vasuki in their attempt to churn the cosmic ocean of milk. Ten headed Ravana is spearheading the asuras by anchoring near the head of Vasuki while Hanuman is doing the same with Devas anchoring near the tail of Vasuki. The gates sport benevolent looking and smiling faces of Bodisattva Lokeswara on four sides of the tower. The face has broad noses and remind us of the statues of Pallava style of Dravidian architecture. The mysterious face is based on Buddha's calm face with facial features of King Jayavarman 7 (affectionately called as J7), arguably the best Khmer king. A big moat is running around the city. As we had gone in a rainy month moat was full. At the center of Angkor Thom is the Bayon temple which is a Buddhist temple with a good fusion of Hindu symbolism. Our guide Chhen Kol explained that J7, though himself a follower of Mahayana Buddhism, exhibited tolerance of religions and provided places of worships not only for Buddhists and Hindus, but also for those following animism and spirit followers. The panels depict normal daily life in those periods - cooking, food distribution, boar cooking, barbequing, midwife nursing a delivery of a baby etc. There are scenes of war and close combat between Chams (Vietnamese) and Khmers sculpted in detail. The naval fight in Tonle Sap lake with the flora and fauna of the lake is also very vividly described. Army march with its band, supply lines are well presented. In short they are all poetries of stone. The towers sport the faces (supposed to be 54 in total, but available now is slightly less). My admiration for J7 is big and I intend to do an in-depth study on this fascinating king. For want of space I stop my commentary on Bayon here. There are so many places of historical importance are in Angkor Thom. To name a few, 1) Elephant Terrace from where the king and royalty watched games on the ground 2) Leper king terrace which hosts the cremation place of J7, the great. Today a statue resembling Buddha is kept on the place of creamation 3) The lunar towers which were used to judge the right from the wrong in a case referred to royal court 4) Phimean akas (Royal temple) 5) Baphuon a huge temple
Must visit.. Excellent sight-seeing. The carvings are perfect and represent an interesting historical period of deep Hindu influence in Cambodia.
Big Daddy. This place is huge and takes time to enjoy. Wander and marvel at all that is here. Takes one back into a time when we knew how to build things with our hands...amazing and a must see.

Fascinating Archeological Site. Angkor Thom, whilst smaller than Angkor Wat, is just as interesting and is quite different from the Wat, having many different features of interest. Well worth a visit, allow around one and a half hours to enjoy the best of this site.

The gate is special. Angkor Thom was a walled city and its main gate was elaborately decorated. The lines of elephants standing side by side with their trunks hanging to the ground are still in good condition and different to other parts of Angkor.Within the walls are Bayon temple and Elephant Terrace - see separate reviews
One of my favourites. As with all the temples go early if you have enough days in your trip. As with all of the temples you'll take a stack of photos. Beautiful!
MUST DO. Must do -has a Wow Factor -If you only have one day In Siem Riep This is must do! its the gateway to Bayon Temple-you can get a guide book at site for $4-$5 and self guide thats what we did!

Not to be missed. Angkor Thom is truly impressive and well worth the trip. We were fortunate to be on a Gate 1 tour. They engaged Hoy Pheakdey as our local guide and we would certainly recommend his services. We also read the novel Temple of a 1000 Faces by John Shors prior to going which helps understand the context. Plan to reread now that we are home. Don't miss the hike to the top to enjoy the view. Many guidebooks imply that you need hiking shoes for this excursions but we were fine with good supporting sandels, hats and water.

ANGKOR THOM IS TERRIFIC. Departing at 5.30am from our hotel we headed out of Siem Reap with our guide and caught the beautiful sunrise over Angkor Wat and then we proceeded to the nearby ancient 12th Century Angkor Thom. Although we were the first to arrive at this spiritual temple there were many eyes starring down on us. The carved faces that adorn the magnificent temple are everywhere and as a result they are a photographers delight. Be sure to walk into the central depth of the temple so you can look up at the sky - a great sight within this ancient architecture. The inside stone pavers can get very slippery so take care.You should allow at least an hour or two here. Be careful if you take a packed breakfast box (available from most hotels if you pre-order it) because the monkeys that 'caretake' this temple think that your breakfast is theirs and they will do anything to get it. They liked my 'donation' !A temple not to be missed.

Smaller than Angkor Wat. We visited this site before we visited Angkor Wat. It was smaller than the impressive Angkor Wat site, therefore, one take more time looking at the different temples, carvings, and other structures. This site was more enjoyable because we could really look at everything without rushing about trying to see it all. Another reviewer suggested seeing this site first and early in morning. I agree with that. As the morning progressed more and more visitors arrived! At Angkor Wat it didn't matter what time of day one visited, it is always crowded. Also, there are less stairs to climb at Angkor Thom!
Angkor Thom. Ancient and awe inspiring with many unique historical features!Huge and needs at least 1/2 day. We had a beautiful day to visit.
Best part of the park. By far the most interesting of the sites, would start there on my next visit. Best time of the day is later in the afternoon.

Fantastic.. This is a must see in Siem Reap - sure, it is not as impressive as Angkor Wat , but if you had to pick two of the dozens of temple ruins to visit this would right there just behind the massive Angkor Wat complex. It is FLOODED with tourists - so go early early. The massive carvings are extraordinary (when you can see them for the hoards of camera toting folks) - but be advised that some of the steps are EXTREMELY steep - worse coming down than going up. Once you climb it though, you are in for a treat. The view is terrific. Amazingly well preserved - you wonder how long it will stay that way with thousands of visitors a day clambering over it.

Stunning temple. This is.a must see. Spacious temple and good photo oportunities. However it is quite dangerous in the wet. One particular passageway was flooded and you had to climb slippery bricks to avoid.

Beautiful!!. While visiting the temple sites be sure to climb all the stairs and observe the view from the top. Amazing, stunning, fantastic. There truly are not enough adjectives to describe the temples that surround you from this site.Worth every minute exploring.

My favorite. This is an absolute must! Go really early (5 in the morning or something like that) watch the sunrise while hearing the sounds of the jungle! Just awesome. This place is really mystical. The huge faces are really surreal!

Impressive but not a knockout. Larger than I expected but without the distinguishing features of some others. Worth a visit & photo but not a jaw-dropper. Could take this and the Terraces on in an hour.

Great place to visit. The temples in this complex are magnificent, especially Bayon and Baphuon. And just like in Angkor Wat, it is really a great experience to climb up to the top of the temples so leave your fear of heights behind.

Bigger than you think. This temple complex is bigger than you think, so give yourself time to explore! Well worth the effort it takes to get here, and worth having a guide or a good guide book with you to help interpret what you are seeing.

a must if you're in Siem Riep. Another spectacular temple at Ankor Wat complex. It was super quiet and although this is only a little temple where you can spend a couple of minutes, the tree is pretty cool. The elephant ride was a nice experience too. My friend pressured me into it and I actually enjoyed it.Highly recommend this place.... get a driver to help get you round the Ankor complex!

Large Scale. Ruins of a large old city. Bayon is the best attraction in Angkor Thom. The rest are Baphuon, Royal Palace and the terraces. The terraces and Royal Palace are mostly in ruins. Baphuon is a restored site.

Rainy October visit. It was pouring during our afternoon visit to this distinctive temple. This is the one with the large Buddha faces. Inside, the walls were detailed with carvings showing the history and culture of the khmer people leaving at that time.nthese were surprisingly in good condition. Nearby we visited the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leopard King.

The old capital a must see as well. Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat are the musts of any visit. All other parts add significant to your understanding of this place.The whole Angkor Park area covers 400 sq kilometers with so much to see. The old capital from the entrance gate to the temple in the middle is so interesting to see. Don't miss it.

Don't underestimate the quantity. It's huge, full of temples, vast expanse and full of variety.I suggest a full day or at least long day is not a stupid option.It's not just Bayon and Elephant temple.

Huge city makes Angkor Wat seem small. It would be tough to see every part of this on most vacations. A huge walled city with several areas to see and sights within it's boundaries. A day won't cut it here. you need at least the 3-day pass to really get some exploration into your trip.

moats,walled city and giant faces that look like a girlfriend of mine. This is by far, one of my favourites.Its name means Big Angkor and measures three km squared ,walled and moated royal city. There are five gates to the city,one for each cardinal point and the victory gate leading to the royal palace area. Each gate is crowned with four giant faces,that resemble a girlfriend of mine. the south gate is often the first stop on a tour,so pick late afternoon or dawn to capture a people-free photo gem. You can spend hours getting intimate with the details that abound .
Huge - must see.. Huge site. 9ksq km. Take time to take a few pictures on the bridge as you enter the gate. I would consider hiring a bike or joining a cycling tour next time.

Home of the Bayon Temple. If you have limited time in Seam Reap, see Angkor Thom where the Bayon Temple is, Angkor Wat, and Ta Prohm. Everything else is similar to one of these, most probably a miniature, and still minimally restored. Angkor Thom is probably the largest of the complexes.

Awesome. Different to Angor Wat but incredible all the same. Well worth the visit although make sure you take some water and a fan to keep you cool!!! I didn't realise I could find so many different things to take a photo of but around each corner there is something new and exciting to discover. A must do.
underrated. I think this is seriously underrated, it was my favorite of the 3 temples. Loved all the trees and the moss on the temple.

Fantastic and very intune with the surroundings. Not as restored as Ankor Wat and in fact I enjoyed it more as there was more forest close and it was less restored, felt more otherwordly. Just incredible.

Heaven part 2. If you have not checked out Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom, they should be in your bucket list! Walking around and checking out the nook and cranny of the place made me feel like I was traveled back in time. The architectural structure of the two places made you wonder if they were built using manpower or something else...I will leave it up to your judgement and imagination to determine :-)

Yet another temple complex. Good to wander around and see the various temples. It was raining on the day so we never saw the Terrace of the Elephants or the Terrace of the Leper King well out of the covered in Tuk Tuk
Ruins of Seimreap. Beautifull sculptures of asuras and devathas both sides will welcome you on the enterence gate Indian mythology stories are good in stone carvings nice to see

flooded. i went in the middle of the rainy season and the temple was a bit flooded. they had wood planks set up but i still got my feet wet. go prepared if you go in the rainy season. nevertheless i loved this temple, it has a mystical feel with trees roots taking over the structure and decorating it.

2nd favourite temple. After the famous Angkor Wat this is easily the next best temple. Lots of greenery gives the place an awesome atmosphere, I'd recommend heading there early to avoid the crowds, even ask your guide to skip the others after you've seen Angkor Wat. Definitely worth the visit.

Happy faces. Loved the different temples here. Our guide Kimthet took us to the quieter north gate for some great photos. Loved the buddhas at Bayon. Water blessing at the Pagoda at Preah Palilay was a true highlight

A wonderful Tour Experience. I vises this temple along with Angkor Watt & Thom Pron about 5 years ago but wanted to come back and tour them again. This time was just as good as the first. Two days is really enough to see the main temples. Do plan on going ton them for sunrise.
Highly photogenic. I was amazed by the ruins of Angkor Thom, where its stone hallways and labyrinth of walls are overgrown by jungle. This site is a photographer’s dream space, highly recommended.

The Elephant Temple. Angkor Thom is a site which encompasses Bayon, the Elephant Terrace, the Leper King temple and others. The most stunning building is the Bayon temple entrance, with the approaching balustrade. The first time I saw it I was awed, it is fantastic. If you go in the morning, have a ride on the elephant. It is US$15 a person, but worth it, as he takes you around the site and you get a different view. I was a initially concerned about exploitation of the elephants, but they used to be used in the illegal logging trade and there is no natural jungle left for them to live in, if they were released they would starve. They are well cared for and fed and kept in their social group so while not ideal, they are well off.

Bigger Than Angkor Wat. If you have spent an hour or so at Angkor Wat and were impressed by the size then Angkor Thom is about five times bigger and just as impressive with its palaces and temples and open spaces.You would need most of a day to see all of this area.
Wonderful. This is one of the best part of our tour.Its unique set of Bayon faces that are enticing and intriguing...needs a good amount of physical sweat out to discover this wonderful site
Angkor Thom - anytime of the day. This is one that can be done during the hotter part of the day. Need to spend time to really come to terms with the enormity of the structures and enjoy the area
So many to see!. Many temples to see, each sufficiently different to make the full tour interesting, and each with a fascinating history.
Be ready to walk and climb stairs, but wow!. Angkor Wat is beautiful, but be ready for the heat, humidity, and lots of walking and climbing! Very photogenic place and lots and lots of tourists.

More than everything. Definitely is a must go place during your trip to siem reap. I am as a lazy human being that is difficult to wake up early in the morning able to woke up at 4.30 am just to went there and watch sunrise..hahaha...

Wow-ed!. if you think Angkor Wat was a wow... wait till you see Angkor Thom and her various complexes. your will be wow-ed many times over on how this could have been even thought of in terms of its complexities in construction and building methods almost a thousand years ago.all i can say is - WOW!!!

Seeing is believing. You can do these sites at your own pace by bike or private tuk tuk. There really is no reason to have big organised tours unless you are in a group. We had a very knowledgeable tuk tuk driver that gave us enough info, coupled with our book we were able to extract the beauty of the place.

Temples at Angkor Thom. We didn't avail the tourist guide from the hotel since it is quite expensive. So the manager gave us a map of the temples which truly guided us especially to this temple. When we got here, we were just instructed by our tuk-tuk driver to meet him at the other part of the area. So I guess we didn't understand that there are several temples. When we got inside, we just walked and looked around. There is this teenager who asked us "where are you from lady" This is they're usual introduction to all tourists. So since I thought he's a local and he's being nice of taking pictures of us, we accommodated him. But we he found out we're already leaving, he asked us a donation which he ended up compelling us to give more. He explained to us that he does not have a father anymore and he wants to study. So my hubby gave him US$5 as a donation but he asked for more. I just asked my hubby to leave him since he is already harassing us for more money. So when we exited, we heard some Korean Nationals being hysterical because he lost his expensive cellphone and wallet. I just told my hubby that just take note of his valuables since there are some locals roaming around and you really don't know their intention of talking to you even you are in good faith. This is our first day of tour and first temple we visited. I think anywhere you go you should always take extra caution especially on your valuables.Good thing we didn't lose anything but the experience of being harassed to a foreign country because of money is quite traumatic. So whenever we go around and locals ask us where we are from, we just pretend that we didn't hear them and didn't mind them even they are just in front of us. We didn't ask any locals anymore (except if they're officials of the temple/security guards). Just beware.We just went on the the other temples of Baphoun (which has very steep stairs. This temple has strict officials and had DRESS CODE. They will not allow you to get inside the temple if you have short shorts or skirt and revealing or skimpy outfit. just make sure you have shawls with you to cover your legs (considering the weather is seriously warm!)

Its the Trees!!!. This is where the famous Tomb Raider movie shoot the film. Trees were so old and matured... This was part of the temple I visited for the 1-day pass trip. Its quite difficult to take photo as there's a lot of people taking their own photos. There's a line queing for the famous tree for the photo shoot.

Angkor Thom - The forgetten Capital. This is 'Angkor Thom' you need at least one day to explore this area and temples around, Bayon and Baohuon are big temples in this area mostly over shadowed by famous Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom is much bigger than Wat, This was once the capital of Khmer Empire and surrendered by walls.Best time to visit is during cool season, you can not bare the heat otherwise.

Another great place to visit in Cambodia. Loads of history in Cambodia, there are so many temples and tombs to comb through, we really enjoyed this one. Unfortunately we were there is a great flood and walked thigh deep in flood waters to get anywhere. Always hoping some ugly snake didn't bite under the waters

Worth the visit!. If you are looking for the perfect photo of the Angkor temples, then this is a must stop. The overgrowing trees hugging the temples is an amazing sight here. Of course, this is a bit touristy due to the movie shoot (Thumb Raider) but worth it.
Another Amazing Site. This site has unusual architecture and is a good counterpoint to Angkor Wat. I can't imagine coming all the way to Cambodia and not seeing this site.
Amazing and worth any extra time needed to check it out. It's Angkor Wat - ditch the big bus tours (it is possible) walk along and find your own space and enjoy it.
bayon is the pearl. if angkor thom is a crown, the bayon temple is the pearl on top of this crown...there others are just fine...
Breathtaking. A walk through this ancient city is beautiful.. Make sure you don't allow your guide to convince you to skip the remaining ruins of the palace and the temple behind 'The Elephant Gate'.

Stunning!. Wowed me! This was my favourite. Felt I could explore at my leisure. Just awesome! If you have a guide, ask about the 'kissing' Buddha which, apparently, the Japanese and Koreans love to photograph.
gorgeous and so impressing!. we were there in low season, so no overcrowded places. beautiful and impressing place , a must do in Cambodia !
Amazing. Again, have a private guide as this allows you to manage your time. Only cost $20 for 8 hrs and then $15 for the tuk tuk... well worth the money

A good temple but no Angkor Wat. The title says it all. Worth a visit but not even close to Angkor Wat.
If you are ding this temple, do it BEFORE Angkor Wat or you will be disappointed.

Impressive, but almost too big. We visited Angkor Thom with our children (ages 13,10). It's not a single temple, but instead a city. The Bayon Temple and it's many faces is definitely worth a visit. But after an hour of walking around, our 10-year old's attention started to wane. Add the heat and you've got a recipe for one cranky kid. (We also had a very, very long-winded tour guide.) We only did a cursory visit of some of the other sites at Angkor Thom. Truthfully, our favorite temple at Angkor Wat was actually Ta Prohm. It has more appeal for kids.If you'd like to see photos or get ideas about other kid-friendly things to do in Cambodia, check out our travel blog at www.aroundtheworldin72days.com

Angkorthom better than Angkor wat. I think it is more nice and more beautiful the Angkor thom than Wat.Angkor wat is more nice to see during the sunrise but I don't think is better than oia sunrise or sunset in santorini.
OH MY GOODNESS. this place is simply amazing!!!!! the trees, the temple, the whole area is exceptionally amazing and the scale humbles you!!! a must see in cambodia...
Best smile. I like Bayon temple with beautiful smile that is best to see at 4pm before sunset. The light over the temple is perfect

Our Favorite Angkor Site. While many only look forward to seeing Angkor Wat in Siem Reap, we found Angkor Thom to be our favorite site due to the numerous, elaborate carvings we saw. We suggest arriving early in the morning to beat the crowds later in the day. As with Angkor Wat, we recommend asking your hotel to arrange a driver and guide for your visit. (It will not only save you time but give you insight you cannot get through travel books.)

Huge complex. Walking up to the south gate we had no idea what was in store for us. This complex contains Bayon, Baphuon, the Royal Palace and the Terrace of the Elephants and a few others. We enjoyed walking around Bayon, with the beautiful faces, and then onto the other buildings/ temples/terrace trying to take in all the sights and wonderful buildings. This is the largest complex and does take time to walk around but thoroughly enjoyable and a must to visit. By the terrace of the elephants there are toilets and stalls to purchase drinks/food.

What an amazing place!. It took us hours to take in everything within Angkor Thom. We went there on two separate days, once in the morning and then on an afternoon. It was incredibly hot around midday so try and avoid it then if you can!
Best Temple. Amazing, never saw a temple like this really unique and differente to all of the temple you may see in asia.

Breathtaking. It is amazing how they managed to build this temple so long ago. You will need to climb some steep steps to get a good view of the area. Was well worth it. It has many different area to explore

Larger area than you might think!. Over 9 square km and once housing over 80,000 to 150,000 people, this was one of the last inhabited cities of the Khmer empire...as recently as the early 1600's. Take lots of water, cool towels, and mosquito repellent and investigate! Make sure to have a good map of the area before you set out on foot....or go with a guide. It's easy to get lost here.

An early morning delight. All sites are worth seeing and just ambling through and around.I enjoyed the journey there via a bicycle and recommend if your healthy enough.Aim for being there between 7 and 10 am as tourist buses pour in after 10

Best temple. We arrived in the morning and were the only people in the temple for quite a while. Perhaps that is why I found this one to be the most memorable. The silence and isolation, the feeling of time and timelessness, the great beauty that is discovered rather than immediately evident connects you to the former culture in a way that no other temple can. July 2012

Truly great ancient city. The first place we were brought to by our driver when visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park area was Angkor Thom (Great Khmer City), which was the great ancient capital city of the Khmer Empire constructed during the late 12th century.It was a very large area about 3km by 3 km and fortified by an 8m high laterite wall all along its perimeter and accessible only through five tower gates. Angkor Thom is also surrounded by a 100m wide moat and the water seen from the Southern Gate, our entry point, was so calm and serene with small ripples caused by some gentle breeze. The road leading to the gate was even more spectacular with 2 rows of very much weathered huge stone figures, 54 lining each side, leading up to the towering gate, and folklore has it that the left row were gods and the right demons but both meant to guard Angkor Thom.The Southern Gate tower, constructed of sandstone rises up to a height of about 23m and a four-faced stone sculpture like that of Bayon Temple’s could be seen right above the entrance of the towering gate. After passing through the gate, which was only one truck wide, there is a long laterite road which welcomes you with lush tropical trees lining both sides and this road leads to the other temples and attractions within this ancient capital city viz. Bayon Temple which is centrally located, Baphuon Temple, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King and a couple of other smaller temples. Angkor Thom must have been a grand thriving capital city during the rule of the Buddhist king, Jayavarman VII and thereafter, as attested to by the remnants of the massive ruins within the area now. It is definitely a must-see in the itinerary of any visitor to Siem Reap.

Wide ancient city. Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.Tired.

A trekkers delight. So many views in just one visit: the massive Gallery of Elephants, to the Bayon temple, to the smaller hospital-temples to the massive gates (esp. the northern gate).Read the guides so you can fully appreciate every corner of the complex
Lots of steps but great views. Another must do temple but there are quite a few steep steps to get to the top. Not as many tourists here as part of a larger "complex" of temples.

Favorite. This was our favorite Temple yet. We are not big temple people, but really enjoyed this site. This is the temple you can actually do a bit of climbing on if you want. Take the time aside and go here. Pay $20 for a ticket which gets you into here, Angkor Wat, and more. Well worth it.

History, history, history.. It was a great visit despite the heat. We arrived just a little too late to partake in the elephant ride. Get there before 9.30am otherwise you'll miss out. Was most disappointed.
The views from the top are wonderful and it's well worth the visit.
Go!. At least 4 temples can be seen in a day and each is worth a visit as one is different than the next. It's fabulous to see restoration being done.

Wow! My favourite temple area.. My favourite area of all the temples - amazing. Wear good shoes and women don't forget to cover your knees and solders or you won't be able to explore all areas of the temple. Washrooms are located by the shop area and are clean and free with your Angkor pass.
Wonder!. This is part of Angkor archeological park and if you do Angkor, you would also do this. Same kind of energy as Angkor. Do not miss it.

Wow! totally awesome. This is a definite must see if you are travelling to Siem Reap. The architecture is amazing. You can't help but marvel at the sheer size of the area it covers. I have been there a few times now and it still takes my breath away.

my favorite. Read my review re Angkor Wat. Same advice.
Good to have guide to explain things and to backup with a couple of books that detail the history.

Awesome!!!!!!. I thoroughly enjoyed my walk through the whole site and made me wonder how it was built in those days when we didn't have the modern technology. Being an Indian made me feel proud of this temple in Cambodia where Hinduism was followed then. It is a wonder of wonders.

Just another temple. If you go with a knowledgeable tour guide, you may find out how this temple differs all the other temples in the Angkor Watt area. Its condition and lack of site management are just as deplorable.

angkor thom for me thom!!!. the (once) great city of angkor thom which is famous for the 3d Budda Heads. For me this was the most fascinating site in siem reap. the property is so huge that you won't notice the other tourists. the oversized buddhas along the bridge were eye catching and moving. restoration projects are also being undertaken!!!!
Just Brilliant. A must see, cannot describe the feeling being there. As much annoying as it was to pay $20pp to enter it was worth every penny of it.

This is a mega Temple. I have visited Angkor Thom twice: The sunrise is spectacular. There are hundreds of tourists at this time of the day waiting for sun to lit the temple walls. The best location is near the lake. Please make sure to allow at least 5 hours for this temple. This temple also has a back entrance. Please make sure to read about the wall carvings first before visiting the temple.

Smiling in all Directions. This is the site you see so often that represents Angkor in general...the giant smiling face in four directions. Can be crowded and most people are polite and try to stay out of your photos. Have fun.

The Largest Temple - Angkor Thom. This temple has the highest points. We could climb the steps to the level just below the highest point. It is huge, intricate with carvings and wonderful details. Hot day, take plenty of water and lots of pictures.
Well worthwhile. This is part of the 4 temple complex, so you will generally visit it with Angkor Wat. If you have the time, spend the day and visit all 4.

Another brilliant temple.. Like the entire complex this is very impressive, and like the other temple you must wear clothes that fall below the knee and also cover your shoulders. This temple is again awesome to see. Make sure by this point you have plenty of fluid because you would have been walking a lot by now. Also when you are walking the grounds don't just look up but watch your steps as well. We saw 2 very large spiders on the tracks with their legs cocked up in the attack position and we also saw a snake on the tracks as well.
The best of the temples. Angkor Wat is the most famous by far, and given its size and the level of detail, rightfully so. But for my money, Angkor Thom with all its faces is the most beautiful.

Out of this World. Absolutely stunning and magical. We didn't book a guide so were very overwhelmed at first but one of the guards decided to give us a personal tour with so much information and took photos for us. We also went on the elephant ride around which was good fun!

Worth visiting. This temple seemed to get less attention but in many ways was as fascinating as Angkor Wat. We visited late on a July afternoon, after a short rain shower. There were no crowds to speak of so we were able to tour the complex at our leisure. Other than a few annoying hawkers near the entrance, we loved this temple. Our private guide was excellent and he provided some great color to the story of this amazing place.

Fascinating. Enjoyed this area of the park best. Lots to see. Elephant rides available for $35 Return. Vendors everywhere for water, food or tourist junk. Don't buy here but go to Centrlal Market in town and haggle.

Spectacular. This is the highlight of a visit to the temples around Siem Reap. It is dramatic, spectacular, awe inspiring and fascinating Lara Croft's visit certain adds to the adventure but what really strikes you is how nature is reclaiming what man has made. This is one not to be rushed. This is one to dedicate a morning to. Go, take your time and save it for last.

In some ways we liked better than Angkor Wat. Less crowds, and the fact that it was less restored was a nice change. The jungle comes very close to the edges of the complex which was also anappealing difference from Angkor Wat.
Quite spectacular city within a city. A must see here but be prepared for lots of walking in the heat! Great exercise and absorb the beauty of an ancient city

Great Buddism Temple in 12th. Big Angkor is 3km *4 walled and moated royal city and was theLast capital of the Angkorian empire. After Jayavaraman VII recaptureed theAngkorian capital from the Champ invaders in 1181. He began a massive buildingCampaign across the empire constructing Angkor Thom as his new capital cityBayon set at the center of the city. There are five entrances (gates)To the city one for each cardinal point .the south Gate is oftenThe stop on a tourIt you come to Cambodia don't miss your change to visit this beautiful of 216 different smiles face

Angkor thom and gerry. If you like temples its fantastic, if (like most people) you get sick of them after 5 minutes, then its boring. Ladies need to cover your shoulders and men cannot wear singlet vests into the temple.

Angkor Thom is large, very large. Angkor Thom is large, very large, and contains some magnificent stone sculptures, many of which are actually part of the fabric of the temple and temple walls. Like everything else in the Angkor complex it is on a large scale, and well worth the time and effort to visit.

Beauty !. The largest constituent of the Angkor Archaeological Park, Angkor Thom consists of a lot temple including the Bayom Temple and the Elephant Terraces.I went around the place on bicycle and it was pleasant with cool wind blowing, I loved the site !
So many towers and stories in this temple. So much has been squeezed into this temple with carvings everywhere you look. So many towers and stories in this temple.

Siem reap. I actually rate this better than Angkor Wat. You can climb it. It's bigger and you get the feel more. Remember if you come across a lady or man near the middle with a buddha statue with insense or a friendship bracelet they are wanting money and need to pray to Buddha. 1$ is cool. Just pretend.
Earlier in the day. Again this temple was mid morning to avoid the crowds. But it starts to get busy as people come from sunrise and the early AM around Ankor Wat.
Wonderful!. One of the best places to see. If have few days, besides Angkor Wat, it is the second place you can not miss.

Angkor Thom means "big city". Just so you are clear, Angkor Thom means "big city" which is true as it is 10sq kms in total.
The main temple is called Bayon and famous for the towers with 4 faces on them. You could easily spend a whole day here alone.

absolutely "wow" gate, you won't missed it unless you travel by bus, amazed and surprised when first pass by the gate, but soon. absolutely stunning gate to amazed by its grand entrance, many of such gate in the park, so you can't miss it. I was filed with surprised and excitement the first time I visit Angkor.
Another winner. Like all of the ruins in this area it has to be seen to believe the scale of it and skill that went into it's construction
So many Towers. We got so many nice pictures at Angkor Thom. The towers and faces make for some great photos. Make sure you give yourself enough time to really enjoy this site.
You have to see it. Whilst interesting. Not as spectacular or nteresting as some of the other temples. But it is still a must see
Khmer empire. Angkor Thom was the last and most enduring capital city of Khmer empire. We went there on July during wet season. But to the best of our luck, it was sunny all day long.

Awesome. Wow - I'd read the complex was bit but wasn't quite prepared for how immense. Allow at least a couple of hours. Ensure you're wearing clothes that cover your knees and shoulders to be able to got up into the high section of the temple. Look around and haggle before you buy at the market stalls nearby.

A bit of a highlight for us!. It may have been as we went to Angkor Thom on the first day so it was all new, but personally it was better than Angkor Wat, yes the sunrise was nice but just didn't really get it there. With all the renovation work and barriered off areas it just wasn't quite as spectacular. Yes it is huge in scale, and some of the detail was there but overall Angkor Thom had more of the wow factor for us, as with a number of other sites around, make sure to take note of the other and get on the bike with your 3 day pass to look around!

so much construction work. a lot of areas were cordoned off due to the restoration work. The first time visited this place was in September 2012. Some of the huge trees were felled down at it seem the awe inspiring feeling of several trees soaring to the sky was also diminished.
Full of history!. We had a guide to explain the history behind the huge city. it was really nice to see all the carvings and symbolic statues. but the afternoon heat can be really oppressive though

whats not to like?. All about angkor thom is great.When we where there it was really early so we were able to see monkeys, and we had the pleasure of nice temperatures and some shade.Great visit. In my opinion if you are not that into history you can do all the temples in one day. Just wake up at 4 am.Visited february 2012

Tomb Rider temple. It was an amazing feeling to be at this temple and most of it it was in setting of Tomb Riders movie of Lara Croft (Angelina Jolie). The trees and the roots were so gigantic around the temple. So magical.. !

this must be 3rd temple in our list. Ok, Banyon is our favorite, Angkor wat is no 2, Angkor Thom is such a big place and consist of a few temple, and Banyon one of it. (correct me if im wrong as too many temple together), basically we drive around with tuk tuk... and walk too... i like the location, as alot of matured trees and cool feeling inside.
Awesome, and beyond words. Essential to get a good guide, as it makes the world of difference to understand what you are looking at, and the history and architecture.

A city on it's own!. Huge place. Felt like we've walked for miles. But it was all very amazing. The building structures, the carvings and even more so, the stories behind it! Make sure you get a tour guide when you are on your tour!

To describe in one word - MAJESTIC !. Starting with the impressive gateway at Angkor Thom, going into Bayon, Bapuon, Elephant Terrace, Leper King Terrace et al, it is a fantastical example of human artistic & architectural skills. Definitely the better of the 2 - thom wins hands down over Wat! At least for me it did.

Baphuon. Bring a large scarf or two - they won't let you enter and ascend the Baphuon if you are wearing shorts or a short skirt or if your shoulders are not covered. The scarf can be used also as a wrap around skirt.
Amazing complex. Ancient architecture with such intricate details.Trees growing out of the ground covering the ruins
A must see. Have visit this site 2 times earlier in the last 10 years, and it is still one of the must see complex in Angkor Complex. Again it is always difficult to choice which temple you like best

First impressions amazing. The entry to Angkor Thom is very impressive with carved Buddah heads and a moat around it. You need to be a little agile to climb in and around the temple buildings, but worth it. Lots of tourists unfortunatley - us included. Clean bathroom facilities close by as well as lots of vendors.

Must See. Fascinated with the entire place. A lot of walking, and steps to do and this is not recommended for elderly.
Definitely need to climb to the top of the tower. Climbing down part can be pretty scary with the 70 degrees tilt.
Beautiful. Very busy, very amazing lots of walking a must do in Siem Reap Thom is part of the Huge Angkor Wat complex so is part of the tour of Angkor Wat
Interesting place. Given the information around the site, one does get a good view of ancient Khmer history and is fabulous irrigation works. Really a place to be preserved for future generations.

Great location. The temple Angkor Thom is fantastic.
The statues on the "bridge" are stunning!
The entire location of this temples is wonderful!
Must see temple when in Angkor!
Best to go to the temples in the morning. You'll definitely need to give yourself a few hours for this place alone. The East Gate is quite a climb & the Terrace of the Elephants is exquisite.
great. best to go to the temples in the morning as not so many tourists , we used a tuk-tuk to tour , a great way to see everything . The other temples were great as well .

Deep into the jungle. I've seen a lot of temples in Mexico and Central America, but never nothing like Angkor Thom. The temple has been taken by the nature with the trees inside the temples, making it a really special place to visit. The mix between rocks, sculptures and man set bricks is incredible and ancient time mysterious. Tip: Visit the temples early morning as no many tourist come here early and there are no many mosquitos at this time. Visit this temple first and the go to Angkor Wat.

Huge and Interesting. Be careful to 'dress appropriately'. Given the heat and humidity there is a tendency to underdress but there are portions of the complex where 'modesty' is enforced. Don't miss them because you can adjust your layers.

one of the best ruin temple. among all those amazing temple, Angkor wat is somewhat the great one. there must be great story behind this temple and how people still take care to keep it as ancient temple, again im glad i had this trip its a lot and a lot worth a visit.
More temples. Angkor Thom is a little younger than Angkor Wat and demonstrates the transition to a Buddhist phase. The site is quite complex and can get a bit crowded, but is well worth a visit.
maybe the best-. all of temples have their own character and interest, but this may be the best one--don't skip any, they are all amazing-

Ankor is exceptional. If there is only one place you visit.... This is one of the most incredible ruins in all the world. I've spent years seeing all of the Maya ruins and they don't come close to this and Ankor Wat. I can't believe it took me this long to come to Ankor. Truly exceptional!

The best temples in the complex!. Angkor Thom was my favourite in the whole complex - the smiling faces on all the aspects and the sheer size of it. We went to the museum as well (pricey!) to get a proper background about it, and that really helped to put the epic nature of the build in perspective
Tomb Raider. Within the Angkor Wat complex and the trees taking over the temple as in the Angelina Jolie movie - took guide for the day with aircon car US$85

Surreal experience. Angor Thom is a massive complex that houses many temples, mostly in ruins. It is a very impressive sprawling complex, that is evident from the massive south gate itself. Apart from the multitudes of ruinous complexes, the trees and lush greenery make this a very surreal place. The restaurants and touristy shops are hidden away in a enclave. The food there wasn't too cheap, but it was good.

Beautiful Southern Gate. Southern Gate which is the most beautiful gate since before the gate we were greeted by statues of the Gods (devas) and the asura (foe of the devas) who were holding a naga portraying the "churning of the sea of milk" myth. Some of the heads are not the original ones anymore, so they replaced them to make us able to picture how it would look like in the olden days. The gate itself is like the ones in Bayon, of which on top of the tower has 4 faces, facing 4 different directions, and on the below are elephant heads.
Loved the faces!. An amazing site that must not be missed. The craftsmanship just blows your mind. Take your time to absorb the history and serenity.

temple complex. Bayon temple is the main in this complex and worth spending time and amazing. other are Ruins of Royal palace with elephant and leaper king terraces. another is a Baphuon temple. If you have only 1 day, then see this as time permit.

My mistake: Not getting a guide. The 20usd entrance fee to enter the Angkor Wat includes entrance to Angkor Thom and La Trom as well. It probably includes some other smaller temples but i'm not very sure about them as my family and i only went to these three temples. This temple is fairly small and we covered it in under an hour (probably because we were exhausted after walking in Angkor Wat and wanted to finish viewing all the temples quickly). However there were very little tour guides at the entrance of this temple and we did not take hire a tour guide here. I would recommend getting a tour guide from Angkor Wat (there are plenty of tour guides flocking there) and make arrangements so that he would be a tour guide for all three temples (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and La Trom). Having getting used to having a tour guide at Angkor Wat, walking on our own here seemed a little made us feel a little lost. I believe i would have enjoyed it more if someone explained to me what i was looking at. p.s. I 'm not sure if there are proper eateries within all the temple complex, so maybe it might be good to pack sandwiches or so for lunch. We did not pack anything and were wary to eat from roadside stalls and hence had a very late lunch after we have finished viewing all three main temples. Walking around without lunch was indeed tiring!
Amazing atmosphere. Really enjoyed this location, much to see, much bigger than Angkor Wat, with lots of statutes that are more intact, don't miss it.
largest of the bunch. HUGE AREA OF Angkor era temples. Amazing to see. Elephant rides available here, but we walked the area and climbed many temple sites.
great. The main attraction , certain must visit here , awesome and grand , many tourists , better in the early morn
The trees are great. Take a look at the trees wrapped around the temples. It's so cool. It's great here also. Have a guide with you - it's worth the money!
Stunning. Set amongst the jungle - amazing atmosphere and history. Less people than Angkor Wat and an incredible temple to explore.

Another amazing temple. Angkor Thom has a lot to see, spend some time at the entrance since there is a lot to see. Highlights are the terrace of elephants and the entry way, if you pay attention you can see the monkeys on the road.

Beautiful ancient city. Allow yourself plenty of time to stroll around and sit and take in this amazing ancient city of beautiful temples. This one of our favourite places that we visited. We actually believed we had saved the best for last!

Simply Amazing. Another amazing temple to visit besides Angkor Wat. Its history and grounds tells you more of the era of the Khmer empire and its kings who built these wat. This is a definite inclusion to your day trip itinerary.

Worth seeing this. This is worth seeing. You can visit the Angkor Thom and ta prohm in one day. We rented a air conditioned car and driver/guide for the day which made it easy to get from place to place.

A massive complex - try to get off the beaten track.. Angkor Thom is a massively large temple complex which includes Bayon, Baphuon and a few others, not to mention the massive gates at each compass direction. Most tuk-tuk drivers will stop at the South Gate and then take you to Bayon, from which you walk through the main parts of the temple. If you have the time, it would be well worth doing the little walk outlined in Lonely Planet - west along the wall from the South Gate and then north and back into the middle. The main parts of the temple complex are crowded with tourists.

A must see temple in Siem Reap. One of the must see temples when you visit Siem Reap.
Not so big and not so many tourist, but nearby Ankor Watt and worth visiting.

Dark but interesting. Althought the temple is on a smaller scale than Angkor Wat, it is interesting for the multitude of buddha faces carved into the walls.
Elephant rides available nearby.
check it out. just as amazing as ankgor wat... awesome to look at and touch this ancient structure... walk up to the top and see the beautiful view too.

Amazing!. This was the first place we visited! After a rather bumpy elephant ride around the main temple we set on exploring. It is really big and there is so much to see! If you have a good guide with you, then you are in for some really good photo spots as they can point you to less crowded places or angles from which you can see the details and beauty of this ancient wonder!

Amazing. Angkor Thom is absolutely beautiful. The remaining stone temples and buildings are far enough apart that if you imagine the wooden buildings that used to fill the gaps you can see that this would have been quite an amazing city. Devote an entire morning to it and get there early (no later than 7 or 8am) because you do not want to be braving the harsh sun after about noon. Be prepared for some climbing of steep steps, and also remember to dress modestly because a few of the temples (such as Baphuon) request that your knees and shoulders are covered. Also wear supportive footwear as the ground is very uneven and my fiancé did his ankle in the very first temple we looked at.Make sure not to miss the East and South gates. The towers on the eastern side of the city are fascinating (they are named Prasat Suor Prat - read up on the legend surrounding them) but the locals believe it is bad luck to go there. So if you are with a driver try to view the towers from an acceptable distance, so as not to offend or worry them.We didn't go for an elephant ride (they didn't look happy).
Must see. The Angkor Thom complex is fabulous. Bayon is the temple we liked the most, but also enjoyed the terrace of the elephants and the lepered king terrace. To be seen absolutely

Breathtaking Sightseeing. The complex of Angkor Thom houses some incredible ruins. The Bayon is the temple that you will have seen on many postcards - adourned with trippy facades of faces - it is incredible, especially in the late morning when the sun finally makes it over the foliage and hits the temple, or close to sunset when the soft light gives the faces an ethereal quality.You will also find Ta Prohm, commonly known as the 'Tomb Raider' temple. Overgrown and left for centuries to the ravages of the forest you will see giant tree roots intertwined with the incredible Angkorian architecture - it is a fascinating, spellbounding infusion of man made inegnuity and the power of nature.If you are using Siem Reap as your base I would strongly recommend that rather than using a Tuk Tuk you take a bike (you can hire them for as little as $1 a day) - it is a far richer and more rewarding experience that allows you to take in the scale of the site and enjoy the jungle too. The tuk tuks are so cramped that you can see very little and you will spend a lot of time spluttering from the engine and exhaust fumes. For longer journeys you may need a tuk tuk but Angor Thom (and Angkor Wat) are an easy 15-20 minute cycle from Siem Reap.Talk to local guides, hoteliers or other travellers about what are the best times to visit the temples. Massive swathes of Korean tourists career through the temples by the busload and this can be really irritating and ruin the ambience and experience a little bit. With a little investigation you can avoid the onslaught as most of the package tourists follow the same programs.
all looks the same. i felt that after seeing angkor wat that they all start to look the same there is only so manyyou can look at before it looks the same

Lots of ground to cover. A lot bigger than expected. Gates in all 4 directions are good to check out too. Bought some beautifully coloured temple carvings etchings in there. I reckon you could easily bargain them down to around $2 - $3, depending on rice paper size. These etchings are also available elsewhere.

The temple of Roots. You can see big roots from the trees on top of the temple. unfortunately these roots are destroying the temples. Some of the trees were already cut. This temple is under reconstruction , most of the structures are not there.
Another special temple. Smaller than Angkor Wat but just as beautiful and well preserved. Make this one of the 3 or 4 temples you visit in this area.

Was a city during the ancient Khmer civilisation. This ancient enclosure has four gates for entry (North, South, East and West). Angkor Thom was a city around 800 years ago. It is not a temple, but has several large temples within the enclosure (Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas). It also has the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leper King. It will take at least 3.5 hours to explore Angkor Thom. The people who have posted reviews and called Angkor Thom a temple are mistaken.

Another temple in the area but with its own undual features. Much smaller than Angor Wat, so able to see the entire temple and walk though it in a half a day. Because it is not to US standards for safety, you must m be in good shape and have good balance as you truly feel like you are making an archeolgical find for the first time. It is amazing and the entire experience was something hard to describe.

Sprawling and magnificent.. So much to see and absorb in Angkor Thom so make sure you take your time. Make sure you wear comfortable walking shoes and keep hydrating - it gets really hot esp if you are visiting between May and July. My favourite temple was Bayon, located in the center of Angkor Thom - i loved it so much that I bought a carving replica of the stone faces, seen on the towers here. Even the entrance itself is grand - it is flanked by a row of demons of the left and gods on the right, both carrying a snake body or naga as they call it. Well-worth the visit!
used to be a city. can we believe that it used to be a city?build by end of 12th century and our generation still can see, touch and feel it :)

Visit if in Siem Reap. This is another in the series of temples in the Angkor Watt complex of structures. Plan for a full day of viewing. Early morning is best for this site because it gets shot and muggy in the afternoons.

Amazing better than Angkor Wat for me. I loved this area, especially Bayon with the faces, just amazing. We were there in may and it was incredibly hot but I meant that it wasn't so busy ( though I can't compare, but we didn't find it busy). We decided against a guide because after watching others we thought in the tremendous heat we just might get "over" hearing every minor detail. We watched a DVD in the cool air con of our room instead and felt we learned enough to really enjoy the experience.Our driver mr changla was lovely, with just enough English to tell us what we needed to know.

The Great City. Angkor Thom means "the great city" in Khmer. The 12th-century royal Buddhist city is especially famed for its grand Bayon Temple, but has several other sights of interest as well like Baphuon, Leper King Terrace, Elephant Terrace, Royal Palace and Phimeanakas temple. Angkor Thom has 5 gates which are the South gate, West gate, North gate, East gate and Victory gate in the east. You need to spend 4 hours to explore Angkor Thom

Great to get an all round introduction to the temples. Went with a guide and although very hot we enjoyed Angkor Thom. The guide (From Beyond Unique Escapes) gave us lots of history and was able to point out special things we may not have found ourselves. Be prepared for the crowds even in low season - driving through the entry gate can be bedlam!
Spectacular. Scenic place with unique atmosphere, mighty trees overwhelming the ruins, perfect background for family pics.

Yep, another temple. By the time we'd 'done' 3 temples, they ended up being all very similar. We were 'templed out' after five and photos of two more. We are not hugely into the history of it all but wanted to see it anyway, we would not have come to SR if we hadn't.
Better than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is prettier and more intricate than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is the old capital of the Khmer empire. Beautiful and Amazing!! A must see when visiting Siem Reap!
Fascinating place. The roots growing over the buildings were fascinating. The architecture is very different. A must see along with Angkor Wat.

The Best Place to Start Your Visit. The best place to start your visit of the temples in Siem Reap is probably by visiting Angkor Thom. You should enter through the south gate (the most popular one), but if you fancy taking photos with nobody around, ask your tuk-tuk driver to take you to the Victory Gate, which is just as beautiful, but has less tourists. Inside Angkor Thom the best temple is the Bayon, which is right in the middle of it, the second best temple is right next to it and is called Baphuon, then you can take a walk down the Elephant Terrace and carry on visiting more temples if you have the time.Tips:Take a hat, sun lotion and water.Do not wear sandals, IF it rains the ground can become muddy.Take plenty of memory in your camera, do not underestimate the amount of pictures you will take.Inside Angkor Thom, across the road from the Elephant Terrace, there are places to eat/ drink and toilet facilities.The best tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap is a guy called Rado Doung (tuk-tuk 5). You can find him outside the Tara Angkor Hotel, on the road to Angkor Wat.Take a map of the temples inside Angkor Thom with you, so if you have time, you can explore the whole area. The temples are close to each other, so you can easily walk from one to the other.
AMAZING!!. beautiful experiencing all the temples of siem reap, although we started to get a bit templed put but its well worth the visit for sure

Possibly the best. It was manageable and demonstrates that no matter what man achieves, the force of nature will eventually swallow the greatest of human endeavours if not maintained. The countries who are contributing to the upkeep of Angkor Thom and all the other temples have to be applauded, and loudly

A city not a temple. Angkor Thom is a fortified city built at the end of the 12th century to withstand further attacks by the Chams, they had sacked Angkor in the past. A guide or a good guide book is a must to get best value from the 10sq km site although most of the key elements are central, these include Bayon, Baphuon (both reviewed separately).Don't just walk along the top of the Terrace of Elephants or you will miss all the carvings of them on the front. Sadly, walking along the top it is clear the paving has been "restored" very poorly. The northerly half of the terrace is called the Terrace of the Leper King, we were told that this was not because he had leprosy but because the lichens that were growing on his statue looked as if he had.The climb up Phimeanakas is worthwhile, the steps are not signposted and are at the back of the structure. At the top, a good view and an area to climb around but be warned it is not all neat and tidy as some of the fallen stonework has not been cleared, which is fine so long as you are careful.

Never to be forgotten!. We thougt Angor Wat could not be excelled, but Angor Thom is even prettier! What you shoul do, if possible, is to see it very early in the morning as the heat in may can be unbereable!
liked this better than Anghkor Wat. Less crowded and more 'natural' Wear some good shoes as the walking is a bit roughProbably some of the best pictures of the area were taken here

Huge temple complex. Its best to stop at the west gate entrance to see the moat, the bridge and the gatehouse,after you have seen this area its best to get back into your transport because it is about 1KM.further to Bayon temple at the center of the complex.You can take an elephant ride from the west gate to the Bayon temple I believe it costs around $20.The Bayon temple is most notable for the number of faces on the towers,there are many steep steps on the temple if you want to climb to the top but the views from the top make the climb worthwhile,I would recommend wearing decent shoes to walk in as some of the ground is quite uneven and the steps are steep and narrow.After Bayon if you head towards the east gate you eventually you come to the terrace of the elephants and the terrace of the leper king,both well worth seeing.Just after these there are many stalls selling all the usual gifts and places to eat and drink,the prices of the drinks are quite expensive but they will give discounts if you ask.

Bayon Temple Great!. Well worth the visit. the south gate was beautiful, walking around Bayon was great - faces everywhere.The Elephant Terrace was fascinating and a really great way to spend the morning
excellent. Extremely interesting and amazing what was built those many years ago.The remains from the 12 century Bayon with its beautifully crafted central towers.

Out of this world City. The first time I set foot in Angkor Thom is that I felt like being transported to a different world. Everything is not just so earthly. The temples are huge and I can't imagine ordinary people doing it.

A much quieter place.... After having to deal with all of the people and the crowding at Angkor Wat it was refreshing to come to Angkor Thom and walk among the various ruins without bumping into the masses. The quiet was enjoyable and there is so much to see.
Fabulous!. Amazing compound... Take at least half a day. Marvel at the sculpture, take your time with photography and take the elephant ride.

Angkor Thom is a Must. Even with all the crowds and noise, there is a serene beauty of Angkor Thom. You can wander all over the complex without falling over another person. This is the capital of the Khmer King Jayavarman VII in the 12 century and part of the largest temple complex in the world.

A lovely environment. Having done the big temple it was nice to come to this calmer area, slightly smaller but still great images to be captured with the faces.
Part of an amazing day at Angkor Wat

A collection of structures. I visited AT as part of a 1 day tour with Angkor,Temple Guides,(see my,review there for English call MrDy 855977616129. )I really enjoyed the diversity of features including the 4 faces of Bayon,the elephant terrace where they once held a stadium for elephant fights and the Leper Kingdom. As a big elephant fan, the many incarnations of elephants was Grande.We went about 11.30 and it was fairly empty.Remember to bro,g sweets for the child vendors outside temples. Giving them money encourages their parents to keep them out of school so avoid.We got a 3 day pass which you can use anytime in a week. They punch a hole for each day used and you must present it at each entrance.
Huge temple complex. Huge complex, try and enter through the south gate, do the Bayon then the elephant & leper walks. exit via the East gate, tarts the one at the beginning of Tomb Raider

A thousand-year-old city restored.. I visited Angkor Wat in 1966, when some of the restoration was just beginning. Angkor Thom, several times larger than Angkor Wat, is one of several parts of the complex that are more accessible now, and one gets a better sense of what it all looked like before the jungle took over.
Simple beauty. We were lucky enough to have special dinner at night there so saw it candle lit, but beautiful, smaller than ankor wat and not too much climbing about
spot the faces in the rock. Another spectacular temple at Ankor What complex. Highly reccomend this place.... get a driver to help get you round the Ankor complex!

Elephant rides!. I didn't know anything about this temple and was pleasantly surprised. There was a lot to see. It was incredible! The elephant ride was a nice experience too. My friend pressured me into it and I actually enjoyed it.

A must!. As mentioned, book a guided private tour and let the guide decide time and areas to visit. They are good and happy to do a good job. Have not heard of any scams like in neighboring Thailand. They are trained and licensed.

Stunning. Everyone talks about Angkor Wat, and it is an extraordinary place, but the Bayon temple is beyond words. Essential to get a good guide, as it makes the world of difference to understand what you are looking at, and the history and architecture. Awesome, and beyond words.

Don't forget the Preah Palilay. We loved Bayon and walked via the terrace of the elephants to the back of the palace grounds and via a smaller dirt track through the woods we ended up at Preah Palilay. It was super quiet and although this is only a little temple where you can spend a couple of minutes, the tree is pretty cool. There are people living in huts everywhere in the woods and the lady after Preah Palilay had set up a cold drinks and fruit stall. We had a drink in the cool shade and watched the chickens and dog roaming free whilst the baby was getting some food, it was just very peaceful!
Amazing place. The visit to this 12th-13th century city felt surreal. Fills one with wonder at the architectural and engineering genius of the Khmers of that era. A must see
Cambodia temple visits. Visited this in conjunction with Angkor Wat; Angkor Thom which was once the capital city of Khmer rulers. Amazing architecture
A complex temple. So much has been squeezed into this temple with carvings everywhere you look.So many towers and stories in this temple.

Huge Temple Complex. This place is huge, literally a temple city. Notable highlights are the Terrace of Elephants, with its numerous elephant carvings, and Phimeanakas. The latter is very steep, but if you dare to climb to the top, there is a magnificent view.
another Temple to appreciate. Well its a little of the same but different in other ways but you really must see the ones you know about

Breath-taking climb and view. Beginning with the long walk on the bridge leading to the entrance you get the feel that this place was meant to be special. The climb to the top, and the view it provides validates that feeling.

Better than Angkor Wat. This site may not be as well known as Angkor Wat but for us, it was the star of the Angkor Archeological Park. It's sheer size and majesty are totally awe inspiring. And, the best thing, it's less crowded.
A Temple City!. This is the whole huge city of temples and when you drive around in your auto rickshaw, you see how huge it is.
amazing view. although is more less the same as angkor wat, but this one looks more older and more story! we claimed up to the top! it was very exciting!

little gem of the Khmer empire. This beautiful temple was the last and most enduring capital city of the Khmer empire. It was built quite fast so it has a more of a rugged appearance, with less detail and carving than many of the other temples around Siem Reap, but it was definitely my favourite of the many temples we visited. It was built in the late twelfth century by king Jayavarman VIIT, and was the centre of a massive building program.tip: take an official guide to at least some of the temples, they cost around 25$ per day, and are very knowledgable.
Awesome. We had a guide who could explain for us the history and this help make the experience so much better.
Massive. this place is huge! try to get it in early in the day to avoid crowds and the crazy cambodian sun. it gets really hot during the day.
i like it ..... i like it .... cuse when i visited most of the temple they were empty with no much of tourist around... go there explore it but have bike or toktok driver with yea
Amazing!. As good as Angkor Wat - a little less crowded which was nice, but nonetheless very interesting and beautiful!
Royal City. The last capital of the Khmer empire built in the late 12th C by King JayavarmanVII. It contains the Bayon,located in the centre of the site with all the towers of smiling faces.

Magnificent. Given the enormous size of Angkor Thom, you fell quite insignificant entering the city site. Like Angkor Wat, the vision and construction of the area is awe inspiring. So fortunate to have had the opportunity to visit these architectural masterpieces. Wear comfortable shoes, light clothing, take lots of water and enjoy every minute of the experience. Once in a lifetime!!

BEAUTIFUL!. In my opinion, this was equally as breathtaking as Angkor Wat (if not better)! Angkor Thom gave us some of our best pictures from the trip. There are a lot of stairs so be ready for the climb (and was also VERY hot outside in early March) but a great experience.
Angkor Thom. wonderful place again I am glad we did not miss it the carving on the stone and history of the place fasinating

Oh that GATE!. The gate is the best part! Its quite cool, that this place was the town once! I saw some people do the elephant ride in from the gate up to Bayon temple. I think there are set timing for it, so if interested do find out about it in advance!

So much more than meets the eye at first.... Apart Bayon temple, always very crowded, I managed by meer luck to stay ahead and behind the big masses of organized bus tours, so that I could enjoy many of the sights in Angkor Thom in tranquillity, often being the only one walking along some corridors and paths
Worth the Visit. A definite MUST SEE when in Siem Reap. Come while you can before the crowds build and the restrictions grow. Fantastic experience.

Wonderful. Huge complex which was the last capital city of the Khmer empire. Built in the late 12th century by King Jayavarman VII. Famous for its state temple the Bayon which is in the centre of the city. Fantastic entrance gate with loads of statues lining the way in one side gods and the other demons both pulling on a long snake. Fantastic carvings in great condition and the Bayon was wonderful with its beautifully carved faces. It was boiling and very humid when we visited (in the afternoon!!!!! - but it was part of the tour), we nearly melted. Visiting temples is my 'thing' but even I was waving the white flag by the end of the afternoon with total exhaustion. We only had 2 full days in Siem Reap one day to visit the outlying temples and the second day to visit Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, this is a hard trip to do in a day but worth it. The trouble is if you broke this trip up to 2 mornings when it is cooler (JUST), I don't know what you would do in the afternoon, we couldn't have sun bathed it was too humid it was like sitting in a sauna our hotel had a lovely pool but we could not sit outside by it. To summarise we had a fantastic day, Angkor Thom was amazing I think I preferred it to Angkor Wat (am I allowed to say that?). Enjoy and count yourself privilaged to visit such a fantastic historical site.

Allow a full day for this one!. Go prepared for a full day! The area of the old city is large, and well worth a full exploration. Wear comfortable shoes, and clothes that cover knees and shoulders, as you will not be allowed in one of the temples otherwise! A good guidebook and lots of water are a must, and be prepared to get dirty. Also, make sure you have lots of room on your camera, you will need it!

Angkor Thom is an interesting 2nd fiddle to Angkor Wat. The buddhas lining the bridge over the moat around Angkor Thom were most interesting. The buildings or what remains of them are not as interesting as Angkor Wat, but nevertheles worthy of the traveler's attention and time.

A must see in SE Asia. This is a fascinating and beautiful temple complex. Part of the whole Angkor experience. We were on a private tour arranged by Travel Cambodia/Travel Vietnam and our guide, Maray, was full of great information and facts, both modern and historical. Although there were a lot of people there the site is so large it does not feel at all overcrowded.

history at its best. Ankor Tom is in my opinion the most interesting of all the temples in the historical park including Ankor Wat, intricate carvings and the feeling of ancients is prevalent whilst walking through this magnificent piece of ancient history

The highlight is the Bayon temple. Angkor Thom is huge! You can easily spend an entire day here. The highlight is the Bayon temple (the one with the faces), and it is magical. Spend some time here and don't rush, when you climb the temple to the third level you'll discover the beauty of it.

Marvelous site. Angkor Wat is not the only amazing temple in the Siem Reap area. There are a number of them in the park and across the countryside, many from different periods, built by different rulers, each distinctive. Angkor Thom is one you will not want to miss for its sites made famous Hollywood adventure movies.

Stunning ancient walled city. Angkor Thom is a walled city (the last capital of the Khmer empire) and each side is about 2 miles long, so it's huge and will take a goodly amount of time to properly explore. Bayon sits in the exact center and begin your visit there at dawn when the early morning light shines on the stones. The city is laid out as a model of the universe and construction began around 1,000 years ago. The area to the north of Bayon is best seen by taking your time and walking around. Unfortunately some areas that were previously open to passage are now blocked off but there is still plenty to see. Be sure to climb to the top of the temples which allow access. A myriad of temples awaits your discovery! I never tire of them.
Restoration was amazing. Looking at the results of repair and refurbishment was very impressive. Another interesting temple!! Definitely go!

a great temple. as like all historic ruins having a good guide really helps,as you learn more then what you can read in a book so you see all the greatness and not looking at the book trying to figure out where you are

Overwhelming. So much area to cover, so much to see. Would recommend going the first time with a guide and then going back to explore in more leisure. Checking out maps and deciding on "must sees" ahead of time would be helpful.
Another gem. This is just as good or better than Angkor Wat and not as many people. Can be just as hot walking around and many steps but well worth the effort. Beware of clingy hawkers at the gate.

best temple. i loved angkor thom from the row of statue at the entrance to the lovely carved face that are an integral part of it. Elephant rides are available at the entrance. cant remember the cost but i did think they were a little pricy

Brilliant Khmer City. One of the largest Khmer cities ever built and with the Bayon at its centre, a microcosm of the universe. Face towers and causeways of the the city gates are spectacular. The naga balustrades lining the approach and across the moat are very atmospeheric and set the tone for your visit.

beautiful ruins, but try not to go after 10am!. Another beauty of the Angkor Wat area.
Again is I mentioned it in my other reviews, try to go before 10am, because gets very veeeeeery hot.

Love the carved faces. Every view is spectacular. This temple is a 'sleeper'--not one that makes the travelogs. There are steep steps, so be prepared. Bayon's 216 faces represent omnipresence of King J the 7th.
beautiful!. one of the most beautiful places i've seen. i would always love to come back to this nostalgic place. a photographer haven.

An Area with Notable Temples. This is an area that was the ancient capital of the Khmer people. Today, various tamples are located within it, such as Bayon and Baphuon.
