A visit to the temple complex will provide you with a sense of the size of Angkor Thom, and the large number of people who lived in this capital city. What an achievement!

Must. What a beautiful amazing place. I really had no idea how big the whole Angkor complex was. Looking at ruins is great, but knowing what they were for is even better. With a good guide you get all the important information.

Amazing. Amazing temple - my partner liked this better than Angkor Wat. Interesting history behind all the faces of the Buddha. We wished we had hired a guide so we could better understand what we were seeing. Definitely want to go back here next time we visit.

Impressive. Less stunning than Angkor Wat but well worth seeing, particularly for the amazing sculpted faces on the towers. The more you stand and look the more faces you see. A great atmosphere, and less busy than Angkor Wat.

Crowded but great place.. If you're still fit after walking around the other temples then this is yet another stunning place to visit. Does get crowded but not enough to take anything away from the experience.

The elephant wall is great. same as the old king's Palace, the temples around and the General Setting. There's a place where they display a sort of sport games on the wall. Great to see, lot of Details.

A must do !. Probably less impressive that Bayon or Angkor but very interesting to see the rooted trees and story of the French re-discovering Thom.
Pls see my review on Angkor Itself more more info

South gate entrance to Angkor Thom. This is my 4th visit to the Angkor temples. This review is for the South gate entrance to Angkor Thom. There is a long walk way to the entrance surrounded by god and demon faces on both sides. This is your first view of the famous stone faces of Angkor Thom and Bayon. Take your time to stroll down the walk way and enter the Angkor Thom complex.
Unbelievable scale. An amazing construction on a grand scale. The brain reaches saturation point very early on in the visit. A pity that with Angkor Wat it makes for a very hard day's work.

My favorate of all the Angkok structures. Pictures don't do this historic site justice. Must be seen in person to get the true grand scale of this whole structure. So many nooks and crannys to explore.

excellent compound -- take time, don't rush. many visitors will see only the main sites at Angkor Thom -- the bayon temple and little else. Take the time to see the other sites as well, especially the double walled area by the leper king pavilion. The double walled area has some of the best reliefs that we saw in all of Angkor!

Temple Tour. Probably, in my opinion, the most interesting of all the beautiful temples in the Seam Reap area of CambodiaTo visit all the other temples is easy enough, over 2/3 days,by Tuck TuckA ride on the elephant at Angkor Thom, provided the opportunity to see the temple from on high. A highlight.

Great faces of Buddha. This is special because of the huge carved faces of Buddha on every pagoda - they are in great condition and very photographable!!! Well worth just wandering round the whole structure with different views in every direction
Awe inspiring. The extent of the city is amazing. A highlight was to see the elephant wall sandstone glowing in late afternoon sunlight.
Mystical ruins. Very different from Angkor Wat in terms of style and sculptures.. can feel a bit eerie with the faces of King Jayawardhan everywhere, but nonetheless a marvel of ancient minds.

Must see complex. You could see Ankor Thom in a day or 2 if interested in detailed tour. Angkor wat, nearby Elephant terrace, Victory momument, and Bayon are all this. A little ahead of the Elephant terrace, you can see some restaraunts, curio shops, all kept neatly away from the precious attractions in a well shaded place, where you can enjoy tasty Amok (various meat inside tender coconut) & fresh coconut water. carry enough camera memory/battery, since you'll have unlimited photo session.
Spiritual experience. I am still completely blown away with how OLD these structures are and amazing the condition they are still in. I preferred Angkor Tom to Angkor Wat...less people it seemed like

Fascinating complex of temples. You need few hours to visit this complex, the main temple is the Bayon but afterwards there are more smaller interesting ruins to see like the Phimeanakas, Terrace of the Elephants, the entrance gates etc. It gets very busy after 9 AM but by noon time most people try to get away from the heat.
So many faces!. This was well worth a visit, the range of images / heads was fascinating. I found this one of the most interesting of the Temple sites.

The first temple we went to. Favorite part was the elephant walk. Good introduction to the many temples as you walk under a gate to get to it & then there are lots of grounds around it that you can walk through.

Again... Lovely. If you're doing the Angkor tour, and aren't a historian, then after a point all temples may start seeming the same. I had short listed 5 to see- Ta Prohm, Bayon, Angkor, Angkor Thom and one with the reclining Buddha. I believe each of these was different, and for a day tripper, those are the 5 I recommend. Angkor Thom is filled with history and legends. Worth it.

Khmer Kingdom Capital. We entered fro the South Gate to visit Bayon Temple. Outside the gate there is a long line of statues from both sides who are holding perhaps a naga (snake which protects Buddha). In other Gates many statues are without head because poor people during the civil war took them and sold them to live. As one can see poverty destroys everything!!!!

Get there early in the morning. We visited Angkor Thom after watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat, but first we climbed the hill to the ruins at the top just before the gate to Angkor Thom. We recommend skipping the climb up the hill or doing it later. To avoid the crowds, go as early as you can to Angkor Thom, especially the towers of Bayon which were our favourite site. Or go a little later in the afternoon around 3:00. If you have limited time and you're not sure how to spend your time, this is a must see, especially the towers of Bayon.

Angkor Thom. This is the first temple we visited.... I thought it was the greatest!! But came, Angkor Wat..... wow, that was the majestic! Angkor Thom is unique on its own!! Very interesting carvings.... and the land area is also huge like Angkor Wat!
Wow. What more can I say but...WOW! One of my favourite places I have ever had the luck and pleasure to visit...

Worth the effort. After climbing up the last flight of stairs I understood why there was a warning for pregnant ladies not to enter Angkor Thom...;) It can be risky to climb very steep, neverending stairs.The view was spectacular though. One of the highlights among Angkor Temples.

Most beautiful temple in Angkor. Our preferred temple in Angkor, with the 4 faces statues/towers. really impressive. It is a beautiful place too, in the forest. Therefore it is not as painfully hot as Angkor Wat.I recommend the elephant ride, especially with kids. Need to book in advance as they have reduced the number of elephants and waiting time is several hours otherwise (at least when we went there, Jan 2013)
get buddha'd. a temple of smiling buddhas, hundreds, huge. and the dancing girls in bas relief hiding in every corner. dont miss it! i liked it better than angkor wat.

Gorgeous. Smaller than Angkor Wat ( isn't everything) this temple should not be missed. The sheer beauty of the delicate, intricate carving covering every centimetre is breathtaking. Just try and imagine how spectacular it would have been walking into it when it was newly completed. Wow!

More intimate than Angkor Wat. Not quite crawling with throngs of tourists than the more famous Wat. Not so many locals out to sell drinks or postcards here either. This place is smaller but no less impressive than the Angkor Wat. Nestled in a nice forested area, the restoration works aren't quite as extensive as in Angkor Wat so more of it seems to lie as ruins and heaps of rubble that seems to shroud the place in a bit more mystique than the more touristy counterpart. Seen many tourists actually managing to find their own little spots to sit and meditate there. Quite peaceful. Highly recommended!
Another great stop. Another great stop on the ANgkor temple circuit. They are all unbelievable and make sure you have a good guide and the Lonely Planet bible to help out.

Angkor Thom was beautiful too.. Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!

Bayoun at Sunset: Yes.. As for my own visit to Siem Reap, I booked a boutique hotel with a pool not far from downtown. The first evening arrival I had one of the bell hops take me around to the bars on a motodop and they were all kind of trashy and exotic at the same time, fun, maybe a little like fantasy island in the middle of a rubbish heap. I got the multiple day pass for Angkor Wat which allowed a first free sunset admission. Rented a bike and rode up to wait at the gate where you can chat with other visitors while you wait. Then the next day hired an a/c van to visit the farther temples outside the main ring and my favourite had to be Bang Melea. It's a couple of hours out and back round trip. However arranging a tuk-tuk to take you to Bayoun Temple in late afternoon for sunset is a great bet. What an incredible place to see the sunset; the light and these monolithic multihued ancient stone heads as well as the opportunity for a more intimate visit with fewer people around was mystical and marvellous. Scrabbling and exploring around the Bayoun and hearing the voices of others carrying through the passageways was an unforgettable experience. However for longer day trips throughout Angkor Wat by tuk-tuk would recommend a gas mask or suitable breathable scarf as the dust on the roads around the various ring temples can be pretty bad. The farther you want to go the more suitable a proper a/c transport will get.

Awesome. To see this temple in person after seeing it in others pics is just magnificent. I can't comprehend how this was done hundreds of years back. Yes theres explanations and exhibits but to see the stones that are a few tonnes placed in such high areas is just something else.

Overwhelmed by .... Well ... only one description, Overwhelmed by jostling Chinese tourists. Maybe I chose the wrong moment to visit the place but it was packed to the brim with tourists from China smoking indiscriminately in the temples itself, even though "No Smoking"signs were all over. (Not that the dust kicked up by vehicles bad enough, but the puffing made it almost unbearable) If you should visit, do so at a time when China is not on holiday :)
another place not to miss. another place not to miss while visiting Angkor Wat. GReat face profiles but the detail work of local life on the front wall is outstanding.
Go there ASAP. Get your lame photo of the sunrise at Wat then book it straight for Thom. I liked Thom better than Wat, and to have Thom all to yourself in the early AM rocks!!

The most interesting in the Angkor complex. Although far less intact than its big brother Angkor Wat, I found Angkor Thom the most interesting of the three. The giant smiling faces are mesmerizing, and they appear to be everywhere. The photo opportunities here are the best in the complex. A must see!

Mystic place for all!!!. What time is the Angkor Thom old forgotten town best - late afternoon! Dust and day steam are combined to specialy hot atmosphere and the daylight will be purple. Rain forest in the Angkor thom has a lat of secrets, for example new visited pagoda Preah Palillay or Preah Pithu V. on the opposite side of the road... remember it, angkor Wat is nice, but Angkor thom is A heart of all here. All year other view, all year anything new, with parrots and wonderful birds around You. One of Worlds wonder!

Bayon, Baphuon, and much more. Take your time - a day or two - to enjoy all the temples of Angkor Thom. We went with a guide on our first day, who really gave us a solid understanding of the history and religious significance of the place, before taking a second day to climb around and have fun.Head up to the very top of Baphuon to get one of the best views of Angkor, and make sure you head to Preah Khan - but just pick your own route, and see what you fancy. A fantastic few days.

Temple Run. Here, you need a lot of strength to climb the temple. Has three layers of steep stairs. Tiring to go up, scary when going down. Do not forget your water. You need it from all the climbing.

So big!. Angkor Thom is truly a wonder. It is really hard to comprehend its size and complexity. The remaining structures and statuary are amazing but the remaining 'civil' works like the lakes and walls are a true wonder.
A must see. We preferred Angkor Thom to the better known Angkor Wat. Take plenty of time to walk around and see the outlying areas. It is a truely amazing experience.
Lost!. Amazing, as is everything in the complex. Make sure you designate a meeting place and time as cell phones don't get reception in the park.

Another great temple to see. An amazing place to visit. Employ a guide and get the most from your visit. The day we went, it was very busy (about 9.30am). Wear comfortable shoes and always carry water with you.
Angor Thom. good day out for all....but very hot so very tired after such a long day walking up and down hundreds of stairs maybe even thousands lol...

Big, bold, old and beautiful. Angkor Thom is large, very large, and contains some magnificent stone sculptures, many of which are actually part of the fabric of the temple and temple walls. Like everything else in the Angkor complex it is on a large scale, and well worth the time and effort to visit.
Wow. I liked this site better than Angkor What. Its smaller and crowds make for some tight squeezes, but still well worth the visit.

Lots To See And Take In. An Experience.. Visited this site early morning, about eleven and was very surprised at the lack of tourists, yes they were there but not in the numbers we later experienced at Ta Phrom, the jungle wat. The location is so big it also helps to spread the visitors around as everyone gets dropped of at one location and you make your way through the city to he pick up point I really enjoyed this location as it has three or four locations you can explore but beware the heat is extra ordinary, by the time we had finished I was ready to collapse, it's hard going in the middle of the day. Probably why it was so quiet. You need a good couple of hours to get around this location. Despite the heat it was very enjoyable and my favourite.
We loved Bayon!. Angkor thom/ small circuit as it is referred to has the most gorgeous ruins and temples. We loved the bayon the best! The chaotic art really speaks to the visitors.

Big city. Angkor Tom, the ancient capital of Angkor dating 11th-12th century is a must to visit. It will take about two hours if you want to visit the south Gate, Bayon, Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Lepra king.

The buddhas are pretty. It's a beautiful place, but after seeing so many temples, you do get a bit numb. Could be the guide that i got seemed very jaded, so i'd recommend a good one.Do check out the chinese people etched on the wall with long beards... quite interesting

Another fabulous temple. So we loved this temple but after a while of seeing so many temples everywhere it just gets abit much, so choose two or three temples - go see them, take pics, then go do something else like the markets and try and talk to the people.

Just amazing!. This ancient city just keeps throwing marvels at you. To see everything would take weeks. It is getting a bit crowded, but is an incomparable spectacle which I rate on a par with the pyramids in Giza.

Great. Angkor Thom is unbelievable. We`ve never been to the Pyramids in Egypt - but these temples must match them. The feats of engineering to move the stone, the building and carvings are incredible - as is the size of the moat surrounding the temple complex, all dug out by hand !
A tick in the box attraction. recommended and a good attraction. completes the must see sites in Siem Reap. some unique features to be seen.

Angkor Thom..Ruins amidst moss and vines... Much documented and photographed for its mystery and beauty,Angkor Thom rests in its secret space awaiting its discovery,as if,for each individual traveller,it is revealing itself for the very first time ..It's weathered stones and fallen obelisks lie quietly on beds of moss ,held tight for centuries in twisted arms of vines.Around its edges tangled jungles lie,dripping green! To visit Angkor Thom is like no other place I have ever experienced..Wild and Holy!
Not as large as ankor wat, but definately worth a look. Nice to get there by bike. Consider ride along ramparts, where no traffic. Buhda images have nice smiles

In the jungles of Cambodia. You really need to reinforce to yourself where you are as you visit the temples of Angkor. Reviewing my photos at home, it looks like a Disney ride. It seems so familiar - again, that's why you need to take it in and remember that you are in the remote jungles of Cambodia. The nation itself is a dismal result of a mad mans rule - but the temples are worth the price of having to put up with the country for a few days. While Angkor Wat gets the glory - Angkor Thom deserves as much praise or more. It was large enough so the crowds were not too overwhelming. It was as photographic as any place I have ever been. And it was busy - as Cambodia's tourism industry grows by leaps and bounds over the next few years, these temples will be a mosh pit at best. The entrance with its "receiving line" of sculpture warriors, and that cave like entrance must have been truly daunting in its day. A fascinating place to visit for an hour or two.

As featured in films such as 'Tomb Raiders'!. Amazing illustration of the force of nature - reclaiming the land on which humans had built temples. It now features a combination of ruined temples with trees growing up through them, creating romantic and weird vistas. The trees themselves are very unusual, and with a little imagination you can 'see' some having almost "human-like" features (e.g. branches that look like arms or legs!). Well worth a visit.
Amazing. Don't miss this one, and get a guide to walk you through the history it will make the visit. No dislikes.

Represents restored and decaying temple. The temple Is really huge and has 4 gates. 1 gate is restored to near original and the rest of the other gates are still in ruins, which gives you a picture of how it used to look and how it looks when the French colonizers discovered it. Truly amazing and awe inspiring to see such great handiwork of empires long gone.
More great photo ops!. The entrance to this temple has a really great story - make sure you get a tour guide to tell you about it! The rest of the temple is just magnificent!
fabulous. get a guide to show you around. Angkor Thom is beautiful and well worth a visit as part of a tour around the temple sites.

Incredible. After checking into our hotel in Siem Reap, Angkor Thom was our first visit on the list of temples visits in the area.We entered into the city from the South Gate across the bridge over the moat lined with smiling gods on the left-hand side and evil-looking devils on the right.The South Gate is the best-preserved of the gates with its tower and four faces.After entering through the South Gate we headed off to Bayon Temple.Our guide was extremely informative although I did get really confused with the names of the various kings during the Khmer reign.
Angkor Thom A must see. The early contruction of Angkor Thom makes you wonder how they managed to be such a Magnificent place. One of the many musts ee places in Cambodia.

A Must. After Angkor Wat, make sure you go to Angkor Thom, while not as big as Angkor Wat, it is quite different. Carvings of the four faces on each tower is beautiful. The terrace of the elephant and the terrace of the leper king is within this complex, so a must in Siem Reap.

interesting. Everything we saw in the "park" was incredible. It was extremely hot when we went and our guide thoughtfully gave us huge umbrellas to keep the sun off and our driver always had fresh cold towels and water for us.

Don't Miss it. Inside the Angkor archaeological park (entrance fee 20 USD / day) is 'the city' fortified with the famous Bayon temple , impressive example of architecture that you can not 'forget. Do not miss!

Angkor Thom Complex. Angkor Thom is a huge complex that was populated by at least 1 million people during its heyday. The complex houses the Bayon, Terrace of Elephants, Baphoun, Terrace of the Leper King and other temples. The impressive architecture and history within one place is something worth experiencing. The Bayon is definitely the highlight of this complex. Bet to go during 7am so that few tourists are in the area.
First trip. Beautiful place - clean and well preserved. Friendly people and a lot to see in this area. Recommend at least three or four days.

Not the big name, but great. Our group went here early morning by 8 a.m. and there were few tourists. The light was wonderful with tree roots working down the stone of a thousand year old temple. All of these require a lot of climbing up and down stairs but this one less so than Angkor Wat. I wouldn't miss it but try to get there before the crowds

An Unforgettable Experience. We entered Angkor Thom complex through the South Gate, by crossing a causeway over a moat. Flanking the causeway on the right were 36 angry looking demons, pulling on a Naga (snake) and on the left by 36 smiling gods pulling on a second Naga. From a distance the Bayon looked like a jumbled mess - a bunch of ruined towers surrounded by heaps of stone rubble. Past the perky hawkers are the steps to the first tier of the Bayon. The large outer wall is covered from top to bottom with intricately carved, beautifully detailed, and well preserved bas-reliefs of historical battles, processions, mythology, and scenes from village life. The same wall also serves as part of a structure containing another gallery of reliefs on the interior. The paths inside are circuitous, and non-intuitive. In each direction were long shadowy pathways decorated with bas-reliefs in surprisingly good condition. The second tier is the home to the many faces of Avelokitesvara. They were there, everywhere you looked. Bayon had originally 49 towers, out of which only 37 are still standing, all crowned with faces looking out to the four cardinal points. It is also possible that the faces represented that of Jayavarman VII himself, as a new expression of an old Khmer tradition of belief in the apotheosis of kings.While in Angkor Thom do not miss out on the terrace of the elephants and the terrace of the leper king. The elephant terrace is decorated by a procession of elephants in bas-relief, each about 2 meters high. The terrace of the leper king has one of the big surprises - a 5 headed horse carved in bas-relief.Visited in January 2006
Interesting. This is still in a state of renovation but the size and frescos are amazing. It is hard to believe the population was once greater then London.
A partner to Angkor Wat. With Angkor Wat these 2 places demonstrate the advanced development of the Cambodiam Kingdon. At a time when London had 250,000 people, this city had 2,000,000 people.

Indiana Jones must-see. We wandered round this huge site admiring the way the tree roots had been preserved twining around the stonework. Many passages and towers and well preserved friezes, restoration work was still in progress but they were doing a great job.
Our favourite!. This was our favourite site in the whole Angkor area. A beautiful, warm feeling here. Amazing carvings and sculptures!
The details are amazing!. Make sure to do lots of stretching before going in. Your agility will be put to the test as you go up-down-side-up-down on the ruins of the temple.
Not far from Angkor Wat. Just down the road is another magical place with fewer tourists. Worth the short ride to experience a completely different temple

Angkor Thom translates as Great City - how appropriate. Angkor Thom covers something like 9 square kilometres and contains a number of monuments including the Bayon. The south gate entrance alone is worth going to see as is "Terrace of the Elephants".Because of the large size of the area be prepared to spend considerable time there and if possible arrange a local guide who can explain the significance of what you see. Don't forget your camera and plenty of water. The architecture, statues and carvings make you realise how talented the people were when these structures were built, all without the help of modern machinery etc.

Bigger than you might think. Amazing to see -- but much larger than I thought! Be sure to bring enough water for multiple hours if you plan to see it all.We were shocked at how large the complex was. Well worth the walking and climbing, though. Just be more prepared than we were!

The Wonderful Stepchild of Temples. Almost everyone has heard of Angkor Wat and when going to Cambodia, visits Angkor Wat. However, make time to visit Angkor Thom. It holds its own with the more famous Angkor Wat. In my humble opinion, the gates are more spectacular than Angkor Wat and if you find a good guide, the Buddha sculptures in the surrounding jungle are worth the trip by themselves. I really enjoyed my time at Angkor Thom and took many photographs. Worth the time!

Great City!. Angkor Thom literally means Great City and indeed this ancient city lives up to its name. Everything about this place is grand and the temples built within this complex are nothing but magnificent. You can just imagine the beauty and majesty of this place when it was first built and was the capital of Khmer empire. I felt like I should have worn a royal garb when I came to visit but make sure you wear something comfortable, light clothing and shoes fit for walking. Also, the place covers a vast area with a lot to see so be sure t have lot's of water with you and wear sunscreen as the weather can be a bit hot. It will be also nice to have an extra shirt handy.

Wonderful ancient city of stone and trees. This was a city of over a million people back in the middle ages so there are lots of different temples and ruins strewn around a beautiful parkland setting. This is quite a large site so take lots of water and wear comfortable trainers as you will be climbing up and across lots of stone steps and ruins...
Magnificent. You can only imagine how beautiful this temple would have been when it was built.The logistics of carving the faces speaks much of the talents of man.

The very best that Cambodia has to offer. Angkor Thom is a huge area fully surrounded by a moat and encompassing several fabulous sights. We entered through the South Gate of Angkor Thom. The Gate area is a great introduction to Angkor Thom, with its gateways, passages of statues and setting. From there we went to the Bayon – This was our favourite part of the Angkor complex. After that we visited, and climbed the Baphoun before wondering through the area including Phimeanakis, The Terraces of the Elephants and Leper King before leaving passing through the Suor Prasat Towers.The Bayon is fantastic with its haunting faces the highlight of the entire area. Baphuon is great to up close to and climb and don’t miss the Reclining Buddha, and the Terraces, Phimeanakis and Tower all a great backdrop to an hugely impressive area We loved our time in Angkor Thom. I wish I had taken a little longer around the Phimeanakis, Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King and would recommend you do.

If you have one day, see this. If you only have one day see this complex as it has the most interesting temple Bayon. Even the grounds and gate are wonderful. Don't miss this one. Go EARLY, it attracts big crowds.

So many faces. What an amazing temple; carved faces everywhere and each one of them different. Make sure you allow enough time to explore this fabulous temple. Appropriate dress is required - below knee shorts/skirts and no bare shoulders.
Running out of superlatives. We loved everything at Angkor, but the statues on the two sides approaching the gates here by the river were amazing. Not to be missed.
Covers Such a Large Area. You'll definitely need to give yourself a few hours for this place alone. The East Gate is quite a climb & the Terrace of the Elephants is exquisite.

Will take lots of hours. Good use of a 'tuk-tuk' for a few hours. They seem to prefer to wait for you and can save you a lot of dead walking between all the temples, as you need all your energy for the temples themselves. Some women were getting turned away for wearing shorts. Do wear appropriate shoes too. This is not a 'cat-walk'.
great!. angkor thom is a beautiful! its a great place to start exploring all of "angkor way". don't miss it!
Amazing. I loved this whole area, incredible entrance with the faces overlooking the bridge, the snakes, the demons, the elephant terrace -a beautiful place
Incredible. Another fantastic piece of history. Go now sooner than later, unfortunately it isnt being looked after with the dignity it deserves. visitors climb all over the site.

Charming of Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom is the biggest city in Angkor Area. Early in the morning and at lunch time or afternoon is the best time to take photographs. Go to visit these places early in the morning is very quiet and when the sun shine, all of the faces in Bayon are the most beautiful or Afternoon.
Dont miss this!. Loved the grounds and temples in this area. Definately go ther early in the mornig and you have the place pretty much to yourself which is great fro atmosphere and photos.

Not to be missed. This part of the World Heritage Site is spectacular. Make sure you have a certified guide so you can understand the history, the mythologies, and the context. Otherwise, it's just a nice pile of rocks.
Exquisite and unbelievable!. Such a beautiful place, take a guide with you, you'll get the history and the mythical stories which help bring the place to life!

Skip if you don't have time. This was first on my tour and well it was totally exciting...for a little bit. But if you have the time check it out...if not just go to the Angkor Wat and the Banyan temple portion. This is like the Angkor Wat but not as pretty and way hotter.

A lot of walking. Angkor Thom has a lot to see, spend some time at the entrance since there is a lot to see. Highlights are the terrace of elephants and the entry way, if you pay attention you can see the monkeys on the road.
Lovely!. Perfect for photo opportunities. We found it was a little quieter here which was nice. Take a tuk tuk and plenty of water because it gets very hot!
Do not plan too short here. The place deserves to get lost in. Adventure yourself to the small temples around and you will be rewarded. Avoid during the most sunny hours there.

Also a part of the Angkor Wat experience, see it!. This site should be a part of the circuit your driver takes you on. Expect to pay about 20 or so dollars for the day, depending on gas prices. We started out around 8 or 9 am and usualy were back at the hotel by 3 pm in an effort to pace ourselves and not burn out.
Another great temple. I liked this one better than Angkor Wat, it might be the amount of tourists that were in Angkor Wat or that Angkor Thom has more original parts and seems more 'just found'
Wear your walking shoes. Thom has an enourmous amount of area to cover, it really is huge so wear your walking shoes, take lenty of water and take it slow, can really absorb this place so enjoy.

Don't burden yourself by a single day trip. After visiting Angkor Wat & Bayon temple, visiting Angkor Tom can be tiring. Try to break the trip into 2 days - 1 day ticket purchased on 1st day after sunset will entitle you to visit the next day also.

Huge and impressive site. Recommend getting there early or late to avoid mid-day sun or other tourists. Definately get a guide and a taxi to direct you around this huge site, and ensure you see the best bits, and get an explanation of the carvings, and buildings. Hugely impressive.

This is THE reason to visit Cambodia. Angkor Thom and the rest of Angkor are the jewel of Cambodia. There is plenty to love about this country and I recommend that everyone visit it - moreso than even neighboring Vietnam and Thailand, however, please give yourself two days in Angkor. And then more time in Siem Reap. I found Siem Reap to be a lot of fun and a great home base to hit Angkor as well as Battambang. Do not miss Bayon Temple, Ta Prohm, Angkor Wat, or any of the others if you're a temple fan. Sunrise is particularly nice and worth the early rise. Sunset... just okay. Sunrise. Go for it.
great place. this is another temple you will love the stall people are very friendly and do not hassel you. What a shame about all the damage that was done
Excellent. Awesome for photos etc... especially on a clear lovely day. Make sure you carry lots of water with you in the tuk tuk

The Wreck of an Immense City. Within its long city walls only the stone monuments of Angkor Thom survive. But what monuments. Its causeways lined with Naga bearing ogres. Its massive entry gate towers flanked by elephants. The vast level of the Elephant and Leper King terraces, their fronts exuberantly carved. The long line of the Rope Dancers temples across the immense parade ground. The Bayon with its face towers. The Baphuon with its moat. And more and more. And this is only part of the Archaeological Park. A wonder.

Rank 3. I would rank this 3rd among the temples we say..first being angkor wat and 2nd being Tr Prohm (Tomb Raider fame). Unlike Ankor Wat that is spread out and classy, Ankor Thom (the central temple) is a temple of faces. it is not known if the faces belong to the king or gods but are beautifully carved and have a variety of expresssions. Dont miss
Wow!. This one is the one that i loved the most, the trees/nature have tried to claim back the land. Growing over the buildings it is a marvel to experience.
My favorite one. Angkor Thom and Ta prohm are my favorite temples, they stand out by their beauty and are really charming!
Great Temple. This is one of the better temples to see while visiting Angkor. While there are many temples to see I would make sure to add this one to the list.

Good Temple. This place has a different character and structure compair to Angkor Wat! But it is also part of the Angkor Wat Archelogical Park and it is worth visiting this historical temple..Stunning and magnificent..

Superb. The whole of the Angkor complex is breathtaking and this is no different. I thought that I would be 'Templed out' after a couple of long day looking at old buildings.....nothing could be further from the truth. I would love to retrace every step I took in Cambodia and do it all over again. The Temples are beautiful, magical and unlike anything I have ever seen in my life.

impressive. Unfortunately we visited during a prolonged tropical rainstorm which the guide said would only last 5-10 min but managed to totally flood the site within an hour. It is a very large walled city, much more Buddist influence than the mostly Hindu at Angkor Wat, incredible fluid enigmatic carvings everywhere.
A must visit site in Siem Reap. Any traveller visiting this site should must visit Angkor Thom, along with Angkor Wat, Bantey Srei, National museum, Ta Prohm, Preah Kahn, and Phnom Kulen.

lots to see. lots to see including elephants and monkeys on outskirts.good shopping oppertunity but watch bags,purses etc i got my purse taken from inside my bag.be prepared for a lot of scrambbling about and a lot of walking on uneven ground.

still magnificent. I am still in awe of the beauty of Angkor Thom, though not as famous as Angkor Wat this place has its own beauty and mystery. again like in the other places - there is just too many people.

Impressive architecture. The beauty in Angor Thom lies in the inner structure of the building. To my very surprise it is very lightly built with a lot space and still the support of the top. Good to know that the Khmer never mastered the arch, so they have to stack all the stones very carefully.

Amazing Angkor. I took the option of being an early bird and arriving just before 5am to an already crowded ticket booth I spent 7 hours walking around the various temples having hired a tuk tuk driver from my hostel , words can't describe the amazing beauty of this temple complex .ive seen a lot of stuff in the world nothing comes close , steal yourself for the hordes of child beggars working there way around as you visit ,this and the permanent sales pitch of traders can drag on you but try not to let it get you down just remember your effectively in a semi jungle area beware of where you poke your foot /hand into as there are tales of snakebite at ta promh and those cute monkeys will bite you if your silly enough to annoy them , two things take a scarf or bright coloured sarong to tie to your tuk tuk you'll often find your driver has zonked out or gone to get a drink and there are literally hundreds bearing in mind they look the same as do the drivers !!! Early morning take a torch with you , there's a coffee van that serves great tea coffee croissants although far from cheap are v nice ! Hope this helps ;)

Was & remain speechlesss at what they did in 12th Century. I could write for hours and still fail to capture and convey the staggering enormity of what they built here.In a word - GO.That is what I wrote as a Reveiw earlier, but it was rejected as to few words for the TA computer, so trying again.How one describe a inanimate Object - Excellent, Very Good or whatever is absurd. However, I say again - just Go and you will be stunned

Favorite parts were Bayon and Terrace of the Leper King. Bayon is stunning and it contrasts well with the narrow passages and labyrinth feel of the leper terrace, plus it provides some shade. Be prepared to be emphatically directed to pass by yhe vendors before you can return to your car or tuk tuk.

A vast oasis of beauty and antiquity. The ancient history of Angkor Thom is extensive and captivating, and the four of us that toured it strongly advise an open mind and a tour guide. Every surface is extensively carved with pictures of daily life, war and relationships. Be careful of the monkeys.

Lots of fun. This temple is the one used for Raiders of the Lost Ark and it is recognizable. How perfect. It's still a puzzle being put back together as the workers attempt to figure out which stones are supposed to fit up against the others and where they all belong. It's a busy place and hot as hades so take lots of water.

Stunning. Beautiful, no other word. Go there.Beware of 'tour guides' though, we were quite happily wondering around when a 'guide' joined us. He was very helpful, gave lots of information and pointed out all the best places to take pics but got very shirty when our tip for his (unsolicited) services was not to his liking!
Land of Smiling Budhas. One of the temples with a bit more damage but completely worth it for the smiling budhas. Lovely back story.
Amazing. Not to miss, a once in a lifetime experience. Well, second in a lifetime since we were here already in 2005. Words cannot describe this experience. Idem for Angkot Wat and the other temples.
nice. made famous by the movie Tomb Raider, starring Angelina Jolie, this was much better than Angkor Wat. Weather in Cambodia can be very taxing so be prepared !
Amazing. Pictures do not do it justice. Try to go when it's quieter - the busloads of tourists can be overwhelming

A definite must see, but watch out for scammers. This is a very distinct complex with all the faces in the spires. Definitely a must see even if you only have one day. Watch out for uniformed police acting as tour guides that will try to charge you for their services. There were 2 there when we were there so were kept a distance from them since we had already been warned. This is another big complex so take water with you as its quite a hike to get to the water vendors. Lots of climbing is involved and there are 3-4 temples on this stop that go on for about a mile.
A stone marvel!. King Jayavarman established this with Bayaon at the center. I think this is in the most dilapidated condition. This is covered by very tall wall and long moat.
Gorgeous, Climb to the top!. The pictures we took from the bottom came out phenomenal. The walk to the temple and to the top were so beautiful!!

Six stars. The whole Angkor Wat plus sites I found thoroughly interesting, and a pleasure to experience. You can also learn a but about the culture, and the poverty of the local populace just by virtue of the entrance gate areas where they swarm to sell trinkets and objects like drums & statues. Keep your guard up if you wish but also be mindful to stay polite (and firm if you are not interested) and kind to the hawkers and children as they are just trying to make a living in a hard world. We saw some very unkind tourists and that was very unfortunate to me. The sites itself are amazing, if you are a history/archaeological buff, then it may also be the place for you. Many people had a guide with them which I think makes sense but we also liked time to look and take pictures. We bought a guidebook for 7 and later realized we were highly charged but then again bargaining with such poor people didn't make the most sense either to me. So just be aware of a price that you find fairer and be happy with your price and purchase. As most note, it gets very hot very fast so sun protection is a must as is mosquito protection. Dress reasonably but also for the heat. Wear good footwear as there are many open branches and uneven surfaces. Bring H2O or buy at the hawker stands outside. Enjoy.

best large Budhist faces are at Angkor Thom. one of my favourite spots is the entrance gate to Angkor Thom where the large faces look down on you. They are widening the road here and soon tour buses will not be allowed in. For now, it is a good place to watch the bicycles and rickshaws enter the grounds.

remarkable temple. i was really happy and fortunate to get a guide that planned my angkor temple tour itinerary carefully. the angkor thom was the farthest of the 4 temples that we would visit that day, and he decided to go here first to avoid the crowd. with that wise decision i was able to explore and enjoy my visit to this awesome temple.

City of divine ghosts. As I understand it, this is the ancient imperial capital that encloses with a wall and moat all of the major religious and historical sites near Siem Reap. The area is extensive, and there are a number of dramatic gateways that give access to various sections. The buildings of interest are widely separated by landscaped parkland with artificial lakes and canals, as well as by natural swampland and jungle. The most celebrated are Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple ( both of which I have reviewed independently). Other notable sites within the overall complex include the Terraces of the Elephants and Lepers, and the Temples of Baphuon and Phimeanakas that actually preceded the foundation of the imperial city. As to be expected, they are very much the worse for wear, and one has to tread carefully over piles of fallen stones, and up staircases worn thin by the feet of armies, but there is an awesome quality to these monuments that few historic sites elsewhere in our universe can deliver, and it needs an entire day of strenuous physical commitment to do justice to the riches on offer. But be warned: food and refreshments are scarce, and decent toilets even more so.

Nice large site. This area is well worth a visit and is nice to spend some time here. The food is amazing under the tents at the far end. There are several sites here to visit and plenty of walking. Bathrooms and water can be far to reach for those with kids or tire easily, so plan accordingly.
Cambodia - 2012. This is one of the many temples that we visited in Cambodia. This place is a must see if you plan to go to Cambodia.

Peaceful and Beautiful... A beautiful walk, plenty of climbing, wonderful ruins especially the Leopard King. Make sure you climb up to the tops of the temples as the views and photos are just superb. Bloody hot and sweaty work however so take plenty of water. Our Tuk Tuk drivers had water at every stop for us.
Fascinating Angkor. A wonderful place to visit...thorough beautiful location to take in the spiritual location and history of a wonderful country
Fabulous Angkor Thom. We had to walk quite a ways to get to Angkor Thom but the serenity and surroundings was so pleasing one wanted to stay.

big place to watch. it's a very large place to watch, some people Ride an elephant, and we toke a bus, very tired to walk under hot weather.Otherwise, these temple are nice, might be good at guide tour. To help understand the history and struction of Angkor Thom.臥佛石雕很壯麗 鬥象台很可愛~還有十二生肖塔~天氣實在很熱，建議多帶把傘跟帽子遮陽，陽光照在臉上很熱很刺!逛到最後熱得受不了也沒心情聽導遊在說甚麼了
Terrific. Another of the fantastic temples in the area.once again the workman ship and masonry skills of the workers is just terrific.
Great temple to visit. One of our favorites, well worth a visit. We had a fantastic guide who could tell us all the wonderful stories which brought the temples alive.

Beautifull. Marvelous place so beautyfull. But don't go there by Greater Mekong travel and tour. The worst expérience of our 2 1/2 month of travelling. Don't touch!!!
In Angkor thomb you have not enough of your two eyes to see all this beauty.
Take your Time and picture!!!

Impressive welcome. Entrance is at the South gate where visitors are greeted by a row of 54 stone figures on either side of a causeway – demons on the right and gods on the left guarding the city of Angkor Thom. The demons have a grimacing expression and wear a military headdress while the gods look serene with their almond-shaped eyes and wear a conical headdress. They make an impressive welcoming party to the last capital of the Angor empire.

Grand Scale. The scale of the Angkor Thomas complex is enormous. You won't see it all but just soak up the atmosphere at your own pace. Just find a good tuk tuk driver ($15 a day) and let him take you. That way you avoid the tour groups

the "must see" temple site in Siem Reap. largest, most extensive, most dramatic architecture, great detail "bas reliefs", and least reported temple site near Siem Reap. This is THE ONE to visit, after your obligatory tour of Angkor Wat.
Stunning. Wow!! Another amazing place. Have to admit we were v hot and bothered by the time we got here and so we were driven through and only went up into the main area on foot.
Magnificent. Well preserved and impressive this should be on everyone's itinerary. In some ways better than Angkor Wat.

Huge, awesome. This is a big complex. At entrance you see the stone structure in the shape of cobra-snake (naga?) in a tug of war between the good (gods) and the bad (demons), the churning creating life and universe - a motif that is at the heart of Hindu philosophy.The temples that have survived include Buddhas, many towers, endless walls carved with philosophical stories from Hindu and Buddhist epics, all inside a jungle.Angkor Thom was a microcosm of the universe to Khmer civilization centuries ago. A place of awe for ours.

yet another of the temples. Please do not just do Angkor wat .. visit all the other temples in the area .. get a good tour guide to take you .. I recommend Sophana Yous .. excellent .. The differences in the temples is really interesting!
A great way to start a visit to all the historic site around Siem Reap. A must visit to appreciate the size, extent & condition of all the sites which make up the Angkor Archeological Park area

East Entrance. The east entrance is amazing. The renovations have replaced some of the heads, giving an idea of what it would have looked like, but the old, broken, lichen covered ones are the best. The view over the moat in the early morning light is wonderful.

excellent. The vast area of the Angkor Thom ruins, over a mile on one side, contains many stone temples and other features to explore. The city has five monumental gates, 20m high and decorated with stone elephant trunks and the king's favorite motif, the four faces of Avalokiteshvara. Impressive!!

Amazing.. I wish I'd read a little about the sites in Siem Reap prior to my visit as the history is fascinating. If you can, pay for the very inexpensive guides to go with you as you visit the sites, it'll be well worth it.

You need several days. To really take in the whole size of this enclosed city you would need more time than most people have, so select the parts and temples that you want to see. And then you have the excuse to come back to see the parts that you missed!

Cooler than Angkor Wat. just so cool...looks like these rock pushed out of the ground and formed these structures. i look back at photos and they look too cool to be real. there's also a cool face or facade at every turn.

don't miss this area. Because it's bigger, has number of astonishingly beautiful temples inside and in general - you have much more sights to see and enjoy, this could be the hilight of the whole site

A day's worth to visit!. The Angkor Thom complex will take a full day's worth to visit so be prepared with you sunscreen, mosquito repellent, and bottles of water. This complex will give you a good and welcomed respite from many locals selling (or bothering you with selling) what they have. There are only three places where they can be found (so steer away from these places to not ruin your day for those fed up with these happenings), but if you need water or food or even souvenirs, go to these people. (1) parking lot east of Bayon, (2) parking lot across the Terrace of the Leper King, and (3) a few meters away from the back of the Terrace of the Leper King. Things to do in Angkor Thom if you just have the whole afternoon or morning. (1) Enjoy the Bayon with its many face towers. (2) Scale the entirety of Baphuon. This is not for the ones who are afraid of heights as the stairs going up to the top is quite steep. (3) See the site where the Royal Palace of Angkor Thom once stood, but its temple is still there and climbable from the back. (4) Check out the Elephant Terrace. (5) View the hidden reliefs of the Terrace of the Leper King. The Angkor Thom complex is a huge place quadruple the size of Angkor Wat complex, but a walking tour of it suffices if you want an experience albeit very draining. At night, your excuse for a foot massage would be because you did something as crazy as walking all over Angkor Thom.
So much to see. Get the cameraready as so much to see and fabulous photo opportunities - hire a local guide to get the most out of your time and carry plenty or water

Allow a good couple of hours to see it all. Numerous temples are enclosed in what is known as Angkor Thom, its not just one temple its a large complex with the Bayon as highlight. Each one is however worth a meander round and a climb up.
Amazing. As with all the temples, there is much renovation going on which will probably take forever - but worth it.

Gate of 4 Faces. Wow. A naga (sacred cobra) balustrade consisting of a giants' tug-of-war on each side crosses the moat and leads to the South Gate with its 4 huge faces. It is truly amazing. Once through the gate there are many things to see; the Bayon, Phimeanakas Temple, the Elephants' Terrace and the Terrace of the Leper King. You need a lot of time to see it all and if it's hot it will be tiring.

how did Angelina Jolie managed her make up and hair in the movie?!. you can't go there and not think in Tomb Raider. Here this movie was shot. Nice, like the other temples, but bring a guide along or you will miss the pourpouse of each place!

A site to be remembered... A huge site, with many temples and structures scattered inside. I would take atleast a few hours out here to see what this area has to offer. Some beautiful temples and structures lie here including the elephant and leopard king temples. I did covered this area in about 2 hours with limited time. However, i would have stayed longer if given the chance. Recommend you start early (maybe after seeing the sunrise over angkor wat). This helps in avoiding the large buses of tourists and also gets you some "clean" pictures!! :O)
Amazing. I wished I had researched a little more before my visit.It is really amazing and worth the visit. Highly recommend this temple.
Visit before Angkor Wat. Whilst the architecture of this temple is similar to that of Angkor Wat, it should not be missed. If possible have a local guide take you round.

A definite yes on your list of places to visit. Just to the North of Angkor Wat is Angkor Thom which was the last and most enduring capital city of the Khmer empire. It was established in the late twelfth century by King Jayavarman VII. You will probably have just been to Angkor Wat and you will see the contrast here. In a less good state of repair but the Bayon is particularly fine. 47 towers, originally, with the face of a Buddha on each of the four sides. Not as strenuous a visit as Angkor Wat and not an active Buddhist temple. Wear comfortable walking shoes and take a bottle of water. It can be hot here. Visit the Angkor National Museum in Siem Reap before your visit if you can to put the temple into a historical perspective.

Mystic beauty. The most mysterious of many in the Angkor comples. Being restored which can be frustrating but so great to see such an iconic temples being lovingly restored. Visistedby numrous monks hich adds to its allure and mystery and many can be found in quiet contemplation and happy to pose for a photograph - or even takeone of you the tourist!
Many things to see. Angkor Thom is composed of an ancient city and many temples just North of Angkor Wat. Amazing that over 1 million people lived here at about the time London contained 30 thousand.
one of the best and most mystifying of them all.. one of the best and most mystifying of all the temples. terrific design and so pleased they are trying to restore it, though it may take forever.
amazing!. Go there very early in the morning, otherwise it's a kind of Disneyland with hundreds of tourists (and not the good ones...)

The really Great City of Khmers.. You can easily spent a few solid hours walking, climbing stairs, admiring details and you are not likely to feel the flow of time. Good to read up a little bit before going unless you really have a reliably knowledgeable guide with a good command of English. Take a bottle of water, comfortable walking shoes and take a lot of pictures. The place is complex and can be overwhelming in a good sense so it is helpful to have lots of pictures to look back at. You cannot miss the Bayon temple with those legendary smiling, calm faces. It is the place to linger a bit and recall the movies which used it as a set. Baphuon is also grand. It is an exploration of its own and you get there through the causeway 200m long which gives everybody lots of photo opportunities. Do not miss the Terrace of Elephants used for viewing parades. Some day I want to go back with plenty of time and "loose myself" in Ankor Thom again.

Angkor Tom as in Indiana Jones. As I live in Thailand I come to visit Siem Reap many times. The small to town is changing fast. However the Temples keep to amaze me every time. Lot's of renovcations going on at Angkor Tom and the Giant Rubber Trees are still crunching the structures. Wonder for how long this can last. Doc Kaelin
Liked it better than Angkor Wat. Again, take water to carry. Nice walk around, beautiful ruins. Light some incense if you choose. Lovely pond for picture taking
Another must. There are so many sites to visit in Siem Reap, Angkor Thom is one you see when visiting Ankor Wat, a fascinating place

Angkor Thom is an area and not one specific temple.. Just so you are clear, Angkor Thom means "big city" which is true as it is 10sq kms in total.The main temple is called Bayon and famous for the towers with 4 faces on them. You could easily spend a whole day here alone.

Just Spectacular!. Can't be missed, the temple is beautiful, and the level of detail of the faces carved in the temple tower takes your breath away.Ensure you spend some time here, it can be crowed with people walking fast like in a mission of taking pictures. Just admire and immerse in what you are seeing you wont regret it !
Great start to Angkor. Went here as part of tour group. Guide was essential for context. Started here, then went to Angkor Wat. Less crowded and going from smaller to larger helped understanding.
Amazing temple. This site was also absolutely an outstanding place to visit. It was very impressive -- a photographer's delight!!
Fantastic temple. A great photographic opportunity it can be busy with tourist groups therefore go over lunch time if you can

Huge, beautiful area. Angkor Thom is a very big area with heaps of temples and terraces. You could probably spend a whole day just wandering around here. Some temples can't be entered, but they're just as amazing to look at from the outside. Definitely worth spending at least 1-2 hours here.
Here another temple. This temple is very big and surrounding by the big tree and I enjoy very much to see many thing here. Don't miss to have a look.

Worth a day to itself. Covering a huge area and incorporating the Bayon and Baphon, amongst a host of other sites, Angkor Thom is amazing. What it must have been like when it was a city of a million people!

Excellent day. This temple is part of the Angkor temple day tour , this really is a day not to miss if your in Siem reap.... If you have been to Cambodia and have not been to Angkor temples then you have not seen Cambodia,

What I imagined Angkor Wat to be. Ready to lose the crowd and the hustlers? Angkor Thom has some amazing sights and still has that 'jungle ruin' feel to it. You can wander around the edges and find amazing carvings and statues without running into other tourists, which was a refreshing change.
Worth Visiting. Similar to Anghor Wat and nearby. Also has alot of folks visiting along with plenty of vendors selling their wares
Lovely!. Lovely, as everything in Angkor Wat! Impressive, unusual and gorgeous! You can't miss it! one of the 'musts'

Beautiful. This is one of my favourite temples, along with Bayon and Angkor Wat. I recommend visiting the temples from sunrise at 5.30am so that you get to enjoy the temples before the tour buses arrive around 9am. You lose the serenity and majesty of the temples if there are too many people around. Going early also means you are free to do other activities later in the day.
Outstanding Ruins... I thought in some ways this was even greater than Angkor. not to be missed if you get to Cambodia.. Best months to go Nov. and Dec. It was hot in Oct.
Vast. We went just before dusk which was cooler and quieter, so more enjoyable but still light enough for decent photos.

Reminds me of Borobudur. Angkor Thom is quite possibly the highlight of the Angkor temples. It is huge, and the statues near the top are amazing. It reminded me of the Buddhist Borobudur in Java. It's a must-see.
Another must. Many places to see, and lots of details here and there. Hire a guide for this site, he will tell you lots of stories!
Another must see. Ok there's a lot of temples, but you really wouldn't want to come here and miss any of them. Every one is different and has it's own charms.
Nice. Nice and also big but we liked Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei most. Also nice was the national museum in Siem Reap to learn more about the history of the temples.
As Beautiful As Always. This was our second visit, the temple remain as beautiful as it always does. Amazing craving and well-maintained. You will get to see some smiling face over there.

What you expect to see in Angkor. So many images you have seen are from Angkor Thom rather than Angkor Wat. Easier walk, more sheltered and easier to walk around. I think it is better than Angkor Wat. Take your time, plenty of water and you will need some time to wander.

a whole city of temples. This is a walled city of temples. to make the most out of your trip it is really recommended to take a guide.You enter the city through the south guide and can visit several temples, the old royal complex and a number of terraces. The buildings are close together, so it is only a short walk through the woods - much nicer than being driven from one attraction to the next.

What a complex... Make Sure you visit the southern gate..a beautiful ancient city..don't be lazy and climb to to the top of the temples you won't regret it..some of climbs can be daunting but one has a hidden shrine where you pray if it's your thing and receive a blessing..amazing views..

Beautiful City. can you imagine being one of its million inhabitants? because i cannot, yet somehow wish I were... :-) what a breathtaking look at what man can accomplish. Make sure you check out the detailing of the Apsara (dancer carvings that are everywhere) at the Terrace of the Leper King, there are so many that are relatively freshly discovered and some are even really rough carvings leading researchers to believe that they were never really finished. It feels like you get to see history before it became history, but rather in the process of being made!
Awesome. Amazing experience to be transported back in time to marvel at this ancient wonder. You need to have an expert guide to really appreciate the history and get accurate facts.
Majestic stupas. Part of the Angkor complex. Well maintained. Beautiful carvings. Easy access. Vendor area separate. Amazing structures.
the face temple. Quite different from Angkor wat, this one has towers with smiling faces on 4 sides. There are less people during lunch time
Loved the stone work. really nice place, the faces are magical, hard to imagine that this is the kind of architecture that was built that long ago.

A test for your legs. Try to visit this temple as early as you can as it gets very hot quickly and it is a long and steep climb to the top. The steps are very steep and they will not allow children under 12 years of age to climb. You climb up one side and down the other. They have covered the worn and extremely narrow stone steps with wooden steps with metal rails, but these too are still steep and you have to keep going as you will create a traffic jam if you stop along the way to check the view or catch your breath. You cannot climb the last part to the top, but you still get a view from the topmost tier. If you have some of your party who have not done the climb get them to come around to the right hand side where they can either take your photograph coming down the steep steps or they can join you on the continued tour to other parts of the monument located beyond the main one. At the rear of the monument is a strange outcrop. There is an old photograph under a shelter that shows the outcrop in earlier times, where it clearly shows a face. It would have been a really large face.Generally, your driver or tuk tuk driver will have left you at the main gate and told you that he will collect you after you have walked past the Elephant Terrace. They are required to park near the trinket shops. There is a toilet hidden away behind the trinket shops.If you do not wish to visit the other parts of the temple you can walk along the top of the structure and have a great view of the 12 Suor Prat towers. No one seems to have any information about these towers but they are lovely to see.Along the top of the walk there are built out areas where the kings would sit and entertainers perform.

Amazed at the square stones making this up.. Saw this in the morning before Angkor Wat in the afternoon and was more impressed with this site, all those stones almost the same size built into this temple. Most stones have holes in them so they could be dragged from the mountains by elephants.
South gate of Angkor Thom. Please pay a sunset visit at South gate of Angkor Thom. A beautiful sightseeing which no much traveler knows.

Worth the extra trip. What makes Angkor Thom so special is the wonderful carvings which have been so well preserved. One worries that having so many tourists crawling over and touching so many of these will cause a more wear in the next 20 years, than the last 1000 years.

Huge area with much to see. We visited all the little temples in the centre of the complex. Wish had more time to see more of that area.The place is very wild in spite of its touristiness. That's part of the attraction though!

HUGE, amazing city. It really is a city, not just 1 temple, & is even more vast than Angkor Wat. You could probably spend the better part of a day just in this complex (including Bayon). We were here in the heat of the day, so it was a little overwhelming.Like all the other sites around Siem Reap, you're besieged at entry & exit by kids who want to sell you postcards, guidebooks, bracelets, etc. You can probably get the cheapest deals from them, but they should be in school, so save it for a shop in town.

Beautiful place. We rained out the first day, so went again the second day. That's how nice this place is! The temple is set in a beautiful landscape with the treeroots covering parts of the temple and it seems like time just stands still!
Our favourite. We arrived very early and were the only ones there with our guide. It was very special to have the place to ourselves to take photos etc.

2nd most visited site within Angkor. The larger palace site that houses Bayoun and Baphoum. go to visit during the afternoon when it is more empty... most of the tours will go here first then Angkor Wat in the PM, so plan for the opposite and avoid the crowds.
The exciting part. We reached there early by 8.30 so did not have too much waiting time to take photos at the best places. Since it was the first sight of our visit, it was even more amazing.

one of my favourite. Angkor Thom was the last and most enduring capital city of Khmer empire. We went there during wet season. But to the best of our luck, it was sunny all day long. There are elephants out of the south gate and you can ride on the elephant from the bridge of goods and evils, through the south gate to Bayon temple, terrace of elephants and etc. We did not tried, by the way.
Awsome. After we saw sunset at Angkor Wat we headed straight here. It was first on our list for good reason.
Big site! take a car or a tuk tuk. Beautiful main entrance from the south. Don't go through the Dead gate on the East if you are superstitious.

Very Huge. Angkor Thom is the widest area to go around. It is nice to ride a tuktuk when going back and forth to the different temples. It's nice also to take pictures all around for it has nice sights.
Fantastic. This was awesome! The ruins were spectacular and our guide was wonderful. He even pointed out some great spots for photos and took some for us as well.

Angkor Thom. It was unbelievable! the strucure was amazing! i can definitely feel the efforts that were exered by those who built it thousands of years ago. the temples are definitely fruits of dedication and hardwork and perseverance of a lt of amazing people
Temple. Learnt so much from our excellent guide. Need to wear sturdy shoes and visit as early as possible to avoid the crowds. Spectacular

Beautiful. Angkor Thom is were Bayon is. It's really big with the Terrace of Elephants, beautiful. The South gate is amazing with the 3 Buddha faces and the bridge with the good & evil, churning on the milk ocean. The whole place is amazing.

Please see our Bayon review. Oops I submitted the Angkor Thom review under Bayon. The same comments hold, skip the organized tour and book a personal trip to see this fabulous complex. Take the boat ride - it was great.
Elephant terrace+. Excellent site much to see do not miss smaller temple complexes on the site such as Phimeanakas; Leaper King lower terrace and Bauphuon..
good but not as good as angkor wat. our first temple we visited and it was amazing wlaking between the ruins and looking at the carvings
a wonder. visiting Angkor Thom transported me to the wonders of an old civilization and its legacy. Magnificent ruins, wonderful people.

The adventure starts here!. One of the adventures of visiting the temples of Angkor starts when you go through one of the 5 gates of Angkor Thom. Most people will go through the south gate first and chances are that there could be a lot of people there, so if you can, try to visit the Victory Gate also.It will help you to understand the temples inside the walls of Angkor Thom if you read up on them before you go. The best book to get is "Ancient Angkor" by Michael Freeman and Claude Jacques, and to also have a map of the area, so you don't miss anything. Don't wear your new white trainers around these place, because in the event of rain there will be mud. You can easily have something to eat/drink just outside the Elephant Terrace and there are also toilet facilities there.Tip for getting rid of locals pestering you: Pretend you can't speak English/French, if you don't have a language in commom with them, they can't talk to you.Don't understimate the amount of photos you will take around here, make sure you have enough memory in your camera.Best tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap is Mr. Rado (tuk-tuk number 5),he is outside the Tara Angkor Hotel every morning
wow!. A place full of good scenary and historical element, please do visit all this places when you go to Cambodia!
must be on your list to visit. same advice as other temples - water, photos, small notes and go in morning by tuk tuk, preferably the same one - they will wait for you and go anywhere on your list!
good temple. very good photos plenty o see lots of things to buy do some haggling its good fun and you will get some good bargins

Highlight of the trip!. We loved Siem Reap, and all of Angkor, and Angkor Thom still stands out as the highlight of the trip, above even Angkor Wat. It is a beautiful place, and you can picture life going on nearly a thousand years ago. Plan to spend some extra time here. Among all of the temples and ruins in the Angkor area, this is the only place that stands out as completely unique. Whether you arrive by tuk-tuk or bicycle (we strongly recommend an entire day on bicycle dedicated to Angkor Thom if you have the time), try to walk around the city on foot, and get a feel for the place.

Wow!. Angkor Thom is a huge temple complex, maybe even bigger than Angkor Wat. It is one of 16 temples included in a multi-day pass. Unless you're just passing through while changing planes at the airport, plan to spend 4-7 days in the Siem Reap area. Angkor Thom is a must-see attraction.

Has to be seen to be believed!. Although it was raining I wanted to see as much of Angkor as I could. I was not disappointed!Pictures, CD, others descriptions of Angkok Wat and Angkor Thom have to be seen to be believed. Take the time to see all of the details. They were carved after the stones were put in place. I cannot put into words the craftsmanship that was put into to the work on these temples.If you want to enhance your experience I would suggest an official tour guide. They have had to pass a knowledge test to be able to tour you around.The guide we had Mr. Sarun(Saroon) Peng is knowledgeable and personable.His email is chansarun@hotmail.com. He will enhance you experience in Angkor and other sites within Cambodia..The one day pass is $20 dollars USTake lots of $1,$5,$10 and $20 as they prefer US dollars. If you get any of the Cambodian currency leave it in your room. If you tip, several US dollars are acceptable.Do not give children who are begging money. It only encourages them to beg and not attend school. They may look cute but they can pick your pocket so be careful.To see all of Angkor you need a couple of days.I was there in the rainy season so there are less people. Bring some rain gear and an umbrella! Don't let the rain slow you down. Angkor is one of the must see sites if you love to travel.I will also point out that the level of English fluency amazed me in Cambodia.GO you won't be disappointed

Nice.. We enjoyed better other temples, but this is a must go to see the remains of a sort of "city", how all the temples build one next to the other. Also to see the faces in Bayon, but we liked much more other temples. A bike for this temple is an option, not that far, I'd say.

A lot to see. Angkor Thom merits a longer visit - it is a large area with many things to see. Luckily not that crowded. A guide is recommended for better understanding of the meaning of different elements

Look on it as well as Angkor Wat.. You can see Bayon, Khmer’s smile.The ruins are very large so go to see only what you would like to see.You’ll enjoy feeling great Cambodian ruins as well as Angkor Wat.

government officails. Not for the normal travelers, but we wanted more information on how the area was run and on who ran what, so we hired a translator and visited several government officials to ask questions.

heritage dat may b lost. angkor tom n angkor wat seems 2b in similar condition. most area still in quite good condition. but if left 2 nature this may not b so in future. good to see and marvel of bygone days...

Great place to see. The Angkor Thom Complex are really nice. I could spend 3 days wonder around the complex. Bayon is my favorite as the construction was amazing. Keep wondering how did they manage to create such a temple like this. It's a place you must visit once in your life.

The Many Faces of a Rich Culture. It was simply an amazing experience to actually see and know how the Khmer people value their culture and heritage. The Angkor Thom with many faces holding a giant snake is very symbolic situated at the gates of the temples.
Amazing. Amazing, again get a guide to explain the carvings. The scale of the thing takes your breath away. Maybe wear something a little sturdier than flip flops some of the steps are a bit steep.

Amazing. A great place to see. The infamous trees embedded into the temples are worth the visit alone. Such a beautiful place and quite atmospheric if you visit early (you'll also miss a lot of the crowds).

I love history.... Part of our temple tour was to visit Angkor Thom, and I am glad we went there on the first day of our tour because the next day, I was not feeling and cancelled all the remaining temple tours... The experience is so amazing...Do not forget to visit this temple!
A great start at Angkor. A friend suggested starting at Angkor Thom and our guide did too. It is great and sets the pace for the what follows.

Nice!. I did Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom on the same day. Personally, I think the Wat is must more impressive and well kept. But you must go through the Angkor Thom to understand the history, Especially pay particular attention to the wall carvings describing how the king fought off the Siam invaders.

WOW. Angkor Thom was our first stop as we toured Siem Reap. The grounds, buildings and attention to detail were amazing. The trees are a must see. There is absolutely no wonder why Angkor Thom is a World Heritage site. We spent about 3 hours wandering the grounds and temples. It was fairly easy to navigate the stairs and cobble stone like pathways. We toured in April and please note that it was extremely hot. Make sure you have a hat, sun screen, sunglasses and lots of water. Enjoy!

The overall Angkor temple experience. Angkor Thom consist of several archeological sites. Bayong temple, Baphuon and Phimeanakas are places we have visited. These were nicely renovated and good accessible. We were really impressed by Angkor Thom.

Magnificent. The causeway to the gate alone takes your breath away. I love looking at all those faces holding the body of the naga. You can see a face on top of the gate and wonder who he is.I was able to see Bayon, Phimeanakas, Terrace of the Leper King and Terrace of Elephants. I love the carvings on the terraces and I could imagine it as a stage for performances. I only saw the back of Phimeanakas but I was intrigued by the three layers/levels depicted by the place.
Don't miss this either!. Excellent architecture makes one wonder how much labour had been put into creating such masterpieces!

Angkor thom area is big and beautiful area. Angkor thom area is a big part of the small circuit of angkor.With Baphuon, Bayon, Royal palace, Phimeanakas, terrace of elephants and leper king, preah palilay and so on. Good for a 2 to 3 hour walk if you wanna see averything, and 1 hour walk if you wanna be quick and just take pics from the outside buildings. Dont skip Baphuon in this area. Go inside and climb al the way to the top for some nice views.

awesome!. You go throught the entrance at Angkor Wat and then you see the full glory of Angkor Thom which is very impressive,we spent quite a lot of time here looking at the carvings and stonework.We started at the outside enclosure and worked our way in ensuring we saw as much of the site as possible some people just go straight through the middle and miss so much. The climb to the top is very steep and coming down quite demanding so you have to concentrate hard.We just sat there for 20 mins watching the people and taking in the ambience of the temple, this is definatly one place not to be rushed.

Small but Beautiful. Angkor Thom is relatively small temple, but the interior design inside the temple is so awesome. I went to this temple in the morning, the sunlight inside the temple was so great. I loved to take pictures some alley inside the temple.

Temple at Harmony and in Conflict with Nature. This is what I first envisioned when I wanted to visit the Angkor Wat temples. Old buildings overgrown with Trees, filled with crumbling stone walls, tropical vegetation, green, earthy, damp. I actually prefer this site over Angkor Wat. Far less crowed than the main site, and I wish we had more time to spend here than we did. We only had about an hour, and as such, all we had time to do was march straight through the center with our guide and pick up our tuk-tuk on the other side. There are many opportunities to take photos, though they have guide ropes to shield some of the more popular sites from casual touching. As many others mentioned, Tomb Raider shot some scenes here, and is as impressive as fine of an example of any overgrown temple you will ever encounter in South East Asia. I spent five days in Cambodia, and this one short hour was easily the highlight of my entire trip. If I ever make it back, this will be one of the few locations I plan to revisit, albeit without a guide and a time limit to adhere to.NOTE: I would advise to be careful of what you choose to purchase when in the area. My guide informed us that the "disabled musicians" you encounter on either side are actually quite wealthy by Cambodian standards. Most own cars and good homes and have hired help to drive them around.
Bayon is cool. Personally aftef 2 hours in Wat and an nour at Bayon i found this a little samey. Its pretty and if you are in to temples and have plenty of time definately worth seeing
