Get to see the inner city as it once was. Most of infrastructure still intact and nice to get in and up close.In a few more years i think more will be sectioned off due to renovations.Amazing structure and culture as it once was.

Nice Complex. This is a very interesting complex, just small distance from Angkor Wat, plan to spend 4 hours visiting it. There is so much to see including the South and North Gates, Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Terrace of the Leper King and of the Elephants as well as Khleang.The combination of temple, nature, architecture, peace, makes this place an amazing place to visit.

Lara Croft loved it and so will you. This was the last temple we visited (as it's probably the furthest away from angkor wat) but my favourite. Yes there are huge groups of tourists taking a million pictures but the huge tree roots intertwining with the temples is so mystical and impressive. This is where Tomb Raider was filmed. Go see it, enjoy

favorite complex. huge place, get lost, wander around for afternoon/morning/evening... lots of temples, lots of amazing sights... Baphuon was a delightful surprise! The entire rear of the temple is carved into a reclining Buddha!

Just beautiful. The whole site is so large and complex it is hard to comprehend. It pays to spend more time and have multiple visits. Putting on your hiking shoes will pay dividends as it's really not that hard to get away from the madding throngs of tour buses (and that's in the low season). Don't think I'd bother coming here in high season!

Best Half-day in Angkor Thom. During my college days in architecture, our professor only talked about the magnificent ancient Angkor Wat in history classes. She did not mention anything about this much bigger complex and the remarkable temples on it. That is why when I did a research for my temple itinerary to Siem Reap, my excitement doubled when I realized aside from Angkor Wat, there are many many more to see. I never thought there’d be too many ancient temples in Cambodia. Half our day 1 we spent on Angkor Thom; the other half we spent for Angkor Wat and the petite circuit temples (Sra Srang, Banteay Kdei, Ta Prohm, Ta Keo & Thommanon – all completed in the morning). It would be ideal to start trekking the temples of Angkor Thom in the afternoon. Right after lunch, our tuktuk driver Sokha dropped us right in front of the Terrace of the Elephants. It was an easy stroll from this point to the Terrace of the Leper King, Phimeanakas, Baphuon, and ending the day with a blast at Bayon. These temples are located closely to each other so take your time. It will be extra exhausting if you’re in a hurry.Angkor Thom has a moat too but it has dried up, unlike Angkor Wat whose moat is still filled with water today has provided protection to the temple from encroachment by the jungle. That is why Angkor Wat is a well-preserved temple while Angkor Thom has plenty of vegetation and giant trees growing on ruins.
Excellent. Exceeded expectation, with the aid of a professional guide sourced through our hotel, a fascinating experience.

beautiful. A larger complex of stunning temples and beauty -- take it slow and easy to take it all in as this is a much larger area of numerous buildings -- however it is an unmissable part of the trip!
Stunning worth the visit. This was the last temple we visited on our Angkor temple runs but it was definitely worth the visit, it's really beautiful
Looks like an alien planet. This is such a unique temple because of the growth of the trees. And the restoration project looks very promising.
Buddha's galore. you approach the temple over a bridge with dozens of buddhas on each side, there are many statues of buddhas throughout the temple many with 4 sided buddha faces, lovely temple

Excellent historical place to visit. Angkor Thom is a large complex of many temples and housing complexes. However, only the temples remain since they were made of stone; the houses are long gone as they were built of wood. Angkor Thom includes Angkor Wat, which is the best preserved and largest set of temples. We spent just 1 day here; but many people spend several days. For me, 1 day was enough. The multiple complexes are of Hindu/Buddhist temples, and the cost of entry is $20pp for 1 day. Best to take a rickshaw/tuk-tuk for a whole day as they will shuttle you from temple complex to temple complex as they are a little distant and walking in the heat is no fun (I believe this cost us about $25 for the whole day, English speaking driver). Good idea to hire a guide (only licensed guides are allowed to act as guides; ours was arranged by our tuk-tuk driver for about $25 for the day. Both spoke good English. The best temples I found, were the Bauphon, Bayon, The tree temple (where tress have grown over the structures), and Angkor Wat of course, which is the climax, best preserved and huge in size.
A favorite!. Indeed this location was one of my favorites. The wok to arrive, and then the twisted and turning of the trees of centuries have created a fantasy like fairytale world.

my favourite complex. much to see here, they bayon temple, baphuon, the royal palace complex and terrace of the elephants all stunning. there are other smaller archeological finds on the same site often missed out, but well worth a look (be brave and push through the market sellers).... the carvings are amazing. The trees around baphuon are also really worth a look, reminiscent of Ta Prohm.
The Ancient Angkor Palace City. The Huge Bayon and Baphuon temples.. majestic elephant terraces... ruins of the king's palace and so on. You can spend weeks in this huge place.

Angkor Thom. Our guide suggested a great itinterary which we stuck to - including his suggestions of a lunch spot (yes, I know that he got a kick-back but thats OK!) We were very happy with his assistance and his local knowledge. The temple sites are incredible and we spent quite a bit of time just taking it all in.You need a good level of fitness to undertake the steps - but having said that you can certainly go at your own pace - dont let the steps put you off!

this is the whole area. This is the whole area where angkor wat is and you need a whole day to do the lot and if your really keen you can do 2 days but 1 day was plenty for us it really is an amazing place and only a short distance from siemreap.

Huge area.. This complex is less well preserved than Angkor Wat, but covers an area about 4 times larger. There is a lot of climbing to be done if you really want to have a good look at everything. Be prepared for screaming muscles the next day.
breathtaking. having a local guide is a must, they make sure you see the important sights, and make it very interesting ,without overloading you with too much information

Huge .... Beautiful temple. Wish we had more time to explore the temple, so coming back next month. Bring your own bottle as the weather could get very hot easily and at some parts of the temple was hard to find people selling water bottles.

Sensation. Angkor Thom is a monument right close to Angkor wat.
Bayon, which is at the center of it, was really impressive.
It’s super great that people built this so long time ago.

A huge complex to discover. Next time I will plan a bit more time for Angkor Thom as I did not have time to discover it all, it is that huge While Angkor Wat is quite compact in comparison, Angkor Thom is huge (mind you - the whole complex serves as capital city with 1 Mio inhabitants at a time when London was 40K inhabitants). So do bring time and do note that you will find a temple here, where sleeveless T-Shirts are NOT allowed. The only one in the whole complex BTW

Absolutely stunning. I have seen photos, but this was so amazing to actually see. The whole Angkor area is huge, but we were lucky enough to find a tuk tuk driver who spoke good English and took us around the main sites. We visited Angkor Thom first and it has to be the most impressive of all the Angkor monuments. I cannot recommend it more highly, but I would say to allow yourself plenty of time as there is so much to see.

9 square kilometres! amazing. This was the first stop on our second day. We were very glad we had not visited at the end of our first day when we were tired. From the moment you see the gate looming, you know that there is something special coming.

9 square kilometres! amazing. This was the first stop on our second day. We were very glad we had not visited at the end of our first day when we were tired. From the moment you see the gate looming, you know that there is something special coming.

Enduring tribute to the Khmer empire. Fantastic place - huge in size and concept. Make sure you read about it beforehand - guides can show you key places, buses and tuk-tuks within the Angkor complex facilitate travel between all the different temples on the Angkor complex. Also available are elephant rides, hot air balloons and helicopter flights apparently.
Spacious. We love this area, especially off the beaten track a bit there is some lovely quiet spaces where you can grab a drink & just listen to the quiet of the countryside. Very peaceful.

More authentic because it is less "renovated/rebuilt" than Angkor Wat. The faces of Angkor Thom are simply stunning and quite frankly located everywhere. I think Angkor Thom is my personal favorite in Siem Reap simply due to the authenticity of the ruins as compared to Angkor Wat. Don't confuse my words, I think Angkor Wat is absolutely stunning, but Thom shows its age through the decay of the building. I also don't recall any noticeable rebar (steel used to reinforce concrete) at Thom.Anyway, you obviously are not going to skip Angkor Wat, nor should you, but make sure to have enough time to do Angkor Thom properly as well. I say go when the heat is lowest, forget about morning or afternoon, just worry about shade and heat since you are completely exposed at Thom.

Better in Morning than Angkor Wat. Go for an elephant ride , take water and some snacks and small change for temple homage. Small nap sack is good idea Absolutely do not forget camera , water and sunscreen especially if you are fair .The forest here is superb and deserves three hours Go by tuk tuk not taxi and push bike folk looked overheated and exhausted - its a hot humid beautiful ancient place dress accordingly You wont be disappointed!

Probably the Best Attraction in Siem Reap. Between Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat, it's your choice which is the best, but Angkor Thom offers a little more personality. Get a tuk tuk driver, and also see the surrounding sites on the grounds. There are often festivities, visiting monks, etc.
very nice. one of the must visit temple..i was impressed and fascinated by the whole sculpture.who needs a certified engineer lol

More interesting than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom (and Ta Phrom temple) in my opinion was much more interesting to see than Angkor Wat, which is just a really big area. Angkor Thom and many nice larger structures, with fantastic carvings, including those large face carvings which you don't see at Angkor Wat. Must see if you're at the archaeological park.
Tomb Raider. This was amazing! Very different to any of the other temples, and if you're a fan of Tomb Raider, this is a must see.
A great place. One of my favourite temples, the gates as entry to the city are stunning and history of this place is well worth a read!

An amazing experience!. Please ensure you get a guide to take you around this amazing temple. Having someone that could explain the carvings, the history and the significant of this magnificent structure is an true once in a life time experience. There is almost a magic about this place that makes you want to become part of this building and its history.It is all absorbing and one of the most amazing experiences we have ever had. Make sure you take plenty of drinking water.

The arcs and the monkeys. Most if not all, temples in Angkor are dotted with archways and door frames. This architecture is truly amazing as we look from one door to the next, to the next, to the next, as if there is no end to the door frames. The monkeys provide a playful respite to our long walks.
My #1 Favorite. This place is AMAZING. I have taken so much pictures. I have a difficult time to describe how I feel about this BEAUTIFUL place. I would return here again one day.

Better than Angkor Wat. This is un unbelievable, surrealistic building. It is less preserved than Angkor Wat but we liked it because of its greatness, the splendid smiling faces, the bas-reliefs. A must-see if yo're in the area!

Translation - BIG CITY. The is the big city of Angkor and is home to the Bayon, Terrace of the Elephants, The Leper King Terrace and a host of other places. It's a big area of the Angkor complex so be prepared to walk a little between the places of interest. Is an absolute must see.

Big complex with multiple temples and palaces. This is the one of the famous site. Usually visited with Ta Prom, Bayon, and Ankor Wat. Be sure to bring sunscreen. Food and water are available all over the park.
Get a spare pair of feet if you can. Massive temple complex, very tiring on the feet but well worth the visit. Started off early in the morning at Angkor Wat and ended our temple hopping here.
Must see.. This would be the best of the WATS we visited. It must have been magnificent in it's day and was full of character.

a life long experience. The wonder of the decades of years where one can see the trees growing within the temple walls. It is really a place to admire the beauty of nature intertwined with the wonder of the temple. Again reiteration was done without losing the essence of the place

amazing. I chose to visit only 6 out of the hundreds existent in Siem Rep. This was one of them - and I do not regret it.
Do hire a guide, it makes a difference between understanding what you see and making guesses :-)

Miracle trees. Cool Trees growing on, along the stone walls. Nice details if you look closer. A must visit location. A lot of preservation work is on going. Do compare the before and after photos. How it actually look during its peak before being destroyed by the Khmer Rouge.

Family visit to Angkor Thom. We really enjoyed walking around Angkor Thom and took lots of photos and were intrigued by the background provided by our guide Sam. This is a most visit site for tourists visiting this park for the first time.
225 Faces of Buddha. Leart about the unbelievable foresight of King Jayavarman VII and his exploits and the sheer beauty of Angkor Thom, Merits a visit again

So much to see here. This is mainly a secular site but there is one temple where you won't be admitted if wearing shorts or a vest top. Take a guide book so you don't miss anything and allow a good 3hrs. Highlights are Bayon, the Elephant Terrace and Court of the Leper King.

Nature takes over. I really loved how the trees and the moss seem to be taking over all these structures. This was a great temple to see even if it wasn't in the movie Tomb Raider. The crowd was less and not. Many peddlers either. It was a short walk through but an amazing walk.

Great Complex with many places to visit. We did this temple as part of a full day with guide. Having a personal guide with transportation is absolutely worth the money. They know so much about these places that you would otherwise have to acquire before you visit.
Angkor Thom. These temples from centuries ago are to be seen and not to be missed when visiting Siem Reap. Each one a masterpeice.
The Best. One of the most interesting temple sites, a must see again! Take a guide and you will learn so much.

So much to see. Get your driver to drop you here for a few hours. There are a number of amazing temples to see, and some great walks through the jungle. A fair bit of variety amongst the temples too which keeps it interesting. Try to go early in the day when it's cooler as there is a fair bit of walking involved.

A must see. I thought this was great. So much to see, detail everywhere. The large faces are incredible. It is very busy though and getting certain shots can be pretty difficult, go as early as you can.I think a guide is a must also, there would have been so much we would have missed and a lot we wouldn't have understood. Our guide Mr Change was organised by our driver Alec who can be hired through Mr Kriss .
up there with Angkor Wat. This is an area of various temples with some lakes.Is best to get there late in the evening, no so busy.
great for photography too. I loved the giant faces at the gates and the fact that much is still a bit run down and not over-renovated
worth a visit. Not as much to see as Angkor Wat or Ta Prohm. All the drivers take you here for a look so why not visit.
Definite must-see. The 'Big City' comprises of the Bayon Temple as well as other sites and smaller temples. Spend at least half a day here.

Wonderful alternative to Angkor Wat. This temple holds it's own. Two words, Bayon Faces. Google it. Wonderful architecture, painstaking carvings and overall magnificence. Your trip to Cambodia will be lacking without seeing this place.As I mentioned in my Angkor Wat review, this is not place for kids, it's hot and full of tourists. Best to get a local guide to bring you for more intimate knowledge of the temple and, more importantly, the tour bus schedules to avoid.

I prefer this to Angkor Wat. My favourite group of temples, away from the big crowds of Angkor Wat. I recommend between half to a full day to explore Angkor Thom leisurely, going to each temple in turn. Climb to the top of each temple and sit chatting, while looking at the breathtaking scenery. Amazing!

The Gates Of Angkor Thom. Angkor Thom is another site to admire..with its various entrance gates. The entrance gate lined on either side with 54 Asuras on one side and 54 Devas on the other ..it was a sight to lo and behold. Truly a work of excellent craftsmanship.

Another Temple to see. Yet another temple to add to the list of those you must see,We also took a helicopter flight over all temples to give a difference view point - well recommend the cost to see from the sky.

Awesome. The scale is immense - recommend buying in the markets a copy of the BBC programme on ancient monuments as it explains who, how, why and when all the Angkor temples were built. Worthy of your time and of course photogenic.
Very nice. Angkor Thom was one of my favorite temples. It is an excellent thing to do.

Small but Impressive. Angkor Thom has earnt it's place amongst the regions temples. It has a very unique history, and the reliefs on the wall near the entrance still retain great detail as well as tell quite an interesting story. Like most temples in the area, it is in under-going some restoration works. That said, the areas/structures where work has been initiated reveal the true masonary craft possessed by it's original builders. No cement or other bonding agents were used - only gravity to hold each and every subsequent stone block in place, evem within the roof structures. Totally amazing.

Jungle and temples, a winning combination. Our favorite part was wandering between the temples. We rode elephants around and were blessed at the Buddhist pagoda. Wonderful. Spend time in a quiet spot "feeling" it.
Another Must Do!. A very imposing place! The structures are magnificent! Crowded this time of year and hot and humid!
Back in time. Driving through Angkor Thom in a tuktuk was just wonderful. We saw men riding elephants. Monkeys playing at the roadside. Huge buddha's and of course statues everywhere. Loved it.

Awesome. Thanks to my excellent guide Richard of www.aboutangkor.com for making this trip an awesome one. He is experienced & very knowledgeable, and speaks decent English, making a huge difference in our understanding of this landmark monument. Besides being a very good story teller, he also value-add in pointing out the best spot for photography, even stopping other tourists momentarily for us to capture the best shots.
Fantastic ruins. Go here in the afternoon when the warm sunshine gives a golden glow to the tree cladded gate. Its not far from Bayon so make sure you fit this in before that.

Not as good as expected. Maybe I expected too much but I found this to be a bit of a disappointment. It is very large and there is little information on site. Maybe we were just Wat'd out by this stage but we did Banteay Srei the next day and enjoyed that. I suppose you have to visit as it is the biggest site in Angkor.
Banyan temple the best. In my opinion is was simply the most beautiful temple. A must see and climb to the top to really appreciate the beauty and magnitude of this temple
Amazing. so very nice collection of temples. Although after a while they all look alike, but I would still see as many as one can!

Simply Great. Hard to explain why, but go there and you will agree!Get great views form the Buddha images from the left hand side (northern entrance).Around lunchtime go to the south entrance and see the elephants come through the royal access gate! Picture postcard quality!

Breathtaking. This place is simply fascinating, of all the main temples in the Angkor Wat area, I was most drawn to this one. I think I would be able to sit there for the whole day and just observe the smiling faces on the towers..

Nice surroundings but in reconstruction. I guess everybody will visit this temple since its so famous. This temple is good especially to run away from busy life around the other temples. T get to and from this temple you have to walk through short park which is very nice break. Unfortunately half of the temple is closed and under reconstruction.
Temple of labyrinths. Loved the labyrinth-like layout of this temple. A surprise around each corner and crevice.

Spectacular. This was my favourite due to the vast number of serenely-smiling faces. The scale of this place is mind-blowing - to carve one of these faces would have been a triumph, but there are a vast number of 4-sided towers, an enigmatic smile on each side. Awesome!

Another amazing place. The temples and sites around Angkor are some of the most impressive one could hope to see anywhere in the world. If you get a good tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap he will give you a tour and commentary as part of the day's hiring price.
Great view. I liked viewing the small temples with the big trees from the upper portion of the big temple.

Don't Miss It. Don't be fooled into thinking it's just another temple. Each wat is so unique. It is well worth hiring a temple guide if it is your first visit as their knowledge is immense and they will be able to explain the history of each temple.
Another Impressive Site. Get a good guide and really learn about this place. The history is great.

Repeat visitor, magical place. I was visiting Siem Reap over the weekend and decided to spend some quality time at the Bayon and Ta Phrom. This is my third visit and I see something new and amazing each time. Will be back in January for another visit. Definate "bucket list" destination.
walking down the thom. It is just amazing! loooook around you there are baby monkeys!
Great sight!!. All the temples are amazing to visit although my fave was definitley Angkor Wat.

Another must see temple. If you get to see a few temples, make sure that Angkor Thom is one of them. The smiling buddhas and the ruins in some of the areas are beautiful. Walking up to Angkor Thom is great, so much to see including elephants, monkeys and more. It's definitely worth adding this to your temple list, don't miss it.
Great site. Get a royal feeling walking on the Elephant terrace ! Bhapuan's restoration work is simply amazing!! hats off to all the workers for bringing back the marvel to its life!!
Stunning. The area beautifully maintained, and our only regret was not hiring a bycycle to cycle through this! Parks are beautiful, peaceful.
Gorgeous. I've said it all re Bayon already! Definitely wrth spending time here.
Worthy Second. The second most impressive of the lot. Intricate detail. Huge trees.
Loved the elephant terrace and the smiling faces temple. Awe inspiring.... Temple hopping is just amazing ... This place is addictive... You can't stop at just one... There are so any. Great temples

Huge. Faces, faces famous faces, lots of stairs, really big, do not wear flip flops! Nice light in the early morning for photography. Some guides give way too much information. I would have rather been alone. But really good temple, top three. Lots of tourists doing the nose to nose shot.
Unbelievable what they built. Very interesting, lots of walking and steps. Would suggest go with a guide as there is so much to learn and without a guide you would have no idea.

Pretending to be Lara Croft. If you want to see the ruins where Tomb Raider was filled then this is the spot. It is breathtaking to see how the natural environment has taken over the manmade environment.
Beautiful. This is another amazing site .. Take an organised tour of the temples.. It is worth the money to get expert cometary and to learn the history ,,
Fabulous. This is probably 1 of my favourite temples and was a fantastic experience. Lived it.
WOW!. I'd come back to this place again... it's very near Angkot Wat!

Really nice!. We were In SR when it was really hot. So I would recommend you take your time when you you are in the city. Visiting in the early morning would be the best option as there is a lot to see near Angkor Thom as well. I loved the work of the monument and makes really interesting pictures. One of the guards there suggested where I should stand for the best pictures :D A must see while in SR!

A part of the Angkor Temples. We factored this temple in our 4 day trip to Siem Reap. Our Cambodian guide Sophana Yous who was found on Tripadvisor was a local and someone who had a love for his country and its most amazing temples. This temple is not to be missed.

basics half day - all a few days. if you want to visit basic temples like bayon and elephant terrace, you can do it in half day. But if you want to visit all it might take a few days. Rainy days/wet season might sound bad at first but think of it as a good opportunity of taking pictures without any other tourist. when it is sunny, everywhere is full of tourist and it is difficult take a picture without the head or feet of someone else.

great experience. Angkor Thom is one of the most famous remains in SR.I went here and Angkor Wat.But I prefer here to Angkor wat.The statue gave us a kind smile.We were overwhelmed by their power.You can get on a elephant and go around here.Thats great experience.

Impressive. The further you proceed the more impressive it gets.It can represent quite a long walk after visiting Angkor Wat. Stairs may be quite steep as well and strenuous in the end. Do take breaks frequently and admire the site.
Tomb Raider. All the ruins associated with this ancient culture are truly amazing.
Interesting. Same same but different. Anyone who has been to Asia knows what I mean.
Ancient ruins.... and a plethora of temples to visit in this area, all worthy of your visit.

If you visit cambodia you need to see this place.. This is awesome, breathtaking we enjoyed every single minute in this place, you can just go around or spend hours looking at all the small engraving in the stone. Get a good guide for the visit to get the best out of this place.

House of Bayon. Angkor Thom houses Bayon. The gates and walls to Angkor Thom keep you out only because they are so intricately carved and decorated. Once inside you get a sense of how the city must have once felt. The wooden buildings have since disappeared but the remaining stone structures are more than enough to give you an idea of how everything must have been decorated. The place is massive, we had our driver drop us at one end and pick us up at the other, which was a great idea. Be sure to give yourself some time to take in some pictures and the experience of Angkor Thom.

Less touristy. More natural/less touristy, than the other temples. Just loved the trees climbing through the ruins. Cover your legs girls....I couldn't climb to the top 'cause I had shorts on; even though I'd asked at the hotel in the morning if it was okay that I wore them
Amazing. It was amazing how big this place is - our guide told us that back in it's time, there were 1 million people living within the walls. Incredible! Go with a guide - really worth it.

Part of the Angkor Wat tour. It is part of the package. The story links and you just have to go. DO NOT buy anything from the touting kids. You will just be encouraging them to not go to school to continue such life.

Experience of a lifetime. The beautiful grounds of Angkor Thom were amazing. Well worth the $20 fee for the day to visit all of them. Don't forget to bring covering to make sure that you can enter the sacred temples. I made do with a long sleeve Cheesecloth shirt and a sarong to cover my shorts
Great experience. It was a wonder experience to be able to experience a magical place and the history of it.

A MUST TO SEE. Like the rest of the temples it is amazing.Sometimes you are molested by the local people selling thier wares but anyway it one could understand that
Like the rest of the temples it is amazing

Big city. Angkor Thom was quite a big city although only the stone buildings remain; during the centuries, all the buildings made of wood (houses) have gone. Bayon is the largest temple within Angkor Thom and there are a number of other interesting, smaller temples as well as beautiful terraces full of bas reliefs. Like Bayon, the city gates have mysterious face carvings. Impressive!
Worth a visit. Don't just head for Angkor Wat...take a tour guide who will take you to the best areas and explain everything.

Spot the Smiling Buddha. Of all the temples I visited, I love Angkor Thom the most. When view from far, all you could see was lots of stones made into tower but upon climbing up to the third level, you could notice the four faced buddhas smiling down on you.
Lots to see. If you only have time for a few temples, Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Bayon are the ones to see!
Another must do in SR. Its authenticity is stunning. Hopefully tourists are managed well and these places are kept true to their history.
A great city. Angkor Thom is the bigest city of the complex. It has may temples inside. Might be even enough for one day.

It is enormous. I had only heard about Angkor Wat and not Angkor Thom so to see that it is even bigger than Angkor Wat was unbelievable. It is a magnificent area with so much to see - how could it be built and last over 1,000 years? They are doing a great job in restoring areas of the city but they have a long way to go. Keep up the good work.
Great city. Amazing place. Second best to Angkor wat. Loved watching the elephants enter through the gates.

Big day out. Walk Walk Walk is the key here and sweat sweat sweat i do dislike that the buddist's sit in the top/centre towers and as soon as you walk in they will hit you up for a donation or the the little guy who starts talking then walks with you even after you say no still hit you up for a tip
Amzing and so greatly preserved. This was one magnificent place and something not to miss in your visit. Words can't describe it. you must see to believe yourself.

roots and Ruins. It pays to get here either very early or at lunch time when all the tour buses have gone for lunch. We bought some water here which we think had been rebottled and resulted in 2 of us being very sick the next day. we saw lots of kids collecting used water bottles but didn't realise why until it was too late, so my advice would be to take your water from your hotel or purchased in town and crush your bottled when you have finished to avoid them being refilled.
this was my favourite temple- even over Ankor What. This was a beautiful temple that you can walk all the way through, it has beautiful enormous pillars of 4 faced buddahs. I loved it.
Getting lost... Easy to loose track of time, getting around this premises. The beauty of nature bringing a new meaning to the word beauty.. Don't miss out!

The great city. Angkor Thom aka Great City. This place is HUGE. It's built after Angkor Wat. So now there were some temples in it's ground like the Bayon Temple that had Hindu-Buddhist influence. Here Bayon Temple is a must visit.

Go to the East Gate. Angkor Thom is massive and contains several other temples including Bayon, Baphuon and the Elephant Terrace. Most people will enter through the south or north gates which are spectacular but very crowded with tourists and market sellers. Go to the east gate which is just as spectacular but deserted.

Wow!. Angkor Thom means great city and was covers an area of 9 sq kms. It is a near perfect square, surrounded by a wall and protected by a moat. Enter the site through the South Gate which is the best restored and which is flanked by a moat with statues of 54 gods on the right and 54 demons on the left is most busy but offers the best photo ops. Within Angkor Thom lies Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Terrace of the Leper Kings and Terrace of the Elephants which is among the most popular sites and features to visit. Be ready to climb and climb and sweat!
True jungle experience. Old temple, massive statues...all in a state of being taken over by a voracious forest
Another great ruin within Angkor Archeological park..... Well worth a visit when in Siem Reap ... All part of the Angkor Archeological park and an amazing experience ..
Another Awesome Angkor. Hire a guideGo in the morningWear a hat, bring waterIf you want the "whole meal deal" be prepared to climb steep ladders. The journey is worth it.
Spectacular. Most striking feature are the carved faces in the rock but a truly awesome site. Feel the history and majesty around you...don't miss it when in Siem Reap
So huge. If you want to enjoy this place completely,at least 3days ticket is requred.

Bayon temples. This was our first temple stop. Be amazed at the numerous stone cold faces staring down at you depicting Jayavarman 7. This complex takes half day to tour. It is best to get a guide to understand the bas reliefs, but you could probably get by by reading a guide book before heading to the temple. Bring water and do not forget to put on sunscreen.
Wonderful. must be visited - take a tuk tuk to visit all of the temples in the area - that way you'll see much much more

Beautiful. Gigantic. Set aside a whole day for this.. NOTE: You will need to buy entry passes to visit ALL the temples in Siem Reap. These can be purchased from a central point (near Angkor Wat) and will be personal to holder (they'll take your picture for the pass and all passes are non-transferable.) Passes cost USD20/day, $40/3days or $60/7days. Expensive, but well worth the money.---------------Angkor Thom actually consists of several temples, all housed within a maaaaaassively walled "city". We were told that sunset at Angkor Thom is beautiful, so we had arranged to start exploring Angkor Thom after lunch up until sunset. BIG mistake. I don't know if it was just the timing of the weather in May, but it was too hot and muggy to thoroughly explore all the temples within Angkor Thom from 3-7pm. The heat really gets to you. I'd recommend you take a sunRISE at the temples instead, hang about and explore in the morning when it is cool, then leave when the day starts to get *really* hot and sensibly rest in your hotel until dark makes Siem Reap cool(er) again!Highlights for Angkor Thom, tho: Bayon temple, Baphuon, Terrace of the Leper King. If you can't find the will to see anything else in Angkor Thom, these three are worth the trouble. Bayon is where you'll find magnificent towers of faces carved into the four cardinal points. Mind-blowingly awesome.At Baphuon, you'll be able to climb right up to the highest terrace for stunning views over the whole of Angkor Thom. What I found most amazing was that only then did I get the full appreciation of how grand the Ancient Khmer civilization must have been in its hey-day. Be warned, though, that climbing up the terraces is not for the faint-hearted. The ladders are STEEP and pretty high. There is also close to no shade when you're up there on the terraces, so having a hat, umbrella and water are pretty essential if you're planning to (unwisely) make that climb in the middle of the afternoon, like we did.The Terrace of the Leper King are walls and walls some 20 ft tall, full of beautiful carvings. I forget what the murals were supposed to depict, but it was quite enjoyable walking along the maze-like corridors between the terraces and just looking at the carvings. EXTRA note: The guidebooks that hawkers will try to sell you? I usually give buying tourist faff a miss, but some of the books are actually pretty good. You can get them for as low as USD1, although some hawkers will try to sell them to you for USD60. I'd pay anywhere from USD5-10 per book. An average Khmer's meal will cost approximately $2 (6,000-8,000KHR), so I figure giving them a price of a day's meals in exchange for a book is pretty fair.
beautiful. such a beautiful peaceful place.even the gates to this place are stunning
Sunset. We visited at sunset & was a perfect beginning to the entire Wat temples & was not too crowded.
Gods and demons. The carved faces are fabulous. Walk along the outer walls to get a sense of the scale.

The gate to the past. Entering the gate of Angkor Thom from the victory gate just like entering the gate to the past when the kingdom still alive and the warrior arrived from the war and won the war. This site has 5 gates on each direction plus one as victory gate. Getting around her is easy, get the tuk tuk and will take you to any place you want.
A sight to behold. The entire complex took half the day to complete, but well worth it. Stunning.

One day's not enough. The vast area with tons to discover make one day not enough. Wish I have three days to just grasp more of the place. It was good that we went to the Siem Reap National Museum first so that we have at least a little idea of the history behind the stones.

Another beautiful temple.... We thought that we would be tired of seeing temples by the time we make it to Angkor Thom (it was literally 100F out, afterall) but Angkor Thom was quite unique! We are happy that we decided to visit-

Do not miss!. We loved Angkor Thom and have about a million photos to prove it. Do not skimp on Angkor as you head round Cambodia / Vietnam / Thailand. Most people seem to be here for 3-4 days. Treat that as a minimum and give yourself time to explore this amazing complex of temples. The gorgeous sculptures, the heady heights of the temples, the mixture of restoration and ruin - this is an amazing place. The half-ruined temples are my favourites,at the mercy of trees and strangler figs, it feels like you are in the middle on a slow but intensely fought battle. I have wanted to come here for many years and so often, the places you long to visit don't quite deliver. Angkor Thom delivered.

Worth a whole day. We couldn't guess how we could handle four temples in four days. Even with the heat (95 F.) it was easy and Angkor Thom was the best. 600 meters of detailed bas relief sculpture showing war, peace, heaven, earth, kings, priests and, most fascinating, everyday life a thousand years ago. Our official guide was great, knowledgable and enthusiastic (but he doesn't want us to give his name; he says he has enough business). It wouldn't have been as interesting without a guide. We've always been amazed by Anasazi petroglyphs in the southwest U.S., about the same era, but there's no comparison: ours are graffiti; the Khmer did art.

The hollywood temple!. Try to see this temple due to the interest given by the film and the fact that the roots of the surrounding trees are intertwined with the stone. A smaller temple which is a fascinating 10 min drive by tuk tuk from Angkor Wat.

unbelievable. now this is a site must see! i thought angkor wat was going to be the best but this place takes the cake. bayon was my favourite the faces of the buddhas and the architecture was breathtaking. i cant describe how amazing this place is it just has to be seen to be believed. much better more to see and more detail then the other cities around the area. AWESOME
Opinion: Better than Angkor Wat. Really enjoyed this location, much to see, much bigger than Angkor Wat, with lots of statutes that are more intact, don't miss it.

Best temple in Cambodia!. Of all the temples I've visited during my Cambodian trip, this was the best! It's full of relics and stories and it was soooo interesting.
I know with so many temples you must be confused, which one to visit, but this is a must see temple to put on your list.
Loved it. Take your time, drink lots of water and enjoy strolling around.
An awesome reminder if previous times. Not as big as Ankor Wat but impressive all the same... massive trees had grown through the ruins .. our guide made the experience even better
Trees en birds. The trees growing over, under and through this place are amazing and the sound of the Bee Eaters flying around made it even a more lovely place to walk around.
Walk among history. I love the temples and how they have been marvellously preserved. Its like walking during the time these majestic structures were built.
Great temple. Visited in April and it was so hot. But the temple was amazing and worth the visit.
Amazing location WOW Factor. A must see, you wont regret it. Historically important , stunning scenery, a real wonder

Take a map. The complex is beautiful and gives a good impression of life way back. It's a large area and the signs are not always very clear. So if you don't have a guide, make sure you bring a clear map.

Angkor Thom my favourite. Angkor Thom is my favorite of all the temples it houses several smaller temples that are located in the center and close together and I found it amazing to see so many temples in such a small areaA moat surrounds this temple but it is not as full as the one at Angkor Wat Angkor Thom h as 5 elaborate gates each side there is also a huge sculpture at the entrance the south gate which most tourists pass through is north of Siem ReapSeeing how nature has slowly taken back this area is amazing and a perfect picture opportunity with the great roots of the trees extending over the top and down the sides of some of the buildingsMany of the passageways are crumbling and the faces on the towers are like those of Bayon

Impressive. What to say about something that you will see if or if and so much traveling. Without words, Bizarre, mystical and beautiful, Also here you have out, the "small" program should not miss Angkor Thom. Once again it appears that we underestimated the extent of actually slightly Angkor Thom is somewhat larger than the well-known Angkor Wat. Phimeanakas already holds in the long, if you climb the steep stairs to the top and be rewarded with a magnificent view over the jungle all around wird.Überall discover countless other buildings and ruins in the forest! But since there are still the great "elephant town" and the "Terrace of the Leper King," the lure of beautiful sculptures and reliefs! Good to know that at the upper end of a facility with toilets, just a few souvenir shops and refreshment stalls. Nice sweat before going to the Bayon then to finish off the program! Here also a small temple is open with a large golden Buddha statue.
another beautiful site.. lots of tree roots growing on temple ruins...lots of walking with beautiful trees around you...all the temples are worth seeing!
Ruins of Historical Marvel. Too bad this is mostly in Ruins but It adds to the colorful History of Cambodia.
Wonderful. Got to see all the temples and they were amazing.....a lot of walking up stairs and uneven rock.
Worth the visit. Not as crowded as Angkor Wat. Stay away in the middle of the day because of the heat!
Beautiful. About 7 temples to see. All different and beautiful. Get ready to do lots of walking and climbing!
Beautiful and amazing. The whole area with angkor wat and angkor thom and many of the other temples is so amazing a must see turist attraction for travelers to siem rap cambodia
must see. everything about it the renovations that are being carried out were extensive but not intrusive

Better than the movies!. This temple has been in a few great movies but actually being under those massive tree roots and touching the ancient stones has a feeling that transports you back in time. Lots of tourists so go early or late to enjoy the site more.
Went twice- loved it. Went twice. Once for the sunset and one for the temple. I loved this one.
Amazing place. Do it very early! It gets too hot by 11am! We were back at the hotel swimming and having a beer by then!!
HUGE. The Angkor Thom complex took almost a whole day to explore - so much to see!
Charming. Loved this site. Though smaller than ankor wat the jungle trees here intertwined with the ruins adds a level of charm

Another fab site to visit. Again, another amazing piece of history and atmosphere. Take your time to take this all in. Would recommend the book Ancient Angkor sold at all the temples for about $7. It must have been a quiet time because I managed to negotiate a purchase for $3 (though he did call me a mean tourist!!!)
So many temples!!!. Make sure and see as many of these temples that you can. Angkor Thom is a huge complex so pace yourself. I really enjoyed Bayon and the Elephant terrace/wall. :)

Well preserve and a stand out!. This place is amazing and well preserved in my view. One of the highlights in my Cambodian trip. I was glad i hired a tuk tuk and driver for the day as many templates are far from each other. With the heat and humidity would of been a killer. Great photo opportunity if you arrive in the morning or later in the afternoon.

Great at sunset. This was my favorite site to visit right from the monkeys that you can feed on the way in, the huge impressive gates, bayon, the terraces and our amazing guide Ratanak Eath suggested that we stay here for sunset instead of going with the crowd to angkor wat, we had the place entirely to ourselves and got the most beautiful sunset. People at angkor on the same day said it was average due to all the tourists trying to get the perfect photo.

Nature and man. It is remarkable how nature will take back. Nothing mankind can build will be around when we are long gone. Nature will slowly make things right again. This is what I find the most interesting part on how such great stone structures succumb overtime. Massive trees with roots take centuries to work their magic, but in the end, without restoration and mans assistance, things would eventually return to what was before.

My Favourite. Be prepared and learn to say No thank you in Khmer as there is a lot of pressure at the entrances to buy scarfs and odds and ends from children. Hold steong and give your donations to NGO's where your donation will be better spent to give Cambodians a better future. Angor Thom itself is amazing and if you are really into your photography, allow a lot of time to get those early morning or late afternoon shots

Eight Ancient Wonder!!. If the Eighth Ancient Wonder of the World had an address...Angkor Wat would be it!! Be sure to wake your booty up at 4:30 AM for a sunrise entrance to the park. You body may not appreciate the first call reveille, but your memories & photo album will be rewarded for life!!!After Angkor Wat....head over to Angkor Thom for ruins that have not had all the benefits of restoration.

fascinating--not to be missed. These temple ruins sit in a very large area containing some smaller temples and surrounded by a defensive wall and moat. The engineering and the sculpture work that went into this enormous temple is quite astounding. Budget to spend at least 2 hours to take this place in
Do not forget this one. so different and so wonderful, words are not efficient enough for sharing our feelings
man vs nature. Amazing the structure has stood for soon long in the jungle. Massive trees mixed in with amazing structures. A definite wonder of the world.

Take the time - it's worth it. If you can, go early in the morning via tuk tuk before the heat and the crowds, and just take your time to wander around, particularly the Terrace of the Elephants, which is very special. Once the tour buses come in, the whole experience changes.
Much bigger than I expected.. Apart from bayon with the huge carved heads , the elephant terrace is wonderful with friezes and 3D elephant carvings on the corners.
Roots. See how the trees & the temple bind together in harmony . Its fluid vividly.

WATCH OUT FOR ELEPHANTS. Again part of the best Siam Reep has to be we ll worth the visit and a tour through the local craft sellers is a great experience of Cambodian life and very important to them too.
Another temple must see. Preferred this to Angkor as less people, but still worthwhile.

Out of this world. The climb up the stairs to the temple at the top is very precarious. We did it, but on reflection was really foolhardy. The original stairs have not been looked after, and very high and risky climb. Although the experience at the top is trmemdous. Suggest the tousirm ministry consider building a new staircase for access to visitors, like they have done at Tikal in guatemala

Angkor Wat's bigger neighbour.. Even more complicated that the "Wat" - it's hard work and greatly rewarding to absorb it all - again, it's the good guide that makes the difference. Oh, and hang on to your water bottles - the macaque monkeys will nick them out of your hands, rip the tops off and then sit in front of you and drink. What an added piece of fun!
Tranquility. Loved Angkor Thom preferred visiting this site to Angkor. The elephants walking atround made this soecuail

Definitely worth seeing. Another fascinating temple /royal palace complex to wonder around and definitely worth putting on your temple list. The Bayon temple, Elephant and Leper terrace are found here.We would thoroughly recommend seeing this complex with a private guide, so you get the full story of palace and temples and don't miss the beautiful carvings and what they all mean.Part of the main temple in the Royal Palace is still worshipped in so make sure you wear a long skirt, pants and no tank tops or you cannot go up to the top shrine.We visited in the late afternoon, and it was very pleasant to be among the trees and out of the sun and gave the complex a peaceful yet powerful atmosphere.
Also stunning!. You can't really go wrong with any of the sites around here, just take plenty of water and a good tour guide who knows the place inside out!
Just Awesome. Everything - the tree roots - the jumble of masonry
Beautiful temple. It just felt lovely, serene and gentle. Of all of the places visited in Siem Reap, this is the one I'd go back to visit again.
even the trees respect the temple. another amazing temple which is in sympatico with the temple. the tree roots grow around the walls, creating the most amazing sights
As good as Angkor Wat. We found Angkor Thom to be a great place to see and just as good a time as visiting Angkor Wat.

Must tick this off from your bucket list. There are no words to describe it. You have to go and see it at one point in your life. My boyfriend and I were discussing how lucky we are to have been given the opportunity to go there at this time in our lives when we're at the peak of our physical strength. You must explore the whole complex if you can. Was there in April, heat was oppressive and I'm from a tropical country, I wonder how it must be for those who are not used to it. Will bring a bike next time and slap on gallons of sunblock. :)Suggestions: Research best times during the year to go, otherwise, go early in the morning

Worth visiting, very different to Angkor Wat on close inspection. A smaller place yet still with unique and interesting detail. Like Angkor Thom and all the other places here, take a guide with you and plenty of water.
Another temple at Angkor Wat. I honestly forget if it was this one or the Bayon Temple that had the large trees growing inside of the ruins. Whichever one it was it was awesome
Worth the visit. These temples are well worth the visit and do live up to expectations.
Another great temple. This one was not as popular a destination but worth seeing nontheless.
Must see. Great, if your going to go to Angkor wat you should definitely try see them all!

Better than the rest... but everyone knows it. It used to be the standout part of the whole experience but it is now cramped full of tourists and forget managing that 'superb, mystical photograph' that you see in hotels. The view will be blocked by hundreds of Japanese and Korean tourists ignoring the gentle request of "excuse me please"
well worth the visit. Very nice if you have the time to see a few of the temples
The Best of All. This site was our favourite. Absolutely astonishing!
nice temple. I will recommend my friend came , Angkor thom have many area inside Bayon is the good temple I love this temple very nice .

History lovers heaven!. As with the rest of the Angkor complex, this si a must see before it is all fenced away from the thousands of feet that will, inevitably, see it become a "view from a distance" wonder. Although parts of it are now being fenced off for structural work, it is a must visit for anyone visiting Cambodia
Amazing. Beautiful architecture, it is an amazing site to see. Definitely worth the visit.
Interesting. You will need your imagination for this but do so after you visit the surrounding areas; won't be any problem after you do.
Better than Angkor Wat. Less intense that A-W but allow more time in this area as there is so much to see. Take a spare battery for your Camera/phone as you will want to take many pictures.

There's a lot to take in. We visited Angkor Thom on a different day to Angkor Wat and would advise others to do the same. There is so much to see that can not be appreciated or remebered in one day. Eventually everything blurs into one if you don't take time to soak it up. Take it slowly and savour the experience, it worth spending lots of time here.

Lots if interesting temples here. Lots of temples & things to see in this complex, do an elephant ride, it's different & cool, $15 pp which is expensive for Cambodian standards but the elephants are well looked after. You will need to wear a shirt with your shoulders covered to enter Angkor thom, a scarf won't be enough to cover your shoulders. Thus is the same for men & women.
Almost better the Angkor Wat. This site has a very distinct feeling to that of Angkor Wat. They are both do-able in one day.
Another astonding asset to historically sites. This was a fantastic place with a place that must be visited. Angelina Jolie was so right about Cambodia and how wonderful the place and people are.
Fantastic. Another amazing temple, that will not disappoint, everyone should go

So incredible. If you are reading this you are probably thinking of visiting, all i can say is come and have a look, stay at the Golden Mango in Siem Reap and hire a tuk tuk and driver for a day cost $15. Nothing I can write can tell you how amzing this place is
Great to see. This is one of the sites that one must see if you are in Angkor
Tomb Raider.....yes really. Brilliant, again try an avoid peak times, very early morning, lunch time (while everyone else is forced to have lunch) or evening

Huge and tons of fun and variety!. I did this on the same 14-hour day as Angkor Wat, but probably should have spent a entire day exporting Bayon and all the other mind-blowingly beautiful sites within. Bayon is the true star of the place.

Huge. A very large city. We did not do it justice but it was enjoyable wandering the Terrace of the Leper King , Elephant Terrance and the Baphuon. It was a shady walk once you got off the main road and few tourists until you reach the Bayon.

Forget the Tombraider Stuff.... If you are visiting this site jsut for the Tombraider setting then, you will miss much of the beauty :) The roots growing over this temple complex are so interesting! They are massive and all intertwined... Truly awesome!There are massive sculptures here that are seriously impressive! Take a guide bookw ith you and get a little bit of the history. If you limit your trip to only a few spots then, don't miss this one!

Incredible. Lots to see, lots of photo opportunities and one of the highlights of our trip to the temples. Breathtaking experience, however, like all of the main temples, visit when the tour groups have moved on.

My favorite site in Angkor area. This was an absolutely amazing and beautiful location. It is a walled and moated Royal City. All the temple buildings and the main gates had giant Buddha heads built into them, making for stunning views. It was truly breathtaking. IN addition, the bas-relief carvings along the terrace walls were unique and arresting, with huge panoramas of elephants or other figures stretching the length of the walls. Do not miss this site for any reason. I actually preferred it to Angkor Watt, though both were beautiful and both should be seen.
Full Day. Start early as this complex is big and to avoid the tours and the heat, hire a tuk tuk for the day at $15 or it will be to much walking between sites
Not as crowded as Angkor Wat. This area was more spread out so seemed more serene. Also stunning architecture - you can easily do Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat in one day.

Beautiful ancient city. HUGE city complex and the longest running Khmer capital, just behind Angkor Wat. The real beauty of this place is the architectural differences between temples just a few kilometers farther; some with the influence of Buddhism, some others with the influence of Hinduism, a few with both. Huge structures that will blow your mind. This is just as important, if not even more, of an attraction as Angkor Wat.
unique, captivating. This was one of my favorites. I loved the faces. I'm into photography and took some great photos here. A little crowded but that's expected at a world heritage site.
The 54 tower is represent the 54 province of Cambodia. I like this temple that talking the story in the pass. i dont like they show alot of ware.
worth it. Our guide brought us right to the best parts! Worth it in the late afternoon!
Great must see site. Great site - best part of Angkor Wat complex. A lot to see and some great photo opportunities.

This is one of my favorites. The Bayon temple is a Buddhist temple with 54 towers & 200 faces of Buddha, and is one of my favorites. The many faces, some with half open eyes & others full open eyes is interesting and intriguing at the same time. When you're here, it invokes a happy feeling.
lovely to walk around. its a great walk around the different sights, and you can feel like you are the only person in the whole place - great to escape the crowds

bayon and terrace of the leper king were my favorites. We entered Angkor Thom, which means “great city", through the southern gate and stopped there to take a few photos. In front of the southern gate, there are 54 giant statues of gods to the left and 54 demon statues to the right. Once inside, we first stopped at Bayon, which was probably my favorite temple of the day. It stands at the exact center of Angkor Thom and features 216 faces carved into stone.We visited a few other small temples in and around Angkor Thom, but the only one that really struck my fancy was the Terrace of the Leper King. Here you can access a hidden terrace where the carvings look newer than others as they were covered up for centuries.For more info and photos, check out my blog post at http://growninsouthernground.wordpress.com/2012/03/22/siem-reap-day-1-angkor-wat-angkor-thom-ta-prohm-apsara-dance-performance/.
All The Temples Are Good. Its a nice temple, didn't stand out hugely for me but worth visiting.
Amazing. Amazing area, too big to explore in a day if you really like your temples. Take a heap of water with you....

Glimpse into the genius of the past. I think one of the most incredible things about all the ruins in Siem Reap is that it allows is to take a glimpse in the epic history of empires that were capable of these architectural feats. These statues, carving, and buildings makes you feel diminutive in comparison to these monuments and the people behind them...the history...the life...the death...the beauty.
Angkor Thom. More accessable than Angkor Wat with an amazing amount of details carved in stone. Incredible location!
one. take a plnty photos, take tuktut/12 dol full day/ and visit teple one by one
more beautiful than angkor wat. A wider area to wander around and explore, classic temple ruins.
A wonderful site. The many-faced temple is one of a kind. One thing I can definitely say in favor of this site is that the faces make this temple stand out in the Angkor complex.
Most enjoyable.. A must include on your trip.It left us with many questions.

Ancient Khmer Capital !. Angkor Thom was huge ! Comprised many ruins and its peak time at ancient time with great civilization and history. Don't miss your chance to visit this before you close your eye.
Phenomenal. Huge city, many different temples to explore, could take the whole morning.

Take your camera!!!. Angkor Thom is very close to the more famous Angkor Wat. Smaller but, in my opinion, more interesting than its famous neighbour. Easy to get around, although there is a great deal of "rubble". This is where you will get your photos of the trees and their roots intertwined in the buildings, together with wonderful carvings. A photographer's dream! Make sure your batteries are charged up!! Don't go to Siam Reap and just visit Angkor Wat. I would put Angkor Thom in the "do not miss" category.
amazing!!. It's a large area including the Bayon and terrace of elephants, so set aside adequate time to see everything there!
A must see. Another brilliant temple to visit. It's a must see.

Stunning. As a complex, Angkor Thom outranks Angkor Wat as an attraction. The highlight is the Bayon, for which the description "excellent" is just not good enough, but it also includes so many other attractions - including five amazing gates - that even the small overlooked ones would be star attractions anywhere else in the world. Nuff said - go there!
Spell binding trees out of ancient temples. Was surprised to see the Indian Archeological team there helping with restoration work , felt proud. These temples and trees are beautiful.
Best Temple in the area. I believe that this temple is better than Angkor Wat because there are less tourists and you are free to roam around the whole complex.
Tomb Raider Temple. Under renovation, so it's difficult to appreciate in the current state. Found others much more impressive.

Gorgeous architecture; predictably crowded. Definitely a must-see.
bring/drink lots of water, dress appropriately and wear sensible walking shoes

The magnificent walled city. No matter how old these ruins are, the aura and grandeur still remains. Entering through the famous South Gate atop elephants one really feels like the king of kings. Of special mention is the Bayon and Baphuon, which are must see, the former is always overcrowded than the latter. Watch out the narrow and steep steps of the Baphuon; but once you are on the top the beauty will take your breath away. worthy of visit again and again.
Spectacular. Fascinating place. Truly amazing what the ancient Khmer kings and their people built.

Monumental City. Angkor Thom by it size impresses! The approach across the bridge will make you want to stop to see the auras and gods up close. The gate, with it's four faces facing in all directions will make you pause and think about the ancient civilization that produced it.
Great Temple. I really like Angkor Tom. All the faces on the stones and the rustic nature of the temple were really good. I actually preferred Angkor Thom to Angkor Wat.
Inspiring. Loved the spectaular gates, made more impressive as a procession of elephants in red regalia came through while we were there.
A must to see. Bayon is just beautiful. Seeing those huge faces looming down on you is just mind blowing.

Must See. Angkor Thom is awesome. Don't miss the monkeys in the late afternoon-- ask your tuk tuk driver where to go, he'll know-- (but seriously, don't buy bananas from the kids to feed them. Saw a local kid almost get bit-- as well as a tourist-- and it's the biggest cause of trips to the ER. They're wild animals!).
Amazing site. It poured when we were there, and the place cleared out for a half hour. Seeing it in the wet, warm weather was special. My favorite of all the temples in the area.
Faces. Loved the amazing carved faces. Everything is very close and down low.

Moderate your time. This Angkor Thom is really huge. An ancient city by itself. Hydrate lots and lots of water as you walk. There few temples that you may need to walk quite a bit from the "main road".Climb every single step that is safe to climb, you will see Angkor Thom at a different angle.I didn't manage to finish it as I'm too tired after an early sunrise at Angkor Wat that day. So, pace yourself out!
better than angkor wat is some ways--try to get there before the crowds/. the heat can be oppresive. bring water nad cikd towels for your brow

Magnificent. Angkor Thom is the last ancient capital city of the Khmer Empire, and it is comprised of many wonderful temple and terraces. Bayon and the Terrace of the Elephants are both contained within its boundaries. The usual entrance is through the spectacular South Gate, and tho much of the ancient city is now completely in ruins, there are still many magnificent sights to see.
Better tha Angkor Wat. much more interesting then Ankor Wat make sure you have a good guide

Big and beautiful. Wonderfully large temple complex. Lots of walking and lots of sun so bring a hat and water. This was one of my favorite as we were dropped off on one end by our tuk tuk and we walked though seeing many temples and ruins with a shrine or two, one including a giant Buddha. Not as finished off as Angkor Wat, but wonderful to see anyway.
Amazing!. Another amazing temple at the Ankgor site. We could barely believe our eyes. A great effort is made to keep the site safely accessible to the tourists.

Massive Stone Faces. We spent 3 days exploring through the Angkor Wat area. We did Angkor Thom as day 2 (we cycled everything so we took it one chunk at a time). Angkor Thom is unique and different than Angkor Wat because of all of the huge statues with faces carved in them. Climb up to the second story and you can get some really great, close up photos.
Angkor Thom is impressive. Angkot Thom is a 3 square mile compkex of temples and sculptues. There is much to see and much to learn about the culture that built this city.

Huge complex. This is a huge site with lots of buildings and stones that had yet to be assembled. Look out for the part of the wall within a wall walk between to two periods of wall decorations and motifs! Enjoy the elephant butresses on the main gates too.
Amazing!. A beautiful and amazing place. Go early to avoid crowds. Fun elephant ride for our kids.
The best of Angkor. Bayon bayon... Such amazing place, unbelievable! Don't miss it!@
Awe inspiring. Wonderful carvings, brilliant site, so much to look at.
Lots to Explore. You could be here for hours and hours there is so much to see. Lots of amazing temples and history!
huge place with several temples (including Bayon). Getting into Angkor Thom crossing the bridges and trough the gates is very impressive. Its size is awesome!
Buy the 3 day tour TICKET!. word to describe : AMAZING! please come with your most comfortable sneakers/shoes. lots of walking/hiking/climbing to do. or you can just stay far to enjoy the scenery!
Must visit. this is where Tomb Raider take a scene. It's very crowded and there is some places in this site is being renovated at Feb 2012. But you still can enjoy this place.
Fully Mind Blowing. Be sure to bring extra SD memory, I filled my card the first day.

A huge "Wonder". Angkor Tham is the ancient Khamer capital with many temples and ruins to visit. It will take days just to see the major sites. The heat and humidity and sometime rain can really drain your stamina. Sometimes the crowds and dust and vendors will dstract from the experience but is is all worth it. Try visting the most popular sites late or early and look for an alternate entrance to the main gate. It is definately not handicap friendly so take canes and waking sticks if you need any support.

WOW. Take you time, some temples are far from each other and its very very hot, There is one temple you cannot enter with singlet and shorts so bring extra gear. take rest as the sun is so hot and the toilets are far from each other

The best of the best. The 'Lara Croft film site. Simply astounding. The centuries old temples have reverted to nature having been abandoned for centuries with massive fig trees taking hold of vthe walls, and then strangler vines sqeezing the trees.

Almost too much to see. This covers a very large area and it is difficult to see everything in one visit. You will be climbing quite a bit on 'Bayon', the largest temple in this complex. It has 3 levels and you get an excellent view of the area around it from the top level. You could be photographed with some fancy dressed dancers on the top level when I visited. They use your camera. Angkor Thom is at least 5 times larger than Angkor Wat, so budget your time accordingly. I enjoyed it more than Angkor Wat. I am 72 and in good physical condition. You should be in good health to be able to climb to the higher levels. Go and enjoy.

a must-see. if you're going to cambodia, this is where you should go to if only to marvel at temples that have withstood the passage of time and the elements. some of the temples have exquisite and very detailed wall carvings. if you are not into temples, this is still worth a visit if only for the architecture. some of the temples you should see are ta promh, bantay srei, bayon, angkor wat and phnom bakheng.
Wonderful Monument. This is one of the thousands of locations to visit in Siem Reap and well worth it. On par with Egypt, Aztec and Mayan civilisations. One for the "bucket list" definately!

Buddha. Amazing, again get a guide to explain the carvings. The scale of the thing takes your breath away. Maybe wear something a little sturdier than flip flops some of the steps are a bit steep - and you must respect the dress code (show respect generally)

Huge. The Angkor Thom area is not just one temple but many. You can spend a full day in this area and see a variety of temples. Make sure to bring a hat, sunscreen and plenty of mosquito repellant since it is hard to find in the markets.

Wonderful Temples. Another group of temples in Siem Reap, and these don't disappoint! I simply love walking through these places and, yes, imagining I'm some historian-archeologist, seeing them for the first time in ages. And you will get them to yourself if you go before 8am! :)
Top 2nd temple in siem reap. old city of Cambodian people who lived in this city with the Kings for many years ago.
Tomb Raider. You really feel like Lora Croft fantastic experience,once again sturdy walking shoes and go early to avoid too many peple and the heat
Amasing!!!!. Look at the trees and ruins!!!!. It is unblievable to see tree surrounding the ruins

Amazing. A great place to see. The infamous trees embedded into the temples are worth the visit alone. Such a beautiful place and quite atmospheric if you visit early (you'll also miss a lot of the crowds).

beautiful place but beware of food scam. all restaurants have 2 menus, one ridiculously overpriced, and the other reasonable, and feel free to bargain even over the "reasonable" prices, to reason them even further
ancient temples. such a large area to cover to see all the temples, but well worth it.

A Stunning Place . . .. Many temples and ruins are situated in this complex, and they all have their own little 'touches' which make them special. If you can get here before the crowds then this place is truly stunning and you can imagine it in its heyday.
One of the most beautiful places in Angkor Wat's complex. It is absolutely stunning to see all of the carvings and the faces is what you remember the most after a visit.
It is quiet in the morning!. When there is no person in the morning, you can feel the quiet sleeping of these temples. The smile on their faces are all mystery.
Very crowded even at dawn. Very crowded even at dawn. Just another amazing temple that will have you woundering how it was made.
Another beautiful temple. Each of the temples have their own quirks, I loved the colour of this one, though the scale is not as impressive as some of the others
Just Huge. BIG! Thom apparently means grand and so it was. Lots to see, plenty of detailed art within the walls, a few touts at the entrance but not very aggressive.

Great for taking pictures. Take your time and take it slow here, because there are lots to see and absorb slowly. The tiers were also good since not many tourists went there.
Be careful of the sunset scam, though.
LIKED 'THE FACES'. Entry from the South Gate past the row of statues with big faces was great. Fantistic photos.

Its one of the best. I love this temple. Its incredible. The faces are everywhere. Staring sereenly at you from every direction they make you feel peace. Spend some time here...get there early to avoid the crowds. it s a popular one
Very impressive. Amazing place to visit and reflect. Take a camera there are a million photo ops on this wonderful sight.
Another Beauty. Beautifully preserved and well worth the visit. Go in the morning when it is less crowded.
See to believe!. Watch out for unofficial guides hanging around in the temples trying to earn a buck.
Another great temple. I loved the faces in the temples and the story behind the temple itself.

Magnificently Impressive. The vast majority of people to visit the Angkor park region go to Angkor Wat (of course - it's absolutely awesome) but they skip Angkor Thom. Don't do this - you'll be missing out on a stunning ruins site. You must spend as much time as you can roaming and exploring the magnificent ruins in this area at your leisure. There's just so much to see!This is where you'll find the ruins of Prasat Bayon temple, with the huge glorious faces carved into the stonework of the temple spires. A little further out is Baphuon temple, which is also impressive. Phimeanakas and the Royal Palace are fun to explore. It's awesome to think about how impressive this all would have been back in its full glory. The Elephant Terrace, with carved elephant heads and trunks coming out of the walls is cool. Head down the terrace of the Leper King to see huge tree roots trying to re-claim some of the old buildings there. This isn't the same site as Ta Prohm, where Tomb Raider was filmed. That's a different part of the region.Be sure you wear comfortable shoes and take plenty of water. My only wish is that I had more time to explore this stunning ruins site. Absolutely gorgeous.
Excellent, even though the ruins are crumbling. Great visit, and good to see that they are renovating and preserving their heritage!
Not to be missed. A must on your to do list at Angkor Wat Park. This site has not been cleared totally of jungle and huge fig and silk cotton trees grow from the ruins.

Not to be missed. A lot of ppl skips this place but it's one of the most representative places of the Angkor archeological park. Nature recovering itself. Erasing reminds of an empire. this is a must see

The site of Bayon and a hole lot more. Don't skip the elephant terrace, the terrace of the leper king or any of the other smaller sites through there. Also look at the details on the bridge on your way in and look for the monkeys that gather there. We stopped here after Banteay Srei and before Angkor Wat, and i would recommend the same progression from 4 star temples to 7 star temples (at least that is how our guide put it).
The central part of the temples. One of the most amazing sites within the Angkor. This is where Bayon i.e. is located. One of the "must-see's"!.
a must see. bring a camera, comfortable shoes, and lots of water
huge. we really wish we had spent longer in Siem Reap, a week would have been good to have one day on, one day off. We barely scratched the surface of Angkor Thom
Huge, ornate, tons to see. Sites inside range from crowded to totally isolated, most are quite impressive in a great location.
Going back to the old ancient times... Majestic!! Feel like going back to the old ancient times. Was amazed with the architecture, the people at that time really had talents.
Beautiful. Get your timing right and you will get the place almost to yourself.

Don't miss the Terrace des Elephants. Ankor Thom is huge, so walk around, there are several temples, the site of the royal palace, two terraces (the leper king and the elephants), get out and walk around. You'll love it, not nearly as crowded as the "A" list sites, but equally worth your time.
Angkor Thom, wow. It's hard to believe it's all 900 years old, what a lot of history. It's still in good shape.

cannot be missed, when you........ reflect on the fact that this city 1000 years ago had more than 1 mil inhabitants when London only had 30,000. Today what is left is a vast green forest area filled with temple remains and ruins, but with its famous centerpiece of Bayon Temple, still remaining much in mystery as to why all these smiling faces? Being a much natural sequence from our visit to Angkor Wat, our great tuk-tuk guide Mr. tee (more details under Angkor Wat) took us to the south gate entrance of the walled Angkor Thom and after a few historic observations drove us to the Bayon Temple from where we continued walking ourselves via the Baphuon temple, Elephants terrace and the Leper King (from where it is believed that the King overlooked the parades passing by). Angkor Thom may appear a bit dull compared to Angkor Wat temple but nevertheless the ancient grandeur of this city makes it a not-to-be-missed on any tour to Siem Reap.

Get a good tuk tuk driver and spend the day climbing about. Get a good tuk tuk driver and spend the day climbing to the top of temples, seeing the gate (very cool), and enjoying lunch at a local cafe. They say the temples can be seen from space, they are huge

Take a trip off the beaten path when visiting Angkor Thom!. Angkot Thom is HUGE. And oftentimes crowded. One of my favorite experiences in this vast sprawling site is along the south wall towards the southwest corner of the complex. Enter at the southgate and walk along the wall (there's a path) till you meet the corner. Turn to your left and there is a small temple about 10-15 yard to the north. It provides an amazing view of the West Baray at sunset. And you are guaranteed to be alone to enjoy it. Just bring a flashlight for the trek back. Also, take some time to visit the Preah Pithu group in the northeast corner of the site. Few people do and you'll be rewarded with a peaceful experience that is in stark comparison to the tour bus mania of the Bayon.
Magnificent!. The walk through the gateway, Angkor Thom and exploring this temple is fascinating.
another amazing site in Siem Reap. Another must see in Cambodia, loved it. Do not skip the lesser temples in Angkor, they are almost better then the major ones.

Enormous. You could spend an entire day here if you wanted to take your time.
