We did it within a few hours but you could really relax and walk along the park pathways and go exploring if you wanted to spend the day. There's so much to see and take in. Even just to sit and comtemplate the beauty of the place is amazing.

try mornings for less crowds. An absolute gem in the Angkor complex. More beautiful than any pictures. A serene place to stroll if you get off the main path that all the tour guides follow. Though there may be a lot of people, most don't go explore by themselves, which is what brought the most enjoyment to me.

Amzing bas reliefs and carvings. The conservation of Angkor Thom reminds you of what a fantastic city it must have been. The best things: the carvings and bas relief in Bayon which cover the first floor and which show images of real life in those times - childbirth, craftsmen at work, dog fighting etc. - which to me were more fascinating than the battle scenes at Angkor Wat. As you progress up the floors the carvings with the smiling faces seem to welcome you and the views are just great. There are a ton of other temples too numerous to visit so you have to choose your itinerary carefully. We simply opted to walk along the Terrace of the Elephants with its superb carvings - great place.
As interesting as Angkor Wat. Near Angkor Wat and also very well presented, not as a remodeled historic site by the Real Thing.

Don't get mixed up.. We thought this was a separate temple but it is the fortified city that has Bayon at it's centre. The gateways and bridges over the surrounding moat have amazing statues that are the real focus.

Temple of the Old Capital of the Khamir Empire. This temple is quite distinct from Angkor Wat but is still very impressive and in reasonable repair despite the predations of its surrender to the jungle and the invasive and destructive Banyan trees
Breathtaking.. Take your time with this one, thers so much to see.

Budget at least 2 days to really do this justice-more than just Angkor Wat & Bayon temples;). This is a review of Angkor Thom, the main complex, which includes the Angkor Wat temple. The Angkor Thom complex consists of the world famous Angkor Wat, the Bayon temple & several others temples. Scattered over an immense area, the entry is either $20(single day), $40(3 days, which you do not need to use consecutively) & $60(7 days, which you not need to use consecutively). Starting at the Angkor Wat, it is possible to cover the highlights in one day(we did not have more time, sadly). Starting very early morning, we watched the sunrise at Angkor Wat at around 5 AM. Spent the next 3 hours at Angkor Wat & left at 8 AM just when hordes of tourists were arriving(go early, or go at the end of the day!). Went back to our hotel to have breakfast & returned to Bayon at around 9.30 AM. Spent 2 hours there(it is much smaller in scale than Angkor Wat) & then went on to the other temples. Finished with lunch around 2.30 PM(tired by then!) & then or tuk tuk driver took us to Ta Prohm, where the temples among the jungles are. At around 4.30 PM, we left Ta Prohm & went back past Angkor Wat to a temple, where we climbed up & watched the most beautiful sunset. This is just a world class complex of temples! My recommendations would be; 1. Start in the early morning with Angkor Wat, or Bayon, since these are the ones that get most tourists later in the day. It wasn’t very crowded at 5 AM, but the hordes started coming in around 8 AM . 2. Plan at least 2-3 hours for Angkor Wat, 2 hours for Bayon, & then depending on your stamina & the age of the group(it’s a lot of walking between temples, a lot of climbing & not much shade), another 4-5 hours for the other temples in the complex 3. Make sure to carry everything you might need-water, camera batteries, caps- unlike a lot of other tourist spots, not many shops selling this stuff once you start walking 4. Hang on to your pass- apparently there is a fine if you lose/misplace it, though honestly, that whole day, we never saw anyone checking anyone’s pass, nor were we asked to show ours. 5. Ladies- make sure your shoulders are covered & no short shorts- we did see people not being allowed in at some points because of the dress code. 6. The best route seems to be starting at Bayon & going on to the exit where the tuk tuk drivers await you- the temples get progressively smaller as you go- which is a good thing for when energy is flagging! Overall, it’s a stunning complex- we started by watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat & ended with watching a sunset over the temples- just one of the best days ever! If you can, budget atleast 2 days to see everything & do it justice!;-)
Awe-inspiring. From Bayon to the Elephant terrace and all the temples in between...grab a bicycle or walk and enjoy being transported back over 10 centuries.
Beautiful. All the temples are very nice and should be visited.
Face to Bouddha's Faces full of Love. All these so beautiful peaceful and smiling faces ...probably the place at Angkor where my emotion was the deepest

Just short distance from Ankor Wat. Breath taking and a must see while in the grounds of Ankor. Thiere is no additional fee to see this attraction and is one of dozens located in the area . Really need to spend two days just for temples

Good photo opportunities. Our private guide showed us several querky photo opportunities which made the most beautiful photos with my kids like my childs nose matching up to a nose on a buddah on the temple. Looks like they are rubbing noses. So lovely

Needs more than one day. Angkor Thom is unbelievable - way better than Angkor Wat. Do yourself a favor and plan to spend two days going through the whole complex to get the best impression and value. and take a guide - it is well worth the $25.
Highlight of our temple tour. Definitely the highlight of our temple tour. But come with enough energy to spend a few hours!!

Temple City. Angkor Thom provides a great deal to see in such a compact area, from the enigmatic Bayon, the climbable Baphuon, Phimenekas through to the Terrace of the Elephants and the Terrace of the Leper King. Look out for the excellent carvings on the latter.
Gate area best. The main gate is still in excellent condition but creates a massive traffic jam which is not controlled
13th Century Temple. Amazing temple experience. After seeing a few temples they all begin to meld into one another but this one was very interesting.

Get up close. Angkor Thom was an excellent experience. We spent 2 hours there. When our guide told us 2 hours we thought that it was a long time. In the end after a brief tour and some time to explore we ran out of time. This temple is a photographers dream. It is big and has some restored areas and many needing work. It was so big that it didn't have that crowded feel and everyone enjoyed the atmosphere and appreciated the qualityof the carvings. A beautiful place
Another one !. More incredible efforts that only lasted a few centuries
Must visit!. You can't leave Siem Reap without seeing these Temples. Truly amazing.

Wow. Well worth seeing, absolutely amazing. Very hot and not a lot of shade so bring plenty of water (although you can buy it there). Be prepared for lots of hassle, but lots of good photo opportunities!
Amazing!. Take a private guide if possible to avoid the crouds.
Not to be missed. Not to be missed. Amazing tree root entagled temple. The quintessential Cambodian photo opportunity.
World Heritage. Another must see. I regret that i didn't spent more time in Seam Reap. I am planning the next trip, & is going to bring my family along this time.
Very Indiana jones. Seeing the temples covered with those giant strangler fig roots is like seeing a movie set
Wonderful!. HUGE temple complex. Would definitely recommend a guide or tour book to ensure you see all the important bits as SO much to take in
Angkor Thom - a great site. This is a huge site with many different temple relics - you need a guide for the first visit at least.
Superb temple site!. Angkor Thom is gorgeous! Another of the temples that is a must see!
quite nice place. not as impressive as other temples around but it shouldn't be left out on a good temple tour...
arrive on an elephant. what a brilliant way to enter the city. It was part of our package but I spotted a sign saying $15 per ride, well worth it I'd say. kids loved it. Angkor Thom is wonderful.

You Need Stamina!. The sheer expanse of Angkor Thom defies explanation. It is a big, and at times challenging, walk, full of architectural gems and idyllic landscape. Bring lots of water with you - you will need at least two hours to thoroughly explore this royal city. The area is very well sign-posted, but we would recommend finding a map to take with you as well. There are some amazing photo opportunities here.
temple. could man really do this so long ago, it is just amazing to find these things in the jungle
Home of the Bayon. The large complex has lovely surroundings and some of the most charming temples. It is less busy than Angkor Wat but just as impressive in daylight.
Temples. The Angkor Thom temple is one in a series of temples covering a wide area. It is magnificent and should not be missed.
Temple city. Several temples, all different and lovely entrances to the area.
One of the temples who breathtaking. One of the temples who breathtaking, People should come and admire the Khmer culture
One more special temple. Part of the circuit worth seeing..... the ancient temples are baffling and mysterious.

Walk with the Gods. The symmetry of Prasat Bayon put together is unbelievable. From every angle one can see the /four headed statues. Each face giving a sense of peace to your mind. The entrance area depicting the 'Samudra Manthan' - the churning of the sea for creation of elixir of life is beautiful. The whole setting is truly amazing.

Better that Angkor Wat.. Angkor Thom is a 20 minute tuk-tuk ride further into the jungle from Angkor Wat, and in my opinion is even more impressive than Angkor Wat. Angkor Thom is where you will find the huge heads carved out of the stone, for me there are no words that can do this site justice. The temple is in an area known as the Royal Square with numerous temples and ruins that include the Terrace of the Leper King and the Terrace of the Elephants. The whole area takes a full day to explore and is beautifully kept. If you only have time to visit one of the Angkor sites i would recommend this one, its stunning.

Baphoun Temple. Kids below 12 are not allowed in the Baphoun temple as their is a very steep flight of stairs one has to take. So, we had to leave our kids behind with their grandmom when we went exploring inside. The location of the temple is beautiful and we enjoyed are view once we reached the temple top.
Afternoon temple. It was under renovation when we were there so not so nice photos from the front. Nice to visit in the afternoon before the crowds get there.

Wow!!. What an amazing place! It took us hours to take in everything within Angkor Thom. We went there on two separate days, once in the morning and then on an afternoon. It was incredibly hot around midday so try and avoid it then if you can!

Incredible place, but save enough time to do it justice. The complex is huge, and has many delights the prime one being Bayon which is absolutely stunning. It is brilliant to clamber through it and explore yourself, and also to tour around its outskirt on an elephant ride. Against the blue sky the towers with faces sculpted in make for excellent photos.As there is so much to see though make sure you have plenty of time set aside to make it round all of it. There is a fair amount of walking involved, and plenty of steps so ensure you have enough water on hand.
Tomb Raider!. A must see! Jungle vs. Ancient temple... great photos everywhere!
Recommend to visit before Angkor Wat. Great temple complex with varied styles. Plan for extra time to wander (and for lost of waking to see it all).
NOT just another site. be ready to just wonder in amazment of these structures,
Another must.. An essential part of your tour even though lesser known than the other temples.
Wow. I prefer this site to Angkor Wat for it's interest factor. Spend hours wandering around the bottom section, discovering all it's nooks and crannies.
AMAZING. Eveyone should see at least once - it completly overwhelms you
Breathtaking. Really cool complex filled with interesting temples. Don't miss the wild monkeys right inside the main gate/entrance!

Impressive. It is the old capital city of angkor ! It is huge ! Impressive ,! By the time it was build , londo and paris together has 60 thousant people .... There lived more than one million ! Definitelly worth a visit with a good period of time !

Huge complex with so much to see. Loved all if it, each site in this complex is unique and special in their own way: Bayon, Baphoun, Terrace of the Leper King, etc. Even the entrance gates are a sight to be seen. Huge complex in a beautiful setting.

Home of Tomb Raider. Get your Lara Croft impression out! This is a must see and is beautiful - try early morning (7am) to beat the crowds as it can get very very busy. If you have time some of the more remote temples have a similar style but are much quieter.
Gorgeous Angkor Thom. This is just beautiful (all be it not as well preserved as it should). Great photo opportunities, elephant rides and lots to see.

A special part of a magical site.. It may be heretical but we liked Angor Thom better than Angkor Wat. Both sites are impressive and magical but we felt Angkor Thom had especially fine carvings and special features (such as the elephant terrace) that made it stand out.
The second city. Angkor Thom is not a temple in itself - it is a big area with several temples within. Spend at least half a day here. Take your time!

Lots of face-towers; so many temples to visit. If Angkor Wat is known for its bas-relief and Bantey Srey for its intricate carvings, then Angkor Thom is famous for its face-towers. Angkor Thom is actually a large 9 km² area and one of the many temples inside it is Bayon where you will see the face-towers.Inside Bayon, look for the locals in traditional costumes who will offer to take your pictures with them for a small donation. I gave them $2 and they took about ten pictures which turned out great. You can also find several vantage points where you can pose to make it appear that you are kissing one of the face-towers.You will most likely get dropped off on the South Gate so take the time to admire the bridge over a river that connects to Tonlé Sap. Your first stop will be Bayon and then the Baphoun temple. Take the steep stairs to the top for a picturesque view of the surrounding areas. You can also climb the next temple, Phimeanakas.If you walk towards the road, you can walk towards the North Gate with stops at the Elephants Terrace and Leper King Terrace. Prasat Sour Prat is on the other side of the road. We were at Angkor Thom for about two hours.

Amazing site, impressive gates and old palace grounds.. Only second to Angkor Wat temple, this site is where the people or rather royalty lived in the past. Has some amazing temples inside, which are a lot less busy than the main Angkor Wat site. Try get to some of the temples which are a bit smaller and away from the main tourist route as they are very interesting - but be careful of snakes around those as there are less people there and hence more of the creepy crawleys (snakes, spiders, etc).
Beautiful vistas with Bayon. as well as the other sites in Angkor Thom. Clearly deserves the praise that is lavished on it.

The gateway to all other impressive temples. Would recommend for pictures taking at the north gate where there are far lesser tourists and more serene. But tuk tuk and tour buses will usually drop off tourists at south gate as it's the 'usual' route of visiting at Angkor Thom. Don't be mistaken that Angkor Thom (Great City) is a temple. It's actually a 'gateway' to all other temples like Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas and other monuments like Terrace of the Leper Kind, Elephant Terrace and so on. Sad to say that the naga and asuras are either being cut off or heavily restored (hence losing the ancient look on it). Another must see and staple in the itinerary for Siem Reap temple visit.
One of the Nicest temples.. Well preserved, 4 faces of Buddha. Elephants and monkeys are outside the walls. A must see.
Beautiful and different. Very different to Angkor Wat and just as enchanting

Lugar mistico. Someone told me, "Once you see one temple, you've seen them all." Went to AT after AW. Found many differences. Liked this one more. It has more ruins and seemed very mystical. Less people too. It's amazing to think how these temples were built. Take good walking shoes, water and snacks. Good place for picnic.
wow. It is such an impressive site to visit. the detail on the carvings are beautiful. magical place. a true must visit.
Great Place. Was a wonderful place to visit both early morning and for sunset

Ancient walls and dried moats.. Angkro Thom was the ancient city, now it's most forest and temples. The main thing to see (except the amazing temples) are the olg gates, where you can see the entering bridges. They are beautiful, but I suggest to visit there after the rainy season, when they are full of water, water lillies, mosquitos and water buffalos. Otherwise the moat out of the walls will be dry.
Excellent temple. Visited Bayon temple and Ta Prohm temple. Lots of history behind these hindu temples
lots to see. there are several worthwhile structures to visit in this particular complex that one can walk into and down the corridors from ancient times.

Angkor Thom - Don't Miss It. We almost chose not to visit Angkor Thom. That would have been a huge mistake. The history of the cities gave a wonderful peak into what life must have been like for the ancient Cambodians. The relationship with the ancient people of Thailand and Vietnam provides a rich tapestry for the changing world during the time Angkor Thom was in it's heyday. Great visit.

Amazing. This is the actual city in which people from the Angkor period lived in, and consists of many temples, terraces and other old structures. You will need a full day to explore the whole area. Best by bicycle
My 2nd choice. This is a close 2nd to angkor wat, taking as much time to explore this wonderful site
Too Cool. We loved this place....great photo shoot......You cannot see all of the Temples or Wats, but DO NOT miss this one!
Quirky and mystical.. Smaller and less grand than Angkor Wat, but filled with beautiful, intricate stone wall carvings. Well worth a visit to!
Angkor thom. A very impressive temple, left you with a great respect for the cambodian people.
Very Special. This is a must see for all tourists. an amazing look into the past. Loved all of it

Ancient city of temples. This was a city back in the 8th to11th centuries. It housed over a million people at the time London only had 55 thousand inhabitants. It contains several wonderful temples within and the main gate with its four faces and three elephants is truly wonderful.
Great photos. Great photo opportunities - the tree roots are unbelievable.
Fantastic. All the Temples of Angkor are a must see!!!! Get a good pair of Walking shoes and a Tuk-Tuk driver, or better yet a bike and go exploring.
Amazing complex. We saw Bayon, Baphuon and the elephant and leper king terrace. All worth visiting and we enjoyed every moment
Beautiful. Try to organize your tour with your guide to avoid the big wave of tourists.

An Amazing Place. A bit overcrowded, but if you can get your timings right i.e. early in the morning or late evening, it is a truly magnificent place. Of course Tombraider has made it a must see p[lace
Big big Angkor. Quite a big place to explore. Requires some planning to cut the distance and yet catch some of the best sights. Helps with a guide book and a local guide.
Stunning. La Terrasse d'Elephants etc - beautiful, graceful, mysterious - everyone is amazed.
Adventure in Cambodia. If you want to have a great time exploring go to Siem Reap Cambodia! We went to Angkor Thom and it was fascinating.
Great place to see. Tour impact but so nice.... good for photographers if we have the chance to not have Tour bus coming ...
Beautiful. Definitely one of the temples to go to. It's smaller than the well-known Angkor Wat but no less splendid.
smile. the smiling face of cambodia.... one of my fave temples

to see. We could not decide if we liked this more the Angor Wat....it's huge...difficult to climb but it ' worth to go up.Ask the tuk tuk driver to leave you at the south gate and meet him at the north one

very nice!. This is great for pictures and like what I recommended around Ang kor area, do your shopping there for magnets, scarves and post cards, they are cheaper than Old market area. If your driver is good, he would plan the timing for you and tell you which temple to go at what time for best pictures and to avoid the China chinese tourists who basically jams up everywhere and disrupts the peace there.Great for pictures! Do not wear your precious shoes cos its quite sandy every where. Alwways good to have slippers on I feel!
Near Angkor Wat and quite impressive. I like just wandering around and getting the sense of the place.....I don't like having a tour guide. You can read up on it on your own if you like.
Great place to visit. One of the master pieces of Jeyavarman ViI, this place is a real technology marvel in terms of architecture!!

This is the place that contains the Bayon Temple and Baphuon.. If you got no time to spend in Angkor Thom and had to choose , then visit the Bayon temple and Baphuon that lie within it.Both are magnificent and excel with their own merits. Baphuon will test your strength as the climb is pretty steep and quite high compared to the others but once you reach the top the view will take your breath away.Terrace of the leper king that also lies within is just so-so but worth visiting if your have the time.

Soak up the history of the place. Does get a bit crowded, but not as much as Angkor Wat. It's nice to walk around the various ruins, though the whole thing could do with some more signage and information boards and maps. One ends up stumbling across the grounds, reaching a magnificent ruin, asking others there what it is and then referring Lonely Planet. Good fun though!

Stunning structures and carvings with many different styles of temples and adjacent buildings.. The entire site of Angkor Thom is just indescribable. From the elephant terrace to the carvings on the leper king terrace, the Bayon, the Baphuon and it's enormous reclining Buddha in the back of the temple, being actually a part of the temple structure itself, the walk around it, the sound of the crickets to accompany it all. It's pure magic and with a bit of imagination, it isn't difficult to imagine oneself 900 years back in time. Time stood still here and the sites have not been affected by 'loud', in all senses of the word, cafés or other tourist rubbish. Bravo to Cambodia and UNESCO. A walk over the field stretching out in front of the elephant terrace towards the Prasats is fabulous and often forgotten due to time constraints or (too) strict schedules. Take your time here, it's an entire complex that is very complete and even after two times in Angkor, I still find this site simply a-ma-zing and very diverse.
Beautiful. Get a guide so you can look and understand in detail the wall sculptures.

Finally made it there!. The Bayon with its huge stone faces is one of the key images that resides in the public conscience about Angkor Wat. The craftmanship that did go into the making of the huge statues is just amazing. The grace in their faces resembles that of the Mona Lisa or the sphinx. Further highlights visited were the Baphuon, the Terrace of the Elephants and the towers of Prasat Suor Prat.
Wonderful gates. The gates to Angkor Thom are beautiful. A great start to the sights and sites that lie ahead.
Beautiful. Definitely worth the trip to Angkor Thom and its huge property. Be prepared to walk
Another great place not to miss!. This was very interesting especially with a guide. If you have time you can ride an elephant for $15 US each, it looked like fun. Well maintained and preserved area.
amazing. great photo opportunities! The growth of the trees through the structure is spooky!

A wonderful set of temples to visit. Angkor Thom is not just a temple, it's a whole complex, which includes the fantastic Bayon, the newly renovated and re-opened Baphuon, the terrasse of the elephants and of the Leper King, as well as other lesser known temples. It is a must see in the Siem Reap region and, in any case, you are bound to go through it when visiting the Angkor site.

Challenging your physical strength with stairs. It is on a typical sightseeing route after Angkor Wat and Prasat Bayon. Prasat Bapuan requires your physical strength to climb up with more comfortable than before by newly made stairs.
Knocks spots off Angkor Wat. Beautiful carvings, amazing structures - it's rather like a dribble castle only giant and exquisitely crafted!

Angkor Thom is even better than Angkor Wat!. All of Angkor is incredible! While Angkor Wat is clearly the most famous and grandiose of the ruins, I personally thought that Angkor Thom was way cooler. The giant Buddha's heads in stone and the carvings in the wall were one of the coolest things I've ever seen!
Tomb Raider. Angelina wasn't there when we were. But it's a magical, mystical place . . . even with all the tourists. Go early or go late to avoid the crush.
Beautiful!. Another amazing temple. stunning really. Another one to add to your short-list!
Same remarks as Angkor Wat. Wonderful structures... in the middle of a well maintained nature, unfortunately, to many visitors at the same time makes is little stressful....for everybody
Atmospheric. In some ways more atmospheric than Angkor Wat, especially in the morning light.
Excellent. well presented, obviously an on going process, one of the smaller temples surrounding Ankor wat
Angkor Thom. A hot day and too much walking for me but well worth a visit. Some distance from Angor Watt. Derelict.
Angelina Jolie deja vu!. This was just great fun - could almost imagine the blue butterflies I was following. Amazing how it's being held up and taken apart at the same time by trees. Well worth it.
Wonderful afternoon visit. Excellent trip very well organised and our guide was full of information an absolute awe inspiring place
Must See. While not hearly as extensive as Ankor Wat, you must visit here as well. The setting and the carvings are quite spectacular. It is well worth the time.
An Historian and Photographers Delight. Something to be added to everyone's bucket list and even though it formed the 4th of temple sites visited in one day still had something different to offer

More Impressive than Angkor Wat??. 10 square miles. At the South gate entrance look out for the elephants crossing if you are looking at the Demons and Naga on the bridge. This was our introduction to Angkor and it was the perfect start.

Huge complex!. take alot of water and good walking shoes,you will need it!
Huge site and worth having a guide!
My favorite!. Just so amazing. If you want a climax - spare this one for last. It is breath taking!
Tauck-HJK & JMT. Absolutely spectacular sights. This was an amazing part of our tour and one not to be missed
Amazing. I loved the amazing entrances with the different faces at the place. It is just simply amazing. I think I enjoyed this place and others nearby as much as the Pyramids of Egypt.

Astonishing. It's an amazing feeling to be walking on such ancient ground. Would recommend this experience to anyone. The local hawkers are relentless in their harassment, but you just have to be firm, say 'No' and go about your business, they eventually get the message.
The faces!. Loads of heads make this and eerie but incredible experience
Trees of significance. The vegatation at Angkor Thom really show how the Wats surrounding Siem Reap would have been undiscovered for so long! The roots of the trees are a work of art in them selves.

It starts at the amazing gates and ends with the best memory of your trip. From the amazingly beautiful South Gate, to the Bayon temple, this city, comprising 9km2 is superb. So well preserved and truly an explorers dream, you get to see and experience so many different structures in this "city" that you will love every moment of it. I have to say - Bayon temple, in this comlex is my favourite temple of the area. You will not be dissapointed!! 5+ stars!

nice to bicycle to. We rented bikes and rode from Siem Reap town to Angkor Wat and Thom. The road is nice and flat, and the trees provide nice shade. Angkor Thom's walls and bridges have beautiful carved guards and Naga. Bayon and Elephant Terrace are inside the walls and it's nice to pedal around and take your time. From North Gate to Pub street was about 50min of easy but steady pedaling.

One of the largest built cities. The four faced towers.(south side)When entering the North side (gate) you will see on both sides of the lane the serpent carried by figures (most of them without head unfortunately)

Amazing Angkor.... The Angkor Wat and its surrounding temples were like a dream in itself but the Angkor Thom was just another thing altogether. Make sure that you'd enter through the south gate as this is the most restored and intact of all the structural entrances of the complex. Make sure that you pass by the Prasat Bayon where you'd see all the huge (and eerie) faces looking down on you, the Ta Prohm with the huge trees that surround it (made famous by the film Lara Croft: Tomb Raider) and the Pre-Rup Temples which is one of the largest temple complexes ---- amazing beauty within the ruins of history....
Just magical. Angkor Thom was my favorite! The Bayon and Victory Gate are places not to miss. 2nd after Angkor Wat in popularity, should be 1st in my opinion. Loved it!
Angkor Thom after Angkor Wat. A word of a dvice: do not go the same day as Angkor Wat, the site is very big and you will get tired.
Been to Angkor Thom. You should be wearing comfortable shoes when visiting the Angkor Thom. You will be in awe at the size of this temple.
Amazing. Go to Angkor Wat at sunrise at least once in your lifetime.

Too many tourists. Angkor Thom is very commercial, with thousands of tourists all over the place. We went very early in the morning to beat the crowds and the heat. I am a history buff, so must say the place is quite interesting
Another of Cambodia's Magnificent Temple sites !. Breathtaking, these sites are a Photographer's dream.

Magnificent Capital Complex. Modern world has seen many capital complexes - Every country makes it a point to demonstrate its greatness by making sure that its capital is maintained as a showpiece. Obviously, this is not a new idea - anyone who has visited Angkor Thom will testify to this. Angkor Thom was the grand capital complex built by the kings of Angkor more than 1000 years ago. We had visited this place early this month and were most impressed by it. The main temple has a smiling face looking at you from every place. The sculpted images that stare at you from all sides makes for a very interesting sight. From the top of this temple, the entire complex can be seen to be a very large one with several structures spread over the place. It is really very impressive that the kings of those days had a grand vision and spared no effort to bring it to life.The entire complex is very well maintained and is tourist friendly.Angkor Thom is a "Must See" for anyone interested in ancient history and magnificent monuments

Allow some time to look around. Angkor Thom is a walled city complex that includes the Bayon, Baphuon, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Phimineakas, Prey Pallilay, Sour Prat, The Khleang and more. The longer I stayed and the more questions I asked the guide, the more fascinated I became. (please forgive any spelling mistakes)
Step back in time. The scale of Angkor Thom and number of temples and terraces make a visit feel like stepping back in time , allow 3 hours or more at least
Amazing!. Loved the Buddahs. Great photos, worth reading up on the temples before going though.

The synthesis of Hinduism and Buddhism. The giant sculptures of the face of Buddha, which so many associate with Angkor Wat, were an overlay of the earlier Hindu temple architecture, and the combination is a powerful expression of the synthesis of these traditions for the Khmer people.

Ancient grandeur. This place is massive. Enormous walls, still mostly standing after almost a thousand years enclosed a city of some 9 square kilometres, bigger than the CDB of most modern cities. Sadly, the jungle has reclaimed most of the city over time and very little remains to give an idea of the enormity of this place in its heyday.The main entrance is the imposing southern gate, jam packed with tourists, tuk tuks, busses and the occasional elephant. From there you take your favourite form of transport to the central point of Angkor Thom: the Bayon temple. This is a beautiful building with its maze of passageways and enigmatic faces looking down on you. Nearby is the Baphuon, with an enormous reclining budda carved into the back of the temple. This temple has been recently renovated, but was not open for tourists on our visit.A short walk away is the royal enclosure, where little remains of the former palace complex. Another short walk brings you to the Terrace of the leper king and elephant terrace, both interesting in their own way.Ankor Thom is in a more decayed state than Angkor Wat, and minimal restoration work seems to be taking place. This adds to its charm. This also means it's not covered in the ugly plastic tarps that marred Angkor Wat during our visit.
Great place at dusk. Visited early evening when all the visitors had left for the day. Full of atmosphere. Truly amazing. How did they build such a structure.
Really Amazing. The Complex is huge and amazing. Don't get overwhelmed by the number of temples. Try to pace yourself so you have the time to explore each of them.

City-temple complex. A myriad of different experiences awaits you here; from the individual temples to the elephant terrace. Take your time; this place is spread out, and will reward the time you spend here.

More than just another Angkor Wat. Angkor Tom shows the real expanse of this truly historic site of early and developed civilisation. The extent ot eh buildings and development over the centuries are breathtaking.What is lovely is the jungle has had its say in how the buldings have bene preserved. Some well, some almost destroyed. All indications of the transitory nature of our existence.Buddah would certianly approve of the display of magnificence and unity shown by the Cambodian people of thier belief in his teachings. Or, maybe Vishnu, depending on the King at the time...

Best place of entire Angkor complex. If you only have time for one stopat the Angkor complex make it here. The scale, ease of access and the photographic beauty make this the gem of the entire Angkor complex.
better than Ankor Wat. bigger and nicer than Angkor Wat, lot of monkeys its a fun if you have the bananas
a must see. another must see site, not too far from Angkor Wat. all i can say is it is spectacular

Must see ruins.... Pros:
-Amazing piece of history and well preserved ruins. Tour
-Tour guides are very knowledgeable and polite
Cons:
-Not fault of site, but very hot - come prepared to sweat!

Amazing!!. Simply one of the must see places in the world.
Amazing architecture provides a glimpse in the past civilization of Cambodia.
I highly recommend this place and spend some time to appreciate the beauty and aura of the temple.

Right in your face stunning. The gates - particularly those without main roads. You can walk for hours along the walls from gate to gate with only the trees, the monkeys and the occasional local.
The temples are great but I loved the quieter areas most.
World Heritage - anything more to say?. Impressive Buildings on quite a large area, many nice impressions you can get there!
Temples visit. Excellent again but also different. Be prepared for a steep climb if you wish to go to the top. We only walked the perimiter but that was enough to get the feel of it.
Amazing. Wonderful carvings and temple is bigger than Angkor Wat!
amazing wall carvings. pay close attention to the intricate carvings on the wall, they are beautiful.
A great place to start. If you are doing the temples - start here. Amazing carvings and architecture are a great starter course for the larger Ankor Wat.
our holiday to cambodia. like all the temples in cambodia, it was full of history and mystery, with a good guide you get all the important information.
Fascinating. My favourite out of all the temples, the construction is amazing.
For full picture. to have a full impression of the grandioze temple complex in Siem Reap you just have to visit this place too.
Must stop on the temple tour. each of these has their own remarkable, indelible place in the overall experience - dont miss it

Angkor WHAT?!. Absolutely beautiful. The renovations are in the way and there's a lot of restricted access areas which is a shame as it's a place you'd love to just go nuts and get lost in like a 'Tomb Raider' since everyone knows it was the Tomb Raider temple unfortunately. But WELL worth a visit and take a few dollars to buy a CD from the musicians playing on the road up there as they're awesome and trying to earn a living that isn't just begging.

Angkor Thom includes many other temples once inside including the Bayon Temple. Angkor Thom was built in the late 12th century and incorporates many of the other temples in Angkor Park. Included inside is the Bayon Temple, Baphuon, Terrance of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Phimeanakas, Prasats Suor Prat, and many others smaller temples. It is recommended that you do visit Angkor Thom because of the other temples within the walls of Angkor Thom. There are many interesting things here to see. The Bayon temple is the best of the bunch inside and should not be missed.You will need your Angkor Park Pass to get into Angkor Thom and any of the other temples inside. If you need a great guide, please take a look at the guide we used. http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g297390-d2178241-Reviews-Thoeunson_Private_Tour-Siem_Reap.html He is one of the best there is in Angkor.

Fantastic Temple. It was great to visit Angkor Thom and the Bayon Temple, the structure is fantastic and on the way down to the temple there is a great opportunity to stop and feed some monkeys. Dont buy the bananas though as the wont seem to take them. They also took over my girlfriends bike, they got off with a fair bit of resistance eventually. good fun though.No doubt though if you have bought your ticket you will end up here

Overpriced but fantastic. I was happy to pay the $20 admission fee to enter this historic complex until my guide told me that about '85%' of admission fees are stolen by corrupt officials. Seeing the dilapidated state of many of these buildings, it was very sad to know that the only conservation funds were coming from donations abroad. Nevertheless, Angkor Thom was well worth the visit although I would probably not hire a guide and steer clear of the street vendors who are even more aggressive salespeople than in Siem Reap town. Also, you only need a day or two here and you only need to come to Siem Reap for Angkor.

Nice ruins. Great ruins of the Angkor civilizationI was told that it was once the center of the Angkor Empirelots of huge boulders with intricate carvingsthere were also people in costumes who could take photos with youthe huge face on the cambodian riel is also found herenear angkor wat and worth seeing too

Very large complex. This is by far the largest complex of "temples" in the region. Definitely worth seeing. Again, a guide is useful to point out the carvings and various areas and their significance.

The reason you go to Siem Reap. It is truly lovely. I brought along my 2 kids (7 & 9) and we had a great time . Get a personal guide and your own transport. (we chose a tuk-tuk) Very safe and amazingly near town. The complex is big enough to absorb the hordes of tourists. Water sellers aplenty. Toilets are usable but that's about it..Sunblock and bug repellent a must.

Fascinating complex within Angkor. If you spend a few days in Siem Reap, then you will most likely also visit the temples of Angkor Thom. It is a bit less crowded than Angkor Wat and certainly best early morning or later during the day. Beware that at lunchtime the place gets really hot so don't go out without water and try to keep in the shade where possible.Angkor Thom has several temples to visit. Bayon is probably one of the most impressive once with its buddah faces on every site. Its also great for climbing a little bit - lots of stairs, so good if you are a bit in shape. We found it best to explore the temples by tuk-tuk - its cheap as well, just about 15-20 Dollars for the whole day. Really recommended.
Magnificent gateway to Angkor area. You can't actually miss this one when visiting Angkor Area. Step out of the car and admire the figures leading to the gate.

WOW! WOW! WOW!. I went to Cambodia to see Angkor Wat, but fell in love with Angkor Thom. What a beautiful amazing place. I really had no idea how big the whole Angkor complex was and I think I will have to go back there - but no kids and no husband! I think a knowledgeable guide is a must - ours was great and he added to the whole experience. Looking at ruins is great, but knowing what they were for is even better. Give yourself plenty of time to really explore as there is just so much to see.

The Great City. Angkor Thom means Great City in Kymer. Angkor Thom includes the 300 meter long Elephant Terrace, Bayon which is in centre of the city, Baphuon, 12 towers of Prasats Suor Prat and the victory gate leading to the ruins of Royal Palace area. Each gate is crowned with 4 giant faces.Many of these ancient "lost" temples are still being restored. I preferred this site to Angkor Wat. Sometimes the heat can be melting so take bottle of water, wet wipes, sun block, insect repellent and hat.

Awesome Angkor Thom. This site is even bigger than Angkor Wat, in a walled compound surrounded by a 100 metre wide moat. The spell-binding Bayon temple which sits in the centre of Angkor Thom was probably the highlight of all the temples for us. It was the king's state temple and is absolutely captivating as it looks like something from another world. It has about 50 huge towers, each carved with 4 giant faces smiling in every direction. What the faces are supposed to represent is a matter of controversey, although the most popular theories are that they represent the compassionate Bodhisattva Loksvara, or that they're supposed to be a mixture of Buddha and King Jayavarman 7th (whose temple it was).Fortunately when we visited Angkor Thom was a lot less busy than Angkor Wat so we were able to wander around the maze of courtyards in peace. At Angkor Thom we also passed through the Terrace of the Elephants; a 300 metre long terrace wall decorated with, of course, lots of elephants, and opposite and parrallel to that the 12 towers of Prasat Suor Prat.

better than angkor wat. All of the sites in Angkor are truly incredible and otherworldy in their beauty, and to think of the labor that went into building them so many years ago. You read so much about Angkor Wat and it is the site to see when in Siem Reap. But I found Angkor Thom to be the most stunning place I visited on my trip. On the walk up you can hear the monks chanting and there are hundreds of butterflies everywhere. The light even on a sunny day is slightly muted and it all sets the scene for your first views of Angkor Thom. Words cannot describe and your pictures can't do justice to the magnitude of this place. It is stunningly beautiful and hypnotic. I highly recommend it is your first stop in Siem Reap.

Even better than Angkor Wat!. The whole 'city' of Angkor Thom was amazing. Loved it more than Angkor Wat, more diverse in what it has to offer. If you want to just take it all in, spend hours at Bayon (faces are imposing but not threatening, a serene feeling here) and at the terrace of the Elephants. Relief work is incredible and more fun to decipher than the more religious reliefs.
Huge and impressive. A temple well worth a visit, it is huge and there is lots to see. A guide would be helpful as it makes it more interesting.

This place is huge. The complex at this ruins is 9 square kilometers in area. It includes Bayon, Baphuon, Victory Gate, Terrace of the Elephants and Leper King, and Prasats Suor Prat as well as others. These are ever bit as spectacular as those at Angkor Wat which is only a kilometer away. If you visit Angkor Wat, be sure and go the extra kilometer and visit this one also.

Be a savvy barang and do this yourself!. My wife & I are independant travellers who love doing things ourselves. We spent 4 nights in Siem Reap and tackled the Angkor Complex over 3 days as follows...First day we got into Siem Reap in the afternoon after a 6h bus ride from Phnom Penh ($11 pp and pretty comfortable). Once we had checked into our guest house (Golden Mango Inn), we headed to the old market in Siem Reap in search of a guide book. Depending on your haggling skills you could pick up one of the bootleg guides for 4 or 5$. The book we used as Ancient Angkor by Michael Freeman. It's a comprehensive book written by famous Angkor archeologists with loads of illustrations. Hire a guide if you want to but in my opinion for $20 per day you're not going to get your money's worth...plus while we were out there we actually heard some guides giving out wrong information to their tour groups. This is not based on info from the book but from my own personal knowledge of Hinduism. Next thing you gotta worry about is how to get to the complex. Our guest house provided free bikes and we cycled. Depending on where you're staying it could be between 5-7km to get to the complex and it gets really hot! Take lots of water with you, you'll need it! You can hire a tuk tuk for about 12$ a day from Siem Reap and is probably useful if you want to catch the early sunrises or you're visiting the complex at night.The 3day pass costs 40$ and this is what we did:Day 1 - Preah Kahn, Ta Keo, Ta Prohm, Banteay KdeiDay 2 - Phnom Bakheng, Angkor Wat, Banteay SreiDay 3 - Ankor Thom complex - gates, Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Terraces of Elephants & Leper KingBayon we thought was the most magnificent of all and we're glad we did that right at the end. Kind of finishing on a climax...The view of Angkor Wat from Phnom Bakheng is ok, not something to rave about and sunset views are rubbish and you'll end up with loads of barangs (Khmer for foreigner) in your pics!Other thing to note is that there is constant restoration work at some of the temples so don't be disappointed if you can't access certain areas, c'est las vie!
Fresco of daily life. The bas reliefs here are of daily life and the different ethnic buildup of early Cambodians. Making out the scenes is rather fun.

Place to visit before or after the temples?. Went to the National Museum on the fourth day of our stay in Siem Reap. The museum has been around probably about a year because during our previous visit to Siem Reap in March 2007, it was still being built. I was initially of the view that visiting the museum towards the end of our trip gave us a 'summary' of all the temple sights we have benn to. As you will see, most of the statues at the sights have no heads, has missing inscribed tablets etc. In the museum, you will be able to 'place' the heads onto the missing bits. However, a friend of mine has a totally different perspective, which in hindsight, I agree i.e. that a visit to the museum first (before going on a temple frenzy) should be the right thing to do so that you get to put things in proper perspective when you go around each temple sight. There are different halls in the museum, each focussing on looking at the subject matter of Khemer civilisation, the Angkor temples, etc from different angles. For example, there is the Hall of a Thousand Buddhas containing a collection of statues of the Buddha only, from different times. Try to ask the attendant there or try to spot a particular statue in which the head, face and eyes "turn" and keep "looking" at you as you walk from side to side.Then there is a hall dedicated to the history of the Angkor temples. This is especially helpful if you are a history buff before embarking on your temple visits. Then there is a hall dedicated to the cultural aspect and the beliefs, which forms so much of the theme in the temples.We were absolutely delighted at the museum. One can see that there is a lot of effort put into it and it is situated in a purpose built building. Admission is USD12.00 for adults and it is within walking distance from the Sofitel. From Siem Reap town, a USD1 per person ride on a tuk tuk will bring you there. It is opened from 8 am to 8 pm and we had 2 hours in the museum, which was not enough time at all. They require that you leave your bags and camera at a designated counter, so if you have any expensive stuff with you, you may want to leave it at the hotel instead. We were there at around 5pm and to our surpise, we (3 of us) were the only ones there at the time. It may still be new and may yet to be mentioned in travel literature. Whatever the case may be, it is such a pity that there are not many visitors. We found it a wonderful place and a visit to Siem Reap will not be complete without a visit to the museum, either at the beginning or at the end of your trip, whichever way you view it.

Superb Angkor holiday with Mr. Tee. My husband and I are Brits currently living in hot and humid Singapore. Last month his parents came out to visit us for a fortnight and we planned a week's side trip to off-season Cambodia, to see the temples of Angkor.We browsed various holiday websites and finally decided, through recommendations, to contact Mr. Tee (Sopheap Nhoep) at www.angkorholiday.blogspot.com. We were slightly bothered about trusting our deposit money to a stranger, but we needn't have worried - Mr. Tee looked after us royally.He got us a discounted booking for 6 nights at the Angkor Village Botanical Resort which was excellent for our needs; quiet, green, clean and very comfortable. He has a Toyota Camry for 2-3 passengers, and a van for larger parties of up to 6, which was what we had. We paid US$135 for 4 days of tours plus US$25 per day for an English-speaking tour guide. This included a nice touch of unlimited bottles of cold drinking water, very welcome after an hour in the hot sun looking at temples.It seemed to us that nearly everyone in Siem Reap is either a tour guide, or a driver who wants to be a tour guide! Mr. Tee is studying for his tour guide exams and hopes to qualify in a few months. His English is excellent and he already knows a lot about them so he shouldn't have much trouble. Meanwhile he uses qualified tour guides - ours was Chea Vanna (pronounced Wanna), a gentle, softly-spoken, very knowledgeable man.The temples are amazing. Over the first 3 days we saw 16 of them, and took nearly 2,500 photos between us! Many of these ancient "lost" temples are still being restored, some by teams from other countries like China and Japan. There were a few noisy coach-loads even in low season, but they couldn't destroy the feeling of spirituality in the intricately-carved stone-work.On day 4 we visited a floating village on Lake Tonle Sap, and at our request, the Sunrise Angkor Children’s Village, an orphanage in Siem Reap. The children are educated with an emphasis on performing arts, and several have got to university. Some of the 74 children have lost their parents to land-mines. The rest have parents in jail or unable to care for them. These children are the lucky ones: many more are put to work selling tourist merchandise to supplement the family’s income. Alcohol and drug abuse are a big problem.We arranged a free day in Siem Reap so that we could do our own thing. We ended up asking Mr. Tee to take us to visit a silk farm and the artisans’ centre, both of which were very interesting. We gained a new respect for those silk goods and paintings, and the stone carvings and lacquered elephants, deities and temple views when we saw how long it takes the craftsmen and women to create them.In between all this culture, Mr. Tee took us to a selection of local eateries for lunches, so that we could sample the Khmer cuisine. Don't miss trying Amok, which is meat or fish cooked in a coconut, with each restaurant offering slightly different variations. I loved the “pumpkin in oven” with tuna from the Khmer Kitchen Restaurant in Siem Reap. It worked just as well in my oven at home!The US$ is accepted more widely than the Cambodian Riel, and in some places where we tried to pay in Riel we were quoted a very poor exchange rate. Had we known, we would only have brought US$.We loved Siem Reap and the Angkor temples. Not just for “That Tree” in Tomb Raider, but for the knowledge that just by visiting we were helping a community that after nearly 30 years is still recovering from the effects of Khmer Rouge and the Pol Pot regime which lead to the deaths of a quarter of the Cambodian population. Apparently the unknown number of remaining landmines will gradually decompose and disarm themselves in 40 or 50 years. Meanwhile, a family of 2 senior citizens, 5 adults and 4 small children regards themselves as lucky to be able to live in the city in 3 rooms. They want their lovely country to grow and develop, and tourism is the second biggest earner for them. I would go back, and take my friends too.

Angkor Thom; the centre of the great civilisation of Angkor. Angkor Thom was the centre of the 12th Century city of Angkor. With Over 1 million people it was the worlds largest city.  At the centre of the great city of Angkor lies the Bayon Temple. It has 52 towers with the huge serene faces of the Jayavarman VII. To the north is the great plaza adjoining 300 metre long Elephant terrace, which must have been a spectacular meeting place 800 years ago. Behind this are the ruins of the Royal Palace and the pyramid temple of Phiminakas At the rear of the plaza are 12 towers the Prasats Sour Prat. Tight rope walkers used to perform across what is now the road to the Victory Gate.The crowning glory is the huge dome of the Baphuon. This is under restoration at present and will be a spectacular sight when completed . The whole area is dotted with dozens of smaller temples all are of some interest
